HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
A New Bank Hopes to Grow In Brooklyn

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
Not many financial institutions in the nation can boast of making fewer bad loans than the tiny Community Capital Bank of Brooklyn.
"At this point, we are among the most liquid and safe banks in New York," said Lyndon Comstock, its 40-year-old chairman. 
 Mr. Comstock was being facetious. Actually, the bank hasn't made any bad loans, in large part because it hasn't made any loans at all yet. It formally opens tomorrow.
That this might seem like an inopportune time for most entrepreneurs to establish a bank is beside the point: Mr. Comstock first envisioned it 12 years ago; since then, the demand for his type of lending institution has, if anything, increased.
"We are the first bank in New York City to adopt as its main purpose to do community lending on a safe and profitable basis," Mr. Comstock said. "From the point of view of need, it's certainly as great as ever in terms of housing development and of financing small business."
Enlightened self-interest, coupled with legislative prodding for lenders to address the credit needs of their local communities, has led some urban banks to put their depositors' money where their mouths are. But several others have all but abandoned poor neighborhoods -- closing branches or diverting deposits to invest in out-of-town or overseas ventures hat may be even more risky but also are potentially more profitable. The city's Department of Consumer Affairs recently accused some banks of increasing their customer fees, in part to compensate for loan losses.
Also, some institutions that began as neighborhood banks pursued more generic marketing strategies or, at least, less distinct identities as they grew. (In the last decade, the Brooklyn Savings Bank merged with Metropolitan Savings, which became Crossland -- a multistate bank, still based in Brooklyn.)
In addition, money for community development has become tighter because of the recession (the previous tenant at Community Capital's office at 111 Livingston Street in downtown Brooklyn was a brokerage firm) and because of failures and imprudent lending practices by banks and savings and loan associations across the country.
Mr. Comstock, who comes from a Midwest banking family, was first struck by the need for a lender like Community Capital when, while studying for a master's degree in business administration at the University of California at Berkeley, he helped organize affordable-housing cooperatives. His inspiration was the South Shore Bank of Chicago, which helped engineer a neighborhood revival. Mr. Comstock worked at more traditional banks before he began to organize Community Capital full time five years ago this month.
Community Capital Bank is small, so far, with $7 million in assets. Nearly all of that was raised from 248 shareholders. About two-thirds of the bank's $6 million in stock was sold to institutions -- with about half of this from corporations, labor unions and nonprofit organizations, and the rest from religious groups.
Among the biggest shareholders are the Educational and Cultural Fund of the Electrical Industry, the Metropolitan Life Foundation and Ecumenical Development Cooperative Society. Others include J. P. Morgan & Company, the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union, the American Express Company, the Brooklyn Union Gas Company and Time Warner.
"We don't have the resources, experience and skills needed to extend credit to small businesses and to make home mortgage loans in New York," said Michael E. Patterson, executive vice president of J. P. Morgan, whose clients are far-flung and which bought $250,000 of the bank's stock. "For us, it is a way to participate importantly, though indirectly, in financing community development."
Community Capital was chartered as a business, not as a charity. It plans to offer consumers competitive interest rates on deposits, which are federally insured up to $100,000, and on other services. Similarly, it will charge market rates on loans and be guided by what Mr. Comstock regards as "Rule No. 1 of lending: know your borrower."
What distinguishes Community Capital, though, is its willingness -- indeed, its very mission -- to lend money for affordable housing and for business development in New York City's low- and moderate-income neighborhoods. Consequently, the bank hopes to attract deposits from like-minded institutions and individuals in the region and beyond.
Given the composition and the commitment of the bank's shareholders and directors, Mr. Comstock said, its social agenda is likely to endure. "I can't imagine our board approving a shift into financing oil rigs," he said.

HEADLINE: Morris County Sees Taxes Rise As Values Fall

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MORRISTOWN, N.J., Jan. 4

 BODY:
After a 10-year boom in construction and property values, the taxable worth of real estate is dropping in Morris County, all but guaranteeing higher property taxes for homeowners.
After soaring alongside the economy in the 1980's, Morris County's ratables -- the taxable value of its land and buildings and the foundation of its local budgets -- have declined by $2 billion to about $42 billion for the 1991 tax year, officials said. 
 Successful challenges to assessments on commercial properties, including offices, apartments, hotels and a golf course, have added millions of dollars to the decline and shifted a higher proportion of the county's property tax bill to homeowners, already angry about all taxes in the county.
 
Stormy Future for Local Budgets
 Worried elected officials, in turn, have countered with the county's biggest recent number of layoffs in hopes of minimizing the tax increase as they draft the county's estimated $151 million budget for 1991.
If the decline in the tax base deepens in coming months -- and sagging home prices and a soaring number of challenges to property assessments suggest it will -- officials fear stormy years ahead for county, school and municipal budgets, with rising taxes on homeowners and steadily shrinking school, local and county services.
Officials here also believe that Gov. Jim Florio's promise of property-tax relief is doomed this year by the declining tax base.
Morris's $2 billion drop has startled county officials.
"The 80's had them escalating so high that reality has set in," Robert Natoli, the county treasurer, said of property values.
Bud Struble, head of the County Board of Taxation, said, "For the first time in memory, we're going the other way -- real value is coming down." Real, or market, value is a critical part of assessed value.
Fretful about voter animosity over property taxes, Morris's governing body, the Board of Freeholders, has already laid off 34 county workers, the biggest single dismissal they can remember; left 20 vacant jobs unfilled, and used up all but $270,000 of a $2 million surplus in the 1990 budget to keep county spending and taxes down.
 
Paying More for Lost Value
 But unless other cuts are made -- and officials call it unlikely -- the county's property taxes will go up. The chief cause is lost value in the tax base.
At this point, the county's new estimated property tax rate is 27.3 cents for each $100 of assessed value, up 1.8 cents over 1990's rate. Of that total, 1.1 cents stems from the lower tax base. Higher government costs account for the other seven-tenths of a cent.
Eliminating that seven-tenths of a cent from the increase would mean $3 million more in cuts, said Thomas Markt, Morris's Director of Budget Operations.
"I don't think there's any way we can reduce it," Mr. Markt said.
Eliminating the 1.1 cent rise caused by the tax-base loss would require a $5.5 million budget cut. "There's no way for us to offset that," he said.
 
7.1 Percent Estimated Rise
 On a home assessed at $200,000, the total proposed county-tax increase would be $36, to $546, a 7.1-percent rise. Of the increase, the tax base accounts for $22 and increased expenses, $14.
The county-tax rate is one of the three elements in a typical property tax bill, and usually the smallest. The tax base is also used for school and municipal budgets, which account for 75 to 80 percent of each property-tax bill. Assessed values are growing in some of Morris's 39 towns and declining in others. Officials expect an impact on some municipal and school budgets, but the degree is unclear.
Mr. Struble, head of Morris's tax board, said three factors had combined to cut the tax base: sagging sales and prices of private homes; sharp reductions in assessments on commercial and industrial properties in Morris County by the New Jersey Tax Court, and a plunge in new construction.
 
Anger and Appeals Rise
 The slumping real-estate market has cut deeply into Morris's revenues from the state's real-estate transfer tax on all property sales. After peaking at $5.3 million in 1986, this tax revenue fell to and $3.6 million in 1990.
Taxpayer anger over property assessments is rising sharply, both in Morris and the rest of New Jersey.
Morris's tax board received 3,140 challenges to home assessments in 1990, triple the annual rate in the 1980's, Mr. Struble, of the tax board, said. "We lowered very few assessments," he said. "This board is pretty tight with money."
The picture is the same at the state's Tax Court, which hears appeals of commercial assessments of more than $750,000.
Between last July 1 and Dec. 31, the court received 4,500 new challenges to assessments statewide, up 40 percent over the same six-month period in 1989, the court's clerk, Wesley LaBar, said.
 
Less Income, LowerTaxes
 "This was the highest rate of filings we've ever had," Mr. LaBar said.
Since 1987, the number of commercial-assessment challenges statewide has grown by 250 percent, he said. Unlike residential appeals, which are based on comparing assessments of similar homes, commercial challenges can be brought if rental or other income from the property has fallen.
In his office here, Mr. Struble is still sifting through scores of recently lowered commercial assessments and calculating the tax credits due owners.
State officials say that Governor Florio's promise of property-tax relief will be met, mainly because the state has assumed county costs for welfare and mental hospitals and imposed a toughened ceiling on municipal spending and county tax increases.
"I expect county tax rates to drop," said Barry Skokowski, director of the state's Division of Local Government Services, which oversees county and municipal budgets.
Morris officials say the state's changes are included in the new budget and property taxes will still go up.
"In another four or five months, we'll see if all his talk about property-tax relief will be a reality," Mr. Struble said of Governor Florio. "We're going to know soon and I think you're going to see some more marching."

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Remarks by Hussein to Troops on Kuwait

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Jan. 6

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a televised speech by President Saddam Hussein today as translated by The Associated Press from a transcript distributed by the Iraqi News Agency:
 Every year, on the 6th of January, we celebrate Army Day, the anniversary of the army of the nation in the great Iraq. We also reflect on the past, look at our present and project into the future . . . and the pride, sovereignty, liberation and victory that satisfies God that is awaiting us in a world whose lands are infested with scorpions, snakes, hypocrisy and oppression, and its oceans and seas filled with . . . sharks waiting for their prey. . . . This day has become a blessed occasion for Arabs in this phase as it has become a synonym of a glory illuminating the struggle of our kinfolk, the heroes of the stone in dear Palestine.
What a great pride it is, dear comrades in arms, that we belong to a march crowned with glory and satisfying God. . . . In this struggle that you are leading, you are fighting against social and economic oppression, against discrimination . . . , against the oppression pacticed by foreign powers . . . , against double standards, corruption and hegemony.
For these reasons, the battle in which you are locked today is the mother of all battles.
Let no one be deceived. The battle against the tyranny represented by the United States and the slogans of hegemony it is raising on the international and regional level and against the forces of infidelity so they be ousted from our holy lands is not expected to be a short one.
In one battle you had prepared a historical opportunity for which our forefathers had longed and died without witnessing it. That was the return of Kuwait to its Iraqi motherland -- a reality, not a wish or a claim, that made it the 19th province of the treasured political map of Iraq for the present and future times.
It is indeed a source of great pride to accomplish more than one goal in a single showdown. Together with the heroes of stones you have transformed the possibility of ousting the invaders into a tangible and visible reality. Our rendezvous with victory is very near, God willing.
Praise be to God, we are fortunate that this army has . . . grown to accomplish all its goals and take on the enemy within the borders of the homeland with all that has been placed at its disposal by the sons of this homeland. . . . A battle of such scope requires great sacrifices both in qualtity and quantity irrespective of the foreseen and unforeseen consequences, which will no doubt please the friend and anger the enemy.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Votes Backing Use of Force Are Predicted in Congress

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

 BODY:
The likelihood of formal Congressional support for an attack on Iraq increased sharply yesterday when the House Speaker, Thomas S. Foley, said the House would vote on the issue this week and would probably "narrowly" support a decision by President Bush to use force.
Senator Bob Dole, the Republican leader, said he thought the Senate would also support a resolution authorizing the use of force after Jan. 15 if the question could be brought to a vote and was not thwarted by a filibuster. 
 The Administration, which had previously treated anything less than overwhelming Congressional votes as likely to send a message of weakness to Iraq, shifted its stance and welcomed the prospect of action on Capitol Hill.
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, appearing later on the same television interview program as Mr. Foley and Mr. Dole, the ABC News feature "This Week," said a vote by the 60-40 margin Mr. Dole predicted would be "helpful" to the Administration.
 
No Meeting With Hussein
 Mr. Baker, who left yesterday for Europe and a meeting on Wednesday in Geneva with Tariq Aziz, Iraq's Foreign Minister, reiterated the Administration's insistence that he would not go on to Baghdad to meet President Saddam Hussein. He said any such meeting would allow Iraq to "manipulate the deadline" set by the United Nations.
Congressional leaders in both houses now expect to begin debate on the issue on Thursday, the day after the Geneva meeting, and to vote before the Jan. 15 deadline approved by the United Nations Security Council on Nov. 29. The United Nations resolution authorized members "to use all necessary means" to expel Iraq from Kuwait if it had not withdrawn by the 15th.
The House is expected to vote on Friday -- not merely on a proposal comparable to the United Nations action but on one or more contrary resolutions, like a call for continued reliance on economic sanctions, a policy Mr. Foley said he personally favored for the time being.
The shape of those alternatives is still to be worked out among House leaders, supporters of various positions and the Foreign Affairs Committee, which was formally constituted on Thursday, earlier than most committees, so it could deal with this issue. As recently as Friday, House leaders had not expected to act this quickly, but pressure from foes of using force, in both Houses but especially in the Senate, has advanced the timetable.
 
Amendments May Be Sought
 In the Senate a vote will probably come later than Friday, but Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, said he expected the Senate could dispose of the issue "prior to the 15th." Mr. Mitchell also said that he himself opposed "a U.N. type resolution," allowing the use of force at some unspecified time.
Mr. Mitchell, interviewed on the CBS News program "Face the Nation," did not offer any estimate on how votes in the Senate would go, or say just which proposals would be voted on. He said that "the rules permit unlimited amendments, so I expect you'll see any number of resolutions offered as amendments."
Mr. Dole called on President Bush to ask Congress to approve a resolution comparable to the United Nations declaration. He said, "In my view, if we could ever get it to a vote in the Senate -- because there we have unlimited debate, you'd have to shut off debate, that takes 60 votes -- but if we could get it to a vote, I think it would pass with a bipartisan majority." Later Mr. Dole offered a "ballpark estimate" that 60 senators would support such a resolution, and 40 would oppose it.
Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont and chairman of the Appropriations subcommittee on foreign operations, said he believed the Senate was more closely divided than Mr. Dole believed it was. "I think it would be a close vote," he said. "I don't know which way it would go." But he said in an interview that he thought a "strong appeal to the Senate by President Bush" would probably insure passage.
 
Baker Welcomes Debate
 Secretary Baker said "the President has not wanted to ask for such a resolution unless the leadership of the Congress could assure him that such a resolution would be forthcoming, because your hand would be weakened if it were not forthcoming." But he added that Mr. Bush had not ruled out asking for a resolution and said, "We, frankly, are welcoming the fact that there will be a debate in the Congress."
He also said that in his meeting with the Iraqi Foreign Minister, he would not be negotiating, but only telling him that Iraq had two options -- to withdraw from Kuwait, or "they, in all probability, will have force used against them to eject them from Kuwait."
He said that to reinforce the point, he would be carrying a letter from President Bush to Mr. Hussein making those points emphatically. A senior Administration official who declined to be identified by name said more bluntly that the letter's purpose was to "hand over something tangible that Saddam Hussein will have to read in case Tariq Aziz doesn't have the nerve to repeat our message word for word."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, center, yesterday with Bob Dole, left, the Senate minority leader, and the House Speaker, Thomas S. Foley, before they appeared on ABC News program "This Week." (Marty Katz for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: LYNDON JOURNAL;
Search for Piece of Past Offers Lesson for Future

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LYNDON, Vt., Jan. 3

 BODY:
Ruth McCarty and her colleagues on the Lyndon Bicentennial Commission have looked everywhere. They have looked in attics and basements, bank vaults and file cabinets. And still no time capsule.
The first, and perhaps only, mention of the elusive capsule appears in a 1891 newspaper article about festivities commemorating the 100th anniversary of the Town of Lyndon. Mrs. McCarty discovered it two years ago. 
 "Lyndon's first centennial celebration has come and gone," begins the article in the July 10, 1891, issue of The Vermont Journal, a local weekly. "And due arrangements for the observance of the second have been made by procuring an iron box in which the proceedings of the first are to be sealed and remain unopened til July 4, 1991."
No mention was made of the box in the rival Lyndonville Journal that week.
Mrs. McCarty, a Lyndon native who spent 40 years in Connecticut before returning to this northeastern corner of Vermont in 1983, set out to find the iron box.
"We've looked in the town vault," she said. "We've looked in the bank vault. We've looked in the library. Nothing."
It occurred to her that in 1891 the secretary of the Lyndon Centennial Committee, Walter Ranger, was also headmaster of the public high school. So she called the school.
"They said they had a 2-foot-by-3-foot steel box with an inch of concrete on top," she recalled. "It was in the museum at the institute. Richard Boera from the state college went up with me. We certainly had our hopes up. But when we opened it, the box was empty. People said there had been papers in it, but we can't find them."
There are many other explanations for the box's disappearance. In 1891, Isaac Sanborn, the Town Clerk, had his office in his home. After he died, the house was sold and the town records were cleaned out. Fires in 1894 and 1924 destroyed most of the buildings on Depot Street, a main thoroughfare.
And then, Mrs. McCarty acknowledged, the box may never have been buried at all. "It might have been written up for the paper before the celebration," she said. "It rained very hard that day and several events had to be canceled."
The town that would be described in those lost papers was a very different place from the Lyndon of 1991. Then as now, the town consisted of four villages: Lyndonville, Lyndon Corners, Lyndon Center and East Lyndon. In those days Lyndon was smaller (population 2,619, as against 4,923 now), though it was a thriving railroad center and better off economically than now.
The Passumpsic Railroad was the largest employer in the area. The railroad bought a large tract of land near the river and created Lyndonville as a planned community for railroad workers. There were parks and shops and all the houses had to be two stories high.
Revival meetings in the downtown park, the Grove, drew as many as 10,000 people. Most came on the four passenger trains that ran through town each day.
Times are harder now. The machine tool companies that replaced the railroad as the area's major employer are in decline.
Even so, the town is planning a big celebration this summer, beginning with fireworks and a house tour on July 4 and ending in September with a horse showing featuring the Vermont-bred Morgan horse. Iron box or no, there will also be plenty of parades and pageants.
Lyndon was once on the itinerary of the Chautauqua lecture circuit run out of Boston, and in its honor the town has scheduled three days of speeches and music in early August.
One other item is on the agenda: burial of a new time capsule.
Brian Bona, president of the Chamber of Commerce, said the committee in charge of the 1991 time capsule had not decided what to put in it, or where to put it. "It would be nice for people in the future to know who contributed what to the town," Mr. Bona said. "You tend to take things for granted, forgetting that somebody had to have made it that way."
But he is certain of one thing: "We're going to be sure the location is recorded this time. We'll leave copies in the town offices, the bank, the library. We're not going to lose it again."

HEADLINE: F.D.I.C. Statement on Bank of New England

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6

 BODY:
Following is the text of a statement issued this evening by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation regarding its takeover of the Bank of New England Corporation's three main subsidiary banks:
The F.D.I.C. board of directors today established three new full-service banks to assume all deposits and most other liabilities and assets of Bank of New England N.A., Boston; Connecticut Bank and Trust Company N.A., Hartford, and Maine National Bank, Portland, Me. 
 The new institutions -- New Bank of New England N.A.; New Connecticut Bank and Trust Company N.A., and New Maine National Bank -- were chartered by the Comptroller of the Currency today and are owned entirely by the F.D.I.C. The action took place after the Comptroller of the Currency had closed the banks and appointed the F.D.I.C. receiver. The F.D.I.C. has agreed to provide assistance to facilitate their acquisition in the near future by qualified institutions.
 
'Business as Usual'
 "We have two active bidders and other well-qualified bidders might apply," F.D.I.C. Chairman L. William Seidman said. "We expect to announce a transaction soon. In the meantime, it's business as usual."
All offices of the three closed banks will open for business as usual on Monday, Jan. 7, 1991, as offices of the new banks. Full banking services will continue to be available to all deposit and loan customers and at the same hours of operation as in the past. As part of the F.D.I.C.'s program to maintain uninterrupted service to the closed banks' customers, depositors continue to have access to their funds by checks or automated teller machines.
The Federal Reserve System is prepared, in accordance with customary arrangements, to meet any unusual liquidity needs of the banks.
 
Deposits Transferred
 All deposits of Bank of New England N.A.; Connecticut Bank and Trust Company N.A., and Maine National Bank, including those in excess of the $100,000 insurance limit, were transferred to the new banks and thus are fully protected by these transactions. Federal funds sold to the banks, liabilities to trade creditors and employees and foreign-exchange, interest-rate swap and other qualified financial contracts will be transferred to the bridge banks.
Other nonsubordinated creditors will share "pro rata" with the F.D.I.C. in the receivership estates of the banks. The new banks did not assume any of the liabilities of the parent holding company, the Bank of New England Corporation, or its creditors.
The board decided it was necessary to protect all depositors because of financial conditions in the region. As part of the transaction, the F.D.I.C. infused $750 million of capital into the banks.
Bank of New England has total assets of approximately $13.9 billion and total deposits of approximately $9.1 billion. Connecticut Bank and Trust Company has total assets of approximately $7.1 billion and total deposits of approximately $6.8 billion. Maine National Bank has total assets of approximately $1 billion and deposits of $930 million.

HEADLINE: U.S. May Alter Student Lending To Skirt Banks

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6

 BODY:
The Bush Administration is considering major changes in the student loan program that would increase direct lending by the Federal Government and sharply curtail the role of commercial banks, which now lend more than $12 billion a year to college students.
The proposal, part of President Bush's budget request for 1992 and fiercely opposed by the banking industry, is intended to simplify the student loan program. 
 Under the proposal, students would deal exclusively with their colleges. The Government would give colleges money to create a fund from which they would lend to students. Supporters of the plan say the Government would save at least $1 billion a year because it would no longer have to pay the "special allowance" that banks now get as an inducement to offer low-interest loans to student borrowers.
 
Simplifying Enforcement
 The savings could then be used to provide more aid to the neediest college students, in keeping with Mr. Bush's pledge to be "the education President," Administration officials said.
The Guaranteed Student Loan Program is the largest source of Federal aid to college students, and the budget proposal does not envision any major change in the program's overall spending level, $5.38 billion in the current fiscal year. A student now typically borrows from a bank, which often sells the loan to some other bank or financial institution. Repayment is guaranteed by a state agency, which is reinsured by the Federal Government. The Government pays if borrowers default.
Federal officials say it would be much easier for the Government to audit 8,000 schools than to police the current system, in which more than 10,000 lenders and 54 state guarantee agencies have at least $52 billion in loans outstanding to 12 million students.
Student loan defaults, which have been rising in recent years, cost the Government $2 billion last year. While the new proposal would not solve the problem of loan defaults, Administration officials say it could produce savings by eliminating a layer of middlemen.
Education officials say the proposed arrangement would eliminate subsidies to banks totaling more than $1 billion a year. As a financial incentive for banks to make low-interest loans to students, the Government pays lenders a special allowance so that their annual rate of return on new loans is 3.25 percentage points above the interest rate for three-month Treasury bills. The Government also pays the lenders all the interest on guaranteed loans while students are enrolled in school.
 
'Cottage Industry of Middlemen'
 Mr. Bush plans to submit his budget request to lawmakers on Feb. 4., for the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1. The effective date for changes in the student aid program would be set by Congress. An Administration official helping prepare the budget said the proposals on higher education would "eliminate the need for the cottage industry of middlemen and intermediaries that makes the current system of guaranteed student loans so blasted complex."
The General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, said recently that it could not audit the financial statements of the student loan program. Assistant Comptroller General Donald H. Chapin said the program did not have adequate internal controls or accounting procedures to insure the reliability of its financial records.
The Administration proposal has been endorsed by some college officials but is opposed by banks, which have been deeply involved in the student loan program for 25 years and would lose a line of business. Bank officers say they do not want to lose any source of potential profits while many banks are experiencing financial difficulties.
John E. Dean, counsel to the Consumer Bankers Association, which represents more than 700 banks and other financial institutions, said the proposal would make the program more complex.
 "Loans will still have to be serviced," he said. "Somebody will have to make aggressive collection efforts against delinquent borrowers. If the banks don't do it, who will? The Government would have to audit and supervise those organizations."
The Bush proposal is timely for two reasons. Congress must re-examine and reauthorize all higher education programs this year because the legal mandate for student aid, last renewed in 1986, is expiring.
Second, the 1990 budget agreement significantly changed Federal accounting rules. Under the old rules, Federal loan guarantees seemed to cost the Government much less than direct Government loans because they did not show up immediately as cash outlays, as direct loans do. Only much later, when borrowers defaulted and the Government had to pay the sums owed to banks and other lenders were the costs charged to Government accounts.
Under the new rules, the complete cost of Federal loan guarantees, based on an estimate of future defaults, must be recognized in the year when the loans are made. Administration officials said the new rules would eliminate the bias that used to make loan guarantees seem cheaper to the Government. As a result, they said, Congress may be more willing to replace loan guarantees with direct loans to students.
 
Simpler for Students
 Thomas A. Butts, director of the Washington office of the University of Michigan, agreed with Administration officials that direct loans would be much simpler than guaranteed loans for students and colleges alike.
"The current procedures for obtaining, disbursing and collecting guaranteed loans are very complicated and costly, highly subsidized and bureaucratic," he said. "At present, we have a student loan program designed for lenders, not for students. The complexity of the program is one reason for defaults. Students with loans from several lenders, insured by different guarantee agencies, may not know whom to pay and may not realize they can defer repayment in certain circumstances."
Mr. Dean, the lawyer for the Consumer Bankers Association, said that under current law "banks bear some of the risk of default because they may lose insurance coverage if they do not comply with a complex set of Federal rules requiring 13 separate contacts, by mail and phone, with delinquent borrowers." The Administration proposal "would shift that some of that risk from private lenders to the Federal Government," he said.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
IRAQI WARNS ARMY TO PREPARE ITSELF FOR MAJOR BATTLE

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Jan. 6

 BODY:
Three days before his Foreign Minister is to meet Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d in Geneva to discuss the Persian Gulf crisis, President Saddam Hussein told his armed forces today that they were prepared to go to war to keep Kuwait a part of Iraq.
"You are now prepared for one historic battle after the return of the branch Kuwait to the root," Mr. Hussein said over the state-run television and radio. "The return of Kuwait is a fact and not a claim. It is the 19th province on the maps of Iraq, with its long history in the present and future." 
 Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, and the emirate's fate is the central issue that Mr. Baker will bring up with Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz in Geneva on Wednesday. President Bush and Mr. Baker have insisted that Mr. Baker will warn Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait by the Jan. 15 deadline imposed by the United Nations Security Council or face eviction by American-led military forces in the Persian Gulf.
 
American 'Tyranny'
 In his speech today, commemorating the 70th anniversary of the Iraqi Army, Mr. Hussein said he was preparing the nation for a great battle to liberate Palestine and defeat American "tyranny" in the Middle East.
[Such efforts to tie the gulf crisis to the Palestinian question were flatly rejected again today by Washington. Mr. Baker, arriving in London, said he could not support a French proposal because it linked Iraq's pullout from Kuwait to a settlement of the Arab-Israeli conflict. Mr. Baker also for the first time left open the possibility of meeting the Iraqi leader in a third country. Page A11.]
An Iraqi familiar with official thinking said Mr. Hussein's hard line today was in response to a radio address by Mr. Bush on Saturday.
 
Little Hope for Geneva
 The Bush address seemed to rule out the possibility that the Geneva talks could have diplomatic content beyond a restatement of the United Nations resolutions calling for Iraq's withdrawal and Mr. Bush's determination to go to war to enforce them. Baghdad is preparing itself for the failure of the Geneva meeting, the Iraqi said.
Mr. Hussein told the more than a million men he has under arms that they were facing a long and costly war whose aims would be to hold Kuwait, to drive foreign forces out of Saudi Arabia and to create a Palestinian homeland by confronting Israel. "The battle for the liberation of Palestine will not be a short one if we are serious about it," he said, "and we don't believe that the sacrifices will be small."
The tone of Mr. Hussein's speech today, near the eve of the critical meeting on Wednesday between Mr. Aziz and Mr. Baker, was viewed by Western and other foreign diplomats as an attempt to project Iraq's military and political determination and to keep up the pressure on the diplomatic process.
"This was not a direct speech to the West," said a diplomatic mission chief whose Government is part of the military alliance confronting Iraq. "This was a speech really for the army, for Iraqis and for the Arab nation."
 
Iraqi Sees No Compromise
 Iraqis said that Mr. Hussein was preparing his country's 17 million people for the possibility of war and that a number of Iraqi Government officials thought the prospect of war had grown because there was no narrowing of the gap between Iraq's position and the unconditional demand by the United Nations that the hundreds of thousands of Iraqi forces in Kuwait leave in 10 days.
Iraq does not intend to honor the Jan. 15 deadline set by the Security Council, the Iraqi familiar with official thinking said.
In this tense period of brinkmanship, Government officials here said there was a conscious effort in all public statements to convey an unwavering Iraqi resolve to go to war if necessary, while signaling through diplomatic contacts that Iraq is willing to make "sacrifices," or concessions, on Kuwait in a high-level dialogue on all regional disputes between Mr. Baker and Mr. Hussein in Baghdad.
On Friday, President Bush ruled out any mission by Mr. Baker to Baghdad, but Iraqi officials are said to be focused on arranging such a dialogue at the Geneva talks in a way that would effectively prolong the Jan. 15 deadline.
 
A Mixed Signal?
 Even as Mr. Hussein spoke in absolute terms about Kuwait, foreign diplomats taking official soundings in Iraq's Foreign Ministry continued to receive signals that Iraq's position on Kuwait was not absolute. In official contacts, those diplomats have been referred to a statement issued on Dec. 17 by the ruling Revolutionary Command Council stating Iraq's "belief" that Kuwait was part of Iraq and that this belief could never be shaken.
That statement also said: "We want peace. We want dialogue for peace. We respect legitimacy, and we want the international law to be applied on the causes of the Arab nation."
Foreign diplomats who heard Mr. Hussein's speech today reported a mixed reaction. An Eastern European ambassador said he was "disappointed" because he had been hoping that Mr. Hussein would make reference to the prospect of a diplomatic resolution.
Another chief of mission pointed out that Mr. Hussein had not personally criticized Mr. Bush, as he has in recent speeches.
For his part, Mr. Hussein seemed intent on building morale in his armed forces at a time when popular sentiment against the war was rampant in many part of this heavily policed society.
 
A Small Pay Raise
 Last week, Mr. Hussein moved to lift military morale by decreeing a pay raise of 50 dinars for every enlisted man and officer. He moved after complaints that transportation costs to and from the front for reservists going home on weekends was eating up military salaries.
The average Iraqi soldier makes about 100 dinars a month. That amount translates to $322 at the official central bank rate, but soaring inflation has degraded the dinar's value so that the purchasing power of 100 dinars has sunk to about $20.
Iraqis who have been called up to active duty report that absenteeism is running 20 percent or more at regional military centers, where reactivated soliders must report daily. Transportation costs for such duty can run as high as 40 dinars a day, quickly outrunning military salaries and leading to widespread grumbling.
At the same time, Mr. Hussein's full mobilization of his society is regarded as an impressive achievement by a number of foreign analysts, who say the Iraqis are capable of enduring great hardships if called on to do so by the leadership.
In rallying his armed forces today, Mr. Hussein said the battle that Iraq faced was a battle that must consolidate several objectives.
"It cannot be a battle that could be divided into several causes," he said. "On the contrary, this could cause confusion, which will divide the ranks, because if we fight divided battles, the forces working against us could probably neutralize our efforts."
 
'Battle Against Tyranny'
 "But if we fight the battle as one battle," he continued, "a battle that includes and embraces all the objectives of the Arabs at this particular phase, then this is the advantage of the great battle which we will fight."
He said the "battle against tyranny represented by the American Administration" to get "the forces of atheism to leave the holy land of Muslims" and to secure "the liberation of Palestine is not expected to be a short one."
Mr. Hussein said Iraq possessed advantages in any war, and he referred to "facilities of strategic nature that could not be imagined elsewhere -- flow and speed in communications, mobilization and military logisitics" as integral to Iraq's military strengths. His reference to strategic facilities echoed earlier references to Iraq's medium-range ballistic missiles.
Iraq in recent weeks has test-fired several modified Scud-B missiles, which its forces used extensively in the last stages of the Iran-Iraq war of the 1980's to terrorize Iranian cities. Iran also fired Scud-B missiles at Iraq.
Last month, returning Iraqi reservists trained in rocketry were said to have been immediately deployed to their units. While Iraq possesses several dozen mobile launchers for the modified Scud-B missiles, the rocket forces have erected about fixed launch sites in the western Iraqi desert for Scud-B missiles, whose ballistic warheads could reach targets in Syria and Israel.
 
'Miserable Coffins'
 Mr. Hussein praised the military leadership he has streamlined in preparation for further military action. In November the Iraqi President named a new armed forces chief of staff, and last month he named a new Defense Minister, both veterans of the successful final campaigns of the eight-year war against Iran.
"The mother of battles will also be conducted under experienced, cohesive military leadership," Mr. Hussein said. "These are the advantages of the battle."
In a commemorative issue today, Iraq's state-run newspaper, Al Jumhouriya, exceeded the bellicose tenor of Mr. Hussein's speech with an editorial that said, "Saddam Hussein's army will trample under the feet of its heroes the heads of Bush's soldiers, crush their bones and send them to America wrapped in miserable coffins."
 --------
 
U.N. Mission Discussed
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (Special to the New York Times) -- During their meeting at Camp David on Saturday, President Bush and the United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, discussed the possibility that Mr. Perez de Cuellar might go to Baghdad if the meeting between Mr. Baker and Mr, Aziz in Geneva produced no results, an Administration official said tonight.
The United States would not stand in the way of such a trip, but would not encourage it either, the official said, speaking on condition of anonymity.
Mr. Perez de Cuellar raised the idea of traveling to Baghdad during a discussion with Mr. Bush about Mr. Baker's scheduled meeting on Wednesday with Foreign Minister Aziz, the official said.
 
Israeli Sees War Threat
 JERUSALEM, Jan. 6 (REUTERS) -- Foreign Minister David Levy said today that President Hussein's statement that his army was ready for the "mother of battles" to hold Kuwait and liberate Palestine amounted to a declaration of war.
Mr. Levy made the comment as hundreds of foreigners fearing that a gulf war might spread to Israel flew home, nine days ahead of the United Nations deadline for Iraq to pull out or be forced out.
Mr. Levy said Israel was not declaring war on Iraq but would deal a serious blow to Baghdad if it attacked Israel. Mr. Hussein has said Tel Aviv would be Iraq's first target if was attacked by the forces in the gulf.

HEADLINE: A Success Story Turn Sour in New England

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
In only a year, the Bank of New England was transformed from a regional banking powerhouse into a ward of the state, waiting for Federal regulators to choose how and when they will sell it.
While the weakening of the New England economy undoubtedly hurt, the last year has made clear that the company's most severe problems were the result of its own mistakes. It lent an astounding 36.7 percent of its total loans for risky commercial real estate projects, far more than neighboring banks, and it failed to adequately manage subsidiary banks and reduce costs. 
 By the time a new management team headed by Lawrence K. Fish was installed early last year, it was too late. Like a leaky boat that fills with water faster than it can be bailed out, bad loans kept emerging faster than the company could solve its problems by slashing its payroll and selling subsidiaries.
"There were just too many bad loans," said Mr. Fish, who will continue as chairman despite yesterday's Federal takeover of three of the Bank of New England Corporation's banking subsidiaries: Bank of New England, Connecticut Bank and Trust, and Maine National Bank.
"It was a classic lesson in the failure to diversify risk," Mr. Fish said. "The Bank of New England lent too much, too agressively, too quickly, for a number of years."
 
Growth Through Acquisitions
 For years, the company profited from the booming economy in New England and a series of acquisitions that greatly increased its size. In 1985, the Bank of New England acquired large banks in Connecticut, Maine and Rhode Island, vaulting in a single year from a $22 billion Massachusetts company to a large regional concern that for a time in 1989 was the nation's 18th-largest banking company.
When the problems came to light, the blame fell largely on Walter J. Connolly Jr., who, as chairman, had led the acquistion binge and then pushed the company further into the real estate business in the last half of the 1980's.
Loans for commercial real estate were especially attractive when the local economy was strong because they produced the high profits needed to pay for expensive acquisitions. But by September 1990, with the New England economy soured, almost half the loans the company had made for construction projects, and nearly 20 percent of its mortgage loans for commercial projects, were delinquent. The company holds $3.3 billion of loans that are seriously delinquent or in such trouble that payments are not expected when due.
 
Huge Loss Reported
 The lending problems emerged about a year ago when the company stunned Wall Street and its shareholders by announcing a $1.23 billion loss for the fourth quarter of 1989. The loss resulted from a Federal bank examination, the first of several reviews of lending at New England banks.
The quality of the Bank of New England's loans was so poor, and the record-keeping so inadequate, regulators found, that they "read the riot act" to the bank's management, one of its directors said at the time.
Although the loss announced a year ago left the company with a very small capitial cushion to absorb additional losses, banking regulators did not move immediately to close the company. Instead, they gave it time to solve its problems by cutting payroll, selling businesses and reorganizing activities.
Regulators had hoped that the still-solid consumer branch networks of the Bank of New England, which is based in Boston and is the largest bank in the state, and of Connecticut Bank and Trust, based in Hartford and the second-largest bank in that state, would be enough to pull the company through its troubles.
 
Talk of Bond Swap
 But fresh infusions of capital, a key part of the survival plan, were slow to come. Proposals by bondholders of the Bank of New England Corporation to exchange their bonds for stock were actively discussed in the past week but not completed.
As bad loans mounted, the company set aside reserves for loan losses, causing a steady stream of losses amounting to about $650 million in 1990, on top of the $1.23 billion loss in the fourth quarter of 1989.
Mr. Fish said that as the problems intensified in the last few months, other banks, insurance companies and wealthy people became even more reluctant to lend for real estate projects, and Bank of New England's losses grew as it had a hard time salvaging its bad loans by arranging refinancings or partial payments.
"Late last week, they came to Washington and said, 'We just can't push this rock up the hill any longer,' " Robert L. Clarke, the Comptroller of the Currency, said in an interview last night.
On Friday, the company announced that it would lose up to $450 million in the fourth quarter, mostly as a result of losses on its delinquent real estate loans.
The fourth-quarter loss would have left the company insolvent, a condition that did not inspire confidence in the fate of its subsidiary banks. As withdrawals increased on Friday and Saturday to as much as three times their normal level, regulators and Bank of New England executives agreed it was time for a new strategy.
Three of the corporation's banks were declared insolvent; they will reopen today as new banks, owned by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. The banks' books will be open for examination by potential buyers, while shareholders and bondholders will be left to fight over the scraps of assets, estimated to be worth about $50 million.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Lawrence K. Fish, who was installed early last year, will continue as chairman of the Bank of New England Corporation. (Bank of New England)

HEADLINE: BUSH MAY CALL OFF FEBRUARY MEETING WITH SOVIET CHIEF

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6

 BODY:
In the clearest sign of newly emerging problems in Soviet-American relations, President Bush is on the verge of postponing a summit meeting scheduled for Moscow in February because of differences over arms control and uncertainty in the Persian Gulf, Administration officials said tonight.
"We have been going over the prospects for the summit thoroughly in the last few days and there is now a strong possibility that there may not be a meeting in Moscow next month," said an official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. 
The official said the Soviet Union has not been formally notified of a decision to cancel the meeting between Mr. Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. "But they won't be surprised when it happens, and I don't think they'll be too grief-stricken either," the official said. Word that the summit meeting might be canceled was first reported tonight by the Cable News Network.
 
Vehicle for Arms Treaty
 The summit was scheduled as the vehicle for Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Bush to sign a new treaty that would cut long-range nuclear weapons. But an official said tonight that work on that treaty was proceeding more slowly than had been anticipated, and that there have been significant disputes between the countries over another treaty cutting conventional arms in Europe. That treaty was signed in Paris last November.
Senior officials said last week that Congress had made it clear that the conventional arms treaty should not be submitted for approval until those problems had been cleared up, and they said that it would not be possible to proceed to the second treaty on nuclear weapons until the disputes over conventional arms were resolved.
Officials said tonight that the situation was uncertain enough that it made the summit meeting seem like a bad idea. "In addition, the uncertainties about the situation in the gulf also led us to reconsider the schedule," an official said.
 
U.S.-Soviet Differences
 Soviet and American differences over the conventional arms treaty center on American charges that the Soviet Union has evaded counting and verification rules in the treaty.
Senior American officials say that a resurgence of Soviet military influence is behind the Soviet actions, and some also say that political turmoil in Moscow is to blame for the unexpected difficulties in completing negotiations on technical issues in the nuclear arms treaty, including verification and encoding provisions.
Although senior officials at the White House and State Department said last week that they generally accepted Mr. Gorbachev's assurances that he wanted to clear up both treaties and that Soviet foreign policy would not change dramatically, the difficulties in arms control were a dramatic sign of how Soviet internal politics could affect relations between the superpowers.
The officials acknowledged that for the first time since Mr. Bush took office, indeed perhaps since Mr. Gorbachev himself came to power in 1985, the forward momentum in Soviet-American affairs is now slowing.
 Even without any change in Soviet foreign policy, officials said, a crackdown on political activity in the Soviet Union could make the way Moscow handles its internal affairs a negative force in Soviet-American relations, just as it was during the cold war.
Citing the Soviet military's current occupation of a printing plant in Latvia, a senior policy maker said, "There is no question that some of these strong-arm tactics, if they continue, are going to cause problems in the U.S.-Soviet relationship."
 
Bush-Gorbachev Ties
 That, officials said, could could make it harder for Mr. Bush to maintain the warm relationship with Mr. Gorbachev that is so central to Soviet-American relations. Not only would that pose difficulties for a President who relies on his personal contacts, but it comes at a bad time: Mr. Gorbachev's cooperation in the Persian Gulf has been pivotal to Mr. Bush's ability to build and hold together the coalition against Iraq.
As Mr. Gorbachev works to bring order to his country, such considerations will require Washington to strike what a senior official called a "fine balance" between self-interest, like insuring Soviet cooperation in the Persian Gulf, and broader principles like freedom of political expression.
"Everything that Gorbachev does he is bound to say is designed to help promote the reform process, and I don't doubt that's what he means," another official said. "But even if you don't intend things to happen, there are consequences of relying on the old forms of government. It's one thing if there are ethnic pogroms and you have to stop killing. It's something else if you are denying people the right to express themselves politically."
 
Crackdown in China
 Mr. Bush faced this problem after the crackdown on political dissent in China. He made two hotly debated overtures to the Chinese in hopes of improving relations with Beijing, a policy that White House officials have admitted was a failure.
There are differences among American officials over how much Mr. Gorbachev is threatened and how far he would go in exercising his powers. But there is a consensus that the Soviet political situation is likely to worsen as economic conditions worsen and the component republics assert themselves.
Administration officials said they did not know exactly how strong Mr. Gorbachev's position was and could not predict his next moves with confidence. Some officials said they would not be surprised if Mr. Gorbachev imposed martial law or some less dramatic form of "presidential rule" selectively in areas where separatist movements or ethnic tensions are particularly strong. "But we do not expect anything like a nationwide imposition of martial law," an official said.
 
Warning by Shevardnadze
 Although the Administration has been concerned for some time about a drift back to strict central control in the Soviet Union, the resignation of Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze sharply increased their worries. On Dec. 22, Mr. Bush noted Mr. Shevardnadze's warnings of impending dictatorship and added, "Obviously, people are concerned about, are wondering about the concerns raised and expressed by Mr. Shevardnadze."
The President said he would watch Soviet policy "very closely" but took comfort in Moscow's assurances that its foreign policy would not change. "I will continue to work with this new and very encouraging bilateral relationship, work to enhance that in every way possible," he said.
The next week, after meetings in Washington and Moscow, American officials said they were convinced that Mr. Gorbachev remained fully in charge of Soviet foreign policy, at least for the time being. Since Mr. Shevardnadze's resignation, a senior official said: "For the most part, we have not seen any real change in Soviet foreign policy. But the one area where we are having a problem is in arms control, where there clearly is a resurgence of the military's influence."
 
Arms-Control Problems
 Administration officials generally said the Soviet military was responsible for the disputes between the Soviet Union and the United States over the newly signed treaty on conventional weapons in Europe.
The United States has said the Soviet Union's figures on the size of its forces are too low, that Moscow has improperly moved some weapons out of the area covered by the treaty and that the Soviet military has arbitrarily reassigned other weapons to the navy to avoid having them covered.
But there was some division about whether the military was responsible for the problems involving the proposed treaty reducing long-range nuclear weapons, which center on technical issues, like the coding of signals to missiles and the flight testing of some rockets, that are proving harder to resolve than initially anticipated.
As a result, the signing of that document by Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev, an event that once seemed almost routine, is now something of a test of the state of Soviet-American relations.
To some degree, the Bush Administration is where it was two years ago: trying to decide how much to support Mr. Gorbachev.
 
'A Fundamental Struggle'
 "To the extent that Gorbachev has done things that were in our interest, we wanted to pursue them," an official said. "Now we're watching a fundamental struggle and we don't know what's going to come out. But in the end we're not going to be the arbiters of success there, and we have to pursue policies beneficial to our broader concerns. That means our position is to be supportive of Gorbachev, but specifically with the idea this is a guy who helped bring about reform and we want to see that reform process go forward."
The United States also has been groping for ways to prepare for the possibility that Mr. Gorbachev's personal authority -- indeed that of the Moscow Government in general -- could be reduced.
At the urging of Soviet visitors and American experts on the Soviet Union, Washington has quietly moved to expand its contacts outside the Kremlin, officials said. This requires a tricky diplomatic formula.
Mr. Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d have met with the heads of the Baltic republics, Latvia, Estonia and Lithuania, which the United States does not recognize as Soviet territory.
 
Lower Level Contacts
 But officials from the republics of Armenia, Kazakhstan, the Ukraine, Russia and Byelorussia were received at a lower level, by Brent Scowcroft, the President's national security adviser, and by Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger, to avoid alienating Mr. Gorbachev or inflaming Soviet tensions.
Mr. Bush arranged a quick and ostensibly impromptu meeting with Boris N. Yeltsin, when he was at the White House last year before his election as President of the huge Russian republic.
The Administration has also tried to extend assistance to republic, regional and city governments in the Soviet Union on matters like banking regulation, economic reform and court systems.
"But that really is just conceptual so far," an official said. "It is difficult to arrange, and the money for these kinds of programs is in Moscow, not outlying areas."
But there is little the United States can do in these areas, officials said, because it has no realistic alternative to the central authorities who control the Soviet economy, the Soviet military and, especially, the Soviet nuclear arsenal.

HEADLINE: Turning Disease Into Political Cause: First AIDS, and Now Breast Cancer

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 6

 BODY:
Women with breast cancer are taking a lesson from AIDS advocacy groups and using political action to urge the Federal and state governments to pay more attention to their disease.
"They showed us how to get through to the Government," said Shiela Swanson, a breast cancer patient in the Bay Area who helped organize an advocacy group called Y-Me. "They took on an archaic system and turned it around while we have been quietly dying." 
 In cities like San Francisco, Dallas, Washington, Berkeley, Calif., and Cambridge, Mass., breast cancer advocacy groups have recently been formed to press demands for more action on the disease, which strikes one in 11 American women and kills almost a third of its victims.
The groups are lobbying for more money for research, broader insurance coverage for mammograms and experimental treatments and the resumption of stalled studies into the possible dietary or environmental roots of breast cancer. The groups have been particularly successful on the state level in requiring insurance companies to pay for mammograms.
 
Lessons From AIDS
 Organizers of the groups say they were inspired by the effectiveness of advocates for people with AIDS, but experts in health policy note other factors.
The incidence of breast cancer is increasing and beginning to touch the lives of women and men in the huge baby boom generation. And the Federal Government, in the midst of a debate over how to allocate scarce research money to various diseases, has recently conceded that women have not been properly represented in biomedical research.
But the lessons of AIDS provide the immediate impetus for the growing activism around breast cancer. Until the AIDS epidemic, advocates for people with a certain disease had never had such a broad influence on public policy. Advocates for people with AIDS have forced an overhaul in the way AIDS drugs are tested, released and financed and have successfully lobbied the Government for billions of dollars for research, treatment and education at a time of fiscal restraint. In fact, the Government spends nearly as much each year on AIDS research as it does on all cancers combined.
"They have scored incredible coups," said Marguerite Donoghue, a lobbyist for the National Coalition of Cancer Research. "They've left all of us saying, 'Boy, let's learn from their techniques.' "
 
'Perfectly Appropriate'
 The techniques of the breast cancer groups have so far been focused on lobbying for legislation, with only a smattering of street actions similar to those of Act-Up, a radical AIDS organization. With a largely moderate approach and a focus more on prevention and possible cures than on drug trials, the new groups have not antagonized Government researchers and have won tentative praise.
Dr. Samuel Broder, director of the National Cancer Institute, said in a telephone interview that he welcomed the new advocacy as a means of prying more money from Congress to be spent on a wide variety of worthy research projects. "It is perfectly appropriate and in my opinion helpful to have concerned women focus on the problem," Dr. Broder said.
Although the breast cancer groups say they are not competing with AIDS organizations for money and attention, they point out the disparity in Government spending on the diseases: $1.1 billion in federally financed AIDS research in the 1990 fiscal year, for a disease that killed more than 23,000 last year, versus $77 million for breast cancer, which killed more than 43,000 Americans that year.
Federal health officials say the comparison is specious because AIDS is a contagious disease and because the death toll from it is likely to surpass that from breast cancer in years to come.
In addition, Federal officials note that breast cancer receives more Government money than any other cancer, including lung cancer, which claims 142,000 lives each year. And millions of dollars more is spent each year on basic research on cancer in general.
Over all, with adjustments for inflation, the Federal Government is spending 4.6 percent less for cancer research than it did in 1980, Ms. Donoghue said. The National Cancer Institute did not itemize spending for individual forms of cancer until recently, so no similar comparison can be made about spending on breast cancer.
 
Success in Congress
 The militancy around breast cancer comes as Federal lawmakers are calling attention to broad inequities regarding women's health. Last spring, at the urging of the Congressional Caucus for Women's Issues, the General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, studied the performance of the National Institutes of Health and found that the nation's principal source of money for biomedical research was largely excluding women from its studies.
About the same time, the Caucus for Women's Issues proposed more than a dozen bills on health issues. The 101st Congress passed two of them: an extension of Medicare to cover mammograms for women over 65 years old and the establishment of a $30 million screening program for breast and cervical cancer in poor communities, where women die of these diseases in disproportionate numbers.
Representative Mary Rose Oakar, an Ohio Democrat who sponsored many of the breast cancer bills, said the comparison to AIDS spending was a powerful way to convert other lawmakers to her cause but must be broached gingerly.
"You make the pitch that if we can do it to AIDS we can do it for women," Ms. Oakar said. "But you can't buy into the right-wing philosophy that there shouldn't be AIDS research. We shouldn't be pitting breast cancer against AIDS. We should be pitting it against 'Star Wars.' "
Ms. Oakar said she has also made progress in Congress by seeking the help of lawmakers whose wives have had breast cancer. "There are at least 10 of them," she said. "And when it hits your family, boy, do attitudes change."
 
Effects of the Baby Boom
 The power of breast cancer as a issue, experts in health policy say, comes in part from demographics. As a result of the baby boom, there are more and more women in their 40's, who at that age are facing an array of health problems, including breast cancer.
"The women politicized in the 70's are talking about their own health when they talk about breast cancer," said Andrea Camp, an aide to Representative Patricia Schroeder, the Colorado Democrat who is co-chairwoman of the Congressional Caucus for Women's Issues.
Also, Ms. Camp and others said, breast cancer is an issue that cuts across the political spectrum and creates a consensus that has never been reached on over abortion, the primary women's health issue of recent decades.
Among the groups pressing for more attention are the Women's Cancer Resource Center in Berkeley, which was founded by lesbians, and the Komen Foundation for Breast Cancer in Dallas, a bastion of rich and socially prominent Republican women.
The Komen Foundation shepherded bills through the Texas Legislature in 1987 and 1989 that forced insurance companies to reimburse the cost of mammograms for all women age 35 and over and required doctors to tell women of all the alternative treatments for their breast tumors. Twenty-five states have now followed Texas's lead on some form of insurance coverage for mammograms.
 
Roots of Inspiration
 Since the 1960's, interest in women's health issues has been driven by feminists, who urged women to take control of medical decisions previously reserved for physicians.
It was this movement that inspired the gay community in the early days of AIDS. "Most people have no awareness that that is where our roots are," said Eric Rofes, the executive director of the Shanti Project, an AIDS service organization in San Francisco.
These days the inspiration is flowing in the opposite direction.
When Elenore Pred founded Breast Cancer Action here, she turned to the AIDS organizations for help. She prepared for political action by attending seminars at the International AIDS Conference here last spring and learned the vocabulary of drug research and regulation by meeting with the staff of the publication AIDS Treatment News.
"AIDS has created a terrible, wonderful model for us all," she said.
AIDS activism is also the template for the Women's Community Cancer Project in Cambridge, a group that recently demonstrated in Boston at a conference on breast diseases. "We see a parallel situation, also deadly, where people have gotten somewhere by taking this kind of action," said Ellen Crowley Overlan, a leader of the group.
A few of the more politically radical women are imitating Act-Up,, which has disrupted medical meetings and Roman Catholic Masses and which plasters its slogan, "Silence Equals Death," on buildings. A few months ago, a billboard appeared on Valencia Street, the main artery of San Francisco's lesbian community, reading: "Thirty women dead from breast cancer every hour. Marked for death by the National Cancer Institute."
At the same time, advocates for breast cancer patients are pressing their cause in Congress, where a bill to set Federal standards for mammography is pending; in the courts, where women are suing insurance companies for not covering experimental treatments, and in mainstream women's organizations, which are taking a fresh look at health issues.
"Almost every woman in the country has lost someone dear to her due to the neglect of the health-care establishment," said Carolin Head, an official with the American Association of University Women, whose 135,000 members voted last year for the first time to endorse legislation on women's health issues.
"More and more women will be engaged in political action around these issues in the 1990's," Ms. Head said. "That's my crystal ball."

HEADLINE: Rhode Island Announces Bank Withdrawal Plan

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 6

 BODY:
Gov. Bruce G. Sundlun of Rhode Island has announced emergency withdrawal plans for residents left without money after he ordered 45 banks and credit unions to close last week.
Mr. Sundlun shut the institutions last week after their private insurer, the Rhode Island Share and Deposit Indemnity Corporation, turned to the state for protection. About 300,000 accounts containing $1.7 billion were frozen. 
 On Saturday, the Governor announced a plan to help depositors in "dire economic need."
"These regulations are designed to give depositors enough money to meet their immediate needs for essentials," he said. "In addition, there will be access to safety-deposit boxes at these institutions by appointment."
To qualify for emergency treatment, depositors must show imminent foreclosure on or eviction from a principal residence; need for necessary, non-elective medical treatment; maintenance of medical insurance; need of food or heating oil, or imminent termination of a utility.
The Governor's office said applications for emergency withdrawals would be available atabout 11 A.M. Monday at various institutions that remain open, including Fleet National Bank, Hospital Trust, Citizens Bank, Old Stone Bank and Eastland Bank. Checks will be mailed to depositors who qualify.
The Governor said 22 credit unions would reopen on Monday.
The credit unions are the Allied Aftermarket Employees Credit Union, Bostitch Employees Credit Union, Cottrell Employees Credit Union, Coventry Teachers Credit Union, Cumberland School Employees Credit Union, East Bay Industrial Credit Union, East Providence Teachers Credit Union, Federal Products Credit Union, Journal Employees Credit Union, Kent County Memorial Hospital Credit Union, Newport Columbian Credit Union, North Providence Teachers Credit Union, Pawtucket Credit Union, Providence Postal Employees Credit Union, Providence Veterans Administration Hospital Credit Union, Rhode Island State Employees Credit Union, St. Anthony's Credit Union, Vapro Credit Union, Warwick Columbus Credit Union, Warwick Postal Employees Credit Union, Westerly Credit Union and Woonsocket Postal Employees Credit Union.
