HEADLINE: U.S. Hardens Trade Stance With Japan

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6

 BODY:
The Bush Administration has turned more truculent in its economic relations with Tokyo, reflecting both frustration over Japanese trading policies and unease over a wave of Japanese investments in the United States.
Three Cabinet departments -- Interior, Justice and Treasury -- have recently taken steps that strike at Japan. That the White House has not slapped the wrists of those responsible for these steps, which go against the previous positions of the Bush Administration, is widely seen in Washington as tacit approval of the more aggressive approach. 
 Some officials say the Administration's willingness to get tough stems from Japan's refusal to support an effort by the United States and other food-exporting countries to force the European Community to end agricultural subsidies. That dispute led to the collapse of global trade talks in Brussels last month.
 
Expecting Difficult Year
 "By ducking the issue, Japan gave evidence to those in this country looking for evidence that Japan is not a force for liberalization of world trade," said S. Linn Williams, the deputy United States trade representative.
Mr. Williams, who said he anticipated a difficult year on trade matters with Japan, is leading a negotiating team that will go to Tokyo next week for trade talks.
At that session, the United States is hoping to pin down what steps the Japanese are taking to make good on promises they made last year, in trade talks that ended with a meeting between President Bush and Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu.
Some Congressional staff members suggested that the newly tough talk could be intended to head off an expected drive in the 102d Congress to enact punitive legislation on foreign investment and trade.
"There's a hard search for new ways for the United States to get tough," said Kevin L. Kearns, former staff member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee who is now at the Economic Strategy Institute, a Washington research group. "Legislation will begin to take shape that could have a life and momentum of its own."
Some economists link the toughness with the weakening economy. "Whenever you see jobs lost and economic misery rising, these are times when foreigner-bashing activities go up," said Shafiqul Islam, of the Council on Foreign Relations in New York.
In the most publicized action by Cabinet officials, the Interior Department is trying to prevent the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company from retaining the right to do business in Yosemite National Park. By acquiring MCA Inc. for almost $6.6 billion, Matshushita also bought an MCA subsiary, the Yosemite and Curry Company, that operates park concessions.
 
Profits Flowing Abroad
 Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr., who pointedly tells reporters he does not drive a Japanese car, has raised the possibility of trying to cancel the concessions contract, which expires in 1993. In criticizing the low fees such concession contracts provide the Government, Mr. Lujan expressed displeasure that profits from the Yosemite operations would soon flow to a foreign company.
On another front, the Justice Department has said it is preparing to file a civil antitrust lawsuit to block the acquisition of Semi-Gas Systems, an American semiconductor equipment company, by Nippon Sanso K.K. of Japan. That announcement came despite President Bush's finding last year that the deal posed no threat to national security.
Semi-Gas, a unit of Hercules Inc. in Wilmington, Del., makes gas cabinets used in semiconductor production. Its acquisition by the Japanese has been sharply criticized in Congress. The Assistant Attorney General, James F. Rill, said the acquisition would substantially increase the "dominant position" of Semi-Gas Systems in the United States market.
 
Possible Legal Sanctions
 And in another indication of a tougher attitude on trade, the Treasury Department is considering supporting the Fair Trade in Financial Services Act, which failed to became law in the waning hours of Congress last year. Should this occur, it would mark the first time the Administration had supported legislation permitting discretionary sanctions against a country that allowed American companies fewer investment opportunities than its companies enjoyed in the United States.
The bill, sponsored by the chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, Donald W. Riegle Jr., Democrat of Michigan, would empower Federal banking regulators to deny applications by foreign banks for branches if the Treasury Secretary determined that equivalent competitive opportunities were not available in the foreign bank's home market.
A recent Treasury study found that Japanese banks now conduct more than 25 percent of the lending in California, while foreign banks' share of total lending in Japan actually fell to 1.7 percent at the end of last year, from 3.5 percent in 1983.
 
A Shift in Position
 The Justice and Interior complaints about Japanese investments are a sharp contrast to previously expressed positions of the Bush and Reagan Administrations, which generally found that virtually any foreign acquisition was acceptable.
"The actions are clearly motivated not only by concern over foreign investment but by displeasure with Japan's grudging contribution in the gulf crisis and the perception of trade unfairness," said Bradley R. Larschan, general counsel of the Association for International Investment.
In the Tokyo trade talks next week, the American focus will be persuading Japan to make good on pledges to stiffen enforcement against monopoly practices. But Washington is up against powerful Japanese business groups that fiercely oppose any change.
"We feel strongly that adequate enforcement would go a long way to open up the Japanese market," said Mr. Williams, the deputy trade representative.
 
Making Fines Higher
 One issue is the fines that would be imposed on Japanese companies caught in restraint of trade. These fines, which the Bush Administration says are too low, amount to only 2 percent of the sales affected by the illegal monopoly practices. In the United States, the fine is 50 percent of affected sales.
While the United States and Japan have made some progress on trade -- Japanese markets in wood products, telecommunications and other sectors have been opened somewhat -- trade tensions remain high.
"There are still American industries that find it more difficult to sell in Japan than market forces would justify," said Mr. Williams, who practiced law in Japan before joining the trade office two years ago.
While the total Japanese investment in the United States was valued at $75.8 billion by the Commerce Department through last year's third quarter -- well below the $121.6 billion of Britain -- Mr. Larschan of the investment association said the perception of unfairness in Japan reflects how little foreign investment has been made there. Commerce Department figures show that in 1989, American investment in Japan was $19.3 billion.
"There is a growing sense of unease among some of the staunchest defenders of international investment freedom that Japan does not play fair and that something has to be done about it," Mr. Larschan noted.
 
Punitive Legislation
 One possible result is that Congress might enact punitive legislation. Mr. Larschan predicted that the legislative initiatives would develop along four main tracks: stronger efforts to bar investments affecting perceived national and economic security; more attention on foreign influence in the political process; a focus on foreign-owned companies' payment of United States taxes, and measures involving specific industries.
Representative Edward J. Markey, Democrat of Massachusetts and chairman of the House Telecommunications subcommittee, has proposed, for example, that foreign owernship of American cable television systems be restricted.
Under a 1988 law that established procedures for national security review of foreign direct investment, President Bush has blocked only one foreign takeover -- a Chinese company's efforts to acquire Mamco Manufacturing Inc. in Seattle, which supplies aircraft components.
Although the 1988 law has temporarily lapsed, the President is reviewing one Japanese proposal that has stirred controversy here -- the takeover by Fanuc, the Japanese robot and machine-tool company, of the Moore Specialty Tool Company of Bridgeport, Conn. Moore makes precision tools that are used to build casings for the fissionable parts of nuclear weapons.

HEADLINE: A Champion of the Sweet Tooth Is Closed

BYLINE: By ROBERT E. TOMASSON

 BODY:
Another New York landmark closed up shop yesterday. As the last prune Danishes, coffee cakes and Rigo Jancsi chocolate cakes went over the counter, customers shook their heads sadly, as if they were losing a member of the family with the death of Grossinger's Home Bakery.
The closing of a small, worn shop -- only 14 feet wide and 50 feet long -- after 55 years was hardly a ripple in the city's sea of economic troubles. In some ways, it could be considered a sign of economic vitality, since the store on Columbus Avenue at 75th Street will soon be joined with five vacant stores on either side of it into a glistening department store selling jeans and designer sweatsuits. 
 But for thousands of customers like Nancy Franco and Richard Mendelsohn the closing means the end of a habit or a link to childhood memories. For the neighborhood, it is a loss of smells and tastes and heritage, the sort of social landmark that defined a community for three generations.
Ms. Franco is 31 years old now, married,and lives around the corner on 75th Street. After growing up in the neighborhood, the family moved to the Riverdale section of the Bronx.
Her grandmother, Florence Ditchik, 86, never moved away. Ms. Franco moved back after being married, and now lives in the same building as her grandmother. And she came back to the bakery.
"The sugar doughnuts," she said, a warm grin spreading across her face. "They were something, coming in as a kid."
Mr. Mendelsohn has been stopping by Grossinger's for 25 years and on its last day bought a birthday cake that he will freeze until his birthday next week."I'd come in here and argue with your mother," Mr. Mendelsohn said gesturing to the owner, Herb Grossinger. "She kept trying to tell me that day-old prune Danish was better than fresh, 'like good wine,' she'd say.
"I'd say, 'I'm buying Danish, not wine,' " Mr. Mendelsohn said.
"Well actually, some older people do say that day-old prune Danish does have some medicinal qualities," the 51-year-old owner said, quite ready to sustain the singular theory of his mother, Isabella.
Isabella Grossinger died in August 1983, and much of the neighborhood mourned. She was 75, lived above the store and was dressed in her blue uniform, ready for work, when she died.
"That was when the phone in the bakery also rang upstairs, so we could take orders anytime," remembered her son.
It was also a time that Mr. Grossinger described as when "families lived together, ate together and had Grossinger desserts to gether." The customers still come in, he said, but habits for sweets have changed. The rent is $5,000 a month and with the lease up next month, the building owner said he was not interested in keeping the bakery in the midst of an assemblage of property that is geared more toward the kind of upscale boutiques and restaurants that clog Columbus Avenue now than the family businesses that lined the street when the store opened.
"The profit margin is narrower and narrower," Mr. Grossinger said.
But with transformation perhaps being more a trait of New York than demise, Grossinger's will live on in more ways than one. Several blocks north on Columbus Avenue is Grossinger's Uptown Shommer Shabbos Bakery. The main difference from the 75th Street bakery -- aside from memories -- is that it is kosher and therefore closed on Saturdays.
The bakery on 86th Street was started in 1946 by Jerry Stefanas, a baker employed by Ernest Grossinger, Herb's father, who died in 1972. The bakery, with a Greek flavor, sold only wholesale. The Grossingers bought it in 1981, started selling retail, and became kosher in 1988.
And Grossinger's will continue to place one product especially in some of the city's most expensive restaurants, albeit under a pseudonym.
"We wanted a very fancy dessert, but with a French soud, not Grossinger's," the owner said. Thus was born bombe glace, a praline ice-cream cake layered with hazelnut meringue, a dish that merits mention in many restaurant reviews.
One of the proudest, unverifiable and emphatic claims of the Grossinger's Home Bakery is that it is the home of the ice-cream cake.
Ernest Grossinger came to the United States in 1914 and Isabella Grossinger in 1929. In 1930 the first cousins with the same surname -- neither any relation to the Grossingers of Catskills fame -- were married and the bakery came into being.
Mr. Grossinger said he believed his store was one of the last Hungarian bakeries on the West Side. Most are on the East Side, including Budapest Pastry at 207 East 84th Street and the Rigo Hungarian Viennese Pastry at 314 East 78th Street, providing mounds of caloric evidence that the sweet tooth may have been hereditary in the Austro-Hungarian Empire.
"It's depressing," Elizabeth Grossinger, 15, the daughter of the owner, said of the closing. "This is where my dad grew up, living upstairs working down here," she said, adding proudly that she has been working in the store "since I was 8."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Herb Grossinger, owner of Grossinger's Home Bakery, a Columbus Avenue landmark that closed yesterday. (Ruby Washington/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Miss Edersheim Weds B. A. Tuckman

 BODY:
Katherine Ann Edersheim, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hans S. Edersheim of New York, was married yesterday to Bruce Aaron Tuckman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred A. Tuckman of Great Neck, L.I. Rabbi Neil Gilman performed the ceremony at the East River Yacht Club in Long Island City, Queens.
Mrs. Tuckman, 25 years old, is an international market developer at Ebasco Services Inc., an engineering and building concern in New York. A graduate of Yale University, she has an M.B.A. degree from New York University. Her father is a vice president of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, securities dealers in New York.
Mr. Tuckman, 28, is an assistant professor of finance at New York University. A summa cum laude graduate of Harvard University, he has a doctorate in economics from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. His mother, Saundra Tuckman, is the assistant principal for special education at the Benjamin N. Cardozo High School in Bayside, Queens. His father is the sales manager at Avitex, a textiles company in Newark.

HEADLINE: Review/Television;
When America Gave A Poor Account of Itself

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
If anyone can find comfort in the economic pains of the present from the recollection of miseries past, "After the Crash" should provide it. Tonight's chapter of "The American Experience," at 9 on Channels 13 and 49 and at 10:30 on Channel 21, tells of the bitter years 1930 to 1932, when hunger, homelessness and hopelessness spread through the land, and the United States seemed close to revolution.
The hourlong documentary supplements the evocative newsreels and photographs that have become hallmarks of this series with firsthand descriptions of the tough times that were burned into survivors' memories. Rural areas and big cities were hit equally hard. A drought in the summer of 1930 brought ruin to the Cotton Belt. 
 "The ground busted open," says a woman who grew up in Arkansas. In Detroit, a quarter of a million people found themselves out of work.
Federal relief programs were almost nonexistent. The narrator, Jason Robards, recalls that President Herbert Hoover, whose appearances here confirm his uncharismatic reputation, counted on private charity and local governments to manage a situation that had become unmanageable. He did not speak of points of light: Self-reliance was his theme; direct aid from Washington was not. In the South, the Red Cross worked through the plantation owners who had always controlled sharecroppers' lives. In the North, evictions led to the spread of shantytowns. Desperation bred an anger that was worked on by Communist organizers.
The painful pictures bring back such events as a march on an Arkansas grocery store by several hundred starving farmers, who managed to obtain $2.50 worth of food apiece, and big demonstrations and clashes with the police by automobile workers in Detroit. At what came to be known as the massacre at River Rouge, four workers were killed in a march on the Ford plant in Dearborn.
 "After the Crash" has a powerful account of the 1932 journey to Washington by thousands of World War I veterans demanding the bonus that had been promised to them for the future. We see grim families passing wearily in front of the Capitol in what they called a death march. Congress did not respond. Troops were called in -- "two rival armies of Americans" confronted each other, says the narrator -- and soon Gen. Douglas MacArthur, exceeding White House orders, demolished the veterans' shanties. A woman says, "America didn't give a good account of itself that night."
The program ends with poignant pictures of the defeated veterans on their way home, American flags still unfurled, though no longer flying, and a slow-motion scene of President Hoover in his losing 1932 campaign for re-election. He seems to be fading out of history, along with his faith in private charity and self-reliance.
 
After the Crash
 
Written by Steve Fayer; produced by Eric Neudel for "The American Experience"; Henry Hampton, executive producer; Jason Robards, narrator. At 9 tonight on Channels 13 and 49; at 10:30 P.M. on Channel 21.

HEADLINE: Challenges and Rewards of Filming in New York

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
Deep in the winter of New York's discontent, when film making in the Big Apple has nearly come to a standstill because of cold weather and the lingering effects of a labor dispute, a hardy band of film makers is fighting gridlock, inflationary costs, chill winds and the wail of sirens to shoot an entire movie in New York City, about a quintessential New York theme: a slumlord who gets his comeuppance.
The movie, a gritty comedy, is called "The Super," and not only has its shooting schedule been a street-smart tour of the East Village, Harlem and Bushwick in Brooklyn, but it also stars some quintessential New York actors. They include Joe Pesci, celebrated recently for playing the volatile wise guy Tommy DeVito in Martin Scorsese's "Goodfellas" as well as a bumbling burglar in "Home Alone," and Vincent Gardenia, best remembered for his role as Cher's father, the plumber, in "Moonstruck." The film also features Ruben Blades, who appeared in "Mo' Better Blues," "The Two Jakes" and "The Milagro Beanfield War." 
 The story of the production's New York odyssey since filming began on Oct. 29 sums up the joys and the nightmares of movie making in Gotham, and vividly demonstrates not only why producers often feel compelled to bring their productions to town, but also, paradoxically, why they often feel like fleeing from the city in terror. "New York is a character itself in this movie," said Charles Gordon, the film's producer, who also produced the Oscar-nominated "Field of Dreams." "What kind of character, I'm not all that sure."
 
A Game of Cards
 In "The Super" Mr. Pesci plays another of his not-very-nice guys: Lou Kritski, a Scrooge-like landlord whose transgressions against his tenants are so egregious that he has been sentenced by the court to live in one of his own decrepit tenements. Mr. Gardenia plays Big Lou, Kritski's world-class bigot of a father, while Mr. Blades plays Marlon, a street hustler-tenant who raises his rent money by beating the incarcerated landlord at three-card monte.
"The Super" is shooting in New York with the blessing of both the film unions and the movie's distributor, 20th Century Fox, because Mr. Gordon signed the last feature-film contract with a local of the National Association of Broadcast Employees and Technicians, which merged with the International Alliance of Theater Stage Employees and Moving Picture Machine Operators last Oct. 1. Everyone in the movie industry refers to them as "Nabet" and "Iatse" or "I.A."
 Currently the contracts between Local 52 of the International Alliance and the major Hollywood film producers have expired, and the producers have promised to steer films away from New York City until an agreement is reached. The union has said it will work in good faith with producers until a new contract can be agreed upon, as it has done many times before when contracts have expired.
Until agreement is reached, five major producers have declared what amounts to a boycott on film making in New York. The five are Columbia Pictures, the 20th Century Fox Film Corporation, Paramount Pictures, Warner Brothers, MGM-United Artists and Orion Pictures, which participates as a distributor.
Only two big-budget feature films are currently shooting in New York City: "The Super" and Woody Allen's new, untitled film, which started production Nov. 19; it will be distributed by Orion. Several television productions, covered under different union contracts, are also shooting.
 
City's Third-Largest Industry
 According to Patrick Pleven, an assistant director of the Mayor's Office for Film, Theater and Broadcasting, it is hard to tell whether the dearth of film making simply reflects the conditions of New York's normal slow season, or whether the boycott is taking effect. At stake is the employment of nearly 3,500 workers who toil on more than 100 New York film productions yearly as well as the future of the city's third-largest industry, behind tourism and fashion.
"I haven't heard of any specific films that have been turned away," said Mr. Pleven, "but at this time we would usually be hearing of a lot more films that would be in the pipeline. It seems peculiar to me that more projects are not on the drawing board."
Mr. Gordon, producer of "The Super," said he had every intention of shooting in New York again. "I haven't had any pressure placed on me about bringing future projects here," he said. One of his planned films, "The Gossip Columnist," "really has a New York feeling, to me," Mr. Gordon said. "I'd fight to shoot it here."
Still, it is not easy to film in New York City. "It's 15 percent more expensive," he said, estimating that the movie will cost between $15 million and $20 million by the time it is released in August. Aside from the premium pay to members of the International Alliance of Theater Stage Employees and Moving Picture Machine Operators during night and weekend shooting, "when we hire extras, they're all under SAG," he said, referring to the Screen Actors Guild. Less costly non-SAG actors can be hired in many non-New York locations.
In addition, "the traffic and congestion is terrible," he said. "You can waste three hours just getting to a new location across town, and that costs money."
 
No Other City Like It
 In the end, though, Mr. Gordon said shooting in New York "was worth the extra trouble."
"You come here for the look," he said. "The authenticity of that vertical orientation. The bleakness, the grayness. You can't get it anywhere else."
Rod Daniel, the film's director, agreed. "I insisted on New York," he said. " 'The Super' is a tightly balled, character-oriented, in-your-face comedy, and it was perfect for the city. There's a lot of energy in the air, a sense of danger and excitement. It's never boring. And that works its way right up onto the screen. We wanted to flaunt the film's New Yorkiness."
And, he added, there have been moments when New York was positively magical. One of them occurred when Mr. Pesci, Mr. Gardenia and Mr. Blades were standing on a grimy asphalt roof on 10th Street between Avenue A and First Avenue. To the north glowed the Empire State Building and the Chrysler Building, and, only a few blocks away, the festive clock lights of the Consolidated Edison Company Building shone brightly.
The cameras began to roll; Mr. Daniel called "Action!" and Mr. Pesci began saying his lines to Mr. Gardenia, enacting a scene of rooftop confrontation between father and son. "It's my building, remember?" Mr. Pesci said angrily. "You gave it to me. I'm gonna run it the way I think it should be run!"
After Mr. Daniel said "Cut," Mr. Pesci talked about Kritski, the slumlord. "My character, he's the Archie Bunker of the 90's," said the actor, who says his name "PEH-shee," giving it "the good Veronese pronunciation," as he put it.
"Kritski abuses every minority in his sights," Mr. Pesci continued. "But he's honest, and that's what I like about him. I love to play a guy with passion. And I do like comedy. Lou Kritski is so obnoxious and absurd he's funny."
 
Good Timing of Background Noise
 Funny Kritski may be, but Mr. Pesci's movie tour of New York has not always been a laugh riot. "You always run into police sirens, and screeching ambulances," he said. "As soon as you hear the words 'roll sound,' 'speed,' and 'action' -- well, right on cue, some siren goes on."
Then there was the time Mr. Pesci was walking down Nostrand Avenue in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn, preparing for a scene, when a man in the crowd nearby had his throat cut in an argument outside a methadone clinic. "I was walking past him just as he got his throat slit," Mr. Pesci said, "and the guy -- well, he was running around trying to hold his head on."
There have been other, less life-threatening difficulties. For example, the principal exteriors on East 11th Street were a bit too upscale for the look needed for Lou Kritski's slum building. Rather than relocate in a more rundown neighborhood, the director decided that the street should be "dressed down," as set designers say.
So, the community was enlisted in spray-painting on more graffiti; false fronts were constructed; windows were cinder-blocked; razor-wire accents were carefully placed, and the buildings were sprayed with a dirt-and-water mixture to enhance their grittiness. The block will be given a $50,000 restoration when the film making is done.
"I think it's a delight to shoot in New York, and I wish I could do it more often," said Mr. Gardenia, sitting meditatively during a moment between scenes. "After all, I live here." Mr. Gardenia has a house in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn and is a landlord himself. "I have a tenant in the upstairs apartment," he said. "I'm a nice landlord. I am definitely not Big Lou."
"I've only been able to do three movies in New York," said Mr. Gardenia, naming "Death Wish," "Little Murders" and "Moonstruck." "It's a privilege to shoot here once in a while. I hope New York movies don't become an endangered species."

SECTION: Section A; Page 17; Column 5; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 769 words

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
The Letter

BYLINE: By William Safire

DATELINE: MONTREAL

 BODY:
The most historic document of George Bush's Presidency is now in the pocket of his Secretary of State, who is en route to Geneva to deliver it personally to his Iraqi counterpart. It is the letter of final warning to Saddam Hussein.
The letter serves two purposes. First is to make certain that our position is transmitted without conditional shading by the Iraqi dictator's nervous underling. Second is to make plain that no new Yalta is in the works -- no secret assurance that gives the aggressor a way to claim a victory and marshal his forces for a day when he has his nuclear "equalizer." 
 The condition is already being offered by President Mitterrand of France: in essence, "swap Kuwait for Israel." France offers a deal linking a withdrawal from Kuwait to the same face-saver Saddam Hussein proposed after we called his bluff: a promise to try to force the Israelis to give up their security to Palestinian irredentists. Everyone knows that belated pitch is a phony: Saddam Hussein grabbed Kuwait for the money, not for the Palestinians.
The French fig leaf of linkage would guarantee the survival of the Saddam regime, justify the rape of Kuwait and invite other dictators to plunder their neighbors under cover of a jihad. Not even other Arab leaders want that; they know that a deal crowning the butcher of Baghdad with saviorhood would increase his momentum and whet his appetite.
That is why it is vital to define our mission in the gulf: not only to get Iraq to withdraw from what is left of Kuwait, our "stated" goal, but to remove the cancer of aggression before it metastasizes.
Mr. Bush remembers that shameful period of offering trade credits "to bring Iraq into the family of peaceful nations." He ruefully told the interviewer David Frost: "We had Congressmen that went over and came back and talked to me, and they said, wait a minute. . . ."
Waiting a few months led to Kuwait; waiting a few years would lead to nuclear blackmail. Mr. Bush now understands "the worse price to pay tomorrow" and can at last say with conviction that there has been "nothing of this moral importance since World War II." In that same interview, when Mr. Frost asked about "the final sanction" of massive air attack, the President did not join the chorus of mockers of this lower-casualty option: "Without trying to sound bellicose, he would not have air cover of any kind, should there be some conflagration. None, none at all. So, we have awesome air power there . . ."
In his letter, Mr. Bush should sound coldly bellicose. One hopes it will draw on his radio address last weekend and go something like this:
"Dear President Hussein: Withdraw from Kuwait unconditionally and totally before the U.N. January 15 deadline or condemn your nation to terrible consequences. No compromise will be offered; no linkage to any other subject will be tolerated; no oral representations by anyone can modify in any way the choice I put before you today: withdrawal or war.
"Total withdrawal by the deadline date," the letter ought to say, "will avert the world's massive military response to your aggression, but economic sanctions will continue, and the possibility of more forceful action will exist, until you (1) stop all development of nuclear, chemical and biological weapons, and destroy such installations under world supervision, agreeing to on-site inspections and (2) make restitution for money and property stolen from Kuwait and its citizens and resident workers; pay reparations to families of those killed by your unprovoked aggression; make whole those countries impoverished by the influx of refugees; agree to turn over to an international tribunal those charged with war crimes."
A final paragraph is necessary to prevent this letter from becoming a device for delay. The good thing about a letter is its ability to demolish ambiguity; the danger is that it invites a reply asking for clarifications and amendations -- designed to prevent action until war would be costlier or the Mitterrand tactic prevailed.
"Signify your acceptance of these terms by withdrawing totally by the deadline date, and with a letter before that date agreeing to inspection, restitution, reparations, and cooperation in bringing to justice those guilty of war crimes. Failure to respond on time will be treated as your rejection of this final offer to spare your forces from destruction."
This letter should be neither an appeal to reason nor a plea for peace. It should be an unmistakable ultimatum. In Churchill's phrase, "The constabulary of the world is at hand"; the criminal must retreat.

HEADLINE: Let's Talk About Reparations for Slavery;
Sliced Too Fine

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Fine Distinctions for the White House" (editorial, Dec. 19), you suggest that the Bush Administration's effort to separate race-based scholarships paid for with Federal funds from those that are subsidized by other sources illustrates a politically successful, legally defensible and constitutionally appropriate way of making controversial policy choices.
Whatever the political expediency and legality of fudging scholarship support for minority students in this manner, to suggest that the finesse of an accountant can shield all Government policy choices ignores, at the least, the constraints of the First Amendment in other contexts.
Now pending in the United States Supreme Court, for example, is a case challenging the Bush Administration's attempt to employ the very shield you support in defense of a gag rule on professional speech. In Rust v. Sullivan (in which I am counsel of record for the petitioners), the Bush Administration seeks to draw a sharp division between Federal and private funds for domestic family planning. It is defending the censorship of abortion information, counseling and referral in Title X-funded family-planning clinics.
But as Anna Quindlen stated in "Banning the A-Word" (column, Nov. 1), this defense merely spits in the face of the law. Indeed, what she described as the Government's "demand that doctors like Irving Rust trade free speech and professional responsibility for scarce Federal funds" is not immunized from public condemnation or constitutional scrutiny because Dr. Rust remains theoretically free to give information about abortion to his low-income patients with non-Federal funds, outside the Federal Title X program.
Universities too, like not-for-profit health clinics, have to scramble to pool resources from both governmental and private donors in order to provide critical services and opportunities to economically disadvantaged communities. The razor blade approach to Federal policy reflected by the Administration's "compromise" on race-based college scholarships and endorsed by your editorial evidences a callous disregard for this reality, as well as for the power of the Government purse. In the free speech context, however, this approach fails completely to save Government censorship from crossing the constitutional line.
 
RACHAEL PINE
New York, Dec. 21, 1990
 
The writer is staff counsel, reproductive freedom project, American Civil Liberties Union.

LENGTH: 1736 words

HEADLINE: U.S. IS TAKING OVER A GROUP OF BANKS TO HEAD OFF A RUN

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6

 BODY:
Acting to avert a run on one of the nation's largest banking companies, the Federal Government today seized the Bank of New England and two affiliated banks and said it would protect all depositors until the banks could be sold.
The rescue is likely to cost taxpayers at least $2.3 billion, making it one of the costliest bailouts in history. 
 On Friday, the Bank of New England Corporation, which is based in Boston, announced a large loss for the fourth quarter, which left it without reserves to absorb future losses. The other banks taken over today, also owned by the corporation, are the Connecticut Bank and Trust Company and the Maine National Bank.
 
Withdrawals by Depositors
 Government officials said the seizure was prompted by the withdrawal of more than $1 billion on Friday and Saturday at branches of the Bank of New England and Connecticut Bank and Trust. Officials of the parent company said less than $1 billion had been withdrawn.
"The management had already come to us and asked for some Government assistance," Robert L. Clarke, the Comptroller of the Currency, said in a telephone interview tonight. "We decided that the most positive thing we could do for the region was to get the situation stabilized."
The Bank of New England, the third-largest bank in the region and the 33d-largest in the nation, had been in growing distress as the New England real estate market worsened. Developers of office buildings, hotels, shopping malls and condominiums could not meet their loan payments.
"There were just too many bad loans," said Lawrence K. Fish, who became chairman of the Bank of New England Corporation in early 1990. "It was a classic lesson in the failure to diversify risk. The Bank of New England lent too much, too aggressively, too quickly for a number of years."
 
'Too Big to Fail'
 A far smaller bank owned by the Bank of New England Corporation, the Bank of New England Trust Company of West Palm Beach, Fla., was not taken over by the Government.
At a news conference here this evening, L. William Seidman, the chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, said the Government had decided over the weekend to inject $750 million immediately into two banks owned by Bank of New England.
Mr. Seidman said regulators had decided to protect all deposits, including those over $100,000, although the F.D.I.C. is not obliged to do so. That decision is a clear demonstration of the Government's "too big to fail" approach in dealing with large problem banks -- stepping in to avoid the ripple effect that the failure of a large bank would have throughout the economy.
"It was clear to us that to protect the stability of the system, we should protect all depositors," Mr. Seidman said. He said more than $2 billion on deposit at banks owned by Bank of New England, out of a total of $16.8 billion on deposit, was in accounts larger than $100,000.
Asked what had caused the Bank of New England's difficulties, Mr. Seidman said, "They made loans that could not be collected."
The Government's expense in dealing with the Bank of New England had been anticipated in the F.D.I.C.'s estimate that the its bank insurance fund would lose $4 billion in 1990. The fund is at the weakest level since its creation in 1934, and Mr. Seidman has estimated that it could lose another $5 billion in 1991 as the nation's banking problems worsen.
The Bank of New England's failure is the largest since the 1989 collapse of Mcorp, based in Dallas, and the 1988 collapse of the First Republicbank Corporation, also of Dallas. The Government has estimated that Mcorp's failure will ultimately cost taxpayers $2.5 billion and the failure of First Republic at least $1.6 billion, and possibly much more.
As in those cases, the Government created a "bridge" bank that it will control. The bridge bank will own the Bank of New England until it can be sold to a financially healthy institution.
Government officials tonight would not name the banking companies with which they are negotiating the sale of the Bank of New England. Mr. Seidman said he expected the Government would soon disclose the identities of two banks that are bidding. Both are believed to be financially strong domestic banking companies situated outside New England.
The BancOne Corporation, of Columbus, Ohio, which many banking experts had named as a possible buyer, has not yet talked to Federal regulators, its chairman, John B. McCoy, said today.
Mr. Seidman also said other bids might be made.
"Our greatest interest is having a buyer who has the ability to take these institutions and who pays us the best price," he said. In past large collapses, the acquiring bank has often received the right to return poor assets to the Government, adding substantially to the cost to the Government of the bailout.
Mr. Seidman said the banking company's management had agreed to stay on while a buyer was sought.
"This management was not the cause of the bank's failure, in our opinion," he said. "We have no evidence of any fraud at this time."
 
Risky Real Estate Loans
 While the weakening of the New England economy undoubtedly hurt the company, the last year has made clear that its most severe problems were the result of its own mistakes. It lent an astounding 36.7 percent of total loans for risky commercial real estate projects -- far more than neighboring banks -- and it failed to manage the activities of its subsidiary banks adequately to reduce operating costs.
When Mr. Fish and his management team were installed early last year, it was already too late.
Mr. Seidman estimated that the bank would eventually have to declare $3 billion to $6 billion of its $22 billion of assets worthless.
Of the $750 million made available, Mr. Seidman said about $500 million would be given to the Bank of New England and about $250 million to Connecticut Bank and Trust, based in Hartford. Maine National is based in Portland.
The decision to stand behind all deposits is a sharp contrast to the F.D.I.C.'s handling late last year of the collapse of the Freedom National Bank of New York, in Harlem, one of the nation's largest minority-owned institutions.
After Freedom National collapsed, regulators decided they would make good only 50 cents of each $1 for all accounts larger than $100,000. That decision was strongly criticized by some lawmakers and community officials.
 
Bank Proposal Rejected
 In creating a Government-owned bank, regulators rejected a proposal by the Bank of New England's bondholders to provide the company another $706 million of capital by converting bonds into stock, plus another $100 million of new equity capital from the sale of securities to bondholders and stockholders in the company.
"I think our plan would have been the least costly for the F.D.I.C., but they decided that they did not have the luxury of time to consider it," said Wilbur L. Ross, Jr., a managing director at Rothschild Inc., which is representing a group of bondholders.
One banking official who insisted on anonymity said the creation of Goverment-owned banks to replace the Bank of New England units creates even more pressure on the Government to find a new buyer quickly.
"With a Government-owned bridge bank, you have a situation where loans are not being made, officers are busy looking for new jobs and the franchise value is evaporating daily," the official said.
"I'm not surprised they protected every dollar at the Bank of New England," said Bert Ely, a banking and savings industry consultant. "Markets are too nervous right now about banks. There are too many uncertainties out there right now."
Problems in the New England economy, and particularly its real estate markets, have in recent months led to growing problems at many regional banks and savings associations. Last week the Governor of Rhode Island shut down 45 credit unions and banks that had been insured by a private insurer that said it might not be solvent.
Twelve of the credit unions are expected to reopen Monday with Federal insurance. The others remain closed, with considerable uncertainty as to whether their customers will receive 100 cents for each dollar deposited.
Federal officials have been eager to keep the problems at the Bank of New England from spreading to other banking companies in the region. Some of them have also suffered losses from bad real estate loans, but are not in such dire straits as the Bank of New England.
If the F.D.I.C. had insisted that large uninsured depositors bear part of the cost of the bank's problems, large depositors might quickly withdraw money from other banks in New England, including the Bank of Boston, the Shawmut Bank and Fleet/Norstar Financial Group.
Mr. Seidman said that today's decision did not establish a precedent for other problem banks in the region that might require Federal assistance.
"They will be handled on a case-by-case basis," he said.
Because the Bank of New England has such a high level of delinquent loans, analysts assume that any potential buyer would not want to buy all $17 billion of loans outstanding. On Friday, the Bank of New England Corporation said it had $3.3 billion of assets -- primarily loans -- that were not earning interest or were so troubled that the bank did not expect payment on time.
 
Strong Buyer Needed
 No large bank has ever survived as an independent company with such a large amount of its loans failing to pay interest.
Some analysts say the bank's $17 billion in loans could be worth only 75 cents on the dollar. A buyer would be loath to acquire the bad loans, and history shows that borrowers who are financially squeezed feel less obligation to repay a debt owed the F.D.I.C. than a debt owed to a bank with which they might want to do business in the future.
In talks about the acquisition of the Bank of New England, Government regulators have made it clear that the acquiring banking company must have above-average financial strength, so that it would make the necessary investment in the Bank of New England and still have capital equal to about 5 percent of its assets.
But even with a new bank investing perhaps several hundred million dollrs in the Bank of New England, the F.D.I.C. would experience a major loss, primarily from the need to take the Bank of New England's bad loans, which no buyer would accept.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 8, 1991, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article yesterday about the Government's seizure of the Bank of New England misstated the source of the $2.3 billion that is the expected cost of bailing out the institution and two affiliated banks. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's bank insurance fund, which is financed by banks themselves, will be responsible for the cost; it will not be covered by taxpayer funds.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1357 words

HEADLINE: With a New Hybrid Government, Weicker Is Facing a Budget Crisis

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Jan. 6

 BODY:
An unfamiliar hybrid form of state government is shaping up here, charged with the job, beginning this week, of addressing a budget crisis that is equally unfamiliar in its severity. At the center ring in both cases is Lowell P. Weicker Jr.
Mr. Weicker, a former Republican United States Senator, was elected Governor in November as an independent -- only the fifth independent governor in the United States since the turn of the century. On Wednesday he will take command in the face of a worsening economy and a budget with deficits that have grown deeper since the election. Projected sales-tax revenues and corporate tax collections have been dropping every month, with no end in sight. 
 Against such a backdrop -- and with Mr. Weicker maintaining an almost monk-like silence about his plans -- his appointments and nominations for administration posts, drawn from three parties, have fallen from the sky like pieces of an unfinished jigsaw puzzle.
Lawmakers, other state officials and news reporters comb off-the-cuff comments by Mr. Weicker and his aides for hidden meaning, especially for clues to whether he will decide that the state should tax the wages of its workers. Connecticut is one of only 10 states that does not tax earned income.
"Every action, every statement, will be watched and interpreted over and over again," said Jonathan Pelto, the political director of the state's Democratic Party, which controls both chambers of the General Assembly.
Mr. Weicker's nominees to head state agencies are subject to approval by the General Assembly. If all the Governor's choices made so far are approved, Democrats, Republicans and members of Mr. Weicker's fledgling third party, called the Connecticut Party, will be sprinkled across the executive branch in what Mr. Weicker insists is complete disregard for the two-party rules of the past.
He is impatient with those who have not grasped the implications of the new political era in Hartford. He bristles when asked the party association of his nominees and appointees. He argues that politicians and reporters who persist in using what he calls archaic standards to assess his administration are missing the point.
He has declined to be interviewed about his inauguration or his plans and hopes for his administration. When a reporter assigned to write a profile of the Governor-elect approached him after a recent news conference at the Capitol and asked how him how he would describe his management style, Mr. Weicker refused to give a direct reply.
 
'Enough Speculation'
 "I'm not going to describe it," he said. "You guys have done enough speculation, so from now on I think I'll just do it. Then you can report after I've done it, rather than speculate on what can or can't be done."
What Mr. Weicker has done so far is to name a Democrat, William J. Cibes Jr. to head the budget arm of the state government, the Office of Policy and Management. It has been run by Democrats for the last 15 years.
Social-service agencies that supervise the welfare system -- the largest spending category in the $7 billion budget -- would also continue to be led by Democrats.
In contrast, the Department of Economic Development, which seeks to bolster Connecticut's business climate, would be led by a Republican. And control over the Department of Banking would go to a friend from Mr. Weicker's days at Yale University, Henry S. Scherer Jr., whose party affiliations are no help at all in assembling the puzzle. Mr. Scherer has been both a Republican and a Democrat over the years.
Presiding over the State Senate will be a member of Mr. Weicker's Connecticut Party, Lieut. Gov.-elect Eunice S. Groark, a former Republican from Hartford.
 
Former Opponents Appointed
 Of the 10 people Mr. Weicker has nominated to cabinet-level positions, four are vanquished political opponents, including two Republicans and one Democrat who were early candidates for governor last year. Mr. Weicker chose another Democrat, Gloria Schaffer, who challenged him for his Senate seat in 1976, to be Commissioner of Consumer Protection.
The Governor's private staff, which is not subject to legislative approval, is made up mostly of Republicans.
The director of Mr. Weicker's transition team, Peter W. Gold, has said the common denominator of the evolving administration is managerial excellence. No attempt is being made to have a perfect balance of Democrats or Republicans, but neither is such a balance being avoided, Mr. Gold said. He and other staff members say that when Mr. Weicker interviews a prospective manager, he does not even inquire about party affiliation.
 
Record as a Maverick
 All of which leads many of those trying to track Mr. Weicker's real direction to the question of his personality. At 6 feet 6 inches, 59-year-old Mr. Weicker is physically imposing. He has an air of authority -- some call it arrogance -- that can make him seem even larger, especially when one considers his history as a Senate maverick who flouted party lines and left a trail of gored oxen in Washington for nearly two decades.
Invited once to testify before the Republican National Committee about what its national platform should be, Senator Weicker, then a Republican, took the stand and announced that having a platform at all was foolishness because no one cared about or ever read such documents. He then sat down.
In November Mr. Weicker discomfited both the Democrats and Republicans with his third-party campaign. He defeated the Republican nominee, John G. Rowland, by about 33,000 votes, and the Democrat, Bruce A. Morrison, by more than 230,000.
As Governor, Mr. Weicker's personal power will be magnified, politicians say, by the fact that his administration will have no party cohesion to bind its members, who may find they have little in common beyond owing their jobs to the boss. Those who have worked for Mr. Weicker say he has always been an exacting, hands-on manager who knows precisely the way he wants things done.
 
Doing Things 'His Way'
 "He wants it done right: his way," said Hank Harper, who ran Senator Weicker's Connecticut offices from 1971 until his retirement in 1989. "If you can understand that, then he's not a difficult man to work for. If you can't appreciate that, I can imagine somebody would have a lot of trouble."
In government and out, much of the speculation and anxiety about what Mr. Weicker will or will not do concerns Connecticut's troubled budget, especially whether he will propose or accept a state income tax on wages in the legislative session that begins on Wednesday. The state already taxes so-called unearned income -- stock and bond dividends and interest.
The most recent Comptroller's office report projects a $670 million gap for the year ending June 30 and a $1.5 billion shortfall in the year after that in a budget of just over $7 billion. Unemployment edged to 5.2 percent in November, compared with 4.1 percent a year ago.
Mr. Weicker has said that he does not want to borrow money to bridge the deficit and that imposing a new wage tax during an economic downturn could make the downturn worse. But his nominee for Budget Director, Mr. Cibes, openly favors an income tax and ran unsuccessfully for the Democratic Party's nomination as governor last year on just such a platform. Mr. Cibes has said that all such decisions now rest with Mr. Weicker.
How Mr. Weicker makes up his mind on an issue depends on the question at hand, past and present staff members say -- a characteristic that once again sheds only limited light on his administration's possible course.
"He'd listen to both supportive views and dissenting opinions, then make up his own mind," said Richard F. Benson, who was director of Senator Weicker's Hartford office from 1977 until last year, when the office closed after Mr. Weicker's 1988 re-election defeat to Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, a Democrat.
"Very rarely would he just announce, 'Here's the deal, here's how I'm going to vote,' " Mr. Benson said. "Except for some things, where he was just going headstrong into it and that was it."

HEADLINE: Bernard Hellring Is Dead at 74; Battled to Improve Varied Laws

BYLINE: By PETER B. FLINT

 BODY:
Bernard Hellring, a leader in efforts to simplify and standardize state and national laws, particularly in business affairs, legislative apportionment and divorce, died on Friday in Orange, N.J. He was 74 years old and lived in South Orange, N.J.
He died of a heart attack on his way to visit a client, a family spokesman said. 
 Mr. Hellring, a dedicated fighter for right as he saw it, was, for more than 30 years, a New Jersey Commissioner on Uniform State Laws. He helped draft many model statutes in business transactions, trial practices, labor relations and estates, for the state and also for the nation, in conferences with counterparts from other states.
He also led efforts to change New Jersey divorce laws and codify them in the state's so-called no-fault divorce law of 1971, and he helped chart the 1985 Congressional re-apportionment of the state. He was the founder and senior partner of a leading Newark law firm, now called Hellring Lindeman Goldstein & Siegal.
 Bernard Hellring was the son of an Austrian merchant whose family brought him to this country at the age of 3. He grew up in Newark, attended public schools there and earned a bachelor's degree at Lafayette College.
He earned a law degree at Harvard University in 1939 and was later a member of the board of overseers for the university's law school, a president of the Harvard Law School Association of New Jersey and a national vice chairman of the law school's scholarship committee.
In World War II, he served in the Washington Office of Scientific Research and Development. He was later a longtime adviser to the American Law Institute and special counsel to the New Jersey Commissioner of Conservation and Economic Development.
Surviving are his wife of 42 years, the former Sally Horner; two daughters who are both lawyers, Margaret, of South Orange, and Heidi, of Millburn, N.J., and four grandchildren.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gold and Silver Prices Jump As Commodity Funds Buy

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
The futures prices of gold and silver soared yesterday amid heightened fear of a war in the Persian Gulf. But dealers stressed that the price rises were more reflective of buying by commodity futures funds than of significant demand for the actual metal.
At the close of trading on the Commodity Exchange in New York, the largest gold and silver futures market, the nearest active delivery contract, for February, was settled at $396.20 an ounce, up $9 on the day. Dealers quoted a cash price for gold of $394.10, up $9.20 an ounce. 
 The active March Comex silver delivery jumped 13.3 cents an ounce, to $4.34. Dealers quoted a cash silver price of $4.288 an ounce, up 13.3 cents.
At the New York Mercantile Exchange, the spot platinum delivery contract, for January, rose $4.20 an ounce, to $413.90. The far more active April contract was up $2.70, to $417.10.
 
'Expect Increased Volatility'
 "As the Jan. 15 United Nations deadline for Iraq to quit Kuwait draws near, we can expect increased volatility in all markets," said William B. O'Neill, senior strategist at Merrill Lynch Futures. "But in order for a sustained advance in the precious metals to occur, there has to be a significant increase in the demand for physical metal. We have not seen any significant demand in physical bullion of late."
Mr. O'Neill said much of the strength in silver was a result of the buying of futures contracts by commodity funds. The funds were somewhat less aggressive in buying gold futures. "And every time the precious metals rally, for whatever reason, the producers consistently sell into the rallies," Mr. O'Neill said.
The relative lack of demand for actual gold and silver bullion also comes at a time when many investors are avoiding the battered stock market and when interest rates on other investments are declining. The fact that gold is now trading at the levels that prevailed when Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 has not been lost on investors. Silver is selling well below its level of Aug. 2.
 
Platinum Prices Lag
 While the Persian Gulf crisis roils the gold and silver market, the price of platinum, a far rarer metal, has lagged. One reason, oddly, is that the same rise in oil prices that buoys gold has a mostly negative impact on platinum. As oil prices rise, demand tends to decline, along with the use of platinum by refiners.
One of platinum's main uses is as a catalyst in the refining of crude oil into heating oils and gasoline. Platinum is also used as a catalyst to upgrade the octanes of gasoline and other fuels.
Also, increases in energy prices hurt the economy and reuce demand for cars and trucks. Platinum is widely used in catalytic converters, the anti-pollution devices required on automobiles in the United States and a number of other countries.

HEADLINE: '90 Diamond Sales Up 2%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: LONDON, Jan. 7

 BODY:
Sales of rough uncut diamonds rose 2 percent last year, to $4.17 billion, from $4.09 billion in 1989, the De Beers diamond cartel reported today.
De Beers's marketing arm, the Central Selling Organization, called 1990 "a year of consolidation" and called the sales satisfactory. But when adjusted for inflation, which ran at about a 6 percent annual rate in the United States and higher in some other leading consumer nations, diamond sales fell.
Sales dropped 32 percent in the second half of the year from the robust first half because of the international economic climate and the Persian Gulf crisis, the organization said.
Officials for what is formally known as De Beers Consolidated Mines Ltd. said the outlook was uncertain because of the continuing Middle East turmoil, which has undermined consumer confidence by pushing oil prices, and thus inflation, higher.
In 1989, sales fell 2 percent, after gains of 35 percent in 1988 and 19 percent in 1987.
The Central Selling Organization markets 80 percent of the world's diaproduction, about 100 million carats a year.

HEADLINE: Military's Role Raises U.S. Hopes for Better Ties

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS

 BODY:
United States officials praised the Haitian Army yesterday for blocking a coup attempt by a supporter of the former Duvalier dictatorship, saying its defense of the civilian Government would bolster American efforts to improve ties with Haiti's military.
A senior Administration official said Roger Lafontant, leader of the feared Tontons Macoute militia under Duvalier rule, had miscalculated in thinking that the army would support his bid to take power and thus prevent the inauguration on Feb. 7 of the President-elect, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide. 
 Father Aristide was elected on Dec. 16 on a platform promising sweeping economic and social change, rankling some army officers and other members of the traditional Haitian elite.
When Dr. Lafontant's forces seized the National Palace and took the Provisional President, Ertha Pascal-Trouillot, hostage early yesterday, the army commander, Gen. Herard Abraham, appeared on the national television to denounce the coup attempt.
 
General 'the Unsung Hero'
 General Abraham pledged that he would defend the Constitution, and army troops stormed the palace to arrest Dr. Lafontant, a former Interior Minister, and several other plotters.
A senior American official said Mr. Lafontant's strategy "was based on a delusion."
"He was operating like this was Haiti 5 or 10 years ago," the official said. "General Abraham is the unsung hero. His action cemented a bond between Aristide and the army. This leaves no doubt that the army is loyal to the electoral process."
The official said American and Venezuelan diplomats telephoned General Abraham and other officers pledging their support for the civilian Government and urging them to intervene to defend Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot. But he said the army did not need convincing.
Before yesterday's action, the army had shown an ambivalent attitude toward Dr. Lafontant. Officers backed a decision by the National Electoral Commission to disqualify his candidacy in the last presidential election, but they would not act on a warrant for his arrest even when he vowed that Father Aristide would never take power.
 
Americans as Mediators
 The official said the coup attempt could prove to be a blessing for Father Aristide by exposing and removing his main enemy. Now that the army has taken Dr. Lafontant prisoner, his Tontons Macoute, the militia that long terrorized the population in defense of the Duvalier family dictatorship, is thought to lack a central leader.
For the last several months, Bernard W. Aronson, the Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs; Alvin P. Adams Jr., the United States Ambassador to Haiti, and Pentagon officials in Port-au-Prince have tried to convince the military that its defense of the electoral process was in its own interests. Serving as informal mediators, Mr. Aronson and Mr. Adams called a meeting with Father Aristide only hours after his Dec. 16 election victory to urge that he work with the military and private sector.
At that meeting, Father Aristide pledged to moderate his polemics and seek reconciliation with the military. As a proponent of liberation theology, Father Aristide has advocated justice for victims of the 29-year Duvalier dictatorship, a restructuring of the economy to benefit the poor, and a struggle to root out corruption.
 
Increased Aid Studied
 Since the December election, Defense and State Department officials have begun to study ways to increase aid to Haiti, now about $50 million a year. After three years of granting virtually no aid to the military, the Pentagon is considering sending the Haitian Army medical supplies and giving it advice and financing for a civic action program of bridge and road building.
Last year, Congress blocked an Administration proposal to send the army $500,000 in medical and other nonweapons aid based on an assessment that the army was a force halting democracy. The senior official said yesterday's action might help convince Congress that the army merited help.
The White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said yesterday, "We applaud the efforts of the Haitian military and police authorities in restoring the legitimate authority in Haiti,"
Robert I. Rotberg, president of Lafayette College and an expert on Haiti, said of the failed coup: "This is an extraordinarily encouraging development. This is the first time in Haiti's dark and checkered history when the army has intervened to put democracy on its rightful track. The U.S. and the military seem to be cooperating in order to do what is right for Haiti."

HEADLINE: 'Recyclable' Claims Are Debated

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
Alarmed by the spread of state laws regulating the use of environmental claims like "recyclable," many large consumer products companies are seeking national standards.
The companies, some of which have already had to alter such claims, particularly want a rule that enables them to assert that their products can be recycled, even if recycling operations do not exist. Environmental groups, which say such assertions are misleading in the absence of actual recycling, are expected to oppose such a rule. 
 Officials from many states, as well as environmental groups, are also calling for Federal action on environmental claims, although they are likely to seek tougher standards than the manufacturers.
 
Washington May Be Easier
 The companies may expect a more sympathetic hearing from Federal regulators than from state officials. While some states have enacted laws containing specific requirements for using terms like "recycled," an official of the Federal Trade Commission said the agency was likely to favor more general guidelines.
Barry Cutler, the director of the agency's Bureau of Consumer Protection, described the industry action as "an important first step" in reaching agreement on the claims. He said the agency was unlikely to pass "a hard and fast rule" defining each term but might issue general guidelines for how each is used.
At issue is whether manufacturers can seek a marketing advantage for their products by labeling them as "recycled" or "degradable" and what the standards should be for using those terms. The Mobil Corporation was sued by seven states last year for saying that its Hefty trash bags were degradable.
The states charged that the claim was false advertising because the chemical additive in the bags was active only in sunlight and most of the discarded bags are buried in landfills. The company agreed to drop the term, but is still contesting fines.
To prevent consumer confusion, four states, including New York, recent enacted laws on the use of environmentally related terms. For example, Rhode Island's law, the first to go into effect, allows a product to be labeled "recyclable" only if there are collection systems and processing plants available to 75 percent of the population.
In practice, that would mean only aluminum cans and plastic soda bottles could carry the label in most states, said Victor A. Bell, director of Rhode Island's Office of Environmental Coordination.
 
National Guidelines Sought
 Last March, the National Association of Attorneys General called on the F.T.C. and the Environmental Protection Agency to "develop uniform national guidelines" for environmental claims. More recently, a group of 10 state attorneys general who investigated environmental marketing practices called for the Federal Government to "enact a comprehensive regulatory scheme" for these practices.
Manufacturers have increasingly sought to use assertions of environmental friendliness to gain a competitive advantage with concerned consumers. Three-quarters of consumers surveyed last June by Gerstman & Meyers, a package design firm, said they would pay as much as 5 percent more for products with an environmental advantage.
 
Shift by Heinz
 Last year, when the H. J. Heinz Company announced that it would change the composition of its flexible ketchup bottle, it printed the term "recyclable" prominently on the label of prototype bottles. Since then the company has pulled back to review the use of that term.
"The word recyclable will not be on the front label" when the new bottle arrives on grocers' shelves in April, a spokesman said. Instead, a more complex label on the back will explain that the bottle can be recycled with large soda bottles made of the same plastic material.
In addition to New York and Rhode Island, New Hampshire and California have adopted regulations governing the use of environmental claims. Although all are similar, each has differences in detail, which could pose serious problems for companies that market products nationwide. For example, California requires that products labeled "recycled" must contain at least 10 percent by weight of material recovered from trash; New York specifies different minimums for different products.
As a result, a group 24 companies and trade associations, including Procter & Gamble, Kraft Foods, the National Retail Federation and the National Food Processors Association, have been working for the last few months to draft guidelines for the use of the terms "recyclable," "compostable," "refillable and re-usable," and "recycled." They may also include "degradable."
 
F.T.C. Action Sought
 The group plans to submit the proposed rules to the F.T.C. later this month in the hope that the agency will adopt them as a national standard. If the agency does so, the rules would not necessarily pre-empt state laws, but the manufacturers think Federal leadership will discourage states from proceeding independently.
"The common goal of the task force is uniform national guidelines," said Glenn Gamber, who is director of program management at the food processors association. He said the group also wants to "take the steam out of the urge of individual states to regulate these terms."
Mr. Gamber said the most contentious issue was likely to be the use of the word "recyclable." Because virtually everything is recyclable in a laboratory setting, many environmentalists have objected to the use of the claim for materials not being recycled in commercial quantities.
The Consumer Affairs Office in New York City charged the makers of drink boxes with false advertising for saying that the packages are as easy to recycle as a newspaper. The city and the manufacturers are negotiating a settlement. Although the drink boxes are being recycled in small demonstration projects, none are available to city residents.
 
'An Education Value'
 Mr. Gamber said the industry view is that telling customers that a package or product can be recycled "has an education value" that may spur the development of municipal or privately owned recycling operations.
But Allen Hershkowitz, a solid-waste expert at the Natural Resources Defense Council, said, "The earth does not benefit from symbolic gestures." Unless a product is actually being recycled, he said, it becomes part of the solid-waste problem regardless of the words printed on it.
There has been growing pressure from environmental groups, industry and different levels of government to bring some uniformity to what has become known as "green marketing."
A recent report by the group of 10 state attorneys general said that environmental claims should be as specific as possible and refer only to disposal options currently available. "Unfortunately," the report added, "attempts to take advantage of consumer interest in the environment have led to a growing number of environmental claims that are trivial, confusing or even misleading."
 
Ruling on 'Reusable' Label
 Under New York's rules, a product or package can be labeled "re-usable" only if it can be re-used a minimum of five times. The "recycled" label can be used only if the package contains materials that had previously been used by consumers, and the percentage of recycled material must be displayed.
Mr. Gamber said the industry group favors environmental messages more complete than a single word or symbol. "Our materials use statements like 'recyclable in communities where facilities exist,' or 'this package contains 25 percent recycled fiber,' " Mr. Gamber said. "We do not like the naked use of words."
Mr. Gamber said that forcing companies to comply with a patchwork of local labeling laws would destroy economies of scale and lead to higher prices. Mr. Bell said he expected that states would follow the F.T.C.'s leadership if the agency issued guidelines on environmental claims. "We would be happy to go along," he said. "It does not make sense to have 50 different regulations."

HEADLINE: War Fears Send Dow Falling 43.32

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Fear on Wall Street toppled stock prices yesterday and brought the decline in the Dow Jones industrial average in just the first four trading days of this year to an ominous 111 points, or 4.2 percent.
Yesterday alone the blue-chip average -- representing the nest egg of millions of investors either directly or through pension funds -- tumbled 43.32 points, to 2,522.77. 
 Although activity remained sluggish, the market's weakness spread to 1,219, or 60 percent, of the 2,001 Big Board stocks traded yesterday.
Computer-activated program selling accounted for a third of the loss, Birinyi Associates said.
Crude oil prices, which had finally seemed to be on the way down in response to what seemed like signs of peace only a few days ago, soared an astounding $2.75 a barrel, to $27.65.
Gold prices, always sensitive to trouble, shot ahead more than $9 an ounce, to $394.10, lifting gold shares sharply.
Bank stocks, badly shaken by the Government takeover of the Bank of New England, almost universally lost ground, several by $1 or more, as investors worried which bank would be the next to make unwelcome news.
While the nation's financial woes seemed the biggest fear, the crisis in the Persian Gulf never seemed more important than now.
Picking up an Associated Press dispatch from Nicosia, Cyprus, a Dow Jones news ticker headline said, "P.L.O. rejects Shamir offer for peace talks."
From Phoenix, Reuters quoted Vice President Dan Quayle as telling farmers that if force was used, it would be "quick, massive and decisive."
Michael Metz, chief market analyst for the investment house of Oppenheimer & Company, said, "You had a combination of fear that interest rates would go higher because the Fed has run its course in easing monetary policy and fears of further banking stress dramatized by the forced reorganization of the Bank of New England, all of which was compounded by fears that the outbreak of hostilities was imminent."
He specifically mentioned the P.L.O. report and referred to what he called the "extremely bellicose" speech on Sunday by Iraq's President, Saddam Hussein.
Noting that the market was down on "very low" volume, the Oppenheimer executive said he considered this "an ominous indication of the unwillingness of investors to commit funds even at these bargain levels."
One trader said he had advised a number of important clients to wait a while before moving into the market in the expectation that it would continue dropping.
Short-sellers, who sell borrowed stock and hope to replace it later with shares bought for less, were big participants yesterday in many of the big-capitalization issues, from Schlumberger and Disney to I.B.M. and many of the drug stocks, like American Home Products and Eli Lilly.
American Home slumped 1 5/8, to 47 3/4; Lilly 2, to 69 1/4; Johnson & Johnson 2 1/8, to 66 5/8, and Merck 2 1/4, to 83. Among those dropping $1 or more were Forest Lab, SmithKline, Syntex, Upjohn, Warner-Lambert, Cyanamid, Bristol-Myers, Marion Merrill, Medtronic, Millipore and Schering-Plough.
Merrill Lynch prompted a selloff in the group last week after saying that investors were holding too much.
In spite of widespread front-page treatment of the Bank of New England's troubles, trading in banking stocks was not heavy enough to make the top 10 active list of either the New York Stock Exchange, the American Stock Exchange or Nasdaq, which runs the over-the-counter market.
But Wells Fargo fell 1 3/4, to 54; Manufacturers Hanover 1 1/8, to 20 1/8; Bankers Trust 1 1/4, to 42 3/4; U.S. Bancorp 1 1/8, to 19 3/8; Bankamerica 7/8, to 25 1/8 and J.P. Morgan 5/8, to 42 1/4. On Nasdaq, Banks of Iowa fell 3 3/4, to 67 1/2, and Trustco Bank 2 1/2, to 28 1/4.
Nervous traders moved into the market from the opening bell, pushing the Dow down close to 30 points in the first few minutes. The Dow then began building until about 11 A.M., when a steady flow of discouraging news coupled with the steady upturn in the price of crude sent the market heading back downward.
In top spot among the Big Board actives was Student Loan Marketing, a federally chartered company that buys such loans from banks. It slid 2 3/8, to 45 3/4, on 1.97 million shares after The New York Times said the Government was considering student-loan changes to reduce the role of banks. Fannie Mae fell 1 3/8, to 33 1/4, and Freddie Mac 1 7/8, to 47 1/8. Both are quasi-governmental agencies.
Among the gold issues, Newmont Mining rose 3 1/2, to 41 3/4; Newmont Gold 3 1/2, to 42 3/8; ASA Ltd. 2 5/8, to 47 3/8; Battle Mountain 1 1/8, to 8, and Homestake Mining 1 1/8, to 18 7/8.

HEADLINE: Czechoslovakia Gets $1.8 Billion I.M.F. Loan

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7

 BODY:
The International Monetary Fund announced a $1.8 billion loan to Czechoslovakia today, its biggest loan yet to one of the new democracies in Eastern Europe, to support its radical overhaul from Communism into a market economy.
Part of the loan is also intended to help Czechoslovakia deal with changes that the Soviet Union has just put into effect in its financial relations with former satellites in which the oil they buy must now be paid for with hard currency at world prices. 
 Formerly they acquired the oil atsubsidized prices in return for bartered goods. The change is expected nearly to triple what Czechoslovaks pay for their oil.
 
A Seal of Approval
 The I.M.F. has made the money available less than four months after Czechoslovakia rejoined the 155-nation lending agency and the World Bank, its sister organization. It had been an early member of the 45-year-old organization but was asked to leave during the cold war in 1954.
The loan is important not only because of its size but also because it represents an international seal of approval of a country's economic policies, which thus unlocks loans from other organizations.
Hundreds of millions of additional dollars are expected now to flow to Czechoslovakia from the European Community and the World Bank.
The I.M.F. makes loans to help countries balance their accounts with other nations and to finance essential imports. The World Bank makes longer term loans, usually 10 to 15 years, for specific projects such as dams and port facilities, and also to strengthen a country's economic sectors.
The bank is currently negotiating with Czechoslovakia for loans to improve banking and telecommunications and to help it speed the process of selling off state-owned industry.
Poland and Hungary, older members of the I.M.F., have already qualified for both I.M.F. and World Bank loans. Bulgaria, which joined the I.M.F. at the same time as Czechoslovakia, is still negotiating for its first loan.
The Czechoslovak economic changes borrow heavily from those begun in Poland a year ago. Poland borrowed $780 million from the I.M.F. last February, and Hungary $228 million last March.
Czechoslovakia's economic program, worked out with the I.M.F., includes removing price controls on 85 percent of goods sold, closing inefficent state-owned enterprises, establishing commercial banks and making the Czechoslovak crown convertible.
