HEADLINE: THE CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices of Treasuries Drop Sharply

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
A big jump in the price of oil and other commodities -- a byproduct of a weekend of growing tensions over the Middle East -- hurt the credit markets yesterday, as prices of Treasury securities fell sharply and interest rates rose.
The decline, the second in succession, left bond yields more than 20 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, above their level late Thursday. 
 Developments in the Persian Gulf crisis provided clear excuses to sell securities. But traders said auctions today and tomorrow, when the Treasury will sell around $15 billion of new medium- and long-term securities, were also a big factor. With the threat of war building, dealers said interest rates needed to move higher for the new issues to be sold successfully.
 
Fear of Inflation
 If war breaks out, market participants said, they expect oil prices to skyrocket and intensify inflation fears. Rising inflation, or the mere threat of it, is anathema to fixed-income investors because it erodes the value of their securities.
"The big part of this downtrade has to do with the supply," one government-bond trader said. "That fact is being masked by the other news."
Still, the fast-approaching Jan. 15 deadline for Saddam Hussein to withdraw from Kuwait took its toll.
"If you knew how the situation would be resolved, you would be buying most fixed-income assets because the economic fundamentals are so bad," said David H. Resler, chief economist at Nomura Securities International. "But right now, the markets are dealing in a kind of uncertainty they are not used to."
War fears and the coming new supply of long-term securities pushed up bond yields, but short-term interest rates were steady, helped by the Federal takeover of the Bank of New England as well as the continued prospect of a further easing in monetary policy by the Federal Reserve.
 
Big Demand for Bills
 Investor reaction to the Bank of New England move and the unsettled Middle East situation was easily seen in the results of yesterday's weekly auction of three- and six-month Treasury bills, analysts said. Non-competitive bids, a good proxy of demand from small investors, were a record $1.9 billion for the $10 billion worth of three-month bills sold. While not a record, non-competitive bids for the six-month bills were heavy, at $1.4 billion.
At the auction, three-month bills sold at an average discount rate of 6.52 percent, unchanged from a week earlier. Bids on the six-month bills produced an average discount rate of 6.51 percent, up slightly from 6.48 percent last week.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered late yesterday at a price of 104 25/32, down more than 1 1/4 points, or more than $12.50 for each $1,000 face amount, to yield 8.31 percent. It was the largest one-day decline for the issue in three months. At the end of Friday's sell-off, the closely watched issue was offered at a price to yield 8.20 percent.
The drop in Treasury note prices was not so severe. By late in the day, the 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 102 18/32, down 19/32, to yield 8.11 percent. But prices of the 7 1/4 percent two-year notes dipped by just 1/ 32, to 100 1/8, to yield 7.18 percent.
 
Higher Yields Seen
 Despite the big upward movement in long-term yields over the last two days, analysts said that yields might have to move higher in order to insure that the auction of nearly $7 billion worth of 30-year and 39 1/4-year bonds for the Resolution Funding Corporation goes well.
"We are starting to build in a war premium and a supply premium," said Peter Bass, managing director at S. G. Warburg Securities Inc., "but I don't think it is all there yet."
Late yesterday the 30-year Refcorp bonds to be sold today were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 8.59 percent.
Tomorrow the Treasury is expected sell $8.5 billion of new seven-year notes. Those securities were offered on a when-issued basis late yesterday at a price to yield 8.02 percent.
 
Heavy Corporate Borrowing
 Issuance of new corporate debt remained heavy yesterday, as companies fearing an outbreak of war came to market to price new securities.
Among the issuers was the General Electric Credit Corporation, which priced $250 million of four-year notes through an underwriting syndicate led by Kidder, Peabody & Company.
The 8 1/4 percent notes, which mature Jan. 15, 1995, were priced at $99.24 to yield 8.273 percent, 66.50 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 5/8 percent four-year notes at the time of pricing.
The securities are rated AAA by both Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
In the secondary market for corporate bonds, dealers said that accounts wishing to sell outstanding bonds of a number of New England banks, including Hartford National and the Bank of Boston, found few buyers.
"Quoted bids on those banks are down about 10 points" from Friday, one corporate trader said, "but I don't know of any trades that were made. A lot was offered, but there were no real bids."
With the sharp drop in Treasury prices, most corporate bond prices fell by about 3/4 of a point, dealers said.
Activity in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds was quite light, market participants said. Prices of most widely quoted issues slipped by about 1/4 point.

HEADLINE: A New Record For Bond Rater

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The number of corporate credit ratings lowered by the Standard & Poor's Corporation in 1990 nearly doubled, shattering the record set in 1989, Standard & Poor's chief rating officer said yesterday.
Branding the fast-track 1980's "a decade of lost opportunities," Leo C. O'Neill, president of the Standard & Poor's Ratings Group, warned of more painful times to come unless bond issuers put their financial houses in order.
"This year will be a critical test to determine whether the decade-long deterioration of credit quality in the 1980's continues," Mr. O'Neill said in a speech in Manhattan.
In the latest indication of the nation's deepening economic problems, S.& P. reported that the total of 768 downgrades in corporate long-term ratings in 1990 was quadruple the number of upgrades, and nearly double 1989's record number of 419 downgrades.
Ratings by S.& P. and Moody's Investors Service, the other major rating service, are used to help investors weigh the riskiness of new bond issues and have an enormous influence on the amount of interest a bond issuer must pay. The ratings are considered an important gauge of a company's fiscal soundness.
Dun & Bradstreet+ (Moody's) McGraw-Hill+ (Standard & Poor's)

HEADLINE: Profits, and Problems, for Recycler

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JOHNSONVILLE, S.C.

 BODY:
Long before the recent spate of announcements of recycling plans by producers and users of plastic, Wellman Inc. was quietly demonstrating that a large, profitable business could be built using waste plastic as a raw material.
But Wellman's plant here also stands as noisy testimony that recycling is much harder and more expensive than many would-be participants might expect. Wellman has invested millions of dollars and years of trial and error, yet finds itself forced to scramble for new sources of waste plastic, to invent new technology for processing the increasingly mixed stream of plastic it receives, and to find new ways to market the polyester, nylon and other products it makes from the recycled material.
 
Flakes to Fluff to Fiber
 Each day at this sprawling plant in the flat marshlands of eastern South Carolina, an hour's drive from the Atlantic coast, bottles, photographic film and industrial waste undergo a deafening transition from refuse into fibers, which will mainly become carpeting and stuffing for furniture, bedding and sports garments. The waste is transformed into small flakes, then cotton-candy-like fluff, then sleek filament, and finally crinkled fiber. 
 Wellman, which has its bare-bones corporate headquarters in Shrewsbury, N.J., earned $50.2 million, on sales of $623.4 million, in the first nine months of last year. Nearly half of the revenues come from lines that rely on plastic wastes.
The company has long been the nation's largest consumer of waste plastic, but played down that fact until it decided to sell shares to the public two years ago. "We were afraid that our customers wouldn't like it," said Thomas M. Duff, Wellman's president and chief executive.
Wellman's plunge into plastic recycling began here in 1964 when the company, then a family-owned wool processor, wanted to branch into fiber production. Unable to afford the machinery that the Du Ponts, Dows and Monsantos of the world used to create long chains of plastic molecules known as polymers, the company began buying polymerized plastic wastes from major manufacturers to use as a raw material.
Wellman added plastic soda bottles to its stream of materials in 1979, and then photographic and X-ray film waste. The technology used to do the job is a changing patchwork that Wellman jealously guards.
"They visit us often, but they never let me visit their plant," said Jose Fernandes, project manager for the Center for Plastic Recycling Research of Rutgers University. The center's efforts to develop a public recycling technology have been incorporated in Day Products Inc.'s year-old plant in Bridgeport, N.J., south of Philadelphia, which was constructed by Day's parent, the Philadelphia engineering firm Day & Zimmermann.
 
Rival With a Taste for Bottles
 The new plant is the first to rival Wellman's Johnsonville operation in its appetite for soda bottles, although smaller processors also recycle bottles. Indeed, the expansion plans of Day and other rivals may eventually plunge Wellman into bidding wars for its raw material that could trim its cost advantage over fiber producers that use raw chemicals.
That battle could become especially ferocious if the Coca-Cola Company and Pepsico Inc. proceed with their recently announced plans to recycle soda bottles. Environmentalists favor such action, because the plastic would be repeatedly reused instead of ending up in a product like carpeting that would become waste when worn out.
Mr. Duff branded the cola companies' announcement as a public relations stunt that would prove too costly to pursue. He points to the collapse of the Dow Chemical Company's joint venture with Domtar Inc. of Montreal to recycle polyethylene terephthalate, or PET bottle plastic. Dow pulled out of the venture after assessing the operation of a pilot plant for a year; Mr. Duff said Dow's move demonstrated the big hurdles facing even the richest would-be recyclers.
 
A Recycling Jumble
 Still, Wellman concedes that any technological advantage it enjoys may be short-lived. The company is rushing to finish a production line capable of handling a wider range of plastics, because the curbside recycling programs that are the newest supply of waste rarely produce the relatively pure stream of PET plastic derived from collections in the nine states and three Canadian provinces that have bottle-deposit laws.
Wellman has a growing business recycling high-density polyethylene, or HDPE, the plastic used in milk cartons and detergent bottles. But it has no current use for lightweight polystyrene, like the "clamshells" used in packing; polyvinyl chloride, widely used in plumbing components, and other plastics, not to mention a variety of other wastes that confused or indifferent homeowners often leave out for curbside collection. The company also has to contend with continual changes in the materials and adhesives used in caps and labels.
"There's lots of room for materials-handling improvements," said Calvin Hughes, vice president in charge of operations for the plastics business here. "The next plant will be considerably different than the new line we haven't finished yet."
 
'Competing With Landfills'
 In order to grab more plastic, Wellman has made a number of aggressive strategic moves. In 1989, it entered a joint venture with Browning-Ferris Industries, the nation's second-largest waste collector, to promote the inclusion of plastic recycling in curbside programs. Last year, it bought New England CRInc., a builder and operator of plants that automate the separation of trash collected from homes and businesses.
"This gets us into the business of competing with landfills," Mr. Duff said. "That's not great, but we'll get some money out of it, and it will guarantee our supply."
At the other end of the line, Mr. Duff wants to acquire a company that will allow Wellman to sell valuable finished products made from the HDPE plastic the company now sells to other manufacturers. That might seem difficult, given the $415 million in debt it took on in the $554 million acquisition of Fiber Industries from the Hoechst Celanese Corporation in 1989, but Mr. Duff is unfazed.
"We have already paid off $100 million of that debt," Mr. Duff said. "We have shown that when properly run, we are a fairly good cash machine."
 
Acquired From Family
 That ability was first tested when the Narragansett Capital Corporation of Providence, R.I., acquired Wellman from the Wellman family in a leveraged buyout with the current management; Narragansett has since sold its interest in the company. Putting behind them the family's infighting and a period of underinvestment, the managers were able to improve efficiency sharply, Mr. Duff said. Now, the company is benefiting from the production expertise it acquired with Fiber Industries.
"They were a lot more sophisticated than us in process controls," Mr. Duff said. "Ours had become more art than science as we grew."
Wellman thinks the day is coming when some customers will advertise their use of "environmentally friendly" fibers made from waste plastic. For now, though, everyone figures that most consumers do not want to know that their rug or pillow used to be trash, so Wellman generally keeps quiet about who buys its products even as it seeks to generate more attention to its role as a recycler.
 
Overly Enthusiastic Investors
 Despite Wellman's secrecy about its processes and its customer base, investors have heard enough to get excited -- at times overexcited -- by the company's prospects. Investors realized that as more and more states mandated plastic-recycling programs, the company would find it easier to secure the raw materials it needs. That drove up its stock price.
But securing a supply is only one challenge. "Some investors lost track of the fact that we are a fiber company, along with the risks that go into that," Mr. Duff said.
They were surprised when the company's earnings reflected a decline in domestic fiber prices as the economy weakened and as production declined at a Wellman plant in Ireland because of growing import competition in textiles in Europe. Wellman also felt the impact of rising oil prices, since it uses chemicals in its Fiber Industries plants that make fine-grade polyester. As a result, Wellman's stock fell last year from more than $33 in May to a low of $12.875 in mid-October. [The shares closed Monday at $17.75 each on the New York Stock Exchange, down 50 cents.]
 
Taking Market Share
 Some analysts say the fourth quarter may produce a loss and earnings next year will be relatively flat, but that does not mean they are sour on Wellman. The strategy has been to follow the pricing lead of the industry giants, notably Du Pont and Hoechst Celanese, in order to keep production going at close to full tilt.
"Their basic story is still true: they are the low-cost producer in all their businesses and they are taking market share," said Patrick McVeigh, who follows the company for the Franklin Research and Development Corporation, a Boston-based investment adviser.
The Fiber Industries acquisition brought Wellman the Fortrel brand name and 660 million pounds of new capacity, about 150 percent more than existing operations. Wellman's long-run plan is to replace with waste plastic about 25 percent of the 700 million pounds of chemicals Fiber Industries uses annually as raw materials. But the immediate impact of the deal was to make the company look more like a typical fiber producer.

HEADLINE: Sacramento Journal;
At Capitol, Raining Out a Swearing In

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 7

 BODY:
In the fifth year of drought here, Cali fornia's new Governor, Pete Wilson, thanked God for the chill rain that forced his inauguration indoors today and turned one swearing-in ceremony into two.
What was to have been an oath-taking on the west steps of the Capitol instead became two back-to-back ceremonies, one before television cameras and lawmakers in the cozy Rotunda and one for the public in the convention center across the street. The ceremony, the centerpiece of five days of parties, had to be duplicated because the television cameras could not be moved from the Capitol, where the public could not sit. 
 At both, the new Republican Governor received White House greetings from President Bush's chief of staff, John H. Sununu, took the oath of office from California Chief Justice Malcolm M. Lucas and promised to replace "remedial" programs with "preventative" ones to solve the state's social problems.
Mr. Wilson acknowledged the financial crisis facing the most populous state, a budget shortage conservatively estimated at $6 billion over the next 18 months. "Can new programs be undertaken when existing programs seem inescapably threatened by the budget crisis?" he asked.
The Governor answered affirmatively, saying: "Now, more than ever, to lead is to choose. And the choice California must make is to give increasing attention and resources to the conditions that shape our children's lives and California's future."
The nasty work for Mr. Wilson begins almost immediately, with the State of the State message on Wednesday and the presentation of a budget on Thursday; both are expected to be austere. But until then California's 36th Governor, who is 57 years old, decided to kick up his heels.
The celebrations here cost $2 million, all of it from private donations and ticket sales, officials said.
The big event on Saturday was a fiesta for 1,400 of Mr. Wilson's supporters from San Diego, catered by his favorite hometown restaurant, El Indio. Men in dark suits and women in fur jackets dined on burritos, vats of guacamole and mass-produced margaritas that one guest said tasted like salty lime Kool-Aid.
Then on Sunday came a night of entertainment for 6,000. Wayne Newton topped the bill, along with Charlton Heston, Arnold Schwarzenegger, Chuck Norris and the Kingston Trio. Mr. Newton is a high school chum of Gayle Wilson, the Governor's wife.
The Wilsons are known for their sing-along parties, and the citizens of Sacramento are hopeful that they will move the spritely doings here.
There has been much cranky reminiscence this week about Governors who spurned the city. Edmund G. Brown remained tied to the San Francisco social scene. His son, Jerry, slept on the floor and hung out with monks. Ronald Reagan continued to worship at a church in Bel Air, and his wife kept appointments at a Los Angeles hairdresser. And George Deukmejian, Mr. Wilson predecessor, was more or less invisible.
If the inaugural events were typical, all signs point to lively times here. Mr. Wilson's friends arrived in high spirits, tossing beach balls on the airport tarmac and chanting, "Hail, hail, Pete and Gayle." Mr. Wilson was full of amiable one-liners, introducing one of his guests, the San Diego Chicken, as "your chickenship."
The rain put a brief damper on the festivities today and spread chaos through the capital and its environs. Bellmen at the Hyatt Hotel had to rush to a discount store this morning to buy 100 umbrellas for unprepared guests.
Maintenance workers, meanwhile, raced through the puddles, moving potted fig trees from the Capitol steps to the Rotunda. And inside, glum choir members from a nearby high school shivered in the dank hallway and were forced to wear ski jackets over their white puff-sleeved gowns.
But, Mr. Wilson, was for the moment undaunted. "We will not suffer the future," he said. "We will shape it. We will not simply grow. We will manage our growth. We will not passively experience change. We will make change."

HEADLINE: World Lending Shift Is Noted

BYLINE: REUTERS

DATELINE: BASEL, Switzerland, Jan. 7

 BODY:
Banks in large industrialized countries cut their lending to Eastern Europe and the third world and lent more to developed nations in the first half of 1990, the Bank for International Settlements said today.
Overall lending to countries outside their area by the banks fell $23 billion, or 3.5 percent, to $633 billion, the bank said in a report.
The Bank for International Settlements, the central bank to the world's central banks, said total loans to Eastern Europe shrank by $5.1 billion, reflecting a rapid deterioration in the credit standing of some Eastern European countries.
Loans to Latin America fell by a record $22.8 billion, or 13 percent, in the first half of last year, with all large debtor countries sharing in the contraction.
The largest change was a drop of $12.7 billion, or 21 percent, in loans to Mexico after the Brady Plan took effect, relieving $48.5 billion in debt.
Under the plan, named after Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady of the United States, banks exchanged outstanding loans to Mexico for bonds issued by the Mexican Government at a 35 percent discount.

HEADLINE: Oil Jumps By $2.75, To $27.65

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Tough talk about the Persian Gulf, and the approach of a deadline that oil traders are calling "D-Day," helped to push oil prices sharply higher yesterday.
On the New York Mercantile Exchange, crude for delivery next month closed up $2.75, or 11 percent, at $27.65 a barrel. 
 Heating oil also jumped, driven by cold weather and war fears. It rose 7.87 cents a gallon, to 76.17 cents. The move is equivalent to $3.31 a barrel.
Unleaded gasoline was up 7.01 cents a gallon, to 71.63 cents.
"As we approach D-Day, the tension level is increasing," said Christian D. Gohler at Merrill Lynch Futures in New York.
 
Cooling Down
 The market, which rose after the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait by Iraq and has fluctuated wildly since, had been falling and has been somewhat less volatile in recent days. Since Christmas Eve, the biggest move had been a drop of $1.95, on Jan. 2.
Yesterday, the spark for the price rise, traders said, was a statement by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d ruling out an extension of the Jan. 15 United Nations deadline for Iraq to leave Kuwait "or be forced out." Over the weekend, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq publicly told his country to prepare for war, adding to traders' nervousness.
But forces internal to the market added to the price rise, Mr. Gohler said. As the price passed $26 a barrel, participants who were "short," or had purchased contracts requiring them to deliver oil they do not actually have, decided to cover those positions by buying contracts for delivery of oil, he said, and when they jumped in on the buying side, the price rose yet higher.
 
Changing Attitudes
 Many investors who had bought short positions have now switched and gone "long," buying contracts for future delivery at a fixed price, he said.
Peter C. Beutel, an analyst at the Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J., said a marked change in attitude had occurred since Friday, when prices had closed below $25 for the first time since August. "On Friday, we had a market you couldn't convince that there would be a war, no matter what you said," Mr. Beutel said. "It seems right now, there's an overwhelming sentiment that a war seems more inevitable."
Exactly what a war would mean to prices is not clear, he said, since many experts have predicted that the Iraqis cannot seriously interfere with Saudi oil exports, and damage to Iraqi or Kuwaiti fields is of no short-term importance to world oil markets.
As Mr. Beutel put it, "We've proven we can live without Iraq's and Kuwait's oil."
"But psychologically," he added, "the perception is that this could turn much nastier than people thought."
Mr. Gohler said some market participants had concluded that in case of war there would be a brief price "spike," but then the United States would open its Strategic Petroleum Reserve, pushing prices back down.
 
The Fear Is Back
 At the Geldermann Energy Group in New York, another trader, Harvey W. Abrahams, agreed that yesterday's oil price rise was in part because "we got the fear of war pushed back into the market." But he said other factors were present.
The closing price on Friday, $24.90 a barrel, was too low, he said, and would have been higher if the market had not been forced to close early because of a severed telephone cable that affected lines to the Mercantile Exchange. The market had fallen on Friday on news that the Iraqi Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, would meet Mr. Baker in Geneva tomorrow.
"The market never really had time to adjust to that news or figure out what it meant," Mr. Abrahams said. "It probably would have come back."
Despite the growing urgency of the Persian Gulf situation, the market may yet decline. Marcie J. Thornberry, a trader at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., also in New York, said moves this sudden were often followed by reverses. "But in the next two weeks, the trend is up," she said.
"It's definitely a rumor-driven market; whatever news comes in, it will jump up or down pretty easily," she said.

HEADLINE: Democrats Open Battle On Blame for Recession

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7

 BODY:
Congressional Democrats began their campaign today to blame the Bush Administration for the recession.
As the first witnesses at one of the first legislative hearings of the 102d Congress, Senator Edward M. Kennedy, chairman of the Labor and Human Resources Committee, called three unemployed workers who are middle age and middle class. The three were recently laid off from lifelong jobs and have been unable to find other suitable work. 
 With them as props, Senator Kennedy, no longer a Presidential prospect but still a leading spokesman for the liberal wing of the Democratic Party, opened the session by declaring, "The Bush Administration has no antirecession program, no strategy to preserve jobs or relieve the suffering of those who have lost work, home, savings or businesses."
Then, the Massachusetts Senator added, "It is time for the Administration to get as serious about fighting this recession as they are about fighting in the Persian Gulf."
 
No Television Coverage
 The witnesses, one from Massachusetts, one from Indiana and the third from Wisconsin, presented compelling testimony about how they were struggling to make ends meet after plants closed and they lost what they had thought were secure jobs.
But their stories did not reach the daytime television audience that Senator Kennedy clearly wished they would. C-Span, the cable network that regularly carries Congressional hearings, instead showed the hearing about ethics charges against five Senators who were linked to Charles H. Keating Jr. on one channel and a book review program on the other.
While the unemployed workers were at the witness table, other Democratic Senators also weighed in against the Republicans. Senator Paul Simon of Illinois said, "The great legacy of the Reagan Administration is that we have forgotten too many Americans."
And Paul Wellstone, the new Senator from Minnesota at his first legislative hearing, said he hoped the country would "move from the politics of private interests in the 80's to the politics of public interests in the 90's."
 
Liberal Economists Testify
 The only Republican at the hearing, Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum of Kansas, sympathized with the plight of the witnesses but said it was "difficult to know indeed what we can do."
After the unemployed workers, Senator Kennedy called as witnesses two prominent liberal economists, a union president, the former Labor Secretary in the Carter Administration and an expert on women's issues. The title of the hearing was "The Recession and the Work Force."
Senator Kennedy promised that his committee would consider a variety of legislation this year in the areas of education, medical care and childhood poverty, but he did not address how the new programs would be financed.
The two economists, John Kenneth Galbraith of Harvard University and Robert Eisner of Northwestern University, recommended bold new spending programs to stimulate the economy, create jobs and meet national problems like bridges and highways in disrepair. "The duration of the recession and the prospect of recovery depend extensively on what we do about it," Mr. Galbraith said.
Mr. Galbraith said the country should abandon the idea of balancing the budget as long as the recession persists, but he indicated that higher personal and corporate income taxes were necessary to meet some of the additional cost of his proposals.
Mr. Eisner has attacked for years the notion that the Federal deficit and debt were serious problems, and he did so again today.
Lynn Williams, president of the United Steelworkers of America, urged Congress to extend unemployment benefits and approve new programs to create jobs and train workers.
Ray Marshall, Labor Secretary in the Carter Administration and now a professor of economics and public affairs at the University of Texas, suggested steps to improve the skills of the American work force.
Heidi Hartmann, director of the Institute for Women's Policy Research, said that women would be disproportionately hurt by the recession because they were more likely to be employed part time and were less likely to be eligible for unemployment benefits.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Semiconductor Outlook Is Mixed

BYLINE: By Andrew Pollack

 BODY:
WITH the nation probably in a recession and the semiconductor industry's closely watched barometer at one of its lowest levels in years, now might not seem the time to buy semiconductor stocks. But a few analysts say there are bargains to be had.
The industry's barometer, the book-to-bill ratio, fell to 0.90 for November. That meant that for every $100 of shipments, the industry received only $90 in new orders, a sign that business is headed downward. Except for a brief period in 1989, the index has not been that low since the broad electronics industry slump in the mid-1980's. The index touched 0.64 in December 1984. 
 Still, there are signs of life. Some analysts say that the bad news has already been discounted and that investors will begin to buy stocks on the expectation that the bad times will end later in 1991.
"We're looking for the industry to have a pretty good year in '92," said James L. Barlage of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company in New York. "The stocks will respond to that prospect."
Semiconductor stocks underperformed the market through much of the second half of 1990, but in the last few weeks, some have risen strongly.
One sign of hope is that there is an industry shortage in the main type of chip used to store information in computers -- dynamic random access memory chips. In the last few weeks, supplies of one type of this chip, one-megabit D-RAM's, have tightened and prices have risen, seeming to suggest that demand in the computer industry is healthier than expected. This could be good news for Texas Instruments Inc. and Micron Technology Inc., the two American companies heavily dependent on D-RAM sales. But most analysts say the shortage is temporary.
Not everyone agrees, however, that now is the time to buy semiconductor stocks. Some say the companies will report poor results for the fourth quarter of 1990.
Millard H. Phelps of Hambrecht & Quist in San Francisco says business -- and the stocks -- will get worse before getting better. "The industry has not experienced the effects of the recession yet," he said.
While semiconductor stocks often move as a group, the differences among companies is becoming more important.
The Intel Corporation is considered the industry's premier company, and its stock is frequently recommended. That is because it has a monopoly on supply of the 386 microprocessor, the brains of many advanced personal computers.
Despite that monopoly, some analysts have reservations about the short-term outlook for Intel's stock. Michael A. Gumport, semiconductor analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers in New York, said the supply of 386 chips seems to be shifting from a shortage last year to a surplus, and prices are starting to weaken.
Mr. Gumport, who gives Intel a neutral rating, also said the company, based in Santa Clara, Calif., faced for the first time the prospect of competition from companies selling their own chips that imitate the 386 and the 387, a companion chip that does high-speed mathematics. In over-the-counter trading yesterday, Intel stock closed at $38.375 a share,down 37.5 cents. It traded as high as $52 last year and as low as $28.
Mr. Gumport said he favored three stocks that have unique stories. One is Advanced Micro Devices Inc., which looks as if it will be the first company with a chip that imitates the Intel 386. Advanced Micro closed at $5 a share on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, down 12.5 cents. It traded as high as $11.375 last year and as low as $3.625.
Mr. Gumport also likes Texas Instruments, which stands to reap a huge stream of patent royalties from Japanese companies. It finished at $37.375 a share on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, up 37.5 cents, and traded in a range between $44 and $22.50 last year. Among smaller companies, Mr. Gumport likes Xilinx, which specializes in chips that users can program themselves.
Mr. Barlage of Smith Barney still favors Intel as well as Advanced Micro Devices. He also recommends the National Semiconductor Corporation, which has been plagued by losses but is redirecting its product line toward products with higher profit margins.
Mr. Barlage said that the market had "overly discounted" National's woes and that the stock could go to $9 a share. The stock closed at $4.25 a share on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, down 12.5 cents. It traded as low as $3 last year, and reached a high of $8.875.
Mr. Phelps of Hambrecht & Quist recommends the Cypress Semiconductor Corporation, a smaller company with a broad product line. He also likes Cirrus Logic, which designs and sells special-purpose circuits for disk drives and other devices.
Mr. Phelps removed his buy recommendation on Intel a few weeks ago for the first time in two years because he fears the recession will reduce demand for its microprocessors. But "from the long-term standpoint, it's still a strong story," he said.

HEADLINE: Insurance Limit On Bank Funds Seems In Doubt

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7

 BODY:
The decision on Sunday to protect all depositors in a bailout of one of the nation's largest bank companies will make a move to limit deposit insurance less likely, Government officials and lawmakers said today.
With the nation's banking industry facing declining earnings and increasing turmoil, they said any move to reduce insurance coverage now would only undermine confidence in many banks. 
 Officials and analysts said the decision to forestall panic by protecting all customer deposits, no matter how large, at the Bank of New England and two affiliated banks, as well as to keep the institutions open, would have a profound impact on the shape of legislation being prepared to overhaul the program that protects deposits.
"It is going to drive legislation for more early intervention by the regulators," said Charles E. Schumer, a member of the House Banking Committee, reflecting the views of several of his colleagues. "It is also going to break the momentum toward reducing insurance coverage."
As Washington pondered the ramifications of the bailout, the BankAmerica Corporation said today that it was interested in acquiring the three banks of the parent Bank of New England Corporation and that it had begun talking with Federal regulators before the weekend rescue. [Page D8.]
Lawrence White, an economist at New York University, said that before the weekend's events "no one in Washington was talking about runs."
"They were talking about market discipline," he said, adding that the situation in New England "could change that."
The Bush Administration has already signaled its intention to retain the present limit on insurance coverage at $100,000 for an account, but to restrict the number of accounts entitled to protection and limit the protection on deposits held by large institutions like pension funds.
Bank deposits are covered by the bank insurance fund of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. That is the agency that on Sunday officially took over the Bank of New England, the third-largest banking company in the region and the 33d-largest in the nation, and the two other affiliated banks -- the Connecticut Bank and Trust Company and the Maine National Bank. The fund, which is expected to post record losses for 1990 and 1991, will be responsible for covering the expected $2.3 billion cost of the bailout.
The three banks reopened smoothly today, with few signs of depositor concern, as the New Bank of New England; the New Connecticut Bank and Trust Company, based in Hartford, and the New Maine National Bank, based in Portland.
The parent Bank of New England Corporation, meanwhile, filed for Chapter 7 bankruptcy protection in Federal court in Boston, under which the remaining assets will be liquidated. The parent's smallest unit, the Bank of New England Trust Company in West Palm Beach, Fla., which was not taken over, will be sold as part of its parent's liquidation.
On Capitol Hill, some representatives said today that the handling of the Bank of New England would force closer scrutiny of the regulators themselves on whether they could have averted the growing problems at the bank and within the industry.
 
Photographs of Lines
 "With the nation facing growing problems in the banking industry, the Bank of New England case offers the banking committee an excellent opportunity to determine in detail how Federal regulation is being carried out," said Henry B. Gonzalez, the House Banking Committee chairman. "This case may well offer important guidelines as the Congress moves forward on deposit insurance and regulatory reform."
A Congressional aide said that some bankers in New England had complained about the way the bank's closing was handled. One complaint was that the F.D.I.C. had waited too long to close the bank, resulting in photographs of lines of anxious depositors withdrawing their funds on Friday after the bank announced that it expected a large fourth-quarter loss. That led to heavy withdrawals at a few other banks today, the aide said. The aide declined to name those institutions that had called the Congressional office.
Some analysts had been saying for months that the Bank of New England should be closed because of its growing problems with nonperforming real estate loans. Regulators acted on Sunday, when it became clear that the failure to act could have created a panic today.
The bank insurance fund, created in response to the bank panics of the Great Depression, could become insolvent if the economy worsens or a few large banks fail. Including the $2.3 billion estimated cost to rescue the Bank of New England and the two other banks, the insurance fund is expected to post losses last year and this year of more than $9 billion, leaving it with about $4 billion.
 
'We Want to Have Our Cake'
 In preparing a plan to shore up the fund, which it is expected to be announced later this month, the Bush Administration is facing a considerable dilemma. It wants to place further restrictions on the number of bank accounts being protected to impose more discipline on the industry, but it is aware that limitations could encourage runs on banks.
"We want to have our cake and eat it too," said L. William Seidman, the chairman of the F.D.I.C. and a proponent of some limitations on the number of accounts protected.
Measures to limit the number of accounts protected have been introduced in the House.
Mr. Seidman said today in an interview that regulators had considered several other approaches over the weekend for handling the situation at the Bank of New England, but that the staffs of the F.D.I.C. and the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, which regulates the nation's nationally chartered banks, had recommended the plan to take over and sell the banks as the least costly alternative.
He said officials had discussed one plan to leave uninsured depositors unprotected and another to issue an announcement saying that the Government would protect all depositors without taking over the banks. A third rejected plan would have paid all depositors but closed the institutions.
The decision to protect all depositors, however, and the swiftness of the Government's moves over the weekend served as a reminder of the powerful role that psychological forces play in the lives of banks.
 
Backdrop of Bad News
 After the report Friday morning that the banking company expected a fourth-quarter loss of up to $450 million, which would essentially wipe out its reserves to cover future loan losses, many of the branches of the Bank of New England and the Connecticut Bank and Trust Company began to experience heavy withdrawals. Federal regulators have put the withdrawals on Friday and Saturday at about $1 billion, but bank officials, while conceding that volume of withdrawals was dangerously high, say it was closer to $20 million.
The financial report was issued against a backdrop of steadily distressing news in New England. Last Tuesday, the Governor of Rhode Island closed 45 credit unions and banks whose depositors had been insured by a private company that said it might not be solvent. Twenty-two of the smaller credit unions were to reopen today with Federal insurance. There have also been reports of some Massachusetts credit unions that are not insured by the Federal Government were experiencing high withdrawals.
"An important part of the phenomenon at Bank of New England was that even fully insured depositors, those with below $100,000 in their accounts, were pulling their funds," Professor White said. "Even my mother is nervous, but I keep telling her to keep her money where it is."
Responding to the shaky state of the banks, Mr. Seidman spent his day being ushered from one television program to another and sat through a stream of interviews with reporters.
"I'm trying to tell people that there's no reason for panic," Mr. Seidman said.
He also said, as he has before, that about 170 other bank failures are expected this year, "but none at this time of the size of the Bank of New England."

HEADLINE: The Transition to F.D.I.C. Control Is Said to Go Smoothly

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Jan. 7

 BODY:
When officials at the Bank of New England sent out for pizza late Sunday night, they ordered some for officials of the bank's new owners, too -- the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.
That was just one of the novel situations facing officers of the bank, the region's third largest, which was placed in receivership by the F.D.I.C. on Sunday. Today the officers were trying to figure out such elementary questions as who has the authority to make decisions or what were their legal lending limits, an interesting proposition for a bank that has just failed. 
 But Tim McNamar, vice chairman of what the F.D.I.C. has renamed the New Bank of New England, said Federal regulators who had arrived Sunday night had been highly professional, helping to get the legal questions unsnarled so the bank could continue operating today.
"We got the A team," Mr. McNamar said. "This was not your stereotype of them padlocking the doors and seizing the books. They made it very clear they wanted the bank to function smoothly."
In fact, the Federal regulators were polite and discreet, and kept out of sight of customers, said James Dorsey, the spokesman for the bank, which has its corporate headquarters here in Boston.
 
Board Appointed
 The agency did appoint a new five-member board for the bank, made up of agency officials. But because the F.D.I.C. decided to leave current management in place while negotiating to sell its three component banks in Massachusetts, Connecticut and Maine, the number of Federal officers dispatched to oversee operations was relatively small, said David Barr, a spokesman for the F.D.I.C. in Washington. This is the first time regulators have left a management in place in such a situation.
So far, Mr. Barr said, the agency has sent 46 officials to the main office and computer center of the Bank of New England in Boston, 40 to the Connecticut Bank and Trust Company in Hartford and 25 to the Maine National Bank in Portland. These officials include investigators, accountants, office managers and claims personnel.
But Mr. Barr said the F.D.I.C. had deliberately decided not to send its personnel into every branch of the Bank of New England, and was letting the bank's management, headed by the chairman, Lawrence K. Fish, stay in place pending a negotiated sale. Mr. Fish took over only in March, and Mr. Barr said he and his managers "weren't the root of the problem."
"They were doing everything in their power to turn it around," Mr. Barr said. "They just ran out of time." The bank's huge portfolio of bad real estate loans worsened as the region's economy slipped further into a slump.
Mr. Dorsey, the bank's spokesman, said that a number of large corporate customers who had pulled their accounts out of the Bank of New England late last week, contributing to a run, had returned today to redeposit their money. The Government put the size of the run at $1 billion, while the bank said it was only about $20 million. But Mr. Dorsey declined to name any of the companies, citing confidentiality rules.
At tellers' windows today, the evidence of the public's reaction to the F.D.I.C. takeover was mixed. Linda Arena, a 25-year-old office administrator, arrived at the Copley Square branch of the Bank of New England at 7 A.M., an hour before the bank opened, to close out a $1,100 money market account she had opened last year.
"My husband kept saying: 'Why did you put your money in the Bank of New England? It's going to close,' " Ms. Arena explained. "So this morning when he heard the news on the radio, he was, like, 'Told you so.' "
 
A $100,000 Withdrawal
 At the bank's headquarters office on State Street, in Boston's financial district, a woman in a full-length black mink coat withdrew a $100,000 certificate of deposit. The woman, who would identify herself only as an administrator for the Boston School Department, said, "Given the events, there was no question in my mind what to do."
"We saw Rhode Island," the woman added, referring to the closing of 45 banks and credit unions in Rhode Island last week by Gov. Bruce Sundlun after questions were raised about the solvency of the private insurance fund that backed them.
But others were more optimistic. James Shannon, a 32-year-old finance executive, stopped at the bank's Copley Place branch on his way to work this morning just to peer in the glass doors. He said he had a certificate of deposit at the bank but was not worried. "It's insured," he said. "I don't want to break it; it's a good rate."
"This morning my wife said, 'Did you hear about the Bank of New England being taken over?' " Mr. Shannon related. "I said, 'No. Did you know we have money there?' "
Mr. Barr, the F.D.I.C. spokesman, said that the Federal agency would appoint two senior officials to supervise the Bank of New England, but that they have not been selected yet. In addition, he said, the F.D.I.C. wanted to appoint a new board made up of local citizens to take over from the five-member panel just installed by the agency.
Many of the F.D.I.C. officials being sent to the three banks that made up the Bank of England were drawn from a new F.D.I.C. office in Franklin, Mass., near the Rhode Island border.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A customer left the Charlestown branch of the Bank of New England in Boston yesterday morning after the bank opened for business as usual, although under the new ownership of the F.D.I.C. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: BankAmerica Shows Interest in Failed Units

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The BankAmerica Corporation said yesterday that it was interested in acquiring the three failed banks of the Bank of New England Corporation and "is in discussion" with the F.D.I.C., which took control of the banks on Sunday.
The opportunity to acquire the largest branch network in New England was attractive enough for BankAmerica, based in San Francisco, that it began talking with Federal regulators about an acquisition before the three banks were put under Government control. 
 But while BankAmerica has an early start in analyzing the Bank of New England units in Massachusetts, Connecticut and Maine, it is not likely to be the only bidder. Government regulators said two unidentified American banking companies from outside New England had discussed the possibility of acquiring the banks before Sunday and more interested buyers would probably step forward.
 
Interest by Banc One Seen
 The Banc One Corporation, often mentioned as a prime candidate because it is the most strongly capitalized large banking company in the country and has a history of successfully acquiring other banks, also said yesterday that it was interested.
John Russell, a senior vice president at Banc One, said the Columbus, Ohio, company had not received a detailed package describing the failed banks' business, "but when we do, we will certainly look at it."
Thomas Brown, a banking analyst at Paine Webber, said that "because of its economic problems, New England would be low on the list of regions where I would want to own a banking franchise." But he added that "with enough Government assistance, the Bank of New England units should look very attractive." The failed banks' 310 branches and the $16.8 billion of deposits they hold are the most attractive part of the business, he said.
According to one banking representative who has already talked with the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation about buying the Bank of New England units, bankers will insist that the F.D.I.C. keep the worst loans and give the acquiring bank the right to return other loans that prove to be bad. The amount of loans that might be returned and the length of time that they may be returned will be important points in the negotiations between bankers and the F.D.I.C.
Because the New England economy is still weakening, a representative of one bank said buyers might insist on a three- or four-year period for deciding which loans they would accept. In Texas, the review period was two years at most and only months for some small institutions.
 
Consumer Banking Strategy
 For BankAmerica, the nation's No. 2 banking company, a move to acquire the New England banking units is a reminder of its commitment to develop a consumer banking business that reaches far beyond California. Flush with profits that totaled $1.1 billion last year and are expected to be even greater this year, BankAmerica has spent more than $400 million to acquire 193 branches in Arizona and Oregon in the last year.
Richard Rosenberg, the chairman. said late last year that BankAmerica's strategy was to concentrate on the Western United States, but added that the company was mindful of the intangible value of its name in other parts of the country.
Mr. Brown of Paine Webber said the success Banc One and the NCNB Corporation, based in Charlotte, N.C., had had with large acquisitions in Texas reminds bankers of the opportunity they may be missing. "But this has been a year of tremendous pain and uncertainty for banks, and a lot of them will shy away from the opportunity," he said.
Federal regulators are expected to insist that any buyer be in strong financial condition and not too vulnerable to problems with bad loans of its own making. But some analysts say the Government's willingness to hold the bad loans will mean the acquisition might not require the buyer to provide much more than $500 million or $600 million of capital.
A recent study by the First Manhattan Consulting Group showed that "the retail franchise, especially the branch franchise, is the most valuable part of commercial banking," said James M. McCormick, president of the consulting firm. He estimated that the branches and the business they generate account for about $80 billion, or 47 percent of the value of banking companies, but require only $30 billion, or 14 percent, of the capital banks hold.
For some banking companies that have the strength for expansion, the opportunity comes when they are preoccupied with other purchases. Officials at Norwest, based in Minneapolis, and PNC Financial, based in Pittsburgh, two strong regional companies also mentioned as potential bidders, said they were not interested in the Bank of New England and would concentrate on opportunities closer to home.
Because other New England banks like the Bank of Boston, Shawmut and Fleet/Norstar also face loan problems, though not comparable to Bank of New England's, analysts do not expect them to bid.
Large New York banks would undoubtedly like to expand into New England, but may be constrained, analysts said, by the fact that some, like Citicorp, Chase Manhattan and Chemical Banking, are below or barely above the minimum capital standards set by regulators and have had problems with bad loans.
Other potential buyers mentioned by analysts include National City of Cleveland; NCNB and First Union of Charlotte, N.C.; Corestates Financial of Philadelphia; Mellon Bank of Pittsburgh and Wells Fargo of San Francisco. All those companies declined to comment.

HEADLINE: Mosbacher On Recession

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 7

 BODY:
The recession in the United States will be short and mild, with rising exports to Latin America helping to blunt its effects, Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher said today.
Mosbacher, in Detroit for a press preview of the North American International Auto Show, said the American trade deficit had been on its way to falling below $100 billion before the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2.
Since then, principally because of high oil and gasoline prices, the deficit has remained at the $100 billion annual mark.
But exports, Mosbacher said, "will be the engine that pulls out of this downturn or recession or whatever."
Although there are signs that Europe and Asia are beginning to feel the effects of the United States recession, countries in Latin America and South America will be ready to buy new United States exports, the secretary said.
"There's burgeoning demand as the economies in Mexico and Latin America increase," he said. "If the recession, down period, is as short and shallow as it should be, then it will be so overseas."

HEADLINE: Jet Workers' Last Hopes Dashed by Announcement

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 7

 BODY:
It was cold and icy outside when Cassell Williams got the telephone call bearing the news that Defense Secretary Dick Cheney had canceled plans to build a new Navy attack plane. He knew the announcement meant that about 1,500 members of his union would get layoff notices in the next few days.
"I was shocked because I didn't think they could scrap a program that was at this stage," said Mr. Williams, the president of District 837 of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, the largest union at the McDonnell Douglas Corporation. "I thought they could overcome the problems they had." 
 In Fort Worth, where several thousand workers at the General Dynamics Corporation plant will soon be dismissed, the reaction was the same.
 
'A Lot of Shocked People'
 "The gut feeling in the factory up until at least this afternoon was that the Defense Department was trying to salvage the program," said Jim Bricker, president of Local 900 of the Federated Independent Texas Unions. "There are going to be a lot of shocked people."
But Michael L. Hester, chief of human resources at the General Dynamics plant, was optimistic that many workers would be able to find jobs in Fort Worth, or nearby, where the economy has been growing for the last three years.
"We feel confident that many of these people who desire to stay in the local area will come out equal, hopefully, to what they had when they left us," he said.
Mr. Williams and others were not as optimistic for the future of the workers in St. Louis, still reeling from the layoffs of more than 4,000 McDonnell Douglas workers last summer. The city's economy is dependent on military spending and the automotive industry, both of which have been hurt by the nation's economic slowdown.
One McDonnell Douglas worker said he did not expect to lose his own job. Nevertheless, he said, "we're all worrying about tomorrow, with or without the project."
Workers officially learned of the Pentagon's cancellation of the A-12 program at about 6 P.M., when John F. McDonnell, the company's chairman and chief executive, announced the decision over loudspeakers. But local television and radio stations had already been reporting the move for about two hours, and friends and relatives of company workers had been calling the plant with the news.
Terry Lloyd, a structural mechanic who has worked for McDonnell Douglas since 1986, tried to find a reason for hope. In an interview during his lunch break tonight, he said, "Personally, it's not as bad for me, because I'm not married."
But when asked what he would do next, he replied: "Good question. I only have a high school education. I make $35,000 a year now. Any job I take, maybe I'll get $20,000."
The dismissals at both companies will be based on seniority. Mr. Lloyd said his starting date had fallen just short of the deadline set by McDonnell Douglas for the layoffs.
"They're going and laying off people who are actually making airplanes," he said. "I don't understand why they do that."
In Fort Worth, Mr. Bricker said, "I've got some people who are senior in age, but not senior in time."
He added: "We had three brand new hires who came in today who had transferred from the engineering department. They probably will get notices tomorrow."

HEADLINE: For Contemporary Music, Times Are Hard

BYLINE: By ALLAN KOZINN

 BODY:
For the contemporary music world, which has for decades been a vital part of New York City's musical life, the 1990's are shaping up as a bleak time.
The small but dedicated audience for new music has been shrinking just as several of the city's most prominent new-music ensembles -- among them, the Group for Contemporary Music, Speculum Musicae and Parnassus -- have been hit by reductions in government, corporate and foundation funds. Indeed, some groups have been told that their grants are to be further reduced or eliminated next season. 
 Similar financial strains have shaken arts programs of all kinds. But these pressures are particularly hard for the new-music groups to sustain because as their income from grants and ticket sales has been falling, the cost of presenting concerts has been rising.
Many of the ensembles have started cutting back on their New York performances. William Hellermann, who edits the Calendar for New Music and performs with the Downtown Ensemble, said that his publication's concert listings were down by 20 percent from last year.
 
Biggest Worry: Audience Lag
 What worries the musicians most is that some financing agencies are starting to take audience size into consideration when making grants. Anthony Korf of the Parnassus ensemble, which is performing tonight at Merkin Concert Hall, said that when the New York State Council on the Arts cut Parnassus' grant to $9,000 from $11,000 this year, he was told that the cut had been made because his audience had dwindled. When the council made emergency cuts this fall, the grant was whittled to $7,000.
"In the past, the council has expressed concern about the size of our audiences," said Mr. Korf. "But you can't apply market economy values to something like contemporary music. On a per-capita basis, the funding for new music has always been absurdly high. But the value of Parnassus and groups like us is not how many people we entertain in a night. It's that we are helping composers who are living and writing today, and who need the outlet."
Among the composers the 17-year-old ensemble has championed over the years are Donald Martino, Mario Davidovsky, Gunther Schuller and Jonathan Harvey. Tonight's program includes works by Milton Babbitt, Charles Wuorinen and Miriam Gideon, alongside one 20th-century throwback, a Prokofiev song cycle, offered as a centenary tribute.
"For years," Mr. Korf added, "people who play in Parnassus and other groups have taken pay cuts and contributed their own money to be part of this, because they believe in the music."
 
'Paying More Attention'
 Mary Hays, the executive director of the New York State Council on the Arts, said that the size of a group's audience had always been among the factors the council considered. "But we have been paying more attention to it as times have gotten hard," she said. "Groups that have been around for many years have had time to do some marketing and to have made an effort to develop an audience. That's a very difficult thing with the contemporary arts, and we have had some difficult choices to make."
Several directors said that budget constraints were forcing them to program works that require fewer players. One ensemble, the 29-year-old Group for Contemporary Music, suffered a 60 percent cut in its grant income in 1990, and is giving only one concert this season, a program of string quartets. The group has decided to concentrate on recordings instead of concerts. Another ensemble, the 13-year-old Musical Elements, is in the second season of what its director says is a sabbatical.
Whether they specialize in the rigorous, atonal Uptown styles, or in the freewheeling experimentalism of the Downtown schools, the musicians in these ensembles seem to agree on one point: Although they are willing to broaden their programming, they insist that they will not abandon their chosen repertories in the hope of attracting larger audiences or to please potential contributors.
 
Commerce and Trends
 "I'm not sure the problem is completely economic," Mr. Korf of Parnassus said. "Things have gotten more commercialized. People tend to be wowed by trendiness, which is unfortunate. But just because we don't do Minimalism, or aleatoric works, or some of the derivative works that are called neo-Romantic, does not mean that we are a stuffy academic group. We play music that we find wonderful and expressive and rewarding. We have to figure out ways to get people to experience that."
Patricia Spencer, a flutist in the Da Capo Chamber Players, said that her ensemble had lost one of its principal fund sources this year, and would probably lose another next year.
"We'll be looking for additional funds, and making more grant applications than we used to," said Ms. Spencer, whose group is celebrating its 20th anniversary this season, "but we might also have to change our activities. That might mean playing lower-profile concerts in New York, or concentrating more on recordings. But we don't expect these problems to affect our repertory. I doubt that anyone who plays in a contemporary- music group ever expected to earn a lot of money. We play it because it's what we love."
Andrew Berger, the director of the concert division at the Hebrew Arts School, which runs Merkin Concert Hall, keeps tabs on the new-music groups that play there, and has a hand in programming the school's own Music Today series. When Gerard Schwarz stepped down last season as director of Music Today, Mr. Berger undertook a study of the series and found that the sentiments Ms. Spencer expressed were fairly common.
 
More Pay Elsewhere
 "What surprised us were the musicians," Mr. Berger said. "These are some of the busiest freelancers in New York, and we weren't sure whether they were in it because of Gerry, or because it was just another gig. What we found was that if they weren't playing in Music Today, they would probably be making more money elsewhere. But they said that they consider this some of the most interesting and exciting music they have a chance to play."
Mr. Berger added, however, that the audiences for both Music Today and the other ensembles that rent Merkin Concert Hall had shrunk considerably in recent years. One group that performs there, the 20-year-old Speculum Musicae, is addressing the problem by offering discount tickets to college and conservatory students. Others say they have not yet found a solution.
Several musicians noted that there was an excitement in the contemporary music world in the 1960's and the 1970's that had largely disappeared. But most of those interviewed about the audience problem said that they considered the public education system was at least partly to blame for failing to give students a grounding in cultural literacy, or even a sense that the arts are of value. Others said the lack of broad interest in contemporary classical music had deeper roots.
"The real problem," said Mr. Wuorinen, who was a founder of the Group for Contemporary Music, "is that we have reached the stage, under the impulse of cultural populism, where we are incapable of measuring or acknowledging artistic merit except in terms of commercial success. We don't distinguish between the committed, passionate audience and the trend-seeking yuppie audience. We just count bodies and measure sales.
"I'm convinced that this is the result of cultural attitudes that started in the late 1960's. People no longer perceive that there are levels of high art and low art, which we move up and down among according to our needs. In fact, the existence of a hierarchy of values is denied, and one sees it argued that pop singing and opera singing are equivalent. When that drumbeat has been sounded for 20 years, it's going to have an effect."
 
More Competition for Funds
 Most of the groups that reported substantial cuts in government support said that they had been sustained by grants from the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation, the Mary Flagler Carey Charitable Trust, the J. M. Kaplan Fund, the Jerome Foundation and Meet the Composer, all of which have maintained sizable contemporary-music programs. But as government financing evaporates, more groups are finding themselves scrambling for money from the same limited pool of patrons.
"The funding situation for small groups is bordering on the disastrous," Mr. Hellermann of the Downtown Ensemble said. "In the past, we were able to raise money by going around to corporations and small foundations and getting $200 or $500 here and there. But that has dried up."
Groups are finding that larger foundations that have not supported new music in the past are not inclined to start now. "I have been writing to lots of foundations and finding that many of them want a broader appeal and greater national visibility than we can give them," said Amy Roberts Frawley, Speculum Musicae's administrative director.
"The fund-raising climate has always been difficult," said Robert Beaser, a director of Musical Elements and the composer in residence of the American Composers Orchestra. "But doing contemporary music is different from doing standard repertory. Nobody does it to get rich. We do it to generate new works, to play the music really well, to make the repertory happen. If those things are important to you, you do it for your whole life. It's a cause more than anything else. So I think we'll be able to muddle through, one way or another."

HEADLINE: Technology Transcends the Borders of Nations

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"M.I.T. Deal with Japan Stirs Fear on Competition" (front page, Dec. 19) presents a somewhat distorted picture of international scientific and economic trade. 
 When President John F. Kennedy asked me to go to Japan in 1962 to open cooperative scientific ventures, I was surprised to see how good Japanese technology was. It was technically excellent. Much later, in 1979, as president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and co-founder of the M.I.T. Media Lab with Prof. Nicholas Negroponte, I returned to Japan. The technical excellence I had found in 1962 had been transformed into industrial achievement in areas that the United States was clearly -- and shortsightedly -- abandoning.
This was particularly true in communications and entertainment media. I personally remember the chief executive officer of RCA deciding to discontinue further development of videocassette recorders for reasons of short-term costs. And the Ampex Company had to license its VCR to Sony because it did not have the funds to market it. The Japanese industrialists in 1979 did not fear competition. They were used to fierce competition in Japan and anticipated it from the United States.
The Media Lab, the focus of your article, started operations five years ago. Since then, industry has supplied an average of 80 percent of the research funds; Japanese industry has supplied 14 percent. Much of the technology we exploit comes from Japan. The idea to approach Nihon University came in 1986 from a Congressionally mandated United States-Japan committee for promoting trade expansion. The agreement with Nihon and Chiyoji Misawa provided M.I.T. permanent endowment funds of $10 million, which yield about $500,000 a year for the Media Lab's academic program, faculty and students.
The Media Lab has become an international center of creativity in media arts and sciences in the United States, from computerized learning for elementary school students to computer-generated holograms and intelligent pianos.
The Japanese contributions to the M.I.T. Media Lab helped make it possible for American scientists to compete, indeed lead, in these fields. The digital high definition television referred to in "U.S. Makes Gains in Race to Develop Advanced TV" (front page, Dec. 21) was pioneered at the M.I.T. Media Lab, which played an important part in its development.
As for your headline, do Americans really fear competition and free enterprise? Is an export of a United States product automatically good, but an export of a United States idea automatically bad? Should ideas and information be paid for? And what is the nationality of a product or idea? Sony manufactures televisions in California, and Zenith manufactures televisions in Mexico. Does that make a Sony set more "American"?
We have to get beyond the old way of thinking in economics, just as we have in arms control and disarmament. We need an informed debate in the nation and the world, reflecting the subtleties and complexities of international life, trade, economics and how the United States supports scientific and technological research that drives our economy. We need to understand the complexities of the balance of trade of money and ideas.
Your article does not deal in these subtleties and complexities. Indeed, your tone calls your fairness into question. Contrary to what you say, M.I.T. requires that all research done under the agreement is to be freely published, without restrictions.
I note that when United States automobile companies make extensive efforts to replicate the production environment of Japanese car makers, the United States news media do not protest.
 
JEROME B. WIESNER
Cambridge, Mass., Dec. 21, 1990

HEADLINE: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
Rating Lowered For Nynex Unit

 BODY:
The rating on about $2.3 billion in New England Telephone and Telegraph Company long-term debt has been lowered to Aa-2, from Aa-1, Moody's Investors Service announced yesterday. New England Telephone is a unit of the Nynex Corporation.
Analysts at the rating agency said the telephone company's weakened operating performance and debt protection measurements were unlikely to return soon to their levels of the 1980's because of severe weakness in the New England economy and growing competitive pressures.
Moody's said it thought the New England economy would remain weak at least in the near term.
