HEADLINE: Soviet Woes Tarnish Once-Shining Space Efforts

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
THE Soviet Union's space program, the largest and most active in the world, is starting to crack under the crushing weight of political and economic troubles.
Signs of stress abound. The Soviet space shuttle, which was triumphantly unveiled two years ago, has yet to carry astronauts into space. Delays in its flight schedule have upset plans for the winged ship to save the abandoned Salyut 7 space station, whose flaming debris will blaze to Earth in the next few weeks. 
 Over all, rocket launchings are at historic lows for a variety of technical and economic reasons.
And the mainstay of the Soviet program, the 100-foot-long Mir space station, has suffered repeated cuts in plans for expansion and habitation. After declaring a new era in which the manned outpost orbiting Earth was to begin a "permanent" space presence, embarrassed Soviet officials in 1988 were forced to leave Mir empty for four months. More recently, three-man crews have been reduced to two.
"The program is going through a major retrenchment," said James E. Oberg, a Houston-based expert on the Soviet space program who is the author of "Red Star in Orbit."
So hungry is the program for cash that it is offering to sell space nuclear reactors for generating power in orbit -- devices that were once top secret. The United States Government is negotiating to buy one. But the Soviet Union's overall push to market space-related goods and services around the world has largely washed out, proving to be far more difficult than originally envisioned.
Looming ahead is the specter of rebellious republics seceding from the union, threatening to fragment the far-flung space enterprise.
"Rather than having one big space program they may have a lot of little ones," said John E. Pike, a space analyst with the Federation of American Scientists, a private group in Washington. He noted that the Russian republic recently launched its own communication satellite and intends to operate it independent of the central Soviet Government.
Perhaps most painfully, long-range Soviet planning is now in turmoil, jeopardizing such envisioned projects as a bold series of scientific probes, satellites that would convert sunlight into electricity for use on Earth and what had long been the holy grail of Soviet space aspirations -- a manned voyage to Mars.
"There are so many changes going on in the Soviet Union that it's impossible to see how it's going to sort itself out," said Marcia S. Smith, a space specialist at the Library of Congress.
To be sure, parts of the Soviet program are still vigorous, especially those linked to the military. Western experts note that recent overall rates of rocket launchings, while at historic lows, still surpass those of any other nation. Last year the Soviet Union launched at least 75 rockets that carried payloads into orbit. That represented more than two-thirds of such global activity. In the 1980's, the Soviet Union frequently launched more than 100 large rockets a year. The recent reductions, analysts say, have as much to do with the rising life span of Soviet satellites as the economic pressures on the overall space program.
Still, for a nation that inaugurated the space age with the flight of Sputnik in 1957, lofted the first man into orbit and achieved a host of other firsts, the sudden reversals have come as a shock.
Nikolai N. Ponomarev-Stepnoi, deputy director of the Kurchatov Institute of Atomic Energy in Moscow, recently lamented that a factory to make space reactors "is now being converted for the manufacture of automatic systems for producing, of all things, milk cartons."
 
Budget Cuts Take Toll
 The Soviet space program is a vast, secretive enterprise that was formed in the cauldron of the cold war. For decades its successes dazzled the world and were the envy of space-faring nations. Although there are exceptions, its triumphs have tended to come from application of brute strength rather than cutting-edge technology. For instance, its rocket engines tend to be reliable monsters rather than the small, temperamental, high-temperature, high-pressure ones often used in the West.
What has recently started to fracture the program are cuts in funds, especially for manned operations. Mr. Oberg, the Houston analyst, said the program had suffered 10 percent reductions two years in a row.
Nowhere are the effects more noticeable then in the Soviet shuttle program, which got off to a spectacular start in November 1988 with the maiden flight of the winged, re-usable Buran, whose name means snowstorm or blizzard. That flight was unmanned. But Soviet officials confidently predicted that the craft would soon be carrying astronauts into space at least once a year, with the rate eventually rising to as many as four flights a year.
So far, there have been no follow-up flights, and some experts have suggested that chronic problems in the country's economy may keep it that way.
"The question is not when but if it will ever fly again," said Mr. Oberg, the Houston analyst, who recently visited Soviet space centers. He added that the shuttle was seen by much of the Soviet public as a "white elephant."
"It's one of the most vulnerable programs in terms of cutbacks," Mr. Oberg said in an interview.
A prominent victim of the shuttle is Salyut 7. Buran was to rendezvous with the 40-ton abandoned space station and, according to Soviet press reports, bring it back to Earth. At the least, American experts say, large parts of the outpost would have been returned for study. But the derelict station is now expected to crash through the atmosphere in a rain of fiery debris, some of which may strike Earth's surface.
 
A Leap and Then a Crawl
 The space program's most visible element, Mir, is also in trouble, and not simply because of crew cutbacks. Its construction is stymied. The Salyut space stations were simple cylinders about the size of a house trailer. Mir, or "peace" in Russian, when flung aloft in February 1986, marked an architectural leap forward. Although basically a large cylinder, it also had a central hub with five docking ports from which four large research modules, each a pressurized cylinder as big as the core itself, were to be fastened. The extra port was for the Soyuz craft that transports Soviet astronauts to and from the station.
According to plan, all four large add-ons should have been in place and functioning by 1990, with as many as six astronauts in the roomy complex at work on experiments meant to advance the frontiers of science. Instead, only two of the modules have been added and only two Soviet astronauts now routinely occupy Mir. The problems, analysts say, are planning lapses, equipment failures and intense budget pressures that have halted progress and sown confusion.
"They've thrown out the map," said Mr. Oberg, the Houston analyst. The emerging strategy, he said, is to sell as much space as possible aboard Mir to foreign astronauts, as the Soviets did recently by taking a Japanese reporter aloft for $12 million. Expansion of the outpost in space is much harder to justify given the collapse of the economy on the ground, he added.
 
From Pride to Embarrassment
 "With chronic shortages of soap and antibiotics, the issue of space flight is almost embarrassing," Mr. Oberg said.
The Soviet plan to rescue its space program with revenue from foreign sales has been disappointing, Western experts say. The sales blitz started around 1987 as slick brochures and eager managers offered everything from launching services and communication satellites to space photographs and rocket engines.
"Soviet successes have been modest, partly due to business inexperience and partly due to Western technology transfer restrictions," Nicholas L. Johnson, an expert on the Soviet space program at Teledyne Brown Engineering in Colorado Springs who is the author of "Soviet Year in Space," noted in his most recent report. For instance, the technology restrictions have kept Western satellites from being sent into space atop Soviet rockets, an operation that could be quite lucrative.
 
Political Turmoil and Uncertainty
 The trouble has been compounded by jurisdictional warfare within the Soviet space establishment over who should lead the commercial effort as well as the nation's general political turmoil and the West's uncertainly concerning who will be running the country in six months.
 "No one knows, including those in the Soviet Union, what direction the civilian program will take," said Ms. Smith of the Library of Congress. "They have a hard time getting money even for projects that have high priority. The whole bureaucracy is up in the air, which makes it all the more confusing. Over all, the program is in for some very tough times."

HEADLINE: Selling Out the Baltics

BYLINE: By Tunne Kelam and Mari-Ann Rikken; Tunne Kelam is chairman of the Congress of Estonia. Mari-Ann Rikken is vice president of the Estonian-American National Council Inc.

DATELINE: ARLINGTON, Va.

 BODY:
George Bush has drawn a line in the sand in the Middle East but is putting his head in the sand in Europe. While America rushes to war in the Middle East, allegedly to defend the sovereignty of a small nation against aggression by a larger neighbor, the Administration has expressed only its "concern" about the Soviet Union sending troops into the Baltic states.
Mr. Bush must make it clear to Mikhail Gorbachev that even a creeping crackdown by the Soviets would mean an end to U.S. aid -- including the recent food credits. 
 This is all familiar terrain for the Soviet leadership, which historically has sought to synchronize power grabs with dramatic world events. Thus, as President Bush seeks a worldwide consensus -- seemingly at any price -- to support U.S. military action against Iraq, the Soviet Union, hypocritically bemoaning Saddam Hussein's moves in Kuwait, is preparing for a vicious crackdown against three small nations.
Once again -- as the Soviet Union flies in tens of thousands of troops to round up a few thousand young boys who refuse to serve in the Red Army, closes down independent publications and prepares an economic blockade -- Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania seem destined to end up a tragic footnote to larger events of history. This is precisely what happened in June 1940, when Moscow invaded the Baltic states while the world's attention was riveted on the collapse of France.
The same principle should apply to the Baltics as to Kuwait. The West has never recognized the Soviet takeover of the Baltics. Fifty years of supportive messages from Washington to Baltic diplomatic representatives have sustained Baltic hopes for the restoration of freedom.
Now that there are real chances as well as legal grounds for regaining freedom, however, the U.S. is not living up to its promises. Instead of supporting peaceful, democratic movements in the Soviet Union, the Bush Administration seems committed to saving the last colonial empire, placing its hopes on democratizing a Soviet system led by a dictator.
It is truly ominous and ironic that the U.S. appears ready to support a new Soviet dictatorship in the hopes of promoting freedom, rule of law and free competition. Wishfully thinking that a dictatorship may be able and willing to reform itself, the world's leading democracy seems ready to sanction Soviet use of martial law and terror to save perestroika.
The U.S. should stick to its principles. There is a lesson in the events of 1917 to 1920, a period when the superpowers first tried to save the Russian empire, ignoring the national democratic movements. When it became clear that the Czar's empire couldn't be saved, the West finally changed its policies and recognized the states that had liberated themselves.
If Western support consists only of lip service at this crucial moment, the West will have to take responsibility for any desperate moves on the part of the Baltic peoples who are not only being pushed toward extinction by Soviet imperialistic policies but are now being pressured by Soviet paratroopers and economic collapse.
The development of new Lebanons in Eastern Europe can still be prevented by restraining the terror apparatus of the Soviet Union and reaffirming unequivocally the rights of the Baltic nations to independence.
We are facing a crucial test not only for the survival of the Baltic nations but also for the principles of American foreign policy. Lasting world peace and stability cannot be achieved by applying principles of justice and law unequally. Safeguarding the vital interests of the Baltic nations does not require 350,000 U.S. troops. It requires only a firm stand on a principle held for 50 years.
While President Bush is ready to spill the blood of American boys to free Kuwait, his message to the Baltic nations occupied by 300,000 Soviet troops is to help themselves. Does 50 years of occupation by the Soviet Union make such a difference? If so, how long will Kuwait have to be occupied before its sovereignty becomes an internal Iraqi matter?

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Records Broad Gains In Advance of Talks on Gulf

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose broadly yesterday as currency traders stocked up in advance of diplomatic talks today that many viewed as offering a slim chance for peace in the Persian Gulf.
Gold fell in New York, dropping $3.80 an ounce, to $390.30, on the Commodity Exchange. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $390.20 an ounce, down $2.40 from Monday's late quote. But the metal was still up for the week after its jump on Monday of more than $9 an ounce on the Commodity Exchange. Silver futures also plunged 16.1 cents an ounce yesterday, to $4.127, on the Commodity Exchange.. 
 Several currency traders said they thought it unlikely that the United States could avoid an armed Persian Gulf confrontation, despite high-level talks scheduled for today.
The dominant focus on the dollar as a safe investment overrode several economic signs, including an apparent move by the Federal Reserve to ease interest rates and a reiteration by Germany's central bank that it would continue to keep credit tight.
"By and large, traders recognize the Fed may have eased, but until we get some sort of statement from the meeting, I can't imagine anyone would be comfortable being short dollars," said Maria Nordone, vice president at the Security Pacific National Bank in Los Angeles.
Economists earlier said that the Fed had apparently dropped the Federal funds rate, the interest banks charge each other, by one-quarter percentage point, to 6.75 percent.
"Ordinarily, a credit easing would hurt because an easier monetary stance makes it less attractive to hold dollars," said Ronald Holzer, chief dealer for Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago.
Instead, the dollar's appeal as a investment continued to be strengthened by the gulf conflict as well as by strife in the Soviet Union, which has tended to diminish confidence in bordering economies like Germany's.
Currency traders said they bought dollars on news that Soviet troops began rolling into the Baltic region to enforce the Red Army draft. The move came after reports that thousands of young men in the republics are ignoring Red Army draft orders. In reaction to the Soviet move, the United States sharply rebuked the Kremlin for sending troops into the Baltic states.
In London, the British pound held steady at $1.9060 and in New York, sterling weakened to $1.8965 from late Monday's $1.9031.
n Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.25 yen, to a closing 136.30 yen. Later in London, it was quoted at 136.00 yen, and in New York, the dollar was quoted at a closing 136.50, up from Monday's 136.10 yen.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's rates, included: 1.5420 German marks, up from 1.5355; 1.2965 Swiss francs, up from 1.2925; 5.2330 French francs, up from 5.2065; 1,159.25 Italian lire, up from 1,153.50, and 1.1523 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1537.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Saudi Ruler Is Said to Expect a War

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Jan. 8

 BODY:
On the eve of the critical meeting between the American Secretary of State and the Iraqi Foreign Minister, King Fahd of Saudi Arabia has evidently concluded that Iraq is not likely to withdraw from Kuwait and that therefore the international coalition against Baghdad must be prepared to strike at military targets deep inside Iraq without destroying the country itself.
A Saudi official said King Fahd shared the view of most coalition members that the meeting in Geneva on Wednesday between Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Foreign Minister Tariz Aziz of Iraq would not achieve a breakthrough toward persuading President Saddam Hussein to withdraw his forces from Kuwait. 
 "I'm convinced that the highest level of the Saudi monarchy believes that he will not withdraw," a Western diplomat said, although the Saudi official said some senior members of the Saudi royalty were slightly more optimistic than the King.
 
Pessimistic View Prevails
 With the pessimistic view of the Geneva meeting prevalent, officials of Persian Gulf states and Western diplomats said the goal of neutralizing the military capacity of Iraq for future aggression without destroying it was a "shared objective" of the United States and its key coalition partners -- Saudi Arabia, Egypt and Syria.
"Broadly speaking, the consensus among all the coalition partners, particularly among its key players, is that Iraq's capability to wage offensive war must be destroyed, but that the conflict should be managed so that Iraq does not become a vacuum and so it can eventually play its traditional balancing role in the gulf," a Western diplomat said.
Specifically, the official added, that means striking at Iraq's chemical infrastructure -- its weapons factories and stockpiles -- attempting to capture, rather than kill, as many Iraqi soldiers as possible, and "getting it over with as quickly as possible."
Saudi and Western officials agreed that the goal of crippling the Iraqi war machine without destroying the country would be severely complicated if Iraq used chemical weapons. "If they use chemical weapons, and we fear they will," one Saudi said, "then all bets are off, and we will retaliate massively."
 
Liberation, Not Obliteration
 But the determination to avoid the destruction of Iraq was echoed in an interview today by Abdullah Bishara, the Kuwaiti who heads the Gulf Cooperation Council, the regional military and economic cooperation group. "The goal is the liberation of Kuwait, not the obliteration of Iraq," Mr. Bishara said.
Asked whether the coalition was talking tough to persuade Mr. Hussein to withdraw, the diplomat replied that the warnings were a "serious effort" by coalition members to make President Hussein "understand what he faces, in order to avoid a war."
One Western diplomat said that although the Iraqi leader might unveil new proposals or hint at a willingness to withdraw during the Geneva talks, most coalition members were "convinced that whatever he does is aimed at delaying and temporizing."
An analyst of Saudi politics said that while many members of the coalition were publicly pessimistic about prospects for a peaceful resolution of the crisis but more optimistic in private, the opposite was true in Saudi Arabia. Two days ago, King Fahd told Western reporters that he shared President Bush's stated instinct that President Hussein would withdraw at the last minute. But privately, the King is said to be persuaded that Mr. Hussein has been playing for time.
 
Dismembering of Iraq Disclaimed
 Officials involved in crisis planning here have said that there was what one characterized as an "understanding or implicit agreement" among coalition members that a military strike against Iraq should not be used as a pretext to dismember Iraq. A Saudi official said Turkey had given Riyadh assurances, for example, that it would not try to invade and annex the Iraqi city of Mosul and other Kurdish parts of Iraq that were once part of Turkey.
Another analyst said Syria, one of the few Arab countries to have supported Iran during its war with Iraq, was believed to have received assurances from Teheran that it, too, would refrain from grabbing part of Iraq in a war.
Saudi, gulf and Western officials all asserted that cooperation was excellent among what Mr. Bishara called members of the "new order," or what some analysts of the Middle East see as the emergence of a powerful alliance among Egypt, Syria and Saudi Arabia and its gulf allies. One official said the principal states of the alliance might hold a summit meeting in Riyadh to make final declarations and plans before Jan. 15, the date set by the United Nations by which Iraq must withdraw from Kuwait or face the possible use of force to evict it.
One analyst of the gulf crisis said that while the Saudis, Egyptians and Syrians all believed that after a war, every effort should be made to "help Iraq back on its feet in a less aggressive stance," there were differences among them about whether a military conflict would destroy Iraq.
Egypt, the analyst said, has concluded that Iraqi soldiers would not put up an intense fight and hence that a quick and decisive victory over Iraq was likely. Syria, on the other hand, fears that Iraq would resist mightily and might therefore be destroyed in the process. The analyst said that this in turn strengthened Syria's reluctance to send forces inside Iraq, as its public declarations have suggested.
Neither Saudi nor Western officials seem to have given much thought to who might come to power in Iraq in the aftermath of a military confrontation, and there seems to have been little advance effort to prepare Saudi public opinion for what could be a large number of Saudi casualties if there is a war.

HEADLINE: C.D.'s and Bank Funds Off

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields on bank certificates of deposit and money market accounts were down for the week that ended yesterday, continuing a three-month slide.
Robert K. Heady, the publisher of The Bank Rate Monitor, said that judging by the speed in which deposit rates had been falling during this cycle, the downward slide could last longer than most had predicted. If no war breaks out in the Persian Gulf, he said, yields could continue to fall throughout the year. 
 Mr. Heady added that he did not think that the cut in the prime rate last week, to 9 1/2 percent, from 10 percent, would be enough to stimulate the economy and that he saw more cuts in the rate coming.
 
Discount Rates Mixed
 At the Treasury Department's weekly auction of short-term bills on Monday, average discount rates were mixed. The auction results often influence what many banks eventually pay on money market accounts and certificates of deposit.
The three-month bill was unchanged for the third straight week, at 6.52 percent, while the six-month bill rose by 3 basis points, to 6.51 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
In the weekly survey of New York area banks, The Bank Rate Monitor noted that yields on certificates of deposit were off slightly more at commercial banks than at savings banks, but both showed moderate declines in yields.
The average yield for a money market account at a savings institution was off by a basis point, to 6.16 percent, while three-month certificates were off by 7 basis points, to 7.32 percent, and six-month certificates were off by 6 basis points, to 7.46 percent.
Yields on commercial bank money market accounts were off by 6 basis points, to 5.93 percent, while those on three-month certiticates were off by 9 basis points, to 7.01 percent, and on six-month certificates were down by 7 basis points, to 7.12 percent.
 
Other Yields Are Off
 Yields on money market accounts at 20 large banks outside the New York area were only slightly off compared with those in the New York area, falling by a basis point, to 5.97 percent. The drop in six-month certifctates around the country easily matched the decline in New York. The average yield fell by 8 basis points, to 6.90 percent.
The Bank Rate Monitor said its nationwide survey last week showed the ratio of savings rate decreases to increases had slowed to 26 to 1 from the previous week's ratio of 28 to 1. The Monitor's analysts said the ratio was considered another indicator of the direction of interest rates.

HEADLINE: Student Loan Proposal Leaves Colleges Unsure

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d

 BODY:
A proposal by the Bush Administration to streamline student loan programs by eliminating banks from the process has piqued the interest of colleges and universities. But they stopped short of endorsing the plan, because it does not address the problems of loan servicing and collections.
Under the Administration's proposal, all Federal student aid would go from the Federal Government directly to the educational institutions without the intermediate step of the banks, which now supply low-interest loans that carry Federal guarantees in the event of defaults. 
 Higher education associations said the process of awarding Federal student loans would be discussed in Congress, but they were not sure that the Administration's proposal would be adopted because of the questions and concerns it has generated.
 
Using Savings for More Loans
 Supporters of the plan said that by skirting the banks, which are paid fees for offering and handling the loans, the Government could save as much as $1 billion a year. The savings could then be used for more loans.
The proposal covers the three Federal Guaranteed Student Loan programs, which generated $12.3 billion in loans in the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30. Banks alone, through the Stafford loan program, generated $9.7 billion of the total.
But colleges maintained that the proposal did not address who would deal with loan payments and who would be responsible for collecting loans that are delinquent or in default as banks now do.
Nor does the proposal address the availability of money for student loans. Under the current system, banks are free to lend as much as they want. But higher education officials said they feared that more direct Federal involvement might result in more restrictions on how the money is allocated. And they worried that the estimated $1 billion in annual savings would go to other Federal spending, not to more student loans.
 
Restrictions Are Feared
 "My guess is that if they are trying to save money, there may well be restrictions," said Dallas Martin, president of the National Association of Student Financial Aid Administrators, a group representing about 9,000 financial aid officers.
There is widespread agreement that the Federal student loan program needs to be overhauled. In addition to the high rate of defaults and delinquencies, the system is cumbersome, taking weeks and sometimes months to grant students their assistance. Some financial aid officials said the proposal clearly addresses that issue.
"On the surface, it looks pretty good," said Marie Leonard, director of financial aid at Hunter College in New York. "It would put more control in the hands of the schools and would give students a quicker commitment because it would cut down part of the process."
But she and others expressed apprehension over what she called inattention in the proposal to collections and bad debts.
The current structure is a complicated procedure that would take colleges several years to duplicate, if they could even afford to do that, several financial aid officers at colleges and universities said.
In the current system, banks can either sell their loans to other banks or institutions for investment purposes, or let the college or university hold the loans in its own portfolio. Financial institutions also have created networks of collection agencies and hired workers to pursue those who do not repay their student loans.
Several colleges and universities flatly said they hoped a more specific Federal proposal would not require them to supply those services, because they cannot afford it.

HEADLINE: Hope and Realities;
Dinkins Address Expresses Optimism At Odds With Troubles Faced by City

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins's assessment of the state of his city had at its essence an optimism for the future at odds with the harsh realities of the present.
In short, Mr. Dinkins's address was more remarkable for what it did not say than for what it did about the state of City Hall these days. Absent was any description of probable changes among the Mayor's senior aides intended to shore up his political support and impose order on his unruly, uneven and still hard-pressed staff. 
 He spoke of working closely with Gov. Mario M. Cuomo at a moment when relations between the two officials are as strained by their mutural budget crises as they have ever been. He praised "new partnerships" with the City Council as evidence that not all New Yorkers are fractious at a time of the most fractious relations between a mayor and a Council in years.
 
'Right Down to the Bone'
 To be sure, the Mayor took grim note of the city's deepening fiscal problems, warning that services would shrink and that "we will, in fact, cut right down to the bone, and all New Yorkers will feel the pain." And it is an established mayoral prerogative to accentuate the positive in a not-always annual summing up that is not even required by law.
But even as the Mayor acknowledged the crime that has plagued the city's streets and killed too many of its children, he boasted about the diversity of his government and his city's place as "the world's economic command post," and sketched an expansive vision of the future. "This administration will take whatever measures may be necessary to guarantee that we retain the freedom to reach for our dreams, to preserve our ability to overcome whatever disappointments may come our way."
Mr. Dinkins closed by lauding the spirit of the average New Yorker and presenting "gorgeous mosaic" awards to six civic-minded citizens, though he had to prompt his audience to applaud them.
 
'A Speech Is a Speech'
 Not everyone in City Hall shared the Mayor's apparent confidence.
"When you listen to David Dinkins, you really feel his heart is in the right place," said City Council President Andrew J. Stein, who has said he might run for mayor in 1993. "But this is the time for forceful and decisive action and movement, and he has to take it over the next year. A speech is a speech, but he has to act boldly and decisively."
Even as he spoke in such encouraging generalities, some of the Mayor's senior advisers and longtime supporters said they expected staff changes at high levels in the coming weeks as the year-old administration strives to adjust itself to confront the problems ahead.
A number of people close to Mr. Dinkins's chief political aide, Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch, have asserted forcefully in recent days that Mr. Lynch was deeply unhappy in his job and, with the city's bleak economic prospects has been seriously considering leaving. But Mr. Lynch, who just returned from his first vacation in years, denied that he had any plans to leave.
 
'Not in the Best of Shape'
 Even the suggestion that Mr. Lynch might leave was a sign of the pessimism of some members of Mr. Dinkins's electoral coalition, and enough to disturb others.
The Rev. Calvin O. Butts, pastor of the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem, said of the city and the Dinkins administration, "I think both are not in the best of shape." But he said many of the Mayor's problems were inherited and added that he was still a strong supporter, though he said Mr. Lynch's departure would be "a disaster."
"If Bill's not there, there would be some serious questions as to whether Calvin Butts would be there," he said.
It seems almost certain that John Flateau, a former Dinkins campaign aide, will come to City Hall to serve as chief of staff, in charge of the Mayor's schedule and the cadre of too many cooks that has kept Mr. Dinkins complaining that his office does not run as smoothly as it should.
 
Jobs and Attention
 Other senior aides said discussions were also under way with Charles McKinney, an aide to Representative Charles B. Rangel, to supervise the Mayor's political and patronage-dispensing efforts. Party leaders have complained that the Dinkins administration has not rewarded them or their loyalists with enough jobs or attention.
Still undecided is the precise role of Ken Sunshine, a senior special adviser to the Mayor, who had run the scheduling operation from a desk outside the Mayor's suite but has now shifted to work on political and lobbying projects under the aegis of Mr. Lynch from an office across the street.
"First years are always difficult for any leader," said the Manhattan Borough President, Ruth W. Messinger, a longtime Dinkins ally. "This year, for this Mayor, has really been trial by fire. The level of public anxiety about all the things that are wrong in their lives, many of which are not under the Mayor's control, makes the focus on municipal leadership intense."
Ms. Messinger added: "My conclusion is that to have spent a year like that as your first year as New York City's Mayor means that you've bumped into a couple of walls, and you have a real need to try to expand long-range planning, do more consultation and insure that all of the hands and heads of your government are working in concert. And I think that's very much on the Mayor's agenda."

HEADLINE: Mideast Crisis Threatens Unlikely Victim: Junk Mail

BYLINE: By RANDALL ROTHENBERG

 BODY:
The prospect of war in the Persian Gulf may have one unlikely beneficiary: the nation's overstuffed mailboxes. Many direct marketing consultants say they are advising their clients to postpone plans to send out junk mail until after Jan. 15, the date when the United Nations has authorized the use of force to end Iraq's occupation of Kuwait.
January is normally a peak month for mailing magazine subscription solicitations, catalogues and sweepstakes. But the consultants say they are deferring to a debated piece of direct marketing folklore that originated on Nov. 22, 1963, the day President Kennedy was assassinated: Never send junk mail into the face of a national crisis, or you risk losing your customers to the television screen. 
 "I advised all my clients to get their mail out by the end of the year, or hold the mail in the bags to see if war starts on the 16th," said Richard V. Benson, a circulation expert. "If war does start, I'm telling them to hold until Feb. 1." said Mr. Benson, who founded the University of California, Berkeley Wellness Letter, the nation's largest medical newsletter, with a circulation of 900,000.
Far from all direct marketers abide by the crisis theory, and some even cite cases that they say disprove it. But enough marketers believe the theory that the the result is likely to be fewer of the "Dear Reader" solicitations and "you'll be the envy of all the folks in Fair Lawn" come-ons that typically flood into homes this time of year.
Katie Muldoon, the chief executive of HDM Muldoon, a direct-marketing subsidiary of the HDM Worldwide advertising company, said she had told many of her clients, which include General Mills and Colgate-Palmolive, to delay their mailings.
"Historically, what we've seen with national events like this is that people watch their television sets and don't read their mail," she said. But even if war breaks out, she said marketers would only have to postpone their mailings for two to four weeks.
"The American public doesn't have too much of an attention span," Ms. Muldoon said.
The situation in the Middle East is running right into another crisis facing direct marketers, a 25 percent increase in the cost of third-class postage, the Postal Service's category for junk mail. That increase is expected to be approved in late January and go into effect on Feb. 3.
The the near-certainty of a postal-rate increase and the possibility of Persian Gulf hostilities have generated a raging debate among the direct marketers who send some 62 billion packages each year. Many argue that war -- like snow, rain, heat and gloom of night -- should not stop the mail.
 
California Earthquake
 "We mailed into the California earthquake," said Jerome W. Pickholz, the chairman of Ogilvy & Mather Direct and an advocate of continued mailings. "Anybody who mails regularly is bound to mail into a disaster."
Indeed, magazine publishers must maintain the circulation rate-base they guarantee advertisers, so they are forced to continue mailing despite uncertainty. And many of the most prolific direct marketers, like Publishers Clearing House, could not stop their enormous mailings even if they wanted, because they are tied into tight schedules of television and print advertising. That means would-be millionaires eagerly awaiting the prize drawings later this month are not wasting their baited breath.
But many smaller or more flexible marketers, including some catalogue merchandisers and others who were planning small test mailings, rather than mass mailings, are postponing their trips to the post office.
One large mailing house, Mailmen Inc. in Hauppauge, L.I., says it is holding roughly half of the two million solicitations it was planning to send for its clients this month until the storm clouds in the Middle East either burst or clear.
 
History as a Guide
 Those direct marketers who believe the timing is bad cite history as their guide.
"The famous example is President Kennedy's assassination," recalled John Francis Tighe, a consultant in Truro, Mass., who has worked for American Express and Hearst Magazines. "It occurred when people were just mailing out for the Christmas holidays. It had just gone into the mail and was scheduled to hit around Thanksgiving. A great deal of the mailing just died. It was quite an economic hardship on a lot of mailers."
Holiday gift-giving has traditionally made December the heaviest month for most categories of junk mail. But for financial services, entertainment and home furnishings, January has run a close second in many recent years, according to the Kleid Company, a New York direct marketing firm.
 
'The Me Month'
 No one really knows the reason for the popularity of January, which some direct marketers call "the me month." As direct marketing experts are fond of saying, they are more comfortable with the what's than the why's.
"There's a lot of direct mail mythology," said Eli Spielman, a Teaneck, N.J., consultant who creates packages for Chemical Bank and Manufacturers Hanover and who supports the idea of deferred mailings this month.

HEADLINE: THE NEW ISRAELIS: A SPECIAL REPORT;
Soviet Influx Has the Israelis Building, Fighting and in Awe

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TEL AVIV, Jan. 4

 BODY:
Israel has become a nation consumed, not with the prospect of war in the gulf, but with the extraordinary wave of Soviet Jewish immigration that is altering the face of Israeli society.
Nearly as many Soviet Jews have arrived in the last year as arrived in the 41 years since independence in 1948. In their numbers, their skills and their politics, those immigrants -- nearly 200,000 since the end of 1989 -- are changing life here in ways that are exhilarating for Israelis, and also difficult for them to understand. 
 But virtually all Israelis, from politicians of the left and right to ordinary citizens, remain bewitched by the wave of immigration. They are awed by its dimension and confident that when all is said and done, it will bring strength, wealth and increased weight to Israel as a nation and as a military power in the Middle East.
"Per capita, it's as if the United States were to absorb France," said Amikam Oren, general manager of the Israeli Housing Ministry, which expects immigrants to pour in at the rate of 40,000 to 50,000 over the next few months as long as the Soviet Union keeps its doors open to those who wish to leave.
With all the joy and anticipation, there are questions about the speed with which Israel is moving to make housing available to the rushing waves of immigrants, and there are increasingly critical newspaper and television accounts about the fighting between Housing Ministry and Absorption Ministry officials, between religious and secular authorities and between the various political parties that evidently surround the Israeli effort to greet newcomers.
This year alone the number of arrivals is expected to be a record 400,000 Soviet Jews, more than double that of last year. For the first time in its history, Israel has an immigration budget that is larger than its military budget.
Nowhere is the extent of the wave more evident than at Ben-Gurion International Airport outside Tel Aviv.
There, travelers from other countries landing in Israel appear to be a drop in a sea of largely Soviet Jewish immigrants standing amid an awesome pile of battered suitcases loaded on trolleys. Those Soviet Jews, who have spent days or weeks making their way to Israel, appear anxious. They peer across the arrival hall, looking to make a phone call to a distant relative or waiting for the Absorption Ministry authorities to greet them, finish their paper work and send them on to a new home if no relatives are there to take them away.
"It's amazing," said Judith Kipper, a Middle East expert at the Brookings Institution who is studying the influx. "You get to Tel Aviv and there they are in the hundreds standing with their luggage. Then in just a few hours they all disappear, just melting away."
Where they wind up, and their future plans, political and social, have become pivotal and nagging questions.
Many Israeli Jews of European descent, the Ashkenazim, say they are looking to the Soviet Jews to redress what they see as an imbalance that has tilted the weight of Israel's Jewish population toward the Sephardim, or Middle Eastern Jews. Many of the Ashkenazim say that change has affected their way of life by increasing the dominance of the rigorously observant religious parties over Israeli culture, politics and religious affairs.
The numbers of newcomers alone portend a sweeping shift in Israeli political life. At the end of 1989, the Central Bureau of Statistics put Israel's Jewish population at 3.7 million. About 1.3 million of those were counted as Ashkenazim, and 1.6 million were counted as Sephardim. The rest were listed as Jews born to Israeli-born fathers, but considered neither Ashkenazim nor Sephardim by Israel.
If Government projections for the influx on Soviet Jews hold true, as many as a million more Ashkenazim could arrive by the end of 1992.
Israel's Arab population, which excludes the Palestinians living in the occupied territories, is put at 700,000.
 
The Immigrants
 
Who They Are, Why They Came
Dr. Nodari Pichkhadze, a silver-haired dermatologist from Soviet Georgia who arrived here three months ago, pulled his 5-year-old to his lap and proclaimed with a smile, "Meir here wants to be President."
The 50-year-old doctor said he had dreamed of coming here since he was 18. "I am a good physician," he said, sitting quietly in his new apartment in a Tel Aviv suburb. "I don't want to be rich and I am not particularly religious. I am Jewish. My family is Jewish, and the future of my children is here. That is why I came."
Dr. Mikhail Zusman, a 30-year-old physicist who came a year ago from Kharkov in the Ukraine to live and work at Beersheba said Israelis would have to wait and see before a solid body of opinion identified with the Russian Jews emerged on the political scene.
"Generally speaking, the movement from the Soviet Union to here is one from the left to the right," he said. "But all I can say for now is that I have not made up my mind about the political situation. I feel this country is my mother country. This is the main conclusion I can give you, but the problems connected with Arab territories, et cetera, are very big problems that I am ready to deal with and maybe my generation will not see them resolved."
Other Russians, like Vladimir Shklyar, a fencing instructor from Leningrad who has been here for 11 months and has found a job teaching his sport at Hebrew University, said that most Soviet Jews were escaping the economic and political chaos of the Soviet Union and that their politics in the end would be shaped by how they can serve their well-being here.
"As far as what motivates people to come here, I don't think they are coming driven by the Zionist ideals like in 1949," he said. "They are coming out of fear of pogroms and because of economic reasons. But once you are here you begin to explore your Jewish roots and background and you look at the traditon."
Sitting in his modestly furnished two-bedroom apartment in Jerusalem, Mr. Shklyar did not appear optimistic about the Palestinian question.
"If there is going to be peace in the region, it will help the absorption to work out," he said.
 
The Reaction
 
Changing View Of Israeli Life
The dimension of the challenge of the immigration is evident in conversations with almost every Israeli. There is unanimous exhilaration at the notion that this country is watching its population grow by more than 25 percent in the space of three years or so.
"From the East and West, from Persia and Ethiopia, from Bukhara and Samarkand, and from Moscow and Kishinev, the Jews are coming to the only country that wants them and is waiting for them," said Consul General Aryeh Levin as he raised the Israeli flag above Israel's Consulate in Moscow on Thursday.
The influx is changing Israel's perception of many aspects of life here, from its electoral system to its perception of its dispute with Arabs over the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip and its 40-year conflict with the Arab nations around it.
Meron Benvenisti, an Israeli specialist on the Palestinian issue who has warned for years that even before the influx, Israel was in the process of absorbing the occupied territories, said the arrival of the Russian Jews had settled the issue.
"Israel is totally absorbed by the immigration of one million Jews," he said. "It couldn't care less about the Palestinians. They are totally beside the point, which is something the Arabs don't seem to understand. It is not important whether the Soviet Jews will go in West Bank settlements or not. What is important is that they will eventually join the army and patrol the West Bank. This wave means another 100,000 people in the Army of Israel."
That apprehension is shared by the Palestinians living here. Sari Nusseibah, a prominent Palestinian leader in Jerusalem, said in a recent interview: "As long as there is no clear indication of a peace process or any intention of the Israelis to end their occupation of the West Bank and Gaza, immigration is a terrifying prospect because what it tells Palestinians is that we cannot live as equals in this country and that the chances of preserving our Palestinian lands in the West Bank and Gaza for a Palestinian state are getting slimmer by the day."
 
The Housing
 
Construction And Infighting
 Arieh Bar, director of the Housing Ministry for the Negev region, sat in the wind-swept ministry building in Beersheba, the capital of the Negev, speaking of the dream of Israel's founder, David Ben-Gurion, coming true on the maps hanging on his office's wall.
In a contradictory twist, not too far away bulldozers are moving mounds of earth as hundreds of largely Arab workers are putting up prefabricated and new houses for the Jews coming to Israel. "We are going to change this area from a peripheral one to a central area, which was Ben-Gurion's dream," said Mr. Bar, a 45-year-old Iraqi-born Jew who came here in 1949. "Two years ago the whole Negev region received $4.5 million in development money. Today my budget for development is $115 million. Infrastructure planning projects were valued at $500,000 then, and today we are spending $20 million on planning for more in the future."
Leonid Wenkret, one of Mr. Bar's aides, pointed at a barren desert lot called Ramot, teeming with construction workers, and said, "if we go according to our assumptions, we will triple the population in the Negev" from 240,000 in four to seven years.
"Without doubt we are witnessing a historical landmark that can be compared in the history of the Jewish people to the establishment of Israel itself," Mr. Bar said. "This country will go from a Jewish population of 3.8 million to perhaps 6, or who knows, 7 million people. We must succeed. It is like a mission. As someone who came from an Arab country, to me, this, more than anything else, will establish in front of the Arab world the fact that Israel is here to stay."
To accomplish that, Israel is racing to construct housing, using everything from prefabricated concrete blocks to what Israelis call caravan cities, which are a collection of trailers without wheels put in empty lots lent by the army or given by the state or volunteered by existing Kibbutzims.
As the construction boom gets under way, so does the infighting among competing politicians, most particularly Absorption Minister Yitzhak Peretz and Housing Minister Ariel Sharon. And there are already accusations of corruption in the allocation of funds to contractors, although many of them are hard to prove.
Among other things it has laid the fundamental conflict between religious and secular parties. Mr. Peretz, an Orthodox Jew, asserted recently that many of those coming were not even Jews and should have their religious credentials examined. His remark shocked may secular Jews eager for the Soviet influx to go smoothly and to tilt the balance in this country, again, in favor of the secularists.
A few days ago, Mr. Peretz said the Housing Ministry's caravan program was not enough to house the Soviet Jews and called for the purchase and installment of thousands of tents, warning that even with new immigrants living two or three families to an apartment, Israel may be short of housing for some 100,000 newcomers this year.
 
The Homeless
 
Rising Ranks Of the Displaced
 In contrast to the mood in Beersheba, where thousands of housing units are nonetheless being built for the immigrants, there is bitterness at a tent settlement in Jerusalem that houses some of those displaced or shunted aside as a result of the Soviet influx.
On a damp, barren hill beneath the ultramodern Museum of Israel, Sima Maman, a 24-year-old unemployed Israeli woman of Moroccan descent, also talks of the Soviet influx.
Standing inside a tent that serves as temporary home to her 2 1/2-year-old daughter and her husband, a tent pitched in the middle of 22 other tents devoted to homeless native-born Israeli families, Mrs. Maman can barely disguise her anger at being evicted from her apartment because she no longer can afford rising rents, driven up by the new demand for housing for the Soviet wave arriving here.
"I have nothing against the immigrants, but I ask for a solution," she said, standing in her dim and poorly heated tent. "They get a year's worth of subsidy the day they arrive, so they can afford to pay $500 rents. What did they do for Israel to deserve it. I served in the army. My husband served. I was born here. I have rights here, but look at the way I live."
Dede Ben-Shitrit is an elected member of the Jerusalem City Council and a campaigner for a volunteer group that cares for the Sephardim, or Middle Eastern Jews, who have been displaced because their small incomes cannot keep up with the rise in housing costs here.
He said there were 70,000 homeless families in Israel.
"I think the immigrants will be next here in those tents once they run out of subsidies from the state," he said.
 
The Jobs
 
A Problem On the Way?
The problems of absorption become particularly complicated when it comes to finding jobs for the newcomers, many of whom are educated but are heavily concentrated in professions like medicine, engineering, music and the arts, fields where Israel already has a plentiful supply.
Israel's most serious problem may be money to support the immigrants and to expand the economy. The Absorption Ministry's 1991 plan suggests that based on patterns of the 400,000 arrivals estimated for 1990, 15.3 percent may be over the age of 60 and therefore will become a net drain on the state's economy and welfare system.
Herman Branover, a professor of physics at the University of Ben-Gurion at Beersheba, said the caliber of Soviet engineers coming in was quite high compared with other professions like medicine, and as such they are a welcome addition.
But he wondered whether jobs could be found for the thousands of engineers, doctors and musicians showing up in Israel every month.
"Even if we established a symphony orchestra in every village we couldn't absorb all the musicians that are pouring in," he said.
To help, Professor Branover, who came from the Soviet Union in 1972, urged the Israeli private sector and Government to multiply the number of high-technology projects and private-sector companies that it has to absorb the new engineering talents. He has established a new Soviet-Israeli venture laboratory for energy problems in the University of Ben-Gurion in Beersheba, in which he has employed a dozen of the new scientists and physicists who came over the last year.
He has also founded the Ofakim Technology Center to spin off private-sector high-tech companies, for the 15 percent of the immigrants estimated to carry degrees in engineering and are unlikely to find employment in existing companies in Israel.
It is far too early to tell whether Israel will have a serious problem in making jobs available to its newcomers. But the problem does not appear to be immediate for two reasons.
Virtually all those who arrive in Israel receive a generous stipend for living that carries them for a year. It averages $1,000 a month for a family of three. And many are already refocusing their skills in related fields, and the Soviet immigrants, by and large, have proved to be a resourceful lot, with many relatives who appear more than willing to help.
Though he conceded he had had an easier time than others, Dr. Pichkhadze, whose wife is a music teacher, said his sister, who has lived here for 18 years, obtained the two-bedroom apartment where he lives almost as soon as he arrived.
With the stipend he gets from the Government, he could afford the rent, and his two daughters and son will receive schooling for free.
"All I need to do is learn the language," he said. "With my 20 years' experience and many relatives who are doctors, I am 100 percent confident I will find a job. Maybe other, younger doctors will have problems but this country seems to be like a sponge. Will it absorb all these people? I guess so. They say they can absorb two million."
Asked what he thought of the problems of the Sephardim native Israeli Jews who are showing up in tents as they lose their apartments to the higher rents that immigrants like him can pay with Government subsidies, Dr. Pichkhadze said: "We are not getting anything for free. We will have to pay everything with our sweat. I feel some sympathy for those people, but right now everyone is paying a price."
 
The Politics
 
Wooing Voters In a New Arena
On Thursday, Israelis were amused to learn from the television that former Prime Minister Shimon Peres, leader of the oppositiosn Labor Party, was learning Russian, presumably because the Labor Party hopes to attract many of the immigrants to its ranks.
Although much has been made of the fact that most of the new Soviet immigrants would be leaning to the right, it is far from clear yet what political convictions the arriving Soviet Jews hold and how those convictions will change when they consider issues like Palestinian nationalism, war with Iraq, and the Arab-Israeli conflict.
What is clear is that for most, Israel is something of an invulnerable force capable to standing up to any challenge, a place that is much safer than the Soviet homeland they came from.
David Kreizelman, director of the visiting journalists department of Israel's Government press office, said, "They have a somewhat mythical sense of Israel's strength."

HEADLINE: Ever Elusive, O'Neill Left His Mark

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Jan. 8

 BODY:
William A. O'Neill will leave office on Wednesday having served longer than any Connecticut governor in 180 years. Yet even after a full decade on the state's highest public stage, he remains an elusive figure, and even some of the people he is closest to say they do not know him very well.
His gaffes with the language, his stiff public manner and modest, even self-effacing style all veiled what friends and associates said was a powerful intellect seldom glimpsed by the public or the political opponents who disparaged and sometimes made fun of him. 
 In private, Mr. O'Neill, a Democrat, is said to be a witty man capable of discussing the nuances of 17th-century European history. In public he was more noted for his malapropisms and fumbles, as when he congratulated the Trumbull Little League team for "returning the World Series championship to the United States after six years of abstinence"; or, commenting on the arts, said, "I enjoy some Shakespeare, but I also enjoy plays."
The achievements of his long career have similarly been clouded by a turn of fortune that has dumped Connecticut on the doorstep of a budget crisis and a recession in Mr. O'Neill's final months. According to the most recent opinion surveys, conducted just before the November election by the University of Connecticut, more than 70 percent of the 522 people interviewed thought he had done only a fair or poor job in office. Only 2 percent said he had been an excellent governor.
As his popularity slipped last year, he decided not to seek another term.
 
Broad Changes in Government
 Mr. O'Neill, however, is leaving Connecticut's government vastly changed from what he found on Dec. 31, 1980, when as a 50-year-old Lieutenant Governor he grimly took the oath of office to replace Gov. Ella T. Grasso, who had just resigned and was dying of cancer.
In size alone, the state budget bears Mr. O'Neill's stamp: It increased from $3 billion in 1981 to a projected $8 billion for the fiscal year that begins on July 1. The state also had to take on huge new responsibilities in regulation and administration as the Federal Government's role in state affairs receded under President Reagan. The road and bridge system was rebuilt. An expansion of the prison system was begun.
Asked in an interview, however, how he hoped to be remembered, Mr. O'Neill mentioned none of those things.
"I would like, certainly, to be remembered as an honest man -- that I was a man of very high integrity," he said.
 
Judgment of History
 Some of those who have watched Mr. O'Neill's career say history will ultimately redeem the Governor, mainly because historians will distill out the quirks of personality and image that seem so prominent now and will lift from his shoulders the blame for some things that were perhaps not his fault, such as the regional economic downturn.
"Ten or twenty years from now, no one will know about those things," Everett C. Ladd, a professor of political science at the University of Connecticut, said of Mr. O'Neill's awkward public persona. "What they'll see is a very decisive record, a strong image that will grow as years go by."
Some senior Democrats and Republicans also say that Mr. O'Neill may ultimately be remembered as the man who helped elect Connecticut's first independent governor since the Civil War, Lowell P. Weicker Jr.
They say that Mr. O'Neill's personal feud last year with his party's nominee for governor, Bruce A. Morrison, almost certainly eroded Mr. Morrison's support and encouraged some Democrats to desert their party for Mr. Weicker's independent candidacy.
 
Criticism of Morrison
 Mr. Weicker, a former Republican Senator who ran under the banner of his own Connecticut Party, beat the Republican, John G. Rowland, by less than 33,000 votes, largely with the help of Democrats, according to surveys conducted after the election.
Mr. Morrison, who was regularly criticized by Mr. O'Neill during the campaign as a candidate who probably could not win, got barely 20 percent of the vote, even though the Democratic Party is the largest in the state.
"I think it was a large factor," Mr. Rowland's former press secretary, Jack R. Goldberg, said of Mr. O'Neill's role.
Mr. O'Neill steadfastly denies trying to swing the governor's race, though he has acknowledged on several occasions that he believes Mr. Weicker's independent administration, with its mix of Democrats and Republicans, is preferable to the purely Republican administration that Mr. Rowland would have brought to Hartford.
 
The Old Rules
 Mr. O'Neill's allies say the Governor's actions toward Mr. Morrison during the campaign reveal the character of a man who came of age in an earlier time, when party elders were respected and party rules obeyed. It was a system that nurtured Mr. O'Neill from his days in the General Assembly as a lawmaker from East Hampton in the 1960's, through his rise as House majority leader, state party chairman, lieutenant governor, and finally, as governor.
"The Governor lived by certain rules in politics," said John F. Droney Jr., the state Democratic Party chairman. "One of those rules was that you never challenge a sitting incumbent."
When Mr. Morrison openly challenged Mr. O'Neill, who had planned to run for third term, the Governor could not forgive or forget, Mr. Droney said.
"He saw it as a mortal sin," Mr. Droney said. The Governor withdrew from the race for re-election in March as his popularity fell.
Yet Mr. O'Neill professes no bitterness and -- as he has said throughout his career -- no regrets about the path not taken.
 
Sad and Joyous
 "It's a relief, to be quite frank," he said of his final days in office. "It's a sad time also, but it's a joyous time. It's a combination of everything, like any kind of phase that you might go through in your life."
Mr. O'Neill's departure ends a chapter for Connecticut's Democrats, who have ruled the governor's office here for 36 of the last 40 years. He may also represent the last in a long line of Connecticut governors who have stood firm and fast against the introduction of a state income tax on wages.
Mr. Weicker has said that an income tax may ultimately prove inevitable, and that in any event the issue is now one of practical economic and fiscal considerations rather than deep-seated political dogma. A Democrat selected by Mr. Weicker as his top budget adviser, William J. Cibes Jr. -- long an O'Neill stalwart himself over the years -- openly favors taxing wages as a fairer and more workable system of raising revenue.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
String of Dow Losses: Sign of an Off Year?

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
With worries growing that no peaceful resolution is possible in the Mideast, the stock market has gotten off to its second-worst start in history.
Only in 1978, when a plunging dollar and fears of rampant inflation were scaring investors, has the Dow Jones industrial average started off on such a downbeat. That year, it fell 5.6 percent in the first five trading days. 
 So far this year, the average is down 4.7 percent, having fallen 124.25 points, to 2,509.41. The Dow lost 13.36 points yesterday, its fifth consecutive decline.
The selloff has been general, with only one Dow stock, Navistar International, showing a gain for the year. The truck manufacturer is up 50 cents, to $2.75 a share, so far.
Some of the worst performers were winners in previous years: Coca-Cola, Philip Morris and Procter & Gamble, the best Dow performers in each of the last two years, have lost more than 5 percent of their value in 1991.
Smaller stocks, which performed far worse than larger stocks last year, have fallen less than the Dow so far in 1991, with the Nasdaq composite off 4 percent and the Russell 2,000 down 3.5 percent.
The declines have come with relatively little institutional selling, and desultory volume.
"You've had the worst possible combination for the brokers, low prices and lower volume," said Laszlo Birinyi of Birinyi Associates, a stock research concern. "People are selling their large two- or three-year winners, figuring they won't have to pay taxes on the profits until April 15, 1992."
Wall Street's focus on events in the Mideast began in July, when oil prices began to rise as Iraq threatened Kuwait. From its all-time peak of 2,999.75 in mid-July, the Dow declined gradually until a selloff began after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, an act that sent oil prices spiraling upward.
But in the last several months of 1990, other factors drew investors' attention, and there was a lot of hope that a peaceful resolution would be found. Many money managers in private conversations said they thought a war, if it came, would cause a sharp break in prices that would create a buying opportunity, especially if the war ended with a quick American victory.
Instead, as the Jan. 15 deadline for Iraq's withdrawal approached with bellicose talk and no sign of either side backing down, stock prices eroded, without strong selling pressure but with little buying interest. Still, the Dow is 6.1 percent above the low it reached last October.
The 1991 selloff has not been limited to the American market. Since the year began, Japan's Nikkei average of 225 issues is down 4 percent, Britain's FT-SE index 2 percent, and Germany's DAX index 3.2 percent. The German mark has also been especially weak, reacting to rising concerns over both the Mideast and the Soviet Union. Adjusted for currency valuations, German stocks have dropped even further than their American counterparts.
 One longstanding market indicator forecasts that the first five trading sessions of a year serve as an indicator of what kind of year it will be. That indicator has worked in 49 of the 76 years since the Dow was revamped in late 1914, and it would seem to indicate that there is a better than average chance that this will be a bad year.
But the good news for bulls is that the indicator has run into a bad streak in recent years, failing to forecast the direction of the Dow for the rest of the year in 8 of the last 10 years. One of those years in which it failed was 1987, when the Dow rose 5.6 percent in the first five trading days, its third-best start ever. That year continued to look great until October, when the crash wiped out all the gains.
Of the eight years prior to this one that the Dow fell at least 2 percent in the first five trading days, the index managed to rise in the remainer of the year in half the cases, including two years, 1922 and 1955, that saw gains of more than 20 percent.
In 1978, the year the Dow got off to its worst start, prices continued lower for several weeks, but rallied sharply in the spring, and the year ended with the average up 2.6 percent from its level after the first five days.

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Dinkin's Speech: 'Forge Ahead'

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from Mayor David N. Dinkins's State of the City Message:
 Eight months ago, as we nervously surveyed the prospects for a difficult summer, I stood before many of you in this same chamber to urge that you join me in a campaign for harmony, tolerance and understanding. You, and all the people of our city, responded overwhelmingly. 
 Your response lifted us out of a dark season of fear and suspicion and carried us to a brighter day as we discovered in each other a unity of purpose. That sense of brother and sisterhood led us to join hands with Nelson and Winnie Mandela a few weeks later to celebrate the spirit that only freedom can bring. As a result, instead of suffering through a summer of hatred, we reveled in a moment of hope, openness and joy. It is my fondest wish that, before my stewardship is concluded, that moment will come to define the state of our city.
We have begun to create a new kind of government in the past year, a government that draws its strength from the diversity of our people and, in turn, has formed a partnership with them. It is a government that treats each of its citizens fairly, a government that will not abandon a single neighborhood in the shadow. . . .
I have witnessed the strength of our people so many times during the course of this year -- in the compassion of a volunteer providing food to homeless people outside Grand Central Terminal; in the courage of a police officer lying wounded in Kings County Hospital; in the eyes of a young student receiving a diploma at Springfield Gardens High School.
But I have also experienced bitter disappointment; the ever-growing pain of the Federal Government's abandonment of our cities; the violence that stole from us hundreds of our people, so many of them children; an international economic contraction that has forced us to scale back our expectations dramatically.
We will not allow these burdens to limit our vision of the future. This administration will take whatever measures may be necessary to guarantee that we retain the freedom to reach for our dreams, to preserve our ability to overcome whatever disappointments may come our way.
We face difficult obstacles. But in three categories of the public agenda we must not only forge ahead but also win decisive victories: We must maintain our fiscal integrity as we steer our city toward a new era of economic growth; we must guarantee public safety, and we must open the door to the future for our children.
Our economy has contracted at a breathtaking pace, and it shows no sign yet of recovery. Thousands of city employees will lose their jobs in the coming months because the size of our government must fit the size of our rapidly declining economy. However, before we eliminate any essential service, we must first cut out the fat, and we have already begun.
In the future, ours will be a smaller government, but a stronger one, more creative, more productive and more responsive, one able to cope with the rapid changes the rest of this decade will surely bring. And more importantly, it will be our government. By spending no more than we take in, we will maintain our fiscal integrity -- and will avoid losing control to outside monitors. The people of our city elected us to take and make the difficult choices, enlightened by our sensitivity to their needs. We will not seek to escape that responsibility. And until our economy rebounds, we will rely on our resourcefulness to protect those who need help the most.
This is no time for despair. Though our prospects may seem dim at the moment, a rebound is coming, and it will be based on the wealth of resources that we sometimes, in our gloom, overlook.
In a time of economic stress, we must also provide for that most fundamental of civil rights, freedom from fear. We have begun the massive task of redirecting our police force to reinforce our neighborhood-based institutions through the concept of community policing. We anticipate early and favorable action from the Legislature. . . . The legislators know we need the cops, and they share our desire to help our kids through the education, recreation and jobs programs embodied in our plan.
With the police working hand in hand with our communities, we will take back the night and drive away the fear.
We are reaching out to help our neediest children. For many who had no names, we opened nearly 4,000 apartments this year for them and their parents -- permanent, clean and safe places to live -- and we have provided care for 3,900 other homeless families. We will not abandon them.
We must free our children to rise as far as their dreams permit them. We must let them hear the words of Langston Hughes: "O, sweep of stars over Harlem streets, O, little breath of oblivion that is night. Reach up your hand, child, and take a star. Out of the little breath of oblivion that is night, take just one star."
We have made a new beginning. As we pass through difficult times, we will maintain our fiscal stability so that we may assure our children, and all our people, of a safer, healthier tomorrow. We look forward to our journey with optimism, understanding and faith in one another, for we know that we will arrive at a brighter day together.
I thank you for listening.
I thank you for caring.
God bless you all.
Keep the faith.

HEADLINE: Florio's Gamble;
No New Taxes but Talk of Benefits: The Governor Tries Damage Control

BYLINE: By PETER KERR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 8

 BODY:
One year ago, Gov. Jim Florio said his goal was to save the State of New Jersey from what he saw as the failures of his predecessors. This year, both Democrats and Republicans say his goal is to save his party and himself.
 In his State of the State speech tonight, Mr. Florio outlined his plans for a year of political repair work, a time to introduce generally modest programs intended to win back the voters that he alienated last year with a series of tax increases totaling $2.8 billion. 
 But considering the depths of Mr. Florio's political failures in his first year in office, a state economy sliding into recession and a state budget facing as much as a $600 million shortfall, politicians here say his goal of winning back support for Democrats in time for legislative elections in November appears a long shot.
Shortly after taking office last year, Mr. Florio made an unusual political wager: He gambled that a politician who raised taxes to attack the state's most serious problems would be rewarded by voters for his courage. In fact, most politicians here now agree that Mr. Florio grossly misread the public mood in 1990 and overestimated his ability to reach the hearts and minds of average people as they faced increasingly hard times.
 
'The Message Was Too Complex'
 "We all know now that he misjudged the public reaction," said Senator Gabriel M. Ambrosio, a Democrat from Bergen County and a longtime supporter. "Communications were bad. The message was too complex. We never got across that the Governor felt what people were feeling."
In his speech tonight, Mr. Florio offered a host of programs he hopes will have political appeal, including plans to use hundreds of millions of dollars from a state trust fund for new highway construction and the creation of 7,000 new jobs, a $250 million program to help middle-income residents buy their first homes, an end to the state's unpopular system of car inspections, and a savings-bond program to help families send their children to college.
What the proposals have in common is what they are not: They do not raise taxes, they are not controversial, they are modest compared with last year's agenda.
"This is mostly 'mom and apple pie' kind of stuff," Sen. William L. Gormley, a Republican from Atlantic County, said of Mr. Florio's announcements. "He is trying to soften his negatives. It might work over three years. I have trouble believing he can undo everything in one year."
 
Hoping for Appreciation
 In his first six months in office last year, Mr. Florio proposed and the Legislature approved bills that raised the sales and income taxes, banned assault weapons and overhauled the state's auto insurance system. This year, the administration hopes that some voters will come to appreciate benefits from those programs, including property-tax rebates and a promised 20 percent reduction in automobile insurance premiums.
But other factors make it an uphill struggle for Mr. Florio and the Democrats to convince voters to re-elect Democratic majorities in the Legislature, particularly in the Assembly, where the Democratic majority is precarious.
First is the powerful negative image Mr. Florio conveyed to the public last year: a man who would not listen as he pursued policies that many people did not understand. Many supporters, including some in his administration, blame his poor communications for losing the support of all but one in five voters.
It took weeks after the tax package was passed last year, for example, for the administration to release a chart showing that only 17 percent of New Jerseyans would pay higher income taxes. By then, many moderate-income residents were furious about a program that Mr. Florio said was designed to benefit them.
 
Seeming Refusal to Listen
 Perhaps more important, Republican critics say, is that Mr. Florio assumed that the public was willing to trust government to ease its burdens, when, in fact, it was more likely that government would be distrusted and blamed.
Christine Todd Whitman, the Republican candidate for the United States Senate who rode anti-tax sentiment to a near victory against Senator Bill Bradley in November, said that Mr. Florio had offended voters not just by raising taxes but by appearing to refuse to listen. Mrs. Whitman said that his promise tonight to shrink the number of state government departments would probably be met with distrust unless it were accompanied by an outside audit.
In addition, even though Mr. Florio said tonight that New Jersey would weather the recession better than its neighbors because of the effort to balance the budget with increased taxes last year, the worsening economy is expected to force him to lay off thousands of state workers and bring accusations from Republicans that the taxes have only made matters worse.
With economists predicting sharp rises in unemployment this year, Mr. Florio may find it even harder to explain to suburban voters why he pushed a tax program that shifted hundreds of millions of dollars from suburbs to poor city school districts.
 
Democrats Demand Revision
 Powerful evidence of the unease among Democrats about the Florio tax package came this week, when the Democratic President of the Senate, John A. Lynch, proposed shifting $450 million designated for poorer school districts to a new program of property tax relief aimed foremost at suburban homeowners.
In explaining their proposal today, Mr. Lynch and the Senate Majority Leader, Daniel J. Dalton, said that the Florio program, which they voted for, was ill-conceived as passed. Implicit in their statements was the threat that if Mr. Florio did not revise the program sufficiently, they would force him to.
Nonetheless, Democratic legislators argue that if the recession turns out to be relatively mild and if the benefits Mr. Florio promised last year are delivered to voters, the party could see an upturn in its fortunes.
"A year is an awfully long time in politics," Senator Ambrosio said. "A year ago we were on top of the world. Look at how quickly things can change."
