HEADLINE: With Tight Budgets, Dinkins and Florio Speak of Hope;
Florio Promises Jobs, Not Higher Taxes, To Help Economy

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 8

 BODY:
Faced with both recession and voters' hostility, Gov. Jim Florio tonight outlined a 1991 agenda centered on a jobs program to be fueled by new state construction projects and mortgage help for first-time homebuyers.
The Governor, who pushed through the biggest tax increase in New Jersey history just seven months ago, told the state's disgruntled voters that New Jersey could not "tax its way out of a troubled economy." 
 Instead, in his annual State of the State Message, he outlined a program to create some 7,000 new jobs through an expanded program of state highway and related construction to be financed from existing trust funds that are not included in the state's operating budget.
He also unveiled an agreement with the Federal National Mortgage Association that would provide $250 million in reduced-cost mortgages for "middle-class, first-time" homebuyers. That, he said, would help "jump start" the sagging economy and create new jobs by spurring new homebuilding, which is at a near standstill.
 
After Turbulent Year
 But even as he outlined objectives of his administration, the Governor also took pains to defend the actions of the past year, the most turbulent for a New Jersey governor since Brendan T. Byrne began the state income tax in 1977.
"Nineteen ninety, to say the least, wasn't a year for the fainthearted," Mr. Florio told a joint session of the Legislature and a statewide television audience.
"There was," he conceded, "a lot of controversy, much of it because we had to raise taxes."
He had, he said, "moved much faster than many people were prepared to move," and he also conceded that there was "some truth" to suggestions that "we didn't explain what we did as well as we could."
 
Criticism From G.O.P.
 He was interrupted by applause 48 times by the audience, which consisted of people invited by Mr. Florio and the legislative leaders.
Republican leaders were less generous. The Assembly minority leader, Garabed Haytaian of Hackettstown, said the Governor had failed to achieve the political initiative that he had sought.
"The people won't accept it," he said. "He didn't talk about what's on everybody's mind, and that's a $2.8 billion tax increase."
The Senate minority leader, John H. Dorsey of Mountain Lakes, also said the Governor's glancing reference to the tax increase would alienate voters.
"Bill Bradley learned that," he said, referring to the Senator's cliff-hanger victory in November, which he conceded had resulted from his refusal to discuss taxes.
But the Governor, as he has for the last seven months, insisted that his $2.8 billion tax increase, derived from a one-cent increase in the sales tax and higher income tax rates for the state's highest-earning residents, were both necessary and farsighted.
"The steps we took prepare us to move ahead to make 1991 a year where we deliver on the promises of 1990 and find new ways to make life better for our people."
The Governor leavened his address with personal allusions.
Saying he knows that "a lot of people are worried about the future," he invoked the example of "a young couple I know -- Greg and Ann."
Both work, he said, they have "two lovely children," and they have just bought an "old house that needs lots of fixing up."
"Their lives are a constant juggling of work schedules and child care," he said, and "late at night, when the kids are asleep they spend their little spare time painting the upstairs."
"Greg happens to be my son" he said, "but he could be anyone's son," and "He's nervous about the future. Who wouldn't be?"
Mr. Florio also referred to several other famillies across the state with whom he has held widely publicized "fireside chats" aimed at defusing anger over the tax increases.
These families voiced concerns over mounting college costs, educational quality, recession, shaky retirement prospects and other questions, the Governor said.
 
'I'm Not Buying That!'
 "In New Jersey," he insisted, "we're prepared with the answers." And in a combative note in a basically conciliatory address, Mr. Florio said, "The prophets of doom and gloom want to hang out a sigh that says, 'Welcome to hard times.' "
"Well, I'm not buying that!" he said. "As far as I'm concerned they can hang that sign someplace else."
"Because in New Jersey we worked too hard last year to make this state a good place to live."
The Governor said the state's credit rating was "No. 1 in the nation" and insisted that "businesses are moving in."
He gave only one proposal stemming from the findings transmitted to the Governor so far during a sweeping audit of state government functions, saying only that "Our Audit Commission is showing us ways to save money."
The one item was an announcement that, in line with a commission recommendation, the state will scrap its government-operated system of free automobile safety inspections and instead contract with private companies to make the inspections, possibly for a fee. Mr. Florio's aides said details would be announced on Wednesday.
The Governor also renewed a pledge that insurance reform in the state would eliminate a $220 surcharge to pay for the state's discontinued system of paying claims for high-risk drivers and again insisted that property tax increases would stop and "homestead rebates will go up for hundreds of thousands of people."
 
Tuition Assistance
 As part of a continuing and long-delayed effort to revitalize Atlantic City, Mr. Florio said he would go there on Wednesday to discuss efforts to turn the city's airport into a "world-class" airport. It is expected that he will announce that the state is buying the airport from the city, in an effort to make the airport more attractive for a major air carrier to provide expanded service.
He also pledged to push legislation that would help with college tuition for middle-income families through the issuing of discounted savings bonds to build a nest egg for college and through loans of up to $5,000 a year at "fixed, reasonable rates."
He also promised continued efforts to enforce the state's 7-year-old death penalty law, under which no one has been executed but which he has maintained is frustrated by lengthy court challenges that make executions all but impossible, to "double our current resources for child care" and to replace the state's expensive health care fund for uninsured hospital patients, which expired at the end of the year, with a new, more efficient and less expensive system.
And while he pledged to pare down and streamline state government, in part by combining the functions of some of the 19 administrative departments, he provided no details of how that would be done, saying instead that proposals would be announced soon.

HEADLINE: Urban League Urges Action

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8

 BODY:
The National Urban League today urged action by the Bush Administration and Congress to stimulate the economy, saying black Americans were in a "permanent recession" and would bear the brunt of hard economic times.
In its 16th annual report on the state of black America, the civil rights organization also urged passage of civil rights legislation introduced in Congress last week. 
 "We are already in an economic slowdown," the organization's president, John E. Jacob, said at a news conference, "but African-Americans have been in a permanent recession.
"We had double-digit unemployment rates throughout the supposedly good times of the 1980's, and past experience shows that in a nationwide recession the racial gap in employment becomes wider and more severe. So I urge the Administration and the Congress to do whatever is necessary to prevent a prolonged recession, and to insure that the burdens of a downturn do not widen the terrible racial and class divisions in our society."
Democratic Party leaders in Congress have begun talking about anti-recessionary programs, like greater spending for highway construction, to stem unemployment. But President Bush said in a recent television interview he would veto such a measure.
Writing in the league's report, David H. Swinton, dean of the School of Business at Jackson State University in Mississippi, said, "If this downturn has an impact similar to the last few recessions, African-Americans will bear a disproportionate share of its hardships."
Quoting Census Bureau figures, Dr. Swinton said blacks receive about three-fifths as much income per person as whites and are three times as likely to have annual incomes below the Federally defined poverty level of $12,675 for a family of four.
The report also said the American military deployment in the gulf could lead to racial inequality, with blacks paying a greater cost than whites in lost lives and lost leadership.
Mr. Jacob said Mr. Bush must prepare for his re-election campaign "in the context of trying to lead the world in a moral crusade against aggression, a crusade that rests on the power of our armed forces, almost half of whom are black, Hispanic or women."

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 5; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 980 words

HEADLINE: With Tight Budgets, Dinkins and Florio Speak of Hope;
Dinkins Sees Rebound But Offers Few Details To Curb Fiscal Woes

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
As his administration grappled with New York City's most serious fiscal problems since the mid-1970's, Mayor David N. Dinkins offered a message of hope in his first State of the City address, but provided few indications of how the administration would master its budget woes.
"This is no time for despair," Mr. Dinkins said in a speech before hundreds of elected officials and invited guests in the City Council Chamber. "Though our prospects may seem dim at the moment, a rebound is coming, and it will be based on the wealth of resources that we sometimes, in our gloom, overlook." 
 In his 32-minute speech, Mr. Dinkins repeatedly talked of the hope, openness, joy, courage and the heroism he has seen in individual New Yorkers. He said the city needs to look to a brighter future, beyond the current recession that has seen city revenues fall and demands grow for social services for the poor.
 
Preserving Fiscal Stability
 He also called for strengthening laws for juveniles arrested for crimes, to "make sure the punishment fits the crime." He raised the possibility of a march on Washington for stronger gun-control legislation, and called on legislators in Washington and Albany to reduce the mandated programs that increase the city's costs.
In addressing a budget gap that could reach $2.5 billion over the next 18 months, Mr. Dinkins said that the budget would be "cut to the bone" to preserve fiscal stability. He said he wanted to make sure that the State's Financial Control Board, which monitors city finances, does not step in.
But much of his speech was devoted to a recitation of how the city's current adversity could pave the way for a brighter future. He noted that depressed real-estate values here made New York a less expensive place to live in than 40 other cities around the world.
"Because our neighboring states and counties have raised their taxes much faster than ours to solve their own budget problems," Mr. Dinkins said, "no one has to move out of the cultural and commercial capital of the world."
 
Speech Is Not Mandated
 Unlike the President's State of the Union Message or the New York Governor's State of the State Message, the State of City address is not mandated by charter, law or custom. Former Mayor Edward I. Koch started it in 1979, abandoned it in some years, and took it up in others. Mr. Dinkins chose not to deliver the address last year, using his inaugural speech, instead, to present the goals of his administration.
Under Mr. Koch, who governed during an era of rising city tax revenues, the speech, usually delivered in late January, was chock-full of new programs -- sometimes vaguely described -- in areas from the homeless to policing.
Mr. Dinkins chose to deliver the address in early January, a week before the deadline for the submission of a financial plan that will lay out service cuts that have already prompted angry demonstrations at City Hall and firehouses. But with almost no money for new programs, Mr. Dinkins focused on long-term goals and enduring ideals instead.
He ended his address with a Reaganesque touch, citing six city residents, who "have come to the aid of their fellow New Yorkers."
The list included community organizers, bystanders who rescued children from a fire and an advocate for the homeless. The Mayor said that they would receive a mayoral "gorgeous mosaic" award, an allusion to an image Mr. Dinkins often uses to describe New Yorkers' varied ethnic and racial communities.
But as he depicted his vision of the city's future, Mr. Dinkins was unable to summon the former President's common touch. His delivery was earnest, but when he began speaking he found the teleprompter hard to see, and rarely looked up from his papers.
Mr. Dinkins began speaking at 5:04 P.M. at a podium set up in the City Council Chamber, before a backdrop of American and New York City flags. Sixteen palm trees and ferns were trucked in from a Parks Department greenhouse from Forest Park in Woodhaven, Queens, for the occasion.
He received sometimes polite applause 11 times, until the final moments, when he listed the recipients of his "gorgeous mosaic" award. When he paused for applause and none followed, he said, "I think you should applaud them." The speech was broadcast live on five television stations.
 
Notable Absences
 It was Mr. Dinkins's fourth major televised address since his inauguration. Reflecting, perhaps, the lonely and difficult choices a mayor must make, many who cheered Mr. Dinkins at his inauguration were absent.
Many City Council seats were filled by staff members. Borough Presidents Claire Shulman of Queens and Howard Golden of Brooklyn were absent; the City Comptroller, Elizabeth Holtzman, was on vacation, and only a handful of the Congressmen and state legislators who were expected were present.
The address came as the Dinkins administration has been preparing hundreds of millions of dollars in budget cuts to close a gap of as much as $2.5 billion over the next 18 months. With so much bad news in the offing, Mr. Dinkins chose to reiterate the administration's achievements.
The speech was written by Albert Scardino, Mr. Dinkins's press secretary, and Maria Laurino, a former writer for The Village Voice, who was hired as Mr. Dinkins's chief speech writer last October.
For months, the administration has been under attack by critics, including Felix G. Rohatyn, the departing chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, who say the administration's response to the fiscal problems has been ambiguous and inconsistent.
Peter F. Vallone, Speaker of the City Council, said the Council would stand beside Mr. Dinkins in his efforts to solve the city's fiscal problems. "This is a very difficult time to make a speech and rally people," he said, "but the Mayor has the best of intentions."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "This is no time for despair," said Mayor David N. Dinkins, looking hopefully toward the future in his first State of the City address yesterday at City Hall. (Angel Franco/The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (96%);

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Speech By New Jersey Governor

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 8

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from Gov. Jim Florio's State of the State Message:
Nineteen ninety, to say the least, wasn't a year for the faint-hearted.
 There was a lot of controversy. Much of it because we had to raise taxes. And that's never easy. We moved much faster than many people were prepared to move. 
 Some say we didn't explain what we did as well as we could. There may be some truth to that.
But the steps we took prepare us to move ahead to make 1991 a year where we deliver on the promises of 1990 and find new ways to make life better for our people. Tonight I stand here proud of New Jersey and its people, proud of what we've done to prepare for our future.
I know a lot of people are worried about that future.
Change is sweeping the world. It's unsettling. A national recession puts prosperity and opportunity to the test. People everywhere want to know: Is government on my side or in my way?
People have a right to ask these questions.
But let me make it very clear. In New Jersey, we're prepared with answers.
Because in New Jersey we worked too hard last year to make this state a good place to live.
We're ready.
We made choices others are just starting to face up to.
In 1991 we're the strongest state in the region.
Our credit rating's No. 1 in the nation.
Businesses are moving in.
We're going to grow, and build and create jobs for people who want to work.
In 1990, we laid a firm foundation for 1991. More important, we're ready to deliver on our promises because we listened, and we changed things that needed changing.
We need an inspector general to take aim at corruption and waste.
A state that cracks down on those who pollute our water should do no less with those who steal from our children.
In 1990 we started to take a long overdue look at state government. Our Audit Commission is showing us ways to save money. But it also tells us we can be smarter in the way we do what needs to be done.
So I'm announcing tonight that I've accepted the Audit Commission's recommendation to end the car inspection system as it now exists. We can contract with private firms and do only the air pollution testing that's required by Federal law. We'll sacrifice nothing in safety.
We'll keep in mind two goals.
First, having government as small as it can be and still doing what it has to do.
Second, making sure what we do makes sense -- common sense.
That means government should have the courage to do what it must do and the wisdom to get out of the way when someone else can do it better.
Right now our government is like the fellow who drinks, smokes, eats too much and wonders why his doctor is so upset.
Nineteen ninety was a year when a lot of people got involved. From my office I could hear the drama unfold on the steps of the State House. One day some people would come down and say: spend more money on arts, on the colleges on agriculture.
Another day, another group would come. Just as vocal. Just as committed. But insisting we spend less on everything.
A conflict? Sure. It's called democracy. Sometimes it's loud, sometimes it's messy, but it works.
So let me conclude by stressing again: 1990 was about investing; 1991 is about dividends.
March 17: no more ocean dumping.
April 1: no more J.U.A. surcharge.
July 31: Homestead rebates of up to $500.
Tuition help for the middle class.
Home ownership for more of our people.
A more sensible car inspection system.
Leaner government.
New roads.
And jobs.
Let's all work together; there's a lot to do. We have something good here in New Jersey. Something that is worth keeping.

HEADLINE: NEW YORK EASING CITY WATER RULES

BYLINE: By ALLAN R. GOLD

 BODY:
Reversing their position, New York State health officials have determined that New York City will be able to guarantee the safety of its drinking water for many years without having to spend billions of dollars to filter it.
The State Health Department had proposed that the city begin filtering the water it receives from six Catskill reservoirs by the year 2005. They supply the city with 90 percent of its water, long viewed as among the best urban supplies in the world. The proposal followed growing concerns about the future purity of water in the Catskill and Delaware reservoir systems as those areas are developed. 
 But after being pressed by the Dinkins administration and environmentalists to change its stand, the Health Department has agreed that the city's legal actions and regulatory proposals to protect the Catskill and Delaware reservoirs from pollution have been sufficient to avoid the need to build expensive filtration plants. They would have cost the city at least $4 billion, plus more than $200 million a year to operate, the city has estimated.
The Dinkins administration has been moving to preserve the high quality of the city's drinking water by measures that include overhauling more than 35 years of pollution regulations for its reservoir systems.
City officials and experts on the environment have asserted that it would be much cheaper to insure pure drinking water by tightening regulations on the use of the reservoirs' watersheds -- the land around them drained by rivers and streams -- than by building filtration plants. Such regulations may involve limiting construction near reservoirs, restricting agricultural practices like the use of chemicals that could pollute reservoirs, and establishing wide buffer zones between streams and farms to reduce polluted runoff.
Many Catskill residents resent the city's power to control land use in their towns. But a state law passed 86 years ago gave the city the authority to take upstate lands and flood them for reservoirs. The same law allows the city to make rules to insure that the drinking water remains pure.
 
Flowing 100 Miles Away
 The city's 18 reservoirs -- 6 in the Catskill and Delaware systems and 12 in Croton -- supply 1.5 billion gallons of water a day. That water flows from as far as 100 miles away through a gravity-fed network of tunnels and aqueducts. Besides New York City residents, the system supplies people in Orange, Putnam, Ulster and Westchester Counties.
New York City is already building a plant in the Bronx to filter water from its Croton system in Westchester and Putnam Counties, which supplies 10 percent of the water. The plant will cost $600 million to build and $45 million a year to operate. The city was forced to build that plant because the Croton system's water was being degraded by street runoff, sewage and other pollutants. City environmental officials pointed to the Croton watershed in citing the need to protect the Catskill system.
The city's Environmental Protection Commissioner, Albert F. Appleton, has been pressing State Health Commissioner David Axelrod to back away from a draft proposal made in late 1989 that would have required filtration by the year 2005. Yesterday, Mr. Appleton said the lobbying had paid off. "We have demonstrated that the city is serious about watershed control," he said.
 Peter Slocum, a spokesman for Mr. Axelrod, said the State Health Department would "go with a regulation which would not necessarily require filtration as long as the city demonstrated a willingness and ability to adequately protect its watershed." The Health Commissioner made his decision based on a belief in Mr. Appleton's "good faith" and the great expense of filtration, Mr. Slocum said.
 
Trust Fund May Be Needed
 Mr. Slocum said the state would probably require New York City to create and finance a trust dedicated to watershed protection to insure it "fulfills its commitment."
The State Health Department is responsible for carrying out Federal water-quality laws, which were tightened in recent years to require filtration unless strict watershed controls were imposed.
In two weeks, Mr. Appleton said, the Health Department will publish rules allowing New York City to avoid filtration as long as its watershed protection effort goes forward. The decision could be reconsidered at any time.
The city's Department of Environmental Protection is now revising watershed rules. A draft released in September has been poorly received by some Catskill residents, who fear that the new rules would inhibit economic development and badly hurt agriculture.
In particular, residents are concerned about plans to establish wide buffer zones in the watershed to reduce runoff of pollutants. Such zones would be required between streams and certain activities, including farming.

HEADLINE: Many Hispanic Americans Reported In Ill Health and Lacking Insurance

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN

 BODY:
Hispanic Americans lack health insurance more often than any other ethnic group in the United States, according to several reports in today's Journal of the American Medical Association.
They also suffer disproportionately higher incidences of diabetes, high blood pressure, kidney disease, certain cancers and other serious ailments, the reports said. 
 Hispanic Americans are up to three times as likely as non-Hispanic whites to develop diabetes, a disease of unknown cause. The severity of the disease is also greater for Hispanic Americans, with complications like blindness appearing more frequently.
Fewer Hispanic Americans are immunized against measles and other infections, a problem the reports attributes in part to poverty and lower levels of education. Rates of preventable diseases like lead poisoning are higher and violence and narcotic addiction also take a disproportionately high toll among Hispanic men.
Hispanic Americans succumb mostly to the nation's leading killers: heart disease, cancer and stroke. Deaths resulting from cancer of the stomach are twice as high for Hispanic Americans as for non-Hispanic whites. Hispanic Americans also suffer from an excess incidence of cancers of the esophagus, breast, pancreas and cervix.
 
Surgeon General Lead Author
 These and other findings of a disproportionately bad health-care situation for Hispanic Americans appear in an issue of The Journal devoted to the health care of Hispanic Americans. The team was headed by the nation's top-ranking doctors of Hispanic origin, Antonia C. Novello, the Surgeon General of the United States Public Health Service.
The figures, one of the largest compilations yet published on the subject, were obtained from studies in the medical literature and Government reports and surveys. Some data are incomplete, as the reports note. For example, the American Medical Association's Council on Scientific Affairs points out that the United States did not list Hispanic death rates separately until 1988, when the standard death certificate form was changed.
By the year 2000, the reports say, Hispanic Americans are expected to number more than 31 million people, which they say would make it the largest minority group in the United States.
Hispanic Americans are also being unusually hard hit by AIDS. Although Hispanic Americans make up 7.9 percent of the population, they account for 14 percent of reported AIDS cases, with nearly 21 percent of the AIDS cases among women and 22 percent of the AIDS cases among children.
In Puerto Rico, heterosexual transmission of the disease accounts for a higher percentage of the total number of cases than in any other area in the United States.
 
Few Are in Health Professions
 Hispanic Americans are seriously under represented in the health occupations, particularly those requiring higher levels of skill. Fewer than 5 percent of doctors are of Hispanic origin.
In an editorial in the journal, Surgeon General Novello called attention to the diverse populations of Hispanic Americans and the dangers of "uncritical ethnic labeling" of all populations with ancestral ties to Spain, Latin America and the Spanish speaking Caribbean.
Many Hispanics have lived in the United States for centuries and others are new arrivals, and dialects, idioms and vocabulary also vary among subgroups. Not all Hispanic groups suffer equally, the report indicates, with Cuban Americans more likely than the others to have private health insurance, for example.
Inappropriate labels can obscure areas of great need, said Dr. Novello, who eared college and medical degrees in her native Puerto Rico. "Poorly defined groupings can also result in programs that do not respond to actual needs and cultural sensitivities," said a team of authors headed by Dr. Novello.
Dr. Eli Ginzberg, a health economist at Columbia University, wrote in The Journal that the Government began collecting health data based on ethnic background too late to provide adequate measures of the health status of Hispanics, by subgroup and by gender.
Although data are incomplete, the reports said it was clear that more than 70 percent of Hispanics Americans lived in six of the most populous states, California, Texas, New York, Florida, New Jersey and Illinois. Hispanic populations are heavily concentrated in metropolitan centers, particularly the inner cities.
Health-care disparities in states that border Mexico are especially acute, the report said. Dr. David C. Warner of the University of Texas said, "It is unlikely that any other border in the world separates two nations having such variety in health status, entitlements and utiliztion."
Many of those in the Hispanic population along the border live in communities that lack septic tanks, sewers or running water. Outdoor privies commonly abut water wells, making most of the water unfit for consumption. Residents also suffer from water and air pollution and illegal dumping of hazardous wastes.
 
Improvements Are Sought
 El Paso is the only large city along the United States side of the border that has a comprehensive public hospital.
Dr. Warner said Mexico and the United States needed to develop new ways to improve the environment, sanitation and many other health problems and to provide access to basic health care.
Well over one-half of Cuban Americans have private health insurance, the largest percentage among Hispanic Americans, said a team of researchers from the University of Texas Medical Branch at Galveston, the University of California at Los Angeles and the Federal Department of Health and Human Services.
Dr. Fernando M. Trevino of the University of Texas Medical Branch at Galveston, who headed the team, said that more than one-third of Mexican Americans and one-fifth of Puerto Ricans lacked health insurance, as against one-fifth of non-Hispanics blacks and one-tenth of non-Hispanics whites.
 
Failures to Use Care Cited
 Hispanic patients who speak English are more likely to have a regular source of medical care than those who speak only Spanish. But Hispanic Americans who need medical services are often reluctant to use them because of barriers related to culture and language. Also, uninsured Hispanic Americans are less likely to benefit from treatment because their ailments are diagnosed at a more advanced stage.
Dr. Antonio Furino of the University of Texas at San Antonio and Dr. Eric Munoz of the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey in Newark said that although many Hispanic Americans were military veterans and eligible for care from the Veterans Administration, they often failed to use the benefits.
Other authors reported that Hispanic Americans are three times as likely as other groups to receive no prenatal care, thus contributing to deaths and sickness among newborns.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Surgeon General Antonia C. Novello headed a team that found that health and medical problems were disproportionately bad among Hispanic Americans. (Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Consumer Debt Grows Only Slightly

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8

 BODY:
Consumer debt grew by a slim $1.72 billion in November, the Government said today, in another reflection of consumer caution in a weakening economy.
Bill Wood, an economist at Cahners Economics, a forecasting firm in Newton, Mass., said of the seasonally adjusted figure, "It's in line with most of the other indicators of consumer behavior, that they are pulling back a bit." 
 "These are very, very small increases," said Sandra Shaber, an economist with the Futures Group, a Washington consulting firm.
 
Slightly Up From October
 The Federal Reserve said consumer credit grew at a 2.8 percent annual rate, up from a revised 2.2 percent rate in October. The October level was originally reported to have been 2.4 percent.
"The 2.8 percent is less than inflation," which rose at a 3.7 percent annual rate in November, Ms. Shaber said. "The rate of growth in both 1988 and 1989 was nearly 9 percent."
Ms. Shaber attributed the slower pace to consumer caution in the face of a deteriorating economy and the threat of war in the Persian Gulf, as well as to tighter lending restrictions by financial institutions.
Consumer spending represents two-thirds of the nation's economic activity.
 
Fewer Car Loans
 Automobile loans fell for the eighth straight month, down $413 million, or an annual rate of 1.7 percent, after a 3.6 percent drop in October. Car loans have declined every month this year, except for January and March.
While fleet sales propped up the market in early November, sales of the Big Three auto makers -- the General Motors Corporation, the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation -- dropped 24 percent in the final 10 days, compared with the corresponding period of 1989. For all of last year, sales of the Big Three were off 6.8 percent.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Across the South, a Clash of Doubt and Fervor

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BILOXI, Miss., Jan. 8

 BODY:
The electronic sign in front of the Royal d'Iberville Hotel here carries a message that can be found on billboards all over the South.
"Support . . . Support . . . Support Desert Shield!" it flashes out again and again over the broad sandy beach leading down to the waters of the Gulf of Mexico. 
 And to hear the people here and elsewhere in the South, traditionally a fortress of patriotism, there is support for President Bush's demand that Iraq's troops leave Kuwait, by force if necessary.
 
No Rush to War
 But that support often seems to be qualified, hemmed in by doubts and qualms and conditions. It may not be the kind of support likely to see President Bush through a long, difficult war.
"I'm the wife of an Air Force sergeant, and I'll be a good soldier and follow my President on Desert Shield," said Rita Garnier, an office manager at the Royal d'Iberville. "But I say frankly and right up front that I'm against us being over there, that I doubt there's any real reason for us to be involved, and that I have more doubts the longer it all drags on."
In conversations with some 75 people during a weeklong, 1,500-mile journey by car from the shores of the Atlantic near Norfolk, Va., to the shore of the Gulf of Mexico here, the word that came up most often was "doubt."
Other words and phrases were common: "confusion" and "another Vietnam" and "Talk, not fight" and, not least of all, "Go get 'em." But "doubt" was the word most frequently uttered.
 
'I Still Don't Know'
 It was the very first word used in the first of the 75 conversations, a word spoken by Nellie Cutchins of Virginia Beach when she was asked to sum up her thoughts on the American-led operation in the Persian Gulf.
"I want to be a good citizen and support our country," she continued, taking a break from her work as a cleaning woman. "But I keep waiting for somebody to explain to me why we are over there and whether it's worth it. I still don't know, and it's been going on for months. I'm afraid we might be headed for another Vietnam."
The ambivalence that surfaced in informal conversations with Southerners was reflected in the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll, taken Saturday through Monday. It showed that Southerners, like Americans nationwide, were evenly divided on force versus sanctions in the gulf.
Among the respondents, 47 percent of Southerners favored military action if Iraq does not withdraw its troops from Kuwait by the Jan. 15 deadline set by the United Nations, while 47 percent of Southerners preferred to give economic sanctions more time to work. Among Americans nationwide, 46 percent favored military action and 47 percent favored continued sanctions.
The doubt about United States involvement in the gulf was most striking when expressed by military dependents or by members of families with strong ties to the military. Traditionally known for its staunch patriotism, the South is home to an unusually large number of military bases and, further, sends an unusually large percentage of its young people into the armed services.
There are military bases all around Biloxi, just as there are bases around dozens of other Southern towns and cities, all the way back up to Montgomery, Ala., and on to Atlanta and Florence, S.C., and Fayetteville, N.C., and into Virginia Beach and Norfolk. And while each place has its "Support Desert Shield" billboards, each also has its doubters.
 
Will 'Muddy' Politics Kill Her Husband?
 In Fayetteville, home of the elite 82d Airborne Division, one of the first units to head for the Middle East, Belvia Williams worries that her husband, Staff Sgt. Andrew J. Williams 3d, might die fighting for oil and what she calls "muddy" politics rather than to reverse an invasion and violations of human rights.
"The President just hasn't told us enough about why we're there, and that's why I have so many doubts," she said. "And I'm not sure we have negotiated enough. I support our troops, and I certainly support my husband. And I keep to myself in my letters and our few phone calls what I really feel."
In Norfolk, where streets and stores are noticeably quieter because so many ships and troops have sailed for the Middle East, reservations about the possibility of war have divided the Ogdon family.
 
A Father's Pride, A Yellow Ribbon
 A few weeks ago, Glenn Ogdon, a 23-year-old Marine reservist whose military speciality is operating landing craft, was called up.
His father, Donald, a retired psychology professor, was proud to see Glenn go. He recalls wishing him him well and saying, "War is a terrible thing, but we've got to stop Hussein."
Then the professor went out and tied a yellow ribbon around a tree in the front yard.
Glenn's 20-year-old brother, Don, a rock musician, went out and slapped a new bumper sticker on his car. It reads: "War Is Costly. Peace Is Priceless."
"It's a war over oil -- oil that we wouldn't need if we'd just spend war money on energy research," Don argued.
"It's a war to stop a madman," his father countered.
The two agree on one thing: If war comes and does not end quickly, there will be demonstrators in the streets.
"And I'll be one of them," Don said.
In Montgomery, Morris Dees, a leading civil rights lawyer, put it another way: "I believe we have to do something about Hussein, and I hope talk will do the job. But if it comes to war, George Bush better hope it goes the way Rambo would do it."
Thus far, only Atlanta, a city with many residents born outside the South, has seen big peace demonstrations. They have been organized in good part by the Rev. McKinley Young, pastor of Big Bethel African Methodist Episcopal Church, one of the city's major black churches.
Mr. Young contends that United States troops have been sent to defend "the richest refugees in the world -- Kuwaiti oil sheiks" and that President Bush showed "extreme insensitivity" by setting a Jan. 15 deadline for Iraq to get out of Kuwait.
"What he's done," Mr. Young said," is make Martin Luther King's birthday the equivalent of D-Day for a war in which blacks will suffer the most. Blacks have been forced by lack of other opportunities to volunteer for our army in disproportionate numbers, and so they'll die in disproportionate numbers. If any military person seeks refuge in our church, we will try to help him or her."
Most Southern blacks seem not to attach any racial or "third world" connotation to United States involvement in the Middle East. However, from a broader standpoint, many seem concerned about the disproportionately high number of blacks in the armed services and what that means, in a war there or anywhere else. Nationally, 29 percent of blacks said they favored military action in the gulf instead of giving sanctions more time to work, according to the Times/ CBS News Poll. Forty-eight percent of whites favored military action.
On Sunday, Mr. Young declared in his sermon, "Oil and land are never more important than people." Then he and several hundred parishioners wrote antiwar letters and cards and mailed them to members of Congress.
That night, at the First Presbyterian Church, a mostly white congregation in Atlanta, there was a candlelight vigil for peace in the Middle East. One of the thousand or so participants was Marjorie Chandley, an economic development consultant for the state of Georgia.
"What I'm hoping for," she said, expressing a frequently heard point of view, "is that the President will give negotiations and sanctions more opportunity to work. It was O.K. for us to take action to protect Saudi Arabia, and Hussein must leave Kuwait. But this country won't back this President in a war unless it is convinced that talks and sanctions have been given enough time to work. I have my doubts that is the case to this point."
Like Ms. Chandley, James O. Buchanan of Raleigh, N.C., believes that American troops should have been sent to the Middle East and that Hussein must leave Kuwait. But Mr. Buchanan, a B-17 bomber crew chief in World War II, is one of those Southerners who also believes there has been enough negotiating, and that economic sanctions have been given ample time to work.
"The point has come where we've got to move or we're going to get bogged down," he said. "The peace people are beginning to get involved. There's a danger of another Vietnam. Let's do it -- quick and dirty. I learned about war the hard way."
 
Not Everyone Says, 'Enough Is Enough'
 In Montgomery, Mr. Buchanan's viewpoint was echoed by Mack Traywick, a construction superintendent.
"Hussein has been given every possible chance to get out," he said. "Enough is enough. Nobody likes war. But we're free in this country today because those who went before us weren't afraid to take a stand. I trust the man who runs this country. Let's get it over with."
But to many Southerners, among them Clay Herget of Raleigh, a Denison University freshman home for the holidays, Mr. Buchanan and Mr. Traywick mistakenly see the Middle East situation in too clear-cut a way.
"In fact," said Mr. Herget, "its a gray situation with all kinds of confusing factors, from an illegal invasion of Kuwait to whether we have talked enough or too much."
Still, Mr. Herget has no plans to become a peace protester. "For one thing, I roomed with a Saudi prince for a while. For another, this isn't Vietnam. None of my friends are going to volunteer to go. But on the other hand, if the draft starts, they're not going to run into the streets or cut off their toes."
Mr. Herget's father, Barlow, a Raleigh City Councilman, and his mother, Millie, a gift shop owner, say the threat of war is beginning to affect the South's economy. Clay's sister, Casey, a senior at the University of Virginia, says many of her friends already have lost their part-time jobs.
"People are afraid to make major economic decisions on things like construction and major purchases because they don't know what's going to happen," Councilman Herget said.
Mrs. Herget said that some of her stationery customers have said they will return party invitations if war breaks out. "They don't feel it would be right to have a good time when people are dying," she said.
In Florence, S.C., William Harper, owner of Sav-a-Ton Antiques, a glassware business, said sales were off by half because of war worry. "We're being held hostage, economically," he said. "There's a lot of politics in all of this Iraq stuff, along with the craziness of Hussein. But that's life. We have to do what we have to do. Southerners don't see a lot of sense in intellectualizing something like this a whole lot. Just do it."
James T. Owens, a retired railroad engineer from the Atlanta suburb of Chamblee, says he also sees no reason to intellectualize about the gulf crisis. But he's not adverse to applying a little psychoanalysis. "I'm afraid we've got some mighty big egos at work on both sides in this," he said. "How do you keep from loosing face? Does that drive you to war?"
He pondered for a moment, then shook his head slowly. "I hope not," he said. "But I have my doubts."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
A Company Is Finding The Good in Pollution

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

DATELINE: THOMASTON, Me., Jan. 2

 BODY:
A radically different approach to air pollution -- converting harmful combustion waste products into something useful -- is being tested here at New England's only cement plant. A geochemist has found a way to combine the acid and ash emissions from the plant to produce fertilizer, distilled water and limestone for the cement plant, and hardly anything else.
The system's designers think the process will have wide application in other industries trying to cope with pollutants, including paper mills, trash-to-energy plants and some coal plants. In addition to producing a product that can be sold, the proceedure eliminates the problem of disposing of chemicals filtered out of the smokestack and the need to buy neutralizing materials for a "scrubber." It also allows the use of cheap but dirty high-sulfur fuel, even while reducing air pollution. 
 Factories that want to cut pollution have long had the option of installing scrubbers, which capture sulfur dioxide that causes acid rain by spraying the smoke with a limestone solution, chemically locking up the sulfur. But that is expensive, and merely transforms acid that would have gone into the air into a solid that can poison groundwater and must be disposed of.
 
Half the Problem
 And sulfur dioxide is only half the problem for many fuel-burning factories. They also produce ash, which is highly alkaline and can include heavy metals that can easily dissolve in underground water.
In contrast, the "recovery scrubber" here -- a small chemical reactor -- combines the sulfur dioxide and ash to make fertilizer. The process begins with capturing in filters the waste dust leaving the concrete kiln and dissolving it in water. The dust includes ash, limestone that has been contaminated with sulfur, and potassium, which in cement-making is a contaminant. The water is pumped into a tank, and the exhaust gases that passed through the filter, which contain sulfur dioxide, are allowed to bubble through the water.
In the tank, the calcium-sulfur compounds are broken apart, and the sulfur and potassium combine to produce potassium sulfate, a fertilizer. Waste heat from the smoke is then used to distill away the water and recover the fertilizer. The distilled water is used in the kiln. At the same time, the calcium combines with carbon dioxide, and is turned back into limestone.
The inventor, Dr. Garrett Morrison, a geochemist, first tried the chemical reaction in a trash barrel. Then he persuaded the Passamaquoddy Indian tribe, which then owned the cement company, to put up $250,000 for a larger experiment.
The tribe, which had bought the plant in 1983 with the proceeds of a land settlement, has since sold it, but owns the rights to the process and hopes it will be commercialized and applied to a variety of industries.
Proponents of the system say sales of the fertilizer and savings on waste disposal will more than pay for the recovery scrubber. In addition, under the Clean Air Act, a factory that cuts acid emissions can sell the "right" to emit the same amount of pollution. This raises the possibility that some companies will install this kind of scrubber even if they already meet clean air rules, just to increase their profits.
Furthermore, many plants must buy an alkali to neutralize the sulfur dioxide, and also pay to haul away the resulting solids as well as ash, said Thomas N. Tureen, chairman of Tribal Assets Management, the Passamaquoddy's Portland-based company. The recovery scrubber can use that ash in place of the alkali.
 
Prototype Is Tested <--HE>
 An $11 million full-scale prototype began tests late last month, with the cost split evenly between the Department of Energy's Clean Coal Technology program and CDN-USA, a Spanish consortium that now owns the cement company, called the Dragon Products Company.
The recovery scrubber has special value for cement plants because it also rescues for re-use the 20 percent of the raw material, limestone, that ordinarily escapes from the kiln up the stack or into the filters.
Dr. Joseph P. Strakey, the associate director for clean coal technology at the Energy Department's Pittsburgh Energy Technology Center, called the scrubber "extremely promising."
"Usually, you don't scrub at a profit," he said, adding that in power plants, scrubbers can drive up the cost of electricity by 10 to 15 percent. Mr. Tureen pointed out that all other scrubbing technologies release carbon dioxide, a gas believed to cause global warming, as the limestone reacts with the sulfur. But this technology consumes carbon dioxide.
Dr. Strakey and others think the scrubber can probably be adapted to a wide variety of industries, but say it seems especially valuable for cement. At a cement plant, a mixture of limestone and a few other ingredients is roasted with a blast of flame, generally from oil or coal.
Most of the mixture goes on to be cement, but the kiln also produces prodigious amounts of "kiln dust," a pollutant. Collected in filters, millions of tons of this kiln dust can pile up in scarce landfill space, and threaten groundwater. The waste also shortens the useful life of limestone quarries, which usually determines the life of the cement plant.
 
Extending Limestone Supply
 Dragon has about 85 years of limestone left at 80 percent efficiency; recovering the 20 percent will make it last even longer. But Dragon also has a 50-foot mountain in back, a waste pile known as Dragon Mountain, that used to be an 80-foot-deep quarry. It is full, and establishing a new dump could cost $2 million.
Now the mountain can be slowly recycled by the recovery scrubber.
Meanwhile, the scrubber is producing potassium sulfate, a fertilizer. (When backyard gardeners buy 6-10-4 at the lawn and garden center, the "4" is potassium.)
But one problem is that the reaction works only at a cool temperature, so the exhaust gases must be sprayed with water first. And the potassium sulfate concentration in water is only about 2 percent. Most industries would dump potassium sulfate in such low concentrations, Dr. Morrison said, but he added, "That is not only environmentally unsound, but economically unsound."
 
Solution in a Pump
 The scrubber uses waste heat from the stack to distill the water. But the stack gas is only about 245 degrees Fahrenheit, and once it is run through two heat exchangers, to prevent contamination, it is only 100 degrees, far below the boiling point. The solution is a vacuum pump, which lowers the air pressure so that the water boils at 100 degrees.
Apart from reversing the buildup of waste and making a marketable byproduct, the scrubber assures that the remaining exhaust has been stripped of 97 percent of its sulfur. The former system took out only 58 percent. Dragon was already using high-sulfur coal, but a plant that had been on expensive coal or oil that is 1.5 percent sulfur and that had installed such a scrubber could switch to cheaper fuel that is 3 percent sulfur and still cut emissions by 90 percent.
In a paper mill or waste-to-energy incinerator, where there is no kiln dust, the sulfur dioxide would be put in a reaction tank with the alkaline ash to produce the potassium sulfate.
Another advantage: Trash incinerators produce ash with high concentrations of heavy metals, but the reaction in the recovery scrubber makes them insoluble in water, so disposal is safer.
Ordinary coal-burning plants do not produce enough ash to sustain the reaction, but those in Eastern Europe, which use poor quality coal with high ash content, would be suitable, the designers say.
Mr. Tureen, the chairman of Tribal Assets, describes the scrubber as "a mixture of Indian environmentalism and Yankee frugality."

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
BUSH ASKS CONGRESS TO BACK USE OF FORCE IF IRAQ DEFIES DEADLINE ON KUWAIT PULLOUT

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8

 BODY:
President Bush called on Congress today to adopt a resolution supporting the use of force against Iraq if it did not withdraw from Kuwait by Jan. 15. He said such a vote would send a message to President Saddam Hussein that the United States was united in its determination to make him withdraw from Kuwait.
Because Mr. Bush is unlikely to return to Congress again before sending American troops into combat, the endorsement he requested today, if adopted, would be as close as Congress would come to a formal declaration of war in advance of an attack on Iraq. 
 He invited Congress to join him in sending "the clearest possible message to Saddam Hussein that he must withdraw without condition or delay from Kuwait." But he offered a political warning that "anything less would only encourage Iraqi intransigence."
 
An End to Weeks of Indecision
 The President's letter to Congressional leaders, ending weeks of White House indecision over whether to seek support from Congress before sending American forces into combat, sets the stage for a major debate in the House and Senate, beginning on Thursday and due to last through Saturday.
In his letter, Mr. Bush also said a resolution "would help dispel any belief that may exist in the minds of Iraq's leaders that the United States lacks the necessary unity to act decisively in response to Iraq's continued aggression against Kuwait." [Text, page A6.]
The President made his request as Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz of Iraq arrived in Geneva today for a meeting on Wednesday that is considered perhaps the last chance for a peaceful resolution of the gulf crisis before the Jan. 15 withdrawal deadline imposed by the United Nations. Mr. Aziz said he was prepared to conduct "constructive talks," but would not yield to American pressure. [Page A6.]
 
'All Necessary Means'
 Mr. Bush's letter was the first Presidential request for Congressional backing for offensive military action since President Johnson asked for the Gulf of Tonkin resolution on the Vietnam War on Aug. 5, 1964.
Mr. Bush specifically asked both houses to adopt a resolution that "supports the use of all necessary means" to carry out the United Nations Security Council resolution of Nov. 29, which set the deadline. That resolution, like Mr. Bush's letter, used the phrase "all necessary means" as a euphemism for military force. Mr. Bush made the request only after Congressional leaders said in recent days that he was almost certain to receive Congressional endorsement, though not without a heated debate and divided vote that the President several times told them he would prefer to avoid.
The letter arrived on Capitol Hill as several closed meetings were being held by both parties in both houses, seeking to agree on language to propose when Congressional debate begins later this week, probably on Thursday in both houses, after Mr. Baker meets Mr. Aziz. Democratic and Republican leaders said the direct Presidential request would be likely to win over some wavering lawmakers.
Mr. Bush's request came as a New York Times/CBS News Poll, completed on Monday, showed that the public remained evenly split between going to war or sticking to sanctions after the 15th. Unlike some other polls, which asked only whether the country should go to war, the Times/CBS News Poll offered continued reliance on sanctions as an alternative.
The telephone survey of 1,348 adults, begun on Saturday, found that 46 percent said that if Iraq did not withdraw from Kuwait by Jan. 15, then "the United States should start military actions against Iraq." But 47 percent said the United States should "wait longer to see if the trade embargo and other economic sanctions work."
The difference was far less than the poll's margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points, and not significantly changed from a reading in December, when 45 percent favored combat and 48 percent preferred waiting even after Jan. 15.
The Times/CBS News Poll also found a sharply increased expectation of war from the public, with 57 percent saying they anticipated that there would be fighting with Iraq, compared with 44 percent last month. Sixty percent said they thought Congress should have to vote a declaration of war -- a specific statement not on anyone's current legislative agenda -- before American troops went into combat, while 32 percent disagreed.
And although 51 percent expected the Baker-Aziz meeting to "involve serious discussion," compared with 36 percent who said it was "mostly for show," 68 percent wanted a meeting with President Hussein himself before Jan. 15, a meeting Mr. Bush has all but ruled out.
Even before Mr. Bush's letter arrived at the offices of the leaders of both parties in both houses, the Hill buzzed with meetings and rumors of meetings to draft language for resolutions, or at least to narrow and organize the options.
House Democrats met in the office of Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the majority leader, to plan language for two proposals, one asserting Congress' sole power to decide when to go to war, and other contending that while force could not be ruled out ultimately, the time had not yet come to use it and sanctions should be tried for a longer time.
 
Mitchell and Nunn Meet
 The second proposal was said to be patterned on one being discussed in the office of the Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, involving him and Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia, the chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee.
Republicans were meeting among themselves and also seeking Democratic support for a resolution doing what the President asked.
And Senator Bob Dole, the Republican leader, issued a statement complaining that "it's long past time for Congress to get in the game."
Mr. Bush's letter said it would have been helpful for Mr. Baker to have had a Congressional resolution at hand for his meeting in Geneva and maintained that the President had "frequently stated my desire for such a resolution." But Mr. Mitchell said that when Mr. Bush had made such a request orally, he had always conditioned it by saying he wanted a resolution if it could be adopted overwhelmingly and without much debate, something Congressional leaders replied was not possible. Mr. Dole, citing the Bush letter, said, "If Tariq Aziz asks Jim Baker, 'What have you brought from Congress?,' he'll have to say, 'Nothing.' "
But Mr. Baker will be able to take the predictions of such leaders as House Speaker Thomas S. Foley that a resolution supporting Mr. Bush would pass by this weekend.
If adopted, the resolution would be cited by Administration officals as closing off any remaining argument over whether Congress had used its war-making authority to give the President an authorization the White House had often said was not needed.
The Constitutional power of Congress to declare war has been invoked directly and specifically only five times: in the War of 1812, the Mexican War, the Spanish-American War and both World Wars. But the Gulf of Tonkin resolution, sought by Mr. Johnson and approved by votes of 88 to 2 in the Senate and 416 to 0 in the House after reports of an attack on United States vessels, supported Mr. Johnson in his bid "to prevent further aggression" and thus was seen by supporters of the Vietnam War as the equivalent of a formal declaration. Many in Congress later felt they had been deceived into hastily approving military action against North Vietnam, which had in fact been planned months before the incident.
While Mr. Nunn, who could not be reached for comment, was understood to be preparing to advocate delay in using force, his House counterpart, Representative Les Aspin of Wisconsin, said the right vote was a vote to authorize Mr. Bush to use force.
Mr. Aspin's view was shared in a Senate hearing by Alexander M. Haig Jr., President Reagan's first Secretary of State, who said there was little alternative to war and further reliance on sanctions would be "a profound strategic blunder." He also predicted that once Iraq saw that United States force would be used unstintingly, "I think there's a very good chance one of Saddam's colonels will take him out."
At the Senate Foreign Relations Committee hearing, attended only by Democrats, another view came from Cyrus R. Vance, who was President Carter's first Secretary of State. Mr. Vance said that if the United States went to war, it would soon find itself "virtually alone in a bitter and bloody war that will not be won quickly or without heavy casualties."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Ford's Pockets Are No Longer Full

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 8

 BODY:
Just a couple of annual reports ago, the Ford Motor Company was selling cars and trucks so briskly and profitably that union officials moaned about the crush of overtime and some investors fretted that the nation's No. 2 auto maker was not investing its multibillion-dollar hoard of cash quickly enough.
Ford executives have not heard such complaints lately. Now, like the rest of the domestic car industry, Ford is idling assembly lines and laying off workers in response to slow sales. Its financial strength, once the envy of corporate America, has declined to the point that Ford directors, who are to meet at company headquarters in Dearborn, Mich., on Thursday, are facing a tough decision on whether to conserve cash by cutting the dividend on common stock. 
 Financial analysts are predicting that the annual $3-a-share dividend will be cut. The stock price has fallen as investors have sold in anticipation of a dividend cut and a fourth-quarter loss. Ford executives have vowed not to cut the dividend.
The dimming of Ford's star stems partly from perception and partly from substance. As might be expected, Ford's performance is falling short of the hyperbolic descriptions used by analysts a few years ago. Ford was sometimes portrayed as America's answer to Japanese auto makers, largely on the popularity of its midsized Ford Taurus and Mercury Sable cars, its growing market share and its record profit.
"The box score is that Ford gets an A-plus for factory operations," said James Womack, research director of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's automotive study team. "It deals with suppliers better than some other auto makers, and it's trying hard to build a truly global organization. But its products are struggling."
Under Harold A. Poling, who took over as chief executive last year after Donald E. Petersen retired, Ford has retained the depth and experience it feels it needs to weather the tough business conditions. Mr. Poling was orginally scheduled to retire before Mr. Petersen, but senior Ford officials say the board's concern about an impending industry downturn led to Mr. Poling's promotion to chief executive.
Even as Mr. Poling was taking office, it was clear the tide was turning against Ford. Last year Chevrolet grabbed back the lead in overall car sales. The Taurus and Sable are becoming dated, but will not get even a face lift until later this year, nor a complete redesign until 1994. By contrast, the Honda Accord, which in 1989 replaced the Taurus as the best-selling car model in the United States, was redesigned after only four years.
Mr. Womack and others worry that Ford has not managed to introduce new and attractive vehicles quickly enough to keep up with an onslaught from Japanese auto makers and a revived General Motors Corporation, which plans significant changes for several models this year. Sales of some newly redesigned Ford mainstays like the Thunderbird and Mercury Cougar have also been weak.
The recession and continued strong competition from Honda and Toyota have hurt Ford's domestic rivals as well. The Big Three companies reported Friday that sales of cars and light trucks fell again in 1990, by 5.1 percent, to 13.8 million vehicles.
But Ford has begun to show more vulnerability to American and European competition, slowing the momentum it gained with the spectacular success of the Taurus and Sable, which were introduced in late 1985. The popularity of their rounded styling helped Ford pass G.M.'s Chevrolet division in sales; Ford even made bigger profits in the late 1980's than G.M., which is much larger, for the first time in decades.
Since then, however, several efforts at home and abroad have faltered. In Europe, the recent introduction of the redesigned Escort, which differs from the American model of the same name, was poorly received by reviewers. Ford's European operations, which once made a strong contribution to earnings, have suffered in both market share and profit.
 
Conservative Shift Is Seen
 Ronald L. Glantz, automotive analyst for Dean Witter in San Francisco, said Ford became more conservative after breaking the Detroit mold with the Taurus, because it began to make its other cars look like that model instead of recognizing that the Taurus's success stemmed largely from its distinctive styling.
One notable success has been the Explorer four-door utility vehicle, which drew rave reviews from automotive enthusiast magazines. The Explorer has been selling strongly, without any financial incentives or discount programs, since its introduction last year.
Joel Pitcoff, Ford's manager of research and analysis, noted that the Taurus's share of the four-door midsize market "has held up quite well, in spite of the fact that the sales of all of those cars has been falling."
He also defended the time between model redesigns, saying: "I can remember when there was identifiable change every year for every model. With the proliferation of different models and competitors, that's impossible for a full-line producer like Ford. Besides, our consumer research says there's no need for it."
Soaring engineering and tooling costs for new models, coupled with the expense of meeting safety and environmental regulations, will push Ford's estimated capital expenditures to $32 billion in the next five years, compared with $23 billion in the previous five years.
 
Big Expenses at Jaguar
 One of the biggest-ticket items in Ford's capital budget is its $2.5 billion acquisition of Jaguar P.L.C. of Britain, which may require as much as $2.5 billion more in tooling and engineering costs. Although Jaguar's cars are struggling to compete with the latest luxury vehicles from Japan and Germany, Ford made the deal to take advantage of the company's name recognition and heritage.
Many analysts have criticized the acquisition as too expensive, but Ford maintains that it is satisfied, although it says the payoff from Jaguar will not be evident for 5 to 10 years, when new models are introduced.
Ford has also spent aggressively to diversify into financial services and has become one of the largest operators of savings and loans, a strategy that has cost it hundreds of millions of dollars to cover bad loans rather than generate additional capital.
Consequently, Ford has been forced to borrow much more to pay for capital investment and rebates, which average about $1,200 a vehicle, raising doubts among financial analysts of whether it is prudent to keep paying the full $3 stock dividend.
 
Stock Has Languished
 Since becoming a public company in 1956, Ford has reduced its dividend three times, most recently in the 1982 recession. Executives have since asserted that they want to prove the company could be profitable and sustain a dividend during a recession.
In the last year Ford's stock has traded as high as $49 a share, but is now languishing near $25. [The stock closed unchanged Tuesday at $25.50 a share.] Analysts say the price reflects investors' belief that a cut in the dividend cannot be avoided. Currently, however, if the board does not cut the dividend, the $3 payout represents a yield of nearly 12 percent.
Members of the Ford family are particularly interested in the board's dividend policy since they receive about $106 million in dividends each year on their restricted stock. Other public shareholders receive $1.27 billion at the current rate.
Mr. Glantz of Dean Witter said all of the Big Three domestic auto makers were squeezed financially and would cut their dividends, but "right now they are playing chicken -- no one wants to go first."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 2; Foreign Desk

HEADLINE: U.S. DEPLORES PLAN BY SOVIETS TO SEND TROOPS TO BALTICS

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8

 BODY:
The United States today condemned as "provocative" Moscow's plan to send troops to seven restive Soviet regions and suggested that such action could endanger Soviet-American relations if it led to violence or signaled a crackdown on political activity.
Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said the plan to send paratroops to enforce military conscription in the three Baltic republics and four other areas "amounts to intimidation." The Soviet announcement was made on Monday, but no deployments of the paratroops have been confirmed. 
 Adding to the tension and uncertainty in the Baltic region, the Prime Minister of the independence-minded republic of Lithuania and her Cabinet resigned today in a dispute with the republic's Parliament over economic and political policy. [Page A3.]
 
'Reversal' of Progress
 Mr. Fitzwater said the Soviet announcement marked a "reversal" of the progress that Washington had seen last year in talks between the Kremlin and the Soviet republics as secessionist movements wrestled with Moscow over the future shape of their nation.
The Bush Administration's rebuke, which also was read to reporters during a briefing at the State Department, reflected concern over what Washington sees as an increasing alliance between President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and conservative forces in the military and elsewhere in the Soviet Government.
Administration officials also said that although a resurgence of conservative forces was affecting internal Soviet politics, they did not believe that it was causing serious harm to relations between the superpowers.
 
Agricultural Credits Approved
 Even as the Administration leveled its criticism, the Agriculture Department announced today that Moscow had been allocated $900 million in short-term credit guarantees to buy American agricultural products this year. The credit is part of $1 billion in guarantees pledged by President Bush on Dec. 13 to help the Soviet Union through "tough times, difficult times" in its food supply.
Though Administration officials deny serious harm to relations, they have said that they believe a resur- gence of military influence is behind recent problems in arms control, including what the United States says are Soviet efforts to evade counting and verification rules in the recently signed treaty reducing conventional weapons in Europe.
There also have been differences over such issues as verification that have slowed the final work on another treaty that would sharply reduce long-range nuclear weapons for the first time. That treaty is supposed to be signed by Presidents Bush and Gorbachev at a summit meeting in February in Moscow.
But officials have said in recent days that the United States is strongly considering delaying the meeting, in part because of the problems in arms control but even more because of the uncertainty in the Persian Gulf and the possibility of war there, and the increasing political turmoil within the Soviet Union.
 
U.S. Monitoring Moves
 In the clearest signal yet of Washington's concern about Soviet political troubles, Mr. Fitzwater said today that the United States was "monitoring closely" the planned deployment of Soviet forces to enforce military conscription in Moldavia, the Ukraine, Georgia, Armenia and the three Baltic republics of Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia.
"The pace of improvement in Soviet relations continues, I think, in terms of the big picture, if you will," Mr. Fitzwater said. "We still have continuing improvements on any number of fronts. But on the other hand, we feel this is important enough to point out that it is a potential problem."
The fact that the United States issued its statement even before any Soviet troops were reported to have arrived in the seven republics indicated the extent of the Administration's concern about the turn of events, officials said.
In his statement, Mr. Fitzwater said: "This action represents a serious step toward an escalation of tension within the U.S.S.R. and makes the peaceful evolution of relations among the peoples of the Soviet Union more difficult."
 
Action Called 'Intimidation'
 He said the United States was "especially concerned" that the dispatch of troops to the Baltic republics would set back discussions about the status of those regions, which are seeking independence from Moscow.
"The United States urges the U.S.S.R. to cease attempts at intimidation and turn back to negotiations that are conducted free of pressure and the use of force," Mr. Fitzwater said.
Richard A. Boucher, a State Department spokesman, said the American Ambassador in Moscow, Jack Matlock, had raised the deployment with Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze on Monday and asked for an explanation. Mr. Matlock received a return call from the Foreign Ministry today that "basically just confirmed what the Ministry of Defense had put in its announcement" about the deployments on Monday evening, Mr. Boucher said.
"The Ambassador took the opportunity at that time to register our concerns once again," he said.
Mr. Boucher and Mr. Fitzwater both said they had no information to indicate that the Soviet troops intended to go beyond their avowed purpose of rounding up draft evaders. "We believe, however, that some actions of the kinds reportedly planned could trigger violence or bloodshed," Mr. Boucher said.
