HEADLINE: Bankruptcy Petition Is Filed by Pan Am To Get New Loans

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
Pan American World Airways, nearly out of cash, filed for bankruptcy protection yesterday. Pan Am, the nation's pioneer in commercial aviation, is the third of the nine largest United States carriers to seek such protection from creditors in the last 22 months.
The airline will continue to fly and the filing will not affect customers, said Thomas G. Plaskett, the company's chairman and chief executive. 
 The filing, under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code, was necessary because Pan Am, which is struggling to avoid liquidation, is seeking $150 million from United Airlines and the Bankers Trust Company, as a loan against the planned $400 million sale of its London routes and other assets to United. Pan Am sought Chapter 11 protection to persuade United and the bank to help it, since bankruptcy law puts lenders who give money after a filing ahead of other creditors in receiving repayment.
Pan Am needs the money from the route sale to United to help it survive the winter, when there are fewer passengers. In addition, high fuel prices and a weakening economy are hurting the entire airline industry.
Pan Am still faces a short-term hurdle: before Pan Am can get the $150 million loan, the bankruptcy court must approve the London route sale. There is also a long-term obstacle: Pan Am needs the approval of the British Government to complete the sale. It has already received $110 million from United for two Boeing 747-200 aircraft and its San Francisco operations, and it would get the remaining $290 million after obtaining Britain's approval.
The airline hopes to use the money to build a hub at Frankfurt and expand service to Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. The carrier would also keep its Latin American routes, which have been profitable.
Continental Airlines, the nation's fifth-largest airline, filed for bankruptcy protection last month, and Eastern Airlines, which is smaller, filed in March 1989. Both airlines are still flying and are under the protection of the court.
Pan Am, the seventh-largest United States carrier, handles about 19 million passengers a year, flying to about 100 destinations in North America, Europe, Latin America, Asia and Africa.
It also operates the Pan Am Shuttle, which provides hourly service between New York and Boston and between New York and Washington. Mr. Plaskett said that the shuttle was for sale and that two parties were interested. He did not name them, but it has been reported that Northwest Airlines has been negotiating with Pan Am for the shuttle.
 
In Regulated Times
 Pan Am, founded in 1927, prospered and grew when the industry was highly regulated; it had a monopoly on international travel until World War II. Its management excelled at lobbying in Washington and conducting diplomacy with other countries, which helped to develop Pan Am's status as the United States' almost-official airline. It is the carrier that inaugurated service across the Pacific, helped to ferry soldiers and equipment during World War II, ordered the first Boeing 747 and was widely regarded for its Clipper service.
But its management had trouble with the competitive pressures brought by deregulation of the airline industry in 1978 and the growth of other carriers on routes Pan Am had long dominated.
Close to bankruptcy by 1981, Pan Am began a decade of selling assets, including its headquarters building, which straddles Park Avenue in New York, to make up deficits, and sought concessions from its unions to cut expenses.
The fortunes of the carrier improved for several years but were dashed after terrorist attacks in 1986 and 1987 discouraged travel abroad. Pan Am had to sell the Pacific routes it had pioneered to United for $750 million.
 
Explosion Over Scotland
 No sooner had Mr. Plaskett begun to improve the airline's planes and service when a Pan Am jumbo jet was destroyed by a bomb over Lockerbie, Scotland, in December 1988, killing 270 people. Mr. Plaskett estimated that the disaster cost Pan Am about $250 million in bookings in 1989.
Mr. Plaskett began to look for a strong airline to merge with Pan Am, but has not found a partner.
The sharp rise in aviation fuel prices during the Persian Gulf crisis has hurt Pan Am more than other carriers because many of its planes are older and less efficient. The carrier's cash is down to about $30 million, a very small amount by industry standards.
In its filing yesterday, Pan Am listed assets for the parent company, which is included in the petition, of $438 million and liabilities of $89 million as of Sept. 30. But its airline subsidiary had $2.6 billion in liabilities and $1.6 billion of assets. The unit's liabilities included $412 million in secured debt, $381 million in unsecured debt and more than $1.6 billion of other claims.
The Standard & Poor's Corporation listed the corporation's current assets as of Sept. 30 at $1.33 billion and current liabilities at $621 million.
Pan Am shares fell 37.5 cents, to 75 cents each, in New York Stock Exchange trading yesterday. Standard & Poor's announced that Pan Am would be removed from the S.&P. 500 stock index today and replaced by Blockbuster Entertainment, the largest operator of video rental stores.
 
Loan Faces Hurdles
 Pan Am must overcome some hurdles before it can get its hands on the $150 million from United Airlines and Bankers Trust. Judge Cornelius Blackshear of the United States Bankruptcy Court of the Southern District of New York is handling the Pan Am bankruptcy filing and must approve the route sale. Judge Blackshear has scheduled a hearing on the issue for tomorrow.
Pan Am was helped yesterday when the Department of Transportation gave preliminary approval to the sale of its London routes. But in earlier talks the British Government said it wanted important concessions from the United States in return for allowing two strong carriers, United Airlines and American Airlines, to come into Heathrow and compete with British Airways. American Airlines has an agreement to buy the London routes of Trans World Airlines.
Talks are scheduled in Washington on Monday and Tuesday.
If Pan Am cannot secure the money from United, some analysts say, it probably could not keep operating and would face liquidation.
Paul Karos, the airline analyst for First Boston, said it had been impossible for Pan Am to keep up with bigger carriers like American, Delta and British Airways, with their newer planes and improved service on the Atlantic routes. "From food to interiors, Pan Am did not have the funds to keep up with competitors," he added.
Even if it can reorganize under Chapter 11, he said, Pan Am will have to align itself with a big carrier to get a strong domestic route system to feed its international flights and to build the resources to revamp its fleet.
Mr. Plaskett said an offer by Carl C. Icahn, the chairman of Trans World Airlines, was not considered to be workable. Mr. Icahn had sought to buy Pan Am and provide a loan to enable it to operate until it completed the sale of the London routes. Mr. Plaskett said that Mr. Icahn had offered only about half the amount offered by United and that other terms were not acceptable.
Pan Am's bankruptcy filing, following those of Eastern and Continental, highlights the growing role of bankruptcy proceedings in the airline industry, said Russell Thayer, a former president of Braniff Airways Inc. who is now an airline consultant.
 
Not Afraid of Bankruptcy
 Airline executives used to avoid bankruptcy court for anything short of liquidation. "In the old days you wouldn't do it because you thought people wouldn't fly" such a carrier for fear it would skimp on maintenance, Mr. Thayer said. But Eastern, which filed for protection almost two years ago, has continued to attract passengers.
Pan Am's bankruptcy filing will have a large effect on other carriers only if it leads to liquidation, which will probably not happen immediately, airline executives and other industry experts said.
Pan Am's international experience is an asset that is hard to quantify but is very valuable, said Uli Baur, the vice president for aircraft fleet management at Simat, Helliesen & Eichner Inc., a large aviation consulting firm.
If Pan Am stops operating for any reason, its successor or acquirer may find it hard to rebuild market share, he added. "In the past, whenever U.S. carriers went on strike, it was always very hard for the U.S. carriers to regain the market share they lost."
But in the long run, the more profitable domestic carriers may prove tougher competitors because they have more money to invest in new planes and terminals. Pan Am has suffered from a recent image of poor service aboard aging planes.
 
Pension Agency's Claims
 Pan Am said the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, the Government agency that insures certain corporate pension funds, was its largest unsecured creditor, with $490 million in contingent claims.
Other big creditors listed by Pan Am were S. G. Warburg S.A. and Soditic S.A., acting as agents for $40 million in liquidated claims. Other large unsecured creditors include the IBJ Schroder Bank and Trust Company, as trustee of $165 million of 9 percent convertible senior subordinated debentures; Midlantic National Bank as trustee for $130 million of 15 percent senior debentures due in 2004 and also for $100 million of 13.5 percent senior debentures due in 2003.
Pan Am, like other American carriers, has flown troops and materiel to Saudi Arabia as part of the military buildup there. In its court filing it said it had flown close to 100 missions in support of the Middle Eastern operations.

HEADLINE: Thoughts After Layoffs: Making Do and Moving

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FORT WORTH, Jan. 8

 BODY:
Scott Korgel glanced back at the hulking brick building where, minutes earlier this morning, he and more than 2,500 other engineers, technicians and office workers were ordered to clear out their desks and leave for the last time the top-secret development site for the Navy's A-12 attack aircraft.
"There is a lot of depression in that building this morning," said Mr. Korgel, who carried a box crammed with papers and books. A mechanical engineer with seven years' experience at the General Dynamics Corporation plant here, Mr. Korgel and 3,317 other company employees were laid off a day after Defense Secretary Dick Cheney canceled the $57-billion program for the carrier-based stealth aircraft. 
 About 800 of those employees worked in a large building not far from Mr. Korgel's.
"I'll be O.K. for awhile," Mr. Korgel, 32 years old, said. "But for others who have just one income, a wife and two kids, the unemployment check is not going to buy food and do everything else. People are calling their mortgage companies, saying they don't know when they can make another payment, and some are honestly worried about being homeless."
Mr. Korgel said his wife, Rina, a tooling engineer in the nearby General Dynamics plant, said they believed that her job was safe. But he said he was certain that he and most of the other laid-off workers would have to look outside Texas to find jobs that pay as well as the ones at General Dynamics.
The company told its employees not to talk to reporters, and outside the plant today many of them, particularly women, refused to discuss their feelings.
 
Severe Blow to Economy
 The sudden, and largely unexpected, loss of the A-12 program will cut as many as 10,000 jobs and as much as $500 million in trade from the Fort Worth economy, local economists say. Retailers, service companies and home owners will share the blow from lost sales and customers and declining home values, as hundreds of houses come onto the market, especially near the General Dynamics plant on the city's West Side.
Moreover, local government agencies will have to deal with falling real-estate taxes and receipts from sales. Some economists said the A-12 decision would pack an even greater punch if, as they feared, other military cutbacks sweep through the weapons-related industry in North Texas.
"This is not an isolated event, but symptomatic of a longer-term problem for the country," said Don C. Reynolds, an economist here. "There is pain in perestroika, and the A-12 cancellation is part of the pain. Any area that gets major defense-spending dollars should be prepared."
Military contractors in North Texas received $4.5 billion from the Pentagon in 1990, he said.
 
Good-Paying Jobs
 The job losses from the A-12 will increase the unemployment rate in the Fort Worth area by at least a full percentage point this year, Mr. Reynolds said. The rate rose to 6.1 percent in November after averaging less than 5 percent through most of 1990.
More than 2,500 salaried workers were among the 3,318 layoffs today, General Dynamics said. Those jobs paid an average $35,000 to $40,000 per person, and similar jobs will be hard to find in the Fort Worth area, said Bernard Weinstein, an economist at the University of North Texas in Denton.
The economies of Fort Worth and its larger neighbor 40 miles to the east, Dallas, have slowly improved in the last three years after being badly shaken in 1986 and 1987 from the region's worst economic downturn since the Great Depression.
American Airlines expects to add 4,000 workers when its aircraft maintenance plant opens next year at Alliance Airport, a joint project of the City of Fort Worth and the family of H. Ross Perot, the Dallas billionaire. Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, the giant Japanese company, is studying the area for a large manufacturing site that would eventually employ 7,000 people.
Ronald G. Steinhart, chairman and chief executive of Team Bank Inc., the largest bank with headquarters in Fort Worth, said he was optimistic that many of the former General Dynamics workers would not have to leave the area to find jobs.
 
More Diversified Economy
 General Dynamics, based in St. Louis, is the Fort Worth area's largest employer, with 27,100 employees at the end of 1990. The area, which includes the medium-size city of Arlington, has 693,000 employed workers.
"We have diversified our economy," Mr. Steinhart said, "and we have already worked through most of our problems. Absorbing all of these jobs is not something we can do overnight. But we are the best prepared of any time recently to do it, and certainly better prepared than any other part of the country."
Many of the newly unemployed A-12 workers are far less sanguine. "I wouldn't even consider looking" for jobs at other military contractors in North Texas, said Michael V. Schmidbauer, an expert in programming robots and other manufacturing equipment. "Texas Instruments is laying off, and they probably are in worse shape than we are."
Mr. Schmidbauer, 28, and his wife, Cathy, an accountant at a real-estate concern, earned more than $50,000 last year. With their second child due early next month, Mr. Schmidbauer said he was anxious about finding a new job -- outside the military weapons industry -- fast.
"I'll probably end up going to Seattle, to Boeing, and get into commercial aircraft," he said. "Of course, 4,000 other people from G. D. probably will, too."
But the Boeing Company might not hire many of the A-12 engineers. Paul Binder, a Boeing spokesman, said that the Seattle-based company's payroll declined last year by 2,000, to 104,000, after peaking in 1989 and that the company had not announced any hiring plans for 1991.
For Steven O'Donnell, a mechanical engineer, the A-12 cancellation marked the second time in three years he has lost a job as a result of Defense Department decisions. The Baldwin, L. I., native had gotten a job here after the Grumman Corporation lost out in bidding for the A-12 contract in 1988.
"Now I don't know what I'm going to do," Mr. O'Donnell, 30, said. "My wife's got a master's degree in teaching, but she's unemployed. I would recommend to anybody in college to stay out of the aerospace field. You can't get a steady job."
In St. Louis, the other major contractor on the A-12, the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, began layoffs of what it said would eventually total 5,000 employees. One of those dismissed, Mark Serra, 33, a plastic tooling worker, said that he would use the job-finding services that McDonnell, like General Dynamics, has offered, but that he was worried about a more pressing problem.
He and his wife, Linda, a nurse, learned last month that she was pregnant with their second child. Mrs. Serra's insurance does not cover the anticipated $5,000 cost for a hospital birth, and McDonnell officials told Mr. Serra that his family health insurance coverage would expire in a month.
Christopher Schildz, a spokesman at General Dynamics's corporate headquarters, said his company conducted a review with all A-12 employees today to account for classified documents before the Fort Worth building was closed.
"We really regret the disruption on the professional and personal lives of the people involved," Mr. Schildz said. "There were many good people working on that program."

"There is a lot of depression in that building this morning," said Scott Korgel as he moved his belongings out the development building on Fort Worth's West Side. (Jerry Cabluck for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Purse Snatcher's Push Kills Woman With $1 in Subway

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
A 31-year-old Manhattan woman died following surgery last night after a purse snatcher grabbed her handbag containing $1 and pushed her between two cars of a subway train pulling out of an Upper West Side station, the transit police said.
A suspect with eight arrests for subway muggings was seized on a nearby street. 
 The woman, Grace Cheng, was trapped between the platform and a moving southbound C train at the station at 96th Street and Central Park West, said a transit police spokesman, Albert W. O'Leary. Her left leg was almost severed and her pelvis, left thigh and left arm were broken.
She was taken to St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center, where she died at 10:15 P.M. after more than two and a half hours of surgery. Phyllis Goodman, a hospital spokeswoman, said Ms. Cheng suffered a heavy loss of blood from massive injuries.
Two unemployed security guards, Edwin Pacheco, 42, and Felix Burgois, 35, jumped onto the track after the train had crushed Ms. Cheng and lifted her to the platform, Mr. O'Leary said.
Minutes after the 10:45 A.M. attack, two plainclothes transit police officers arrested a New Jersey man as he rifled through Ms. Cheng's wallet near Columbus Avenue, Mr. O'Leary said. The officers were not aware of the purse snatching but said they had seen the suspect run out of the station with a wallet in his hand and had followed him.
The suspect, Brian Lawerence, of 3 Marshall Street in Irvington, N.J., was charged with robbery, assault and possession of stolen property after witnesses identified him as the attacker, Mr. O'Leary said. He has been arrested eight times in subway robberies. Mr. O'Leary said it was up to the Manhattan District Attorney's office to decide whether to upgrade the charges against Mr. Lawerence as a result of Ms. Cheng's death.
The suspect was taken last night to Bellevue Hospital Center for psychiatric evaluation, transit officials said.

HEADLINE: DE GUSTIBUS;
A City Dinner for Greenmarket Farmers

BYLINE: By FLORENCE FABRICANT

 BODY:
THERE was an air of city slicker about the 50 farmers and members of their families done up in suits and ties, silk dresses and high heels who came to town on Sunday. For once, they had not awakened at 4 A.M. to load the truck with broccoli and apple cider and drive to the Greenmarkets. Winter is the time when most farmers, except for a hardy few with potatoes and baked goods to sell, take a break to examine seed catalogues.
The farmers assembled at the National Arts Club on Gramercy Park South to celebrate the 14th season of the urban farmers markets, to trade stories, express their concerns, eat dinner and, while they were at it, poke some fun at the powers that be. 
 "You didn't eat your tomato," said Henry Smith of Sycamore Farms in Middletown, N.Y., across the table to Barry Benepe, director of the Greenmarkets for the city's Council on the Environment.
Ellen Concklin, who, with her husband, Richard, owns the Orchards of Concklin in Pomona, N.Y., interjected, "Is that what that's supposed to be?"
The pale Florida tomato that adorned every plate was an embarrassment, like serving ballpark mustard in Dijon. But then, even boosterism could not enhance the appeal of the rutabaga from Hoeffner Farms in Montgomery, N.Y. Tough crowd.
"You've got yourself a raucous group," Jim Hightower, the guest of honor, who also left most of his rutabaga, told Mr. Benepe.
Mr. Hightower, who recently lost his bid for re-election as Texas Commissioner of Agriculture, is known in farming circles as the official who promoted farmers' markets and diversified agriculture and organic farming in his state.
The Greenmarket system received praise from the participants, although the meeting turned into something of a good-natured roast of Mr. Benepe. Mr. Hightower expressed amazement at Mr. Benepe's purple sports jacket, and the farmers chided him for his comment to the press last year that some of them made as much as $10,000 a day. "The low end of the range, $140, was left out of the quote," Mr. Benepe said.
But Bob van Nostrand, owner of Old Orchard Farms in Orient, L.I., who was among the first to participate in the program that operates in 18 citywide locations in season, put his appreciation very simply.
"We wouldn't be in farming today if it weren't for the Greenmarkets," he said.
Stanley Osczepinski, of S.&S.O. produce in Pine Island, N.Y., also credited the program for the growth of his operation.
"We used to grow 40 acres of onions," he said. "Now, because of the Greenmarket, we have 150 acres of vegetables. If there's money to be made, you have to diversify and change."
Vince D'Attolico, another Pine Island farmer who grows 96 kinds of vegetables, including 36 varieties of lettuce, and has had a stand in the Greenmarket since 1982, said, "A lot of onion farmers are going under left and right because they're so hard-nosed and reluctant to diversify."
Mr. D'Attolico, a former electrical contractor in New York City who moved out 12 years ago after having trouble collecting too many accounts, said he went into farming for the cash. "We're making a living and paying our bills," he said.
Leeks, garlic, cilantro, basil, exotic eggplants, sweet and hot peppers, finger potatoes, red lettuces and collard greens are some highly marketable crops that the New York State onion growers or the cabbage and potato farmers from Long Island have added in response to consumer demand.
In his remarks at the end of the dinner, Mr. Hightower cited an example of a Texas rancher with 7,000 acres in cattle and feed grains who came to Mr. Hightower's agency in desperation because he was unable to turn a profit.
"We discovered that Texans ate 100 million pounds of pinto beans a year and there were none being grown in the state," he said. "Now this farmer has expanded into 25,000 acres and the state of Texas has a new agricultural industry worth $29 million."
He also spoke of his enthusiasm for organic farming, which he said could result in higher yields, lower costs and less water use after the first couple of years, but not all of the farmers at the dinner were convinced.
"You can't do as successfully with apples, not in this damp climate," said Jim Lindsay of Idyllwood Orchard and Farm in Clifton Park, N.Y.
"I had customers who said they would love to buy organic apples," added his wife, Jenne. "So I brought a bushel of them down to the market and sold a total of two and a half pounds."
Like a number of other farmers, she said they do minimal spraying because chemicals are so expensive. "Consumers can be very demanding without understanding what's going on."
The beef and pork the Lindsays sell has not been treated with antibiotics and hormones. "It's a real selling point these days and it doesn't affect the quality," Mrs. Lindsay said.
Hall Gibson, owner of Ryder Farm which has existed for more than 200 years in Brewster, N.Y., and said preserving the family farm also meant caring for the environment. He added, "In this economy I think I'd rather be in farming than anything else."
Robert Lewis, marketing director for the New York State Department of Agriculture and Markets, said the Greenmarket program has helped revitalize open downtown spaces. For many of the farmers the Greenmarkets have also put them back in contact with the people.
"In the Greenmarket you know who your customers are because you see them every week, so you have to care about what you sell them or they won't come back," Mr. Smith said.
"For a big grower in Florida or California, whether or not someone likes what he grows doesn't matter because he doesn't come in contact with the people who eat his products."

HEADLINE: FOREIGN AFFAIRS;
A 'New' Soviet Policy

BYLINE: By Leslie H. Gelb

 BODY:
Marlin Fitzwater reached near-highs of understatement and wishful thinking in responding to threats of a Soviet crackdown against deserters and draft-dodgers in seven rebellious republics. Although Administration officials are hoping for a Gorbachevian miracle, everything is much worse than the White House spokesman let on yesterday.
 Soviet-American relations stand on the edge of yet another new era, after only three years of the old one. The phase that appears to be coming will be marked by drift, mounting mutual unhappiness and no new breakthroughs in negotiation or cooperation. Moscow will be self-absorbed, but not anti-American. This is not what the Bush Administration said yesterday, or should say soon.
 
 Yesterday Mr. Fitzwater warned Moscow "to cease attempts at intimidation." True, Moscow has issued similar threats to round up errant recruits before and backed off, but it's not likely this time. The Gorbachev regime has just about run out of internal credibility and cannot afford to fail the armed forces again.
 Marlin Fitzwater also said the Administration was "still planning" on a Bush-Gorbachev meeting in February. But Mr. Bush simply cannot go if the specter of war still hangs over the Persian Gulf. And with Americans believing that Moscow has used the gulf crisis to blunt the U.S. backlash (much the way the Israeli, British and French invasion of the Suez Canal in 1956 provided the Soviets with cover to put down the Hungarian uprising), the summit meeting would be politically unwise for some time.
 Finally, Mr. Fitzwater said he did not believe that his criticisms would undermine Soviet support for the U.S. position in the gulf. That's probably correct, for the time being. But for reasons of Soviet domestic politics, Soviet-American relations seem poised to go downhill and enter the next phase.
 The question is what the new "new" Soviet foreign policy is likely to be. And what should be the American response?
 We may never know whether Moscow would have threatened the republics again in the absence of the gulf crisis. At the least, the gulf situation made that decision easier. But the point is that a crackdown is inevitable sooner or later.
 Mikhail Gorbachev is moving to the right. He has to because he is getting no support from the center and left. And to move right means necessarily to emphasize the central tenet of the military, the K.G.B. and the Communist Party faithful -- the Soviet Union must remain a union or a viable federation by force and blood, if need be, and even if the bloodshed severely strains relations with Washington. Unity will take precedence over all other foreign and domestic goals.
 Here is what that is likely to mean in practice:
 First, there will be a slowdown, if not a standstill, in making decisions on arms control and other cooperative efforts with Washington. It will be harder to get help from Moscow on places like Afghanistan and Cambodia. The new crowd will want to be seen as tougher in defending traditional Soviet interests than outgoing Foreign Minister Shevardnadze.
 Second, Soviet rhetoric will stiffen, but in a new way. The military will press to maintain its budget, but not by generating an "external threat." The Soviet public would not buy this line, and the military does not need to peddle it. The internal threat is sufficient. There is also likely to be a ratcheting up of anti-Zionist rhetoric. To many Soviet leaders, Moscow's support for the U.S. gulf policy symbolizes the rising influence of the Zionist lobby.
 Third, the new policy most definitely will not call for a reversion to the old hard line of the old cold war. Whatever the new crowd thinks about America's challenge to Soviet values, they know their nation is far too weak economically and politically to revive trouble with Washington. That means they are unlikely to do anything that could jeopardize existing treaties and commitments.
 The inward-turning of the Soviet Union will be ugly, whether or not Mr. Gorbachev orders a crackdown now. It will hinder and delay important advances toward reducing arms and solving third-world conflicts. It will unnerve those living on and near Soviet borders.
 If this phase in Soviet foreign policy comes to full bloom, it should be cause for dismay, not for a re-evaluation of U.S. policy. Marlin Fitzwater was right to skip the self-righteous hysteria, stand up for American democratic values and sound hopeful. That stance can be awkward politically, but it is correct.

SECTION: Section A; Page 20; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 538 words

HEADLINE: Let Every Depositor Sleep Securely

 BODY:
Mobs of depositors descended on the Bank of New England Friday after it announced it was virtually insolvent. Fearing a run that could spread to other banks, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation swiftly took over the big bank and two affiliates and assured their depositors -- including those with accounts exceeding $100,000 -- that all their money would be safe. The banks reopened Monday; not one depositor was hurt.
Contrast that with what happened two months ago. Federal regulators allowed little Freedom National Bank in Harlem to collapse. No Federal takeover. No blanket protection for large depositors. Several neighborhood charities lost hundreds of thousands in accounts they mistakenly thought were fully insured. 
 To depositors in small banks and the bank owners, these two episodes constitute a rank injustice. Put your money in a big bank and you're protected by a policy known as "too big to fail." But put a lot of money in a neighborhood bank and you could lose big. The remedy, say several members of Congress, seems obvious: Stop protecting large banks.
But realistically that won't -- and probably can't -- happen. The collapse of a big bank could trigger a succession of other bank failures and a temporary, though frightening, downward spiral of bank lending and consumer spending. That is not a risk the F.D.I.C. can permit.
A better answer is to offer complete insurance coverage for all deposits at small and large banks alike. And to insure that banks don't mishandle these insured deposits, there must be new, stringent regulatory safeguards.
The threatened collapse of the Bank of New England set off a contagious round of withdrawals from good and bad banks alike that threatened the local economy. Even a healthy bank in Rhode Island had to be sent truckloads of cash from the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston because fearmongering comments on a local radio talk show set off panicky withdrawals. And most withdrawals from the Bank of New England on Friday and Saturday were from accounts that were fully insured.
The F.D.I.C. reacted responsibly in stopping the New England bank run, cold. Now Congress has to find a way to protect the insurance fund, and ultimately taxpayers, from future insolvencies.
An upcoming Treasury Department report on banking reform will outline one answer: making banks more profitable by permitting them to open branches across the nation and underwrite securities. Another answer will be to rein in reckless bank investments by charging risk-taking banks more for deposit insurance and requiring them to hold more capital reserves.
The most important steps will be to improve accounting standards so that regulators are forewarned of insolvencies, and to tighten regulatory powers so that shaky banks can be prevented from extending new loans.
With tighter supervision and safeguards, the F.D.I.C. could safely lift the present $100,000 cap on insured accounts. Any depositor who wants an insured account -- and is willing to accept the lower interest rates that such accounts pay -- could have it. That way every depositor could become too big to fail, and could sleep securely no matter what fears are mongered on radio talk shows.

HEADLINE: Why War Is Irrelevant

BYLINE: By Roger Morris; Roger Morris was a staff member of the National Security Council in the Johnson and Nixon Administrations.

DATELINE: SANTA FE, N.M.

 BODY:
As Secretary of State James Baker meets the Iraqi Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, hopes rise that the talks will amount to more than a repetition of the public postures of the two sides. In an era suspicious of secrecy, millions wish devoutly for a hidden agenda today in Geneva.
Yet, while the timetable clicks on inexorably in the Persian Gulf, there is a gathering sense of irrelevance about the stark options to which Washington is reduced. Neither war nor a last-minute diplomatic device will resolve the deeper issues that have brought us to this bleak rendezvous in the desert. Whatever the outcome in Geneva, the Administration's choices between battle and backdown betray an underlying futility -- and thus carry the seeds of future crisis. 
 Neither military action nor a status quo ante peace will remedy the incipient turmoil of Arabia, where the vast disparity between rich and poor creates bitter conflict within and among nations, where a U.S. "victory," by arms or ultimatum, will only strengthen belligerent forces like Iran and Syria while hastening anti-American upheavals.
Nor can Washington bomb or negotiate away the malignant oil dependence of Europe, Japan and the U.S., which makes this episode such a reckoning on past negligence. No smart weapons or shrewd bargains will alter the caprice of petroleum politics, or the inequities inflicted by the oil market on poor countries. Just as some showdown with Saddam Hussein will not release the resources needed for development and social peace in the Middle East, it will waste precious billions amid a deepening economic agony in the U.S.
Nothing in President Bush's strategy promises a creative initiative on the anachronistic Israeli-Palestinian conflict, at once symbol and substance of the larger crisis. No success now envisioned by the White House, whether through blood or bluster, purges that poison, and will probably only deepen it.
Least of all do Mr. Bush's options genuinely serve the heralded new world order, the beckoning image of a post-cold-war consortium of nations in which the President has wrapped his venture, and for which thousands of Americans may soon die. With its preponderance of U.S. forces in front of token, rear-guard allies, the martial assembly in the gulf may be the precedent for future Punic expeditions by the Pentagon, but scarcely for a new peacekeeping coalition.
Washington's corridor cajolery and economic-political blackmail, simply to gather resolutions and fig-leaf contingents, have hardly lent fresh legitimacy to the U.N. In its reflexive resort to Great Power extortion, the White House squandered a chance for authentic progress toward multilateral responsibility in a new era.
It is not merely that American men and women constitute a de facto mercenary force for the Germans, Japanese, Saudis and gulf sheiks, or that the Soviets, Chinese and others are absent. Just as national units of the gulf force cannot even talk to one another effectively in the field, western diplomacy has been fractured. The European Community, like the Arabs before them, is trying desperately to mount a mediation behind Washington's posturing and media polemics.
The gulf alliance reflects a sadly outmoded concept of collective security. There is no true collection of interests, no secure understanding of the irrelevance of both the old violence and the old diplomacy in a vastly changed international landscape.
No lesson taught the Iraqis seems likely to correct the deep-seated irresponsibility of the regime in Washington: Nothing will erase the fateful prelude to crisis -- a U.S. that had armed and subsidized Iraq for a variety of wanton purposes, that failed for bureaucratic reasons to try to deter aggression months before it happened, that ignored multiple warnings of invasion and left its unalerted citizens to become hostages.
On the eve, the Administration all but diplomatically acceded to the Iraqi attack. Then, in propaganda extraordinary even by the usual standards of political hypocrisy, it sought to incite both national idealism and native chauvinism by labeling its recent client another Hitler.
Imagine the alternatives: a U.S. that had not cynically armed one more dictator nor rendered itself an energy hostage in the greed of the 1980's; a Washington no longer culpable in profiteering and inequity in world resources, a President dedicated to statesmanlike lifting of the Arab-Israeli curse with genuine international initiative, a world in which 400,000 Americans need not be in the gulf because a principled foreign policy was there before them.
Instead, it is to the Bush Administration -- without effective check or balance because of the foreign policy abdication of Congress -- that America and the rest of the world will still be prey, whatever happens in the next few weeks. Perhaps that is what makes Washington's expected victory in the Persian Gulf already so Pyrrhic.
The ultimate irony is that the crisis presents a chance to deal with fundamental challenges of the post-cold-war world. In the grim concentration of global attention, these last days of peace afford an opportunity like no other in this century, and a singular moment for U.S. statesmanship.
A comprehensive and farsighted American peace effort would begin with authentic negotiations with Baghdad, not to reward aggression but to see it in proportion and to look beyond to ethnic, territorial and economic grievances dating to the Ottoman Empire. Iraq would be given equitable national treatment on disputed petroleum and access to the gulf. Kuwaiti sovereignty would be restored under U.N. auspices with an end to predatory oil practices. U.S. and allied armies would be withdrawn in favor of U.N. buffer forces. The price of Iraq's violence would be the dismantling of its threatening arsenals, though part of a larger regional settlement in which concessions would be security for all sides.
Washington would let the European Community take the lead on the Palestinian issue, recognizing the Europeans' stake and credibility as well as setting a precedent for shared responsibility. Simultaneously, every resource of American diplomacy would be applied to forging a united Arab commitment to settlement, to ridding Israel of its indispensable enemy by pan-Arab demilitarization, on the model of Mikhail Gorbachev's arms initiatives toward the U.S.
To Israel the U.S. would pledge, by a joint resolution of Congress, that any invasion of its pre-1967 territory (excluding Gaza) would be equivalent to an attack on the U.S., requiring our full defense. We would urge the U.N., and particularly the Soviet Union, to join us. But with or without their participation, the U.S. commitment would be unequivocal.
If Israel failed to join promptly in European-sponsored negotiations, it would be the U.S. position that our principled support does not extend to mutual suicide, and that Israel would be economically sanctioned like any other international obstructor.
To the Palestinians, the U.S. would pledge its matching commitment to the establishment and integrity of a sovereign state on the West Bank and in Gaza, in return for an immediate end to the intifada and prompt settlement negotiations. As with Israel, Palestinian hostilities under any guise would bring new, U.S.-sponsored international sanctions.
Washington would lead a world consortium to provide special aid to Jordan, and technical and educational assistance to Palestine, enabling them to gain their peaceful equilibrium. Civil rights of Arab citizens in Israel and Jewish citizens in Palestine, along with the multicultural status of Jerusalem, would be enforced by the U.N., a first act of the new world order.
The U.S. and other wealthier nations would press for a new Middle East commonwealth -- adama tziburit in Hebrew, al-tharwa al-oumoumiya in Arabic, the ancient, concept of a shared land and resources, economic and spiritual. A regional development bank would equitably redistribute from rich Arab nations to poor, away from chaos toward equity and vested interests in peace. The U.S. would support a Middle Eastern community, Arab and Jew, no less than it supported European unity, and for similar historical reasons.
A Middle East demilitarization conference, nuclear and conventional, would be convoked by U.S. leadership through the U.N., on the principle of "trust but verify," with international inspection of all states. Regional arms control would parallel U.S.-Soviet-European arms reductions.
The White House would launch at home a program for energy diversification and alternative fuels, aimed not only at domestic realignment but also at international conservation, conversion, and planetary management of scarce resources, environmental hazards and imbalances in development. That -- not the anachronistic and unavailing punishment of Iraq -- would give meaning to the words new, world and order.
If only the rhetorical fictions of politics, the false practicalities and irrelevant experiences did not impede such a breakthrough. If only an American President, letting a petty dictator claim what he will in a small corner, could move confidently beyond to build a legitimate peace and receive his own rightful credit.

HEADLINE: World Farmers Would Gain by Cut in Subsidies

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"The World's Farmers Reject Trade Plan," Lement Harris's Dec. 20 letter, should have been headlined "World's Richest Farmers Reject Trade Plan." Mr. Harris groups northern and southern farmers together as the victims of any General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade round to reduce protectionism in agriculture. This is contradictory and erroneous.
True, dropping levels of support in agriculture would cause some northern farmers to go out of business. However, southern farmers in less developed countries, those who do not enjoy heavy subsidy, would benefit from reduction in agricultural world protectionism. It would level the playing field in their favor by forcing heavily subsidized farmers in industrial countries to become competitive or be forced out of world markets.
Mr. Harris refers to farmers in North Dakota selling loaves of bread for 5 cents each to illustrate the farmer's pathetic share of a $1.50 loaf. This has little to do with domestic and international agricultural policy, but instead with the vast processing and marketing system operating in the United States and most other industrial countries. Attempting to connect the misfortune of some 6,000 farmers in North Dakota who have been forced out of business because of lower prices to the GATT proposal is absurd. Dropping levels of support might slow or reverse this trend, bringing new markets to wheat producers and drawing higher prices for these agricultural products.
Mr. Harris states that we should not be surprised if some American farmers sent a letter of thanks to the presidents of France and Germany. Thanks for what? For denying access to markets in Europe for United States grain and beef, along with many other commodities that United States and third world farmers produce more efficiently than those in France or Germany? Or maybe for contributing to the losses incurred by those 6,000 North Dakota farmers by subsidizing and dumping their excess supply exports into third country markets?
Mr. Harris mentions as opposed to free trade Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Indonesia and Malaysia, members of the Group of 15. These countries are fervent advocates of free agricultural trade and against protectionism that distorts the flow of agricultural commodities. There is continuous support for GATT and free trade from the Group of 15.
A document released during its meeting last June states: "We are concerned that some industrialized countries continue to heavily subsidize farm production and agricultural exports which deprive developing countries of fair and competitive market opportunities. We therefore support steps to reduce, if not to eliminate, such agricultural trade-distorting subsidies."
Thus, while southern countries bemoan low world prices for raw agricultural products, they see protectionism as contributing to low prices and the GATT as a potential saving force.
 
JAIME A. CASTANEDA
COURTNEY HAROLD
Washington, Dec. 26, 1991
 
The writers are research economists at the National Center for Food and Agricultural Policy, Resources for the Future.

SECTION: Section A; Page 20; Column 5; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: World Farmers Would Gain by Cut in Subsidies;
Blame Europe

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Why the Trade Talks Fizzled" (Op-Ed, Dec. 20), Sir Roy Denman, former head of the European Community mission in Washington, dem
onstrates a nifty two-step in suggesting reasons for the failure of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade negotiations in Brussels. Mr. Denman attributes the outcome to a falling economic tide and exaggerated expectations. But neither argument washes.
The breakdown in Brussels developed when the European Community, supported by Japan and Korea, stonewalled appeals by the rest of the world to discipline their trade-distorting agricultural export subsidies and to open their agricultural markets further.
Agriculture has been debated in previous GATT rounds over at least two decades, under varying economic conditions. It is not economic travail that has prevented the development of international rules in this area comparable to what has evolved in the GATT for industrial goods. It is the lack of political will, particularly in Western Europe. If anything, the danger of a global recession should have helped stimulate a positive response by the European Community in Brussels, but regrettably that did not occur.
If expectations were exaggerated, it was the European Community whose views were out of line with those of most of the world, including a host of developing countries. Realizing that the GATT needed to play catch-up in agriculture, nearly all other countries were prepared to undertake major reforms over the next decade. Though change is politically difficult, these countries, including the United States, were prepared to reduce export subsidies dramatically, expose their farmers to global competition and reduce their internal subsidy programs. The European Community, however, wanted to nibble only at the edges of reform.
If there were any negotiations at gunpoint in Brussels, they came from the European Community too -- saying to the rest of the world, "We want to protect our markets from your exports, we want to dump our surpluses on the world market, and we want to retain the policies that permit us to do so." That is trade policy at its worst, and the rest of the world will no longer tolerate it. It should come as no surprise that the European Community was isolated in Brussels.
Let's hope the European Community will yet find the political will to salvage these negotiations. Otherwise, all of us, including Western Europe, will pay a heavy price for failure.
 
CLAYTON YEUTTER
Secretary of Agriculture
Washington, Jan. 2, 1991

HEADLINE: Marko Nikezic, Yugoslav Liberal Forced to Quit by Tito, Dies at 69

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER

 BODY:
Marko Nikezic, a former Foreign Minister of Yugoslavia who was considered the leading liberal politician of Serbia in the postwar era, died of intestinal cancer Sunday night in Belgrade. He was 69 years old.
In 1972, he was head of the Serbian Communist Party, the largest party formation in the country, when President Tito compelled him and dozens of his closest associates to resign after accusing them of "liberalism." Mr. Nikezic had advocated and fostered an independent press, a market-oriented economy and the "democratization of decision-making." 
 Tito's assault on the Serbian leadership was the climax of a campaign he had begun the previous year in the Croatian republic to remove all challengers to his authority. It had the effect of postponing the evolution of Yugoslavia as a whole, and Serbia in particular, toward a more democratic society until well after Tito's death in 1980.
Even though removed from the political scene, Mr. Nikezic remained, in the words of Aleksandr Nenadovic, a longtime associate, "the center of gravity" for Serbs seeking to revive their nation's democratic parliamentary traditions of the 19th century.
In retirement Mr. Nikezic became an accomplished sculptor, and an exhibition of his works in marble and wood is being planned in Belgrade.
 
Fought Nazi Occupation
 Soft-spoken and deliberate in his choice of words, Mr. Nikezic joined the Communist Party at 19 and became a Partisan guerrilla fighting the Nazi occupation in 1941. The German military command put a price on his head in posters distributed around Belgrade. He was subsequently decorated for bravery. His wife, Zora, was also a Partisan.
A former student of architecture, he entered the diplomatic service in 1951 and served in Egypt and Ethiopia. He was appointed ambassador to Prague in 1956 and was named ambassador to Washington in 1958 at 37.
He became Foreign Minister in 1965 and in the Prague Spring of 1968 journeyed to the Czechoslovak capital to praise the democratization process under way there. Following the Soviet bloc invasion of that country, he was elected chairman of the Serbian Communists.
His father, Petar, was an engineer; his mother, Suzanne, was French. He was born in Belgrade in 1921.
In addition to his wife, he is survived by two sons, Branko and Zoran, and two grandchildren.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Marko Nikezic (Associated Press, 1965)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Obituary (Obit)

COUNTRY: SERBIA (96%); SERBIA & MONTENEGRO (95%); CZECH REPUBLIC (90%); EGYPT (79%); UNITED STATES (79%); GERMANY (79%); CROATIA (79%);

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Stanley Expecting Drop in 1990 Net

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: NEW BRITAIN, Conn., Jan. 9

 BODY:
The Stanley Works, the hardware and tools supplier, predicted its earnings for 1990 would be down 5 percent to 8 percent. "Stanley fourth-quarter sales and earnings have been affected by the spreading economic weakness in the United States," said Richard H. Ayers, chairman and chief executive. The company has not yet released earnings for the fourth quarter or the year.
To offset lower consumer demand, the company is cutting staff through layoffs and attrition, a spokeswoman, Patricia R. McLean, said. The number of cutbacks was not specified. Stanley also moved to save money through worker furloughs over the holidays. In 1989, Stanley earned $117.7 million, or $2.71 a share, on sales of about $2 billion.

HEADLINE: TALKING DEALS;
Help for Canada's Nuclear Industry

BYLINE: By Matthew L. Wald

 BODY:
THE last time Atomic Energy of Canada Ltd. had a foreign order for a nuclear reactor was in 1981, when Romania promised payment in everything from strawberries to underwear. Although Romania eventually paid what it promised, it ran out of money and left the plant half-finished.
Stories of unfinished projects have become typical in the hard times that have hit the nuclear reactor industry in the last 15 years. But a recent order from Korea has revived hopes at Atomic Energy that its business has not fully disappeared. 
 Very few countries have broken ground on new plants recently, and export orders have been rarer still. Atomic Energy's last order before Romania's was from Ontario Hydro in the mid-1970's. That is about the same time that American manufacturers saw their last domestic orders (not counting orders for more than 100 reactors canceled before completion).
American companies have had somewhat better success in the world market. In 1987, the Tokyo Electric Power Company agreed to buy two advanced models from the General Electric Company; Combustion Engineering Inc., now a subsidiary of Asea Brown Boveri A.B., sold two to South Korea, and the Westinghouse Electric Corporation won an order from Britain's Central Electricity Generating Board.
Japan, South Korea and Indonesia are the current export targets of reactor makers. Atomic Energy of Canada also thinks an order may come from the Netherlands.
Canada has found exports harder in part because of the unique type of commercial reactor it builds. But while its Candu system -- so named because it uses deuterium in the reactor process -- is often a hard sell because of its uniqueness, it has advantages in sustaining nuclear fission.
American reactors use uranium that has been painstakingly enriched, carrying three times as much fissionable material as is found in nature. The Candu runs on natural uranium, which attracted the Romanians, who would have had to send their uranium to the Soviet Union for enrichment.
The Korea Electric Power Corporation, the Government-owned national utility that gave Atomic Energy of Canada an order recently, was attracted to the Canadian design by this and two other features: The Candu can be made to run on leftover uranium from some of Korea's existing plants. And the Candu can operate nearly continuously, because it can be refueled while running.
Electricity demand is rising in South Korea bynearly 15 percent a year, which implies a doubling in five years. "They have no coal, no oil, no gas and no hydro," said Dr. Stanley R. Hatcher, president and chief executive of Atomic Energy of Canada. "Nuclear is sure to be a big part."
The South Korean company already has a Candu, Wolsong 1, built in 1983. It began operating only 61 months after construction started, half what reactors in the United States take to build, and in 1986, it held the world record for reliability.
Wolsong 2, as the new 700-megawatt reactor will be designated, is to be completed by 1997. The price is $600 million (Canadian), of which one-third will go to South Korean subcontractors and the rest to Canadian companies.
The order may be even more important to the Canadians than the Koreans. Aside from providing $400 million (Canadian) in hardware and service contracts -- signed in Seoul last month -- the project will keep skills alive, Dr. Hatcher said.
"This Korean sale is an important element of keeping the industry viable, and keeping the work in the shops," he said. The sale means 2,000 jobs for four years and another 5,000 created indirectly.
But surviving another nine years without an order "would be hard," Dr. Hatcher acknowledged. The plan of Atomic Energy of Canada and others is to hold on long enough for a turnaround in the business. It is hoped that electrification of growing economies like South Korea's, combined with fear of global warming induced by burning coal or other fuels, will spur new reactor orders.
Ontario Hydro's plans for 10 new reactors is in doubt because of a change of the provincial government last year. But Atomic Energy has a nearby market in mind: It is discussing with the Nuclear Regulatory Commission how to license a small Candu reactor in the United States. Dr. Hatcher said he expected the United States to have a nuclear revival, adding, "We hope to be there."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Sequent Shares Drop by 33.3%

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 9

 BODY:
Shares in Sequent Computer Systems Inc. plummeted today after the company said its earnings for the fourth quarter, which ended on Dec. 29, would be lower than in the corresponding period last year.
Sequent, which is based in Beaverton, Ore., had been the last important computer manufacturer with uninterrupted growth in earnings. Its shares closed today at $11.50 in over-the-counter trading, down $5.75 a share, or 33.3 percent.
While Sequent expects revenue for the quarter to be at least 50 percent higher than the $47.8 million it reported for the fourth quarter of 1989, net earnings are expected to be 10 cents to 20 cents a share, compared with 23 cents in the quarter last year.
The profit decline was caused by a combination of three things, Casey Powell, Sequent's chairman and chief executive, said in a statement. These were a drop, from $16 million in the third quarter to below $10 million in the fourth, in the company's original- equipment manufacturing business, in which Sequent computers are resold by the Unisys Corporation; the softening of the economy, and the transition to a new product line.
Mr. Powell said he expected the first quarter of 1991 to be difficult also. "I think we're going to come out of this healthy," he said. "I don't think we're going to come out of it unscathed."

HEADLINE: Waterville Valley Journal;
Snow Isn't Just a Four-Letter Word

DATELINE: WATERVILLE VALLEY, N.H., Jan. 9

 BODY:
Every night since early November, the residents of this resort community nestled in the White Mountains have waited, eyes upturned, for a hint of the winter storms that are their livelihood.
None of them can recall waiting quite so long. 
 Like other ski areas throughout New England, Waterville Valley is grappling with a dismal lack of snow. The trace amounts of snow that have fallen on the region for much of the season have quickly disappeared, leaving trees, roadsides and mountaintops unseasonably bare. The several inches that fell today made the scenery look better, but it will take more than that to turn the season around.
With two big back-to-back rains on Dec. 23 and 24, the countryside did not look at all like Christmas. A second pair of rainstorms on Dec. 29 and 30 insured that it did not look like New Year's either.
Those who live here year-round and depend on skiers for their income say the weather, coupled with the sluggish economy, has dealt a serious blow to their collective psyche. "Everyone's in survival mode," said Russell Roth, who was recently laid off from the Waterville Valley ski resort and now works at the Great American Ski Renting Company in nearby Campton. "We're trying not to get too depressed."
Much of Northern New England, which usually receives 25 to 45 inches of snow from late November through the second week of January, has had only 11 to 20 inches, said Fred Gadomski, a meteorologist with the Pennsylvania State University Weather Communications Group.
The culprit, Mr. Gadomski said, is a high pressure system off the coast of Florida, which sends pockets of warm air up the East Coast and which snuffs out big snowstorms in their infancy. That system has kept many of Waterville's usual patrons, and their wallets, at home in the Boston area, 130 miles south of here.
Bob Fries, the vice president and general manager of the Waterville Company, which runs the resort, said its revenue is $1 million lower than last year at this time, when the resort was the beneficiary of several bountiful snowfalls.
"No one likes to come out of the holiday period down a million dollars in revenue," said Tom Corcoran, the founder and chief executive officer of the Waterville Company. "But we've got a good chance at making that up, depending on the weather."
Mr. Corcoran's optimism looked justified over the weekend, when several thousand skiers crammed more than half of the resort's 48 trails, which were miraculously covered with a hard-packed cover of what appeared to be snow. Even the giant evergreens bordering the trails were encased in thick white coats, though the surrounding peaks were nothing but grass, rocks and patches of mud.
The skiing was possible because Waterville, like most ski areas in the Northeast, has spent millions of dollars over the last 20 years on a mechanical system that creates snow.
The process, which is simple but expensive, combines water and compressed air. When the mixture is blown out of huge cannons set at strategic points around the mountain, the result is a simulated snowfall, as long as the air temperature is less than 29 degrees.
Though the weather has been cold enough in the last week for snow to be manufactured virtually round the clock, Waterville is struggling to persuade skiers in the Boston area that the resort is open for business. That's because of what the industry calls the "backyard syndrome": if a skier does not see snow in his backyard, he will be reluctant to venture north and spend $35 a day for a ski-lift ticket.
To bring skiers back, Waterville has been broadcasting commercials on Boston television stations that feature Mr. Corcoran skiing with a backdrop of white-covered trails.
The commericals may be working: Waterville sold 17,500 lift tickets from Dec. 31 to Jan. 6, a thousand more than in the same period a year ago, said Mr. Fries, the general manager.
But the "backyard syndrome" can be insidious. As she prepared to board Waterville's chair lift Sunday, Susan Hunter of Bedford, N.H., said she had skied only twice this season, despite investing hundreds of dollars in a season pass.
"From the valley, you look up at the mountains and all you see are these brown patches," said Ms. Hunter. "We really had to motivate to get out here."
And once she got here, Ms. Hunter said she found that much of the powdery "machine made" snow had disappeared by noon, exposing the mountain's base, which in many places is a sheet of ice. By Sunday afternoon, many skiers were trying in vain to dig the edges of their skis into the hard base, which in some places was more conducive to skating than skiing.
As skiers scrambled around the base lodge here Sunday morning, donning parkas and pulling on hats, Greg Gostanian, 41, and his wife Kathy, 40, seemed oblivious. Sitting close to a big fireplace, a tall thermos of coffee their only companion, they said they were not skiing because the conditions were too icy.
"It's not worth it," said Mr. Gostanian. "We can live with it for now. But there's still the eternal optimism: all it takes is one storm."

(Suki Coughlin for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: How 3 Embattled Builders Survive

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

 BODY:
With real estate prices falling and buyers treating the new-home market as if it had a wet basement and no rooms with a view, many builders are struggling to stay alive until the next upturn in sales.
Three home builders, operating in three different regions, have come up with survival strategies that seem to be working. 
 In New Jersey, K. Hovnanian Enterprises is pulling back from the overbuilt condominium market to concentrate on mid-priced houses in the central part of the state for baby boomers who are building their families and moving out of apartments.
In Southern California, Ira Norris has rethought his housing production system, from the first site plans to the last carpet tack, and is forcing supplier prices and his own profits down to where the market will buy. In Boston, Tony Green is working for the banks, finishing and selling developments that have been foreclosed.
"This is strictly a holding action," Mr. Green said. "We're just trying to keep our team together until the market comes back."
In a decade the country's home builders have seen their business go from the richest of times, in the mid-80's, to some of the bleakest of times. Some builders have gone back to their old standby, the home-improvement trade; others are wondering what they will do after completing the houses on order, and many have failed, judging from the falling membership of the National Association of Home Builders, which has tumbled to 158,000, from 161,000 last April.
In 1986, the industry's best year ever, 1.8 million single-family homes and apartments were built. In 1990, the industry put up 1.2 million single-family homes and apartments, the lowest level since the recession of 1981-82 and a drop in business from 1989 of 33 percent.
On Jan. 2, the Commerce Department reported that residential construction spending in constant dollars had dropped for the eighth month in a row to the lowest level since 1983.
"We have worked ourselves into a real recession," said Kenneth Colton, executive vice president of the home builders group. "The terminology you will hear our members use is that suddenly the door slammed shut."
The White House has predicted a short and mild recession. But with buyers already paying more for fuel and in taxes, and with war threatened in the Persian Gulf and lenders wary of making new real estate development loans, builders and industry analysts are pessimistic about an early upturn in their business. They point to the baby bust as evidence that the golden age of residential real estate, just ended, is unlikely to return.
Yet the market is not completely dead. An estimated 1.2 million new households are expected to be formed each year in this decade, down from 1.5 million a year during the 80's. And mortgage rates, at a three-year low, have begun to lift the rate of housing sales slightly in recent months.
 
A New Formula
 Mr. Norris, of Upland, Calif., looked at Southern California's booming population but slumping housing sales and prices and decided that the traditional housing development equation had to be rewritten. His new formula has made him a minor legend in the high desert east of Los Angeles.
Normally, developers like Mr. Norris secure the land and obtain construction permits and then ask for bids from subcontractors. Subcontractors then call door, window, plumbing and framing concerns for prices, add overhead, an allowance for breakage and theft, a profit goal and mail in a number.
Mr. Norris, a big builder who has put up more than 500 houses a year since he formed Inco Homes in 1976, decided to squeeze that process by forcing his subcontractors to negotiate for their materials. "The problem is that these subs are used to being quoted prices, and so they're lousy negotiators," Mr. Norris said.
 
A Matter of Survival
 For subcontractors, he said, this approach is a matter of survival. "We realized that housing contractors that don't concentrate on reducing their overhead and cutting their costs are not going to make it through this recession," Mr. Norris said. "So we told them that we would cut our profit and overhead if they would do the same, and that we would be able to build a house that the market would not pass by."
In addition, by putting 1,800 lots on 500 acres in the western Mojave desert town of Adelanto -- a hard, but not unheard-of, 100-mile commuting trip to Los Angeles -- he kept his land prices low.
The result of both strategies: a construction cost of $27 a square foot, compared with the normal $35 to $40 a square foot, and a two- to four-bedroom house that can be sold for $80,000 to $100,000, compared with $105,000 and up in the adjoining community of Victor Valley, said Mr. Norris, who has built more expensive houses in Los Angeles.
 
Quick Sales
 On Oct. 13, he put his first 55 houses on the market, and by nightfall had sold 47 of them. The remaining 8 were gone the next day, a Sunday, he said. Within a week, all 127 houses in his first phase had been sold, he said.
"He's selling them as fast as he can build them," said Patricia Chamberlin, the Adelanto town administrator.
Of the housing market, Mr. Norris said, "We're predicting a blood bath out there in '91." He added that with his new strategy "we are getting a lot of work and a lot of cash flow but not a lot of profit, but at least we'll be intact and still be in business when the recession ends."
And West Coast banks are still more open to lending to developers than those in the East. Mr. Norris raised 25 percent of the $32.6 million needed to build the 127 houses from an equity partner and the remainder from the Union Bank and the Security Pacific National Bank in Los Angeles.
To ride out the slump, the Boston-based Green Company is working down its inventory and helping banks sell development projects that were foreclosed. In 1987, Green started 70 town houses that went on the market for upward of $240,000. It has seven left, and will soon have none, although it has had to give enticements to close many sales.
"I don't think there is a builder anywhere who isn't willing to do a little something for a buyer to make a deal happen," said Mr. Green, the company's vice president for marketing. "For one person, it may take adding wood floors, another may have to save some money. So you customize the plan a little to cut the costs for him."
The company, which built an average of 60 houses a year and was founded in 1964 by Tony's father, Alan, who is chairman, also has six projects to complete and sell in the Boston area for banks.
Each has required a distinct treatment aimed at overcoming what Mr. Green considers the toughest obstacle to sales these days: buyers' fear of getting a house that will lose value, as houses across the country have declined in value in recent months.
That is not only a matter of price. "It can be priced rock bottom, but if there's a rusting construction trailer or no landscaping or the roads aren't paved, they won't touch it," Mr. Green said.
 
The Impression of Value
 Builders can often add the impression of value to a whole development by investing more money in a few of the houses, Mr. Green said. Only 3 of 24 homes had been sold at the Arbors, a condominium development in Acton, Mass., when it was taken over by the lender, the Foxboro Savings Bank.
Hired to sell the remaining homes, Mr. Green's company thought the problem was that the floor plan, with two upstairs bedrooms, did not fit the project's high-end, $290,000 to $390,000 price range. The mostly older, second- or third-time buyers and empty-nesters who pay these prices often prefer to have master bedrooms on the ground floor, Mr. Green said.
But rather than reconfiguring all 19 of the unsold units, Mr. Green cut the price to $200,000 on all but 7 units. On those, he added 10-by-10-foot extensions to make room for a big downstairs bedroom, at an additional cost to the buyer of $35,000.
"That allowed us to present the unfixed-up home in a much more positive light, because it now appears to be, and is, quite a good deal compared to the fixed-up home," the builder said.
Ten additional condominiums have since been sold, nine of them the unaltered models.
More important, from the bank's point of view, the building permits, which are hard to get in the crowded and growth-conscious Boston suburbs, have increased in value for 36 additional units, offsetting the write-off of about 30 percent of the value of the development that the bank was forced to take to sell the units quickly.
And Mr. Green is counting on his alliances with banks serving him over the longer term. "If we do our job for the Bank of Boston or for Chase Manhattan now, those guys are going to remember us when the next run-up comes." Mr. Green added, "We hope they'll look at us and say, 'Hey, those guys can do it even when things are pretty bad.' "
 
'There Is Demand'
 The basic element of Hovnanian's strategy is to keep prices down.
"We have found that there is demand in the marketplace, but the key is that your product has to be priced properly, and that means lower prices," said Ara Hovnanian, president of the publicly held builder, which is based in Red Bank, N.J.
Mr. Hovnanian's company met this challenge in part by announcing last month that it would take a $19 million write-down on unsold properties in New Hampshire, New York and Florida, and auction the condominiums off at fire-sale prices. The write-down will probably produce a $14 million net operating loss for the year. The Hovnanian company, which became famous in the New York area by holding lotteries in the mid-80's for eager town house condominium buyers, is backing away from the overbuilt condo market to concentrate on the higher-priced housing market.

HEADLINE: MARKET PLACE;
A Weak Outlook For Phone Giants

BYLINE: By Keith Bradsher

 BODY:
THE stocks of the nation's three main long-distance telephone companies all fell sharply last year after three years of strong gains, and some analysts say they are unlikely to recover soon because of concerns about the weakening economy.
Shares in the industry leader, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, fell 34 percent last year. The stock of the MCI Communications Corporation, the second-largest long-distance company, plummeted 55 percent. Stock of United Telecommunications Inc., the parent of U S Sprint, dropped 39 percent. 
 Three problems face the industry: slower growth in long-distance traffic, higher marketing expenses and the possibility of another price war.
For the last several decades, annual growth in long-distance has tended to equal the annual change in the nation's economic growth plus 7 to 10 percentage points. The Federal Communications Commission says the growth in traffic has been particularly robust during the recent economic boom, with an average annual increase of 12.9 percent from mid-1984 through mid-1990.
Now, some analysts forecast growth of as little as 7 percent this year. Long-distance use depends most directly on white-collar employees, who make the many weekday calls that pay for most of the cost of building and expanding the nation's telephone network. "Guys on the G.M. factory floor are not making calls from 8 to 5," said Joel D. Gross, an analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.
White-collar employment has been an early and conspicuous victim of the current economic downturn. New York City accounts for a third of the nation's international calls and up to a fifth of its domestic long-distance calls, in large part because of the enormous reliance of its banks and brokerages on voice and data communications. These businesses are now contracting.
In interviews over the last three months, the chairmen of A.T.& T., MCI and United Telecom have each said they expect long-distance traffic to continue growing even if the economy slumps. "It has always been a growth industry, and it has only been a question of what level of growth," said William G. McGowan, the chairman of MCI.
Indeed, the last years in which traffic actually fell were 1931, 1932 and 1933, in the depths of the Great Depression, said Donald A. Sweeney, an economist at A.T.& T.
When the American oil industry slumped in the mid-1980's, oil companies increased their use of computer messaging over long-distance lines to replace more expensive corporate travel. Long-distance companies hope more companies will substitute telecommunications for travel this year.
Mr. McGowan, Robert E. Allen of A.T.& T. and William T. Esrey of United Telecom all pointed to international telephone traffic, which has been growing more than 20 percent a year, as a source of strength during any recession. The number of such calls grew quickly last year because many American businesses have strong overseas sales, and expansion should continue even during a recession, Mr. Allen said.The Federal Communications Commission's recent effort to drive down the fees charged by foreign monopolies for accepting international calls should make this business more profitable for American carriers, Mr. McGowan said.
But, according to the commission, American carriers collected $5.1 billion for international calls in 1989, or only about 10 percent of the industry's $52 billion in revenues. So analysts say the fee effort may not make a big difference.
At the same time, long-distance carriers increasingly offer big discounts to major companies on contracts that guarantee that the carrier gets most of the customer's traffic. Some corporations are cutting their long-distance expenses by as much as 20 to 30 percent with such contracts, said Berge A. Ayvazian at the Yankee Group, a telecommunications consulting company in Boston.
These corporations often rely on their own switching equipment to send their calls over another carrier if their primary carrier has technical problems, as when a broken cable disrupted A.T.& T.'s New York service on Friday.
If the growth rate of overall long-distance traffic does drop sharply this year, recent history indicates that each carrier, when its own traffic slows, will quickly respond with lower prices or increased spending on marketing. U S Sprint moved 400 employees into marketing after a disappointing second quarter last year. MCI, after a weak third quarter, said it planned to increase advertising this year. Extra spending on marketing trimmed the long-distance industry's profit margins last year.
MCI and A.T.&T. are now preparing for further struggles for market share in the first three months of 1991. "Here you have the two sides armed for war, ready to go after each other's heads in the first quarter, just as the economy's going downhill," Mr. Gross said. "If that isn't cause for concern, I don't know what is."

HEADLINE: New Impetus in Honda Car-Building Effort

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 9

 BODY:
The Honda Motor Company, responding to "a number of socio-economic changes" that have complicated business, including the new Clean Air Act in the United States, announced today that it was intensifying efforts to develop vehicles that will set new environmental, energy and safety standards.
Honda provided few details, except to say it was working on a highly energy-efficient compact model that would be introduced "in the near future." The auto maker will also begin public testing of what it says is the world's first electric motorcycle this year in Japan. 
 Honda also announced it would create in Southeast Asia a fourth area for "self-reliant" automotive marketing and production, in addition to its centers in Japan, Europe and the United States.
What a spokesman characterized as Honda's "new direction" was outlined in a New Year's address and policy statement, delivered in Tokyo by Nobuhiko Kawamoto, who took over in June as Honda's president and chief executive.
Although Honda is one of Japan's smaller auto makers, it has produced some of the industry's most important engine technology, and therefore is closely watched by competitors. In the mid-1970's, Honda's CVCC engine, introduced in the Civic model, surprised the industry by meeting United States emission requirements without a catalytic converter or peripheral engine hardware. More recently, Honda engines have dominated Grand Prix racing.
 
Worldwide Strategy Pursued
 Rather than rely solely on imports, Honda has pursued a worldwide strategy of building separate companies for separate parts of the world that do their own consumer research and build and market their own vehicles. The company operates several plants and laboratories in North America.
Honda sold nearly one million Honda and Acura brand cars in the United States in 1990, surpassing the Chrysler Corporation as the No. 3 seller of cars. Mr. Kawamoto said the company's target for 1991 is one million.
