HEADLINE: Toyota Set to Expand in U.S. Market

BYLINE: By PAUL C. JUDGE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 9

 BODY:
In a bid to expand in the United States market, the Toyota Motor Corporation today announced a two-seat sports coupe made in Japan but aimed at young Americans buying their first cars.
Robert McCurry, executive vice president of Toyota's United States sales arm, also told reporters today that he expects a decision within 60 days on whether the Japanese auto maker will build a full-size pickup truck for the United States market. 
 If Toyota decides to build a full-size pickup, it would mark the first attempt by a foreign auto maker to break into the profitable and high-volume market in the United States for large pickups, which so far has been the exclusive domain of Detroit's Big Three.
Mr. McCurry said he expects the new Paseo sports coupe, due to arrive in dealer showrooms by June, to add 35,000 car sales for Toyota in 1991 and 50,000 the following year, relatively modest increases compared with the 779,208 cars Toyota sold in the United States last year.
Toyota offers a more expensive sports car, the MR-2, which has a base price of $15,148, as well as the Celica, ranging from $12,700 to $19,200, and the Supra, whose base price is $23,800. The Paseo, which is derived from the company's subcompact Tercel, was conceived by Toyota's United States executives to appeal to a growing number of entry-level sports car buyers, particularly young men.
With a tentative price of about $9,500, Toyota Motor Sales U.S.A. has positioned the Paseo to compete against other low-priced sports cars, including Honda's CRX, Hyundai's Scoupe, and Chevrolet's Geo Storm, which is manufactured by Isuzu for General Motors.
"The entry-level sporty car segment has grown dramatically in the last few years," said Christopher Cedergren, a market analyst for J.D. Power & Associates in Westlake Village, Calif. United States sales of sporty, fuel-efficient cars priced between $8,000 and $14,000 have blossomed from 111,000 units in 1989 to an estimated 178,000 in 1990, Mr. Cedergren said.
Toyota would need two years to bring out a full-size pickup, if it committed itself to the project, Mr. McCurry said. One problem Toyota faces, if it decides to sell large pickup trucks, is finding a plant where it can manufacture the vehicles. Although the company is doubling the size of its factory in Georgetown, Ky., all of the new capacity is already committed to expanding production of the compact Camry sedan, and the auto maker's Japanese plants are operating at full capacity.
Toyota sold 182,000 small pickup trucks in the United States last year, and will begin producing small pickups this summer at its joint-venture plant with the General Motors Corporation in Fremont, Calif.

HEADLINE: Connecticut Bank Seizure Stirs Hope

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Jan. 9

 BODY:
State business leaders and bank analysts believe this week's takeover by Federal regulators of Connecticut Bank and Trust, a subsidiary of the insolvent Bank of New England Corporation, could help Connecticut's economy if the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which insures bank deposits, manages to sell the bank to a strong institution within a few weeks.
A new owner might loosen commercial credit, helping to slow the state's downward economic spiral. Connecticut Bank and Trust, one of the state's largest lenders, had curtailed lending over the last year. 
 "The action of the F.D.I.C. has helped clean up the situation to the extent that there will be a buyer, and that it will provide a little bit more lending capability," said Edward J. Deak, an economics professor at Fairfield University in Fairfield, Conn., and the Connecticut analyst for the New England Economic Project, a nonprofit forecasting group.
 
Calling In Loans
 But Peter M. Gioia, director of research for the Connecticut Business and Industry Association, a trade organization based in Hartford, said that if the 135-branch New Connecticut Bank and Trust Company, as the bank was renamed by the F.D.I.C. on Sunday, remained unsold, the bank might have to call in loans to cover nonperforming assets, particularly real estate. "You now have a major New England bank that is not making any more loans," he said.
The bank lends to many of the companies based in the state, many of which say they will keep their accounts with the bank. As of Sept. 30, Connecticut Bank and Trust's loan portfolio was 28 percent commercial and industrial, 7 percent consumer, and 59 percent real estate and construction. The remaining 6 percent was made up of lending to the state and local municipalities and miscellaneous loans.
Since 1989, four other Connecticut banks and savings institutions have been taken over by other financial institutions in the state after becoming insolvent. They were National Industrial Bank of Meriden, Columbia Federal Savings Bank of Westport, Brooklyn Savings Bank of Brooklyn, Conn., and Community Federal Savings and Loan of Bridgeport.
Two other institutions -- the Charter Federal Savings and Loan of Stamford and Financial Federal Savings Bank of Hartford -- have been taken over by the Federal Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency in charge of the Government savings and loan bailout.
 
'A New England Problem'
 "It is statewide; it is probably a New England problem," said Mr. Gioia, also citing the closing of 45 banks and credit unions in Rhode Island last week. "It is happening in New Hampshire; it is happening in New Haven."
Although small and minority-owned businesses have apparently been especially hard hit by the credit squeeze, Diane Goodman, chairman of the business council of the Greater Hartford Chamber of Commerce, said the takeover of Connecticut Bank and Trust probably would not have a dramatic effect on most small businesses. "Small businesses go to small banks," she said.
The bank's larger commercial customers -- Connecticut-based companies like United Technologies, Ames Department Stores, Heublein Inc., Dairy Mart Convenience Stores and Cigna -- appear content to keep their funds at the bank, while the Government searches for a new owner.
"We are definitely optimistic," said Frank Colaccino, president of Dairy Mart, a chain of 1,200 stores based in Enfield, Conn., which plans to keep its commercial accounts with Connecticut Bank and Trust despite the Government takeover.
He said he was pleased with the F.D.I.C. guarantee of deposits of more than $100,000 and by the decision to leave the management of the 4,200-employee subsidiary in place. "From what I understand, C.B.T. was one of the stronger parts of the Bank of New England." he said.
 
Local Officials Optimistic
 Many municipal officials were also optimistic about the takeover. On Monday, the City of Hartford postponed a decision made on Friday to transfer $2 million to another bank.
And Tuesday, the State Commissioner of Banking, Howard B. Brown, rescinded a Jan. 4 order that gave the city 30 days to remove its transaction accounts from the bank.
The order had been issued because the bank fell below the requirement in a state law that says it must keep at least 3 percent of its assets in cash. A spokesman for the State Department of Banking, Dave Tedeschi, said today that the infusion of F.D.I.C. funds over the weekend gave New Connecticut Bank and Trust an equity-capital ratio that exceeded that level.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gold Prices Close Higher After Big Trading Swings

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Prices for precious metals futures fluctuated wildly yesterday, moving sharply lower in the morning on hopes for peace in the Persian Gulf and reversing direction after talks between the United States and Iraq failed to make progress.
Gold for February delivery on New York's Commodity Exchange plunged more than $10 an ounce in early trading as the war premium that built up in recent months was stripped away. Gold rallied in the afternoon, after Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said nothing had come of his meeting with Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz of Iraq. 
 Gold settled 60 cents to 90 cents higher, with the contract for delivery in February at $393 an ounce, up 70 cents. The February contract traded as high as $394.50 and as low as $379.50. The near-month January contract rose 90 cents to close at $391.20.
 
Silver Is Lower
 Silver was 2 cents to 7 cents lower, with March at $4.175 an ounce. Platinum was $1.20 to $2.20 higher, with January at $408.40 an ounce.
"Everything keyed off the Baker and Aziz meeting," said Randolph Donney, a metals analyst for the Pegasus Econometric Group. "There was anticipation some deal was being cooked up. With no peaceful solution occurring, everything reversed."
Grain and soybean futures prices, meanwhile, closed mostly higher on the Chicago Board of Trade.
Corn futures were lower on professional and commercial selling, in the wake of the announcement late on Tuesday that the United States had extended $530 million in feed grain credits to the Soviet Union.
Moscow has been allocated $900 million in short-term credit guarantees to buy American agricultural commodities.
The market reacted to ideas that the Soviets had already bought most, if not all, of the corn it wanted, analysts said.
Wheat futures showed modest gains after reaching contract lows in Tuesday's trading.
Over all, the market continued to be hampered by a lack of export business, analysts said.
Wheat was 1/2 cent to 2 1/2 cents higher, with March at $2.53 3/4 a bushel; corn was 3/4 cent to 1 cents lower, with March at $2.31 3/4 a bushel; oats were 2 cents to 2 1/4 cents higher, with March at $1.11 3/4 a bushel; soybeans were 1 1/2 cent to 3 cents higher, with January at $5.55 3/4 a bushel.
Livestock futures were mixed on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, because of pressure from high slaughter levels and weak cash prices.
Pork futures soared on higher cash prices.
Live cattle were 0.35 cent lower to 0.15 cent higher, with February at 76.70 cents a pound; feeder cattle were 0.05 cent lower to 0.33 cent higher, with January at 88.80 cents a pound; hogs were 0.07 cent to 1.50 cents higher, with February at 51.40 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.08 cents to 1.93 cents higher, with February at 70.50 cents a pound.

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
Themes for '91: A Sense of Limits And Wistfulness

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
Becoming Mayor during a recession was David N. Dinkins's first mistake. So it was no surprise that he referred almost wistfully this week to "a new beginning" as he and the Governors of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, each facing daunting deficits, delivered their ritual prognoses for the new year.
Mr. Dinkins, like the others, hopes somehow to transform economic adversity into opportunity. But he neglected to provide details of just what 1991 in New York City would be the beginning of. 
 In contrast, Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey finished his first year by acknowledging that he might have moved too quickly and not explained his goals adequately -- then he tried to regain the initiative by outlining new ones. (Mr. Dinkins failed to elaborate on why he might have moved too slowly.)
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who is beginning his third term, demonstrated again that it is more difficult for a veteran incumbent to deliver bad news than for a fledgling (like Mr. Dinkins, Mr. Florio and like Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. of Connecticut, who was inaugurated only yesterday). They inherited a legacy, as Mr. Cuomo had in 1983. Then, like this year, he faced the largest projected deficit in New York State's history.
Mr. Cuomo's predecessor, Hugh L. Carey, took office with the sobering pronouncement that the "days of wine and roses are over." For Mr. Cuomo, after eight years in office, to echo that theme risked derision for mere whine and poses. Instead, he called for "refocusing, reform, renewal" and derided the behavior of both parties in "Washington" even more often than he mentioned the word pain or its derivatives, which is what many of his constituents may suffer. (Mr. Cuomo also promised "no sacred cows or sacrificial lambs," but not no more animal metaphors).
Several themes threaded through this week's annual assessments: an unequivocal acknowledgement that fiscal stability is fundamental to any larger agenda, a goal of enlisting the private sector to supplement services that government can no longer afford and proposals that may demonstrate leadership but do not cost much (including Mr. Cuomo's suggested ban on most cigarette vending machines, one measure that the Mayor has already imposed locally). Mr. Dinkins vaguely hinted at only one new initiative: proposed juvenile justice legislation.
Today, Peter F. Vallone, Speaker of the New York City Council, is to deliver his own take on the city; he is expected to recommend a reorganization to make municipal government more efficient. Worse fiscal news follows later this month when the Mayor and the Governor unveil their budgets.
Legislators, public employees, lobbyists and other invited guests who dutifully attended the speeches at City Hall on Tuesday and in the Capitol in Albany yesterday appeared to applaud the loudest when Mr. Dinkins and Mr. Cuomo expressed outrage over crime and at the failure of government -- generally, a government other than their own -- to come to grips with it.
Mr. Cuomo lobbed salvos at Washington (for disingenuously declaring victory in its war on drugs and failing to adopt an energy policy), began his address with an expression of support for United States troops in the Persian Gulf and declared that the Pacific Rim's predominance would be superseded by an "era of the Atlantic" led by "global New York" -- inevitably fueling speculation that his own political ambitions reach beyond Albany, too.
Mr. Dinkins, standing directly under a quotation from Abraham Lincoln, quoted only the poet Langston Hughes in a speech what was otherwise widely described as pedestrian (which doesn't mean any one walked out) and noteworthy for largely missed opportunities: to articulate a vision, and to provide a cohesive framework for some seemingly contradictory decisions.
In a small way, speakers unwittingly provided some insight by what they said without meaning to. Mr. Dinkins predicted that "ours will be a smaller government, but a smaller one" -- then corrected himself and said "a stronger one." Mr. Cuomo said the collective heritage of all New Yorkers contributes to "how great this state was" -- then said "is."
Mr. Cuomo quoted no one, but drew on an address titled "We Cannot Escape History," which he included in "Lincoln on Democracy," a new anthology he edited with an associate, Harold Holzer.
Lincoln is "reassuring to politicians like me," Mr. Cuomo wrote, because "he was himself a big, homely looking politician from a poor family who started off by losing a few elections, yet in the end succeeded brilliantly." By that measure, the Governor is at least five for six so far, but his career has not ended yet.

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Weicker's Speech

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Jan. 9

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s State of the State address to the General Assembly.
 You in this chamber and those who sent me here expect nothing short of total candor in dealing with the problems and opportunities of our state.
So let the message of this day be simple and bold. 
 No more sacrifices postponed. No more decisions ducked. No more lowest-common-denominator solutions.
A deficit has taken control of our lives, coloring all else as it climbs beyond comprehension, sapping our confidence, humbling our visions.
The past is not worth the best of our courage and creativity. That belongs to the future. So let's get this deficit business done, and fast.
 
'Worth Every Moment'
 No broken-field running, ladies and gentlemen. Straight into the line. We take our licks, so that we can restore the caring and quality of life that is Connecticut, unmatched anywhere, hard to define, but a treasure worth every moment of our commitment and spirit during this session.
I can assure you that when I return here in February, we will all be tested for courage and constancy.
The state of the state is rudderless. Well, that's for you and I, if we choose to perform. And we were chosen to perform.
At this moment, Connecticut young men and women are on the line in the Middle East, in the shadow of war. Among them a Marine officer re-elected to this State House of Representatives. It was in tribute to them that those cannon were fired moments ago, and to their families facing lonely vigils.
But in the budget battle ahead, I'm looking to citizen patriots, not partisans. What I seek is your grit and ingenuity, your resolve to accept sacrifices long postponed to gain achievements long denied.
And my door down the hall is as open to you in 1991 as it was to me in 1963 by a great Governor, John Dempsey.
I stand by my commitment to pay as we go. No more downstream debt.
 
To Revive the Economy
 I stand by my commitment to children. In tough times priorities must by set for those who are the most vulnerable. They are children -- our future.
I stand by my commitment to rekindle business in Connecticut, to save and expand jobs, to generate the revenue to turn this state around.
I stand by my commitment to equality of opportunity for all our citizens in all their endeavors. As the bill for good living has come due, so has the bill for constitutional justice denied.
Our pledge is to take responsibility for the problems that confront us and work to see that mistakes are not repeated for the long term.
 
From the Table, Solutions
 There is no time for finger-pointing or scapegoating, barely enough time for solutions so that toughness can withdraw, and compassion and caring once again become our hallmarks.
We will bring everyone to the table -- community leaders, legislators, business executives, labor unions and state employees -- and work out credible solutions that put Connecticut first.
The inference from the election of 1990 is that partisanship and political partnership had best recede even further. People are sick of partisan games and want results, not scorecards.
Lives are at stake -- all our lives.
The people of Connecticut have sent us here to do the right thing, to face up squarely to the facts of a state in fiscal trouble. . . .
Lastly, for those who wonder how solutions can be devised outside of a traditional two-party framework, I refer to the words of Mark Twain, written in Hartford 102 years ago.
 
'The Thing to Watch Over'
 "The country is the real thing, the substantial thing, the eternal thing," said the Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's court. "It is the thing to watch over and care for and be loyal to; institutions are extraneous, they are its mere clothing, and clothing can wear out, become ragged, cease to be comfortable, cease to protect the body from winter, disease and death.
"To be loyal to rags, to shout for rags, to worship rags, to die for rags -- that is a loyalty of unreason, it is pure animal; it belongs to monarchy; was invented by monarchy; let monarchy keep it.
"I was from Connecticut, whose constitution declares 'that all political power is inherent in the people, and all free governments are founded on their authority and instituted for their benefit; and that they have -- at all times -- an undeniable and indefeasible right to alter their form of government in such a manner as they think expedient."
To paraphrase Twain, the state's political clothes are worn out, and it is up to all of us to cut a new suit for these times.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices of Treasury Securities Slide

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Failure to achieve a breakthrough leading to a peaceful resolution of the Persian Gulf crisis threw the credit markets into turmoil yesterday, as prices of Treasury securities tumbled and long-term interest rates rose sharply.
The decline was especially pronounced because early in the day market participants pushed securities prices sharply higher as the talks between Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Tariq Aziz, Iraq's Foreign Minister, dragged on. When the diplomats emerged and Mr. Baker said the Persian Gulf crisis was no nearer resolution than before, a huge selloff ensued. 
 "People got too enthusiastic early in the day because the talks went on for so long," said Joseph Liro, a senior vice president and money market economist at S.G. Warburg & Company. "But now we are on a very clear course to a hot war on the 15th."
From its early peak, the drop in bond prices amounted to more than 2 points, or more than $20 for each $1,000 face amount of securities.
 
Seven-Year Treasury Notes
 Bidders at an auction of $8.5 billion worth of seven-year Treasury notes were especially hard hit.
The notes went on sale at 1 P.M., when speculation that a peaceful solution in the gulf might be reached was roaring through the market.
To make matters worse, the auction results -- the notes were sold at an average yield of 7.95 percent -- were announced just as Mr. Baker emerged to address the world press.
Dealers said that the first trade in the seven-year notes after Mr. Baker's opening remarks took place at 8.03 percent.
Prices for the notes deteriorated further as the afternoon progressed, and by late in the session the new securities were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 8.11 percent.
"The market is awash in paper and the world is turned upside down," said David Duerson, manager of trading at the Security Pacific Bank in Los Angeles. "In that sort of environment, you sell."
The yield on the seven-year notes was down from the 8.76 percent average yield at the last seven-year note sale in October.
 
Bonds Bore Brunt of Beating
 In the secondary market for Treasury securities, bond prices bore the brunt of the beating after the diplomats in Geneva told the world that no progress toward peace had been made. At the same time, the heightened risk of war encouraged heavy buying of short-term Treasury bills, a classic refuge for investors during times of uncertainty.
By late in the day, the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 103 7/32, down 26/32, to yield 8.45 percent, up from 8.37 percent late Tuesday. Early in yesterday's session, the price of the benchmark issue was as high as 105 15/32.
At the Chicago Board of Trade, the price of the nearby bond futures contract fell from a high of 95 27/32 just before Mr. Baker held his news conference in Geneva, which began around 2 P.M., Eastern standard time, to a low of 93 20/32 at the close of trading.
With war fears mounting, traders said that a further rise in bond yields was quite possible in the next few days.
"We are now about 40 basis points higher in yield on bonds than we were a couple of weeks ago," one government bond trader said. "Some of that is a war premium. But I would guess there yields would have to go up another 20 basis points or so before you see some interest."
In the Treasury bill market, three-month bills were offered late yesterday at a discount rate of 6.18 percent, down 23 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates plunged 14 basis points, to a late offered rate of 6.26 percent. And one-year bills were offered at 6.25 percent, down six basis points.
Compared with the movements at either extreme of the maturity spectrum, the change in Treasury note prices was relatively modest.
In late trading, the 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 101 22/32, down 18/32, to yield 8.24 percent. Meanwhile, the 7 7/8 percent five-year notes were offered at 100 5/32, down 3/8 point, to yield 7.82 percent. And the 7 1/4 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 6/32, down 1/32, to yield 7.14 percent.
The Federal Reserve Board, widely seen on Tuesday as having endorsed a further quarter-point decline in the overnight Federal funds rate, to 6.75 percent, did nothing yesterday to dispel that notion, traders said. However, the traders added that since yesterday was the end of a two-week bank reserve reporting period, a time when the funds rate often trades well above or below the Fed's target, it was difficult to be certain.
Yesterday, the funds rate traded in a very wide range, from a high of 7 percent to a low of 4 percent.
Price swings in the secondary markets for investment-grade corporate bonds and tax-exempt municipal securities, while not as violent as in the Treasury market, were evident nonetheless.
Corporate bond traders said that prices of most issues, which had been 1/4 point to 3/8 point higher early in the session, ended up 1/2 point lower.
Participants in the municipal bond market said that prices of most widely quoted issues fell by 3/8 point to 1/2 point. Early in the session municipal bond prices had inched about 1/4 point higher.
In the tax-exempt market, the City of San Francisco offered $120 million of bonds at competitive bid.
A bid from a group led by Bank of America won the issue, which consists of serial bonds maturing from 1991 to 2010. The bonds carry a maximum yield of 6.80 percent in 2010.
The securities are rated AA by both Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

HEADLINE: Cuomo Prescribes Austerity, Not Activism

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 9

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who has often defined his activist vision of government with grand and expensive initiatives, said today that New York's deteriorating financial condition demands a new austerity that must be evenly spread.
Delivering his ninth State of the State address, and the first of his third term, Mr. Cuomo said the state's recessionary economy must be reinvigorated with "new thinking instead of new spending." 
 In past years, Mr. Cuomo has used the State of the State speech, which opens the legislative session, to unveil ambitious new programs that have become hallmarks of his administration -- environmental bond acts, increases in the welfare grant, anti-drug programs and initiatives on child welfare.
 
'Year for Raw Truth'
 In today's 62-minute speech, and the 121-page policy blueprint he released with it, Mr. Cuomo was careful to make few budgetary commitments that he might be unable to keep.
Although the Governor and the Legislature closed a $1 billion budget gap only last month, state fiscal analysts now believe the gap in this year's $29 billion budget could grow by an additional $500 million by the end of the fiscal year on March 31. They speculate that the state could face a budget gap in the next fiscal year of up to $4 billion.
"This is a wonderful year for raw truth," Mr. Cuomo said with a wry smile. "We don't have any money. We don't have any other options. Let's shock everybody. Let's tell everybody the whole truth."
Many of the proposals the Governor highlighted, such as creating a privately financed loan fund for small business expansion, changing the state's fiscal year, and requiring private employers to offer family-leave benefits, were measures that would require legislation but not dollars.
When he made proposals that would require new money, like the creation of dedicated funds for transportation and environmental projects, Mr. Cuomo declined to suggest how they might be financed.
Other initiatives, like a major expansion of child-care services, would be paid for largely with Federal funds. Mr. Cuomo stated flatly that the money was not available to achieve goals like lengthening the school year or establishing universal health insurance. But he pledged to keep debate alive on those issues through study commissions and public hearings.
To a certain extent, Cuomo aides said, the Governor was handicapped by an ever-deepening hole in state revenues, making it politically dangerous for him to outline his budget plans too precisely.
Mr. Cuomo must propose his executive budget, and his plans for taxing and spending, by Feb. 1. He made few specific vows regarding the budget today, other than to promise that "there will be no sacred cows, and there will be no sacrificial lambs."
 
Under Close Scrutiny
 The 58-year-old Governor, who is mentioned regularly as a potential Democratic Presidential candidate, has said it makes no sense for him even to consider a national race until this year's fiscal crisis is resolved. Political analysts from coast to coast will be watching the budget process to judge whether Mr. Cuomo can manage his most difficult financial challenge without sacrificing his political ideals.
Mr. Cuomo conceded in today's speech that the state's fiscal condition poses a serious threat to his philosophy of government.
"Preserving this state as a place that provides opportunity to the able and protection to the defenseless -- that must be our goal now," he said, speaking to a joint session of the Legislature gathered in the Assembly's chamber.
"It will not be easy. The immediate goal is to live within our means, closing the gap between what we would have proposed to spend and our diminished resources. It is essential that we do this, because if we do not maintain fiscal integrity by taking this bitter medicine, then we lose the capacity to pursue the mission."
 
Miller Concerned
 The majority leader of the state Senate, Ralph J. Marino, Republican of Oyster Bay, said he was encouraged by the talk of fiscal discipline. But Assembly Speaker Mel Miller, Democrat of Brooklyn, said he was concerned that the state's social safety net would not be maintained.
"I really don't see anything blueprinted, anything that says how you can bring that budget down $3 billion or $4 billion and still preserve the infrastructure," he said.
Advocates for the poor and infirm were quick to criticize Mr. Cuomo for failing to propose initiatives that would protect society's weakest members from the ravages of recession.
Russell Sykes, a policy analyst with the State Communities Aid Association, a social-service lobbying group, said he was disappointed that the Governor had not proposed an increase in the welfare grant, since a study by the association concluded that the grant's purchasing power had declined by 37 percent in the last two decades.
Assemblyman Richard N. Gottfried, Democrat of Manhattan, said the Governor's promise not to cut funding for AIDS programs was inadequate given that nearly 7,000 new cases were diagnosed in New York State last year. "What the AIDS program needs to stay in place is rapid growth," said Mr. Gottfried, the chairman of the Health Committee.
 
Anti-Tobacco Proposal
 In other health and welfare proposals, Mr. Cuomo said he would submit legislation requiring companies to allow workers to take an unpaid leave from their jobs to care for a newborn child or a seriously ill relative without risking the loss of their job.
He proposed a comprehensive adolescent anti-tobacco bill that would prohibit the free distribution of tobacco products, ban the sale of cigarettes in vending machines, prohibit the use of tobacco on school grounds and ban tobacco advertising in many public places.
Mr. Cuomo promised to expand the state's residential and outpatient drug-treatment capacity by 13,500 spots, although many of those positions have been paid for in previous budgets. He also said he would submit a bill that would give judges more leeway in sentencing nonviolent drug offenders to alternative correctional programs.
As expected, the Governor suggested moving the start of the state fiscal year from April 1 to July 1, a change he said would enable more accurate budget forecasting. The State Comptroller, Edward V. Regan, said the state's bookkeeping system could not be adjusted quickly enough to make the move this year.
 
Criticizing Washington
 In response to last year's defeat of a $1.975 billion environmental bond act, Mr. Cuomo today proposed a limited "pay-as-you-go" trust fund for environmental projects. He did not specify how it would be financed, but said the proceeds would be dedicated to solid-waste management, water treatment, recycling and parks development. He cautioned that there would be no money in the near future for land acquisition.
Mr. Cuomo used the speech to repeat his familiar refrain that New York's economic problems were born in Washington. He spoke emotionally about what he sees as an abdication of Federal responsibility in attacking the urban plagues of drugs, homelessness, crime and AIDS.
"The cumulative weight of this decade-long shift of the burden," he said, "combined with shrinking revenues as a result of the national recession, is crushing many states, including New York."

HEADLINE: BUDGET VS. VISIONS;
Challenge for Cuomo Is Keeping Alive His Programs in Fiscally Bleak Period

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 9

 BODY:
Presenting his State of the State address today, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo banged up against the toughest challenge of his administration: maintaining the liberal agenda he has advocated in good times through a period that promises to be bleak.
 It is a challenge so stark that Mr. Cuomo had little choice but to embrace it openly. Today he said, "The immediate goal is to live within our means, closing the gap between what we would have proposed to spend and our diminished resources." 
 But the "ultimate challenge," he said, "is, while balancing the budget, to keep alive in New York the vision of America."
Just how Mr. Cuomo proposes to meet these twin challenges, balancing the budget and keeping alive "the vision of America," will not be fully known until he proposes his budget this month. But in his address Mr. Cuomo offered important clues about his intentions.
The Governor does not, for example, intend to initiate any new social programs that require state money. The few new programs that he mentioned today -- among them a proposal to introduce parental leave in New York State -- do not involve the commitment of any additional state dollars. Instead, the Governor said, "in everything we do we must emphasize refocusing, reform, renewal."
 
'In Our Hands'
 At the same time, the Governor said he was anxious to avoid retreating from those commitments that he had already made. Today he pledged not to cut funds for AIDS treatment or to abandon the obligation to children that he took on when he declared the Decade of the Child in 1988.
"The future of our children is in our hands," he said. "We will not abandon our commitment to the Decade of the Child."
Keeping a vision alive in hard times is an intangible goal, and whether Mr. Cuomo succeeds at it is a judgment that cannot be made on the basis of conventional political measurements: money spent, miles paved, jobs created. But as soon as the Governor's hourlong address was over, many politicians and advocacy groups took issue with his contention that a progressive agenda could be sustained without additional resources.
"We were expecting the worst, and this doesn't provide us with much to think to the contrary," said Russell Sykes, a policy analyst for the State Communities Aid Association, a lobbying group. "I don't know how you can preserve the mission without taking at least some discrete programs and expanding them. Do you preserve it verbally but not in practice?"
At a time the recession is pushing many of the state's poorer residents further and further into poverty, Mr. Sykes said, simply maintaining existing programs represents a step backward. "I'm afraid that the three R's -- refocusing, reform and renewal -- will become retrenchment, retreat and repeal," he said.
The State Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, Republican of Oyster Bay, offered mild praise, saying the speech "sounded the right tone" for the difficult months ahead. But Mr. Marino seemed only to be weakening the Governor's case when he said Mr. Cuomo "sounded an awful lot like a conservative Republican."
In his remarks today, Mr. Cuomo suggested the terms under which he would like to be judged as he confronts the toughest challenge of his tenure: did he manage to preserve the state's existing social programs?
 
Pressures to Expand
 "We cannot avoid all the pain," Mr. Cuomo said. "But we can use this ordeal to lead us to a new era of progress if we deal with our huge fiscal imbalance without dismantling what we've already built."
But aides to Mr. Cuomo insist that even that goal -- avoiding "dismantling what we've already built" -- will be wrenchingly difficult to meet. Recent tax-collection data suggest that New York's fiscal problems are even worse than was expected when experts predicted that the state would start the next fiscal year, which begins on April 1, with a budget gap of $4 billion.
"The Governor is clearly going to protect the mission and the investments we've made," the counselor to the Governor, Drew Zambelli, said. "But it's unrealistic to say that social programs will not see any cuts."
Assembly Speaker Mel Miller, Democrat of Brooklyn, has often attacked the Governor for not living up in his programs to the liberal thrust of his oratory. But this year Mr. Miller, too, seems to believe that the best that can be hoped for is preserving whatever gains have been made in the past.
"I thought," Mr. Miller said, "it was going to be a speech that basically said: 'We're going to have to do the things we do best even better. We're going to have to make less go further.'
"And I think that was the emphasis of the Governor's speech today, and I don't think you can debate that. The truth is the resources are just not going to be there."

HEADLINE: MARKETS' DAY OF WIDE SWINGS;
Oil Prices Fluctuate Wildly, Then Settle Just 9 Higher

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Oil prices took a wild ride yesterday but came to rest just about where they started. When Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d announced his disappointing news in Geneva just before 2 P.M., the price jumped nearly 30 percent in five minutes, rushing from $24 a barrel to $31.
It was the widest price swing within one day's trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange since trading in crude oil began in March 1983. 
 Worldwide, the price bounced throughout the day. Early in the morning, before futures trading opened in New York at 9:45, prices in this country and in London were slightly higher because of fears that war was likely. But then the meeting between Mr. Baker and Tariq Aziz, the Iraqi Foreign Minister, lasted longer than the market had expected, with reports of progress. Suddenly traders were afraid of holding oil or contracts for oil that would lose value because of peace.
Then came word, which proved incorrect, that the two men would hold a joint news conference, and the market went lower, expecting an agreement. But when Mr. Baker said the talks had been inconclusive, "the market exploded," said Richard D. Donovan, senior vice president at Lehman Brothers. Traders became convinced that the oil or contracts they had sold in the morning would be worth much more later on because of war, and they all turned to buy.
"It's staggering," said Mr. Donovan, who pointed out that oil is the world's biggest commodity. Describing what a move that size would mean on other markets, he said, "Can you imagine the Dow Jones going up 750 points in five minutes? Or gold going up $100?"
Theodore R. Eck, chief economist at Amoco, called the jump "phenomenal."
"It just tells us there's extreme uncertainty and the folly of trying to forecast prices," he said.
Despite the size of the trading range, $7.65, the day ended with crude for February delivery up only 9 cents, at $27.26 a barrel. The surge had been preceded by a huge selloff, and the market, which frequently overshoots its mark, fell back after reaching its peak.
The record change in closing price from one day's session to the next is $5.41, set last Oct. 22. Trading was heavy yesterday, at 126,000 contracts, but short of the record of 185,000 set last Aug. 7.
 
Petroleum Products Advance
 Heating oil for delivery next month closed at 77.09 a gallon, up 2.79 cents, and unleaded gasoline closed at 73.31 cents, up 3.13 cents.
For some traders, however, the volatility yesterday was evidence that in a war, the market could test the price-movement limit recently set in place by the exchange -- a move of $15 a barrel in one day.
"If the market can move $7 in five minutes on a just a press conference, you can well imagine that it could do more in a war," said Nauman Barakat, a vice president at Merrill Lynch. "It's certainly possible that the $15 limit could be reached."
Another analyst, Peter C. Beutel, said, "The thing that has made this market so volatile is the black-and-white nature of the negotiations." Mr. Beutel, who is with the Pegasus Econometric Group, said, "There was no place to be in a middle ground."
But other market-watchers said there was meaning to be gleaned from the fact that the swing was not even larger. At the Petroleum Finance Company, a Washington-based consulting group, J. Robinson West, the president, said, "Although we may be closer to war, timewise and in terms of options, the price was $10 lower than the peak reached earlier."
The reason, he said, was that the trading yesterday "was not an international economic panic, just a traders' panic." When prices peaked above $40 a barrel in October, he said, "all eyes realized that there was a quantum change in trading oil, the fundamental commodity of international trade." This time, he said, it was "traders watching short-term spikes."
Vahan Zanoyan, an analyst at the same company, said that if peace actually prevailed, prices would decline below yesterday's $24, and if war came, they would rise above $31.
This is not the first instance of a huge increase in the price of oil, but the market yesterday was substantially different from the last two crises -- during the Arab oil embargo of 1973-74 and following the fall of the Shah of Iran in 1979. This price revolution is televised, on thousands of monitor screens around the world, making the volatility far more obvious and inviting participants -- oil producers, oil users and speculators -- to join in, perhaps driving the changes even further.
But the market is working well, said Nachama Jacobovitz, a spokeswoman for the exchange. No matter what the price at any moment, she said, "people were able to lock in the prices they wanted to."

HEADLINE: Markets in U.S. Shift Abruptly On Gulf Report

 BODY:
Financial markets gyrated wildly yesterday as traders reacted first with hope, then with alarm, to the American-Iraqi talks on the Middle East. But some markets, notably gold and oil, turned again and ended little changed.
Stock and bond prices rose in early trading, while oil and the dollar declined, after a White House spokesman said the talks were "substantive." 
 But prices reversed just before 2 P.M., when Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d began a news conference.
"Baker came out and said 'regrettably,' and no one had to hear anything else," said Liliana Nealon, a foreign exchange trader in New York with the Union Bank of Switzerland.
The Dow Jones industrial average, up more than 45 points at its peak, closed down 39.11, at 2,470.30.
In the oil pits of the New York Mercantile Exchange, contracts for February delivery of crude oil fell to $23.35 and then soared to $31, the largest such swing ever in oil trading. But prices reversed again as Mr. Baker said President Bush had not decided to go to war; they ended at $27.26, only 9 cents above Tuesday's level.
"It is a world of absolute, massive uncertainty," said Theodore R. Eck, chief economist of the Amoco Corporation. "Nobody knows anything about a war. It's like a football game; the only thing the coach ever knows is what he's going to call for the first play."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Sony's Columbia Unit Planning Theme Park

BYLINE: By MICHAEL LEV, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 9

 BODY:
Columbia Pictures Entertainment, the Hollywood studio owned by the Sony Corporation, plans to enter the theme park business and may build one or more attractions in the United States or abroad.
Columbia said it had received permission from Sony to move ahead with plans for a Sonyland theme park, but that details on the size, scope and location of any proposed project would not be released until later this year. 
 One option it is considering is building an attraction in Southern California to compete against Disneyland and the Universal Studios Tour in Hollywood.
 
'All Kinds of Options'
 "We're looking at all kinds of options," a spokeswoman for Columbia Pictures said. "There really are no details."
The spokeswoman said the Columbia Pictures executive in charge of the project, Paul Schaeffer, was traveling and not available for comment.
Theme parks are crucial to the business of several of Columbia's competitors in entertainment, including the Walt Disney Company and MCA Inc., which is being acquired by the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company. The parks are highly lucrative and considered valuable accompaniments to the film and television businesses of the two large entertainment companies.
The parks, movies, television shows and books are used to promote each other and build each other's businesses. For example, at Disney's parks, many of the rides are based on Disney characters. The parks also sell merchandise based on the characters, films and books.
 
Appeal Among Children
 To increase its appeal among children, the Six Flags Corporation, an amusement park company in which Time Warner Inc. owns a 19.5 percent stake, licenses the "Looney Tunes" cartoon characters from Warner Brothers for use in its seven parks.
For attractions in its theme parks, Sony's options include relying on its library of Columbia and Tri-Star films and television shows, its Sony Music subsidiary, formerly CBS Records, and its huge Sony consumer electronics business.
It could also base a ride or attraction on some of Sony's high-tech products like high-definition television. Another potential basis for an attraction is a film under development for Columbia's Tri-Star studio by Steven Spielberg based on "Peter Pan." The movie, "Hook," will star Robin Williams as a descendant of Peter Pan.
One question for Columbia is whether it will acquire rights to cartoon characters for its attractions. In an effort to build its stable of characters, Disney last year negotiated to acquire Henson Associates, which owns the Muppets, although the deal fell apart late last year.
 
Long-Term Outlook Strong
 While the current market in Southern California for attractions is slow, Joseph R. Schillaci, president of Six Flags' Magic Mountain amusement park in Valencia, Calif., said he believed the long-term outlook remained strong, despite the current recession.
"There is certainly room for more, as Florida has proved where there are several theme parks," he said. "One of the primary reasons for visitors coming to Southern California is to see the parks. One more park is not going to make much difference and it may just add to the appeal of Southern California as a destination."
Following that logic, both Disney and MCA plan to expand their Southern California parks.
MCA is spending $100 million in the next year to expand the Universal Studio Hollywood tourist attraction. And Disney has said it is considering expanding Disneyland in Anaheim, Calif., or building a new park in Long Beach, Calif.

HEADLINE: Regulators Are Glum On Outlook

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9

 BODY:
The nation's senior banking regulators said today that more large failures like the Bank of New England would occur if the economy did not turn around by the middle of the year.
Painting a glum portrait of the banking industry, both L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, and Robert L. Clarke, Comptroller of the Currency, told Congress that there was strong evidence that the economy's problems, particularly in New England, had only begun. 
 "Almost everything we're seeing in unscientific samples shows we're not seeing any improvement and we might see some further decline," Mr. Seidman told the Senate Banking Committee. "I am not prepared to say that the economy has bottomed out."
 
What Kind of Recession
 Mr. Seidman said there would be more large failures if the recession was more than "short and shallow." Mr. Seidman defined such a recession as one in which the gross national product does not decline by more than 2 percent over two quarters and the economy begins to turn around within two quarters, in this case by midyear.
When he announced that the Bank of New England was being seized by the Government on Sunday, Mr. Seidman said he did not anticipate other large failures soon. His remarks today did not directly contradict that position because many economists expect a mild economic decline.
As a result of the threat of large failures, Mr. Seidman said officials and industry representatives had begun exploring ways for the Government to intervene before institutions face the brink of collapse, but he did not describe any specific measures.
The fund that protects bank deposits is at its lowest level since its creation during the Depression, and is expected to lose $5 billion this year from failures, leaving it with $4 billion by the end of 1991.
Regulators have based their estimates of the losses to the Federal fund that insures bank deposits on a forecast of a mild recession.
Mr. Seidman said he still did not expect a Government bailout of the fund, which is financed by a levy on the industry, but he appeared to be considerably less optimistic than he was late last year.
"It's not beyond the realm of possibility that taxpayer money will be needed," he said.
"Clearly the banking industry is under stress," he said. "It is not, however, in a situation like the Great Depression or anything like that magnitude."
The Bush Administration is preparing to present soon to Congress a package of proposals to overhaul the nation's banking system and the program that insures deposits. Despite the consensus on Capitol Hill that the support given Bank of New England would slow the drive to limit deposit insurance, which currently covers all accounts up to $100,000, Administration officials are preparing to reducecoverage so that it does not fully protect larger institutions, like pension funds, that break down their deposits into $100,000 increments so that they can be fully insured.
 
Treasury Proposals
 Treasury officials also said today that they planned to go forward with one of two proposals to limit the amount of coverage sharply for individuals. While technically the coverage of each account is limited to $100,000, the current system enables families and others to obtain protection of significantly more than that by putting the funds in different names and joint accounts.
One proposal is to limit the total coverage for each depositor to $100,000 systemwide. The other would limit the number of $100,000 accounts protected to three for a depositor.
Officials concede that either measure would be difficult to achieve, but would probably rely on a system that uses the depositor's Social Security number.
At a morning hearing before the Senate committee and an afternoon session before the House Banking Committee, Mr. Seidman and Mr. Clarke came under heavy questioning about the way the Government handled the collapse of the Bank of New England.
 
Questions of Fairness
 Lawmakers criticized the decision to protect all depositors, including the estimated $2 billion in accounts of larger than $100,000, and $55 million in foreign branches that do not contribute to the bank insurance fund. They also raised questions about the fairness of protecting all accounts at larger banks, like Bank of New England, but not smaller ones, like Freedom National Bank, the minority-owned institution in Harlem that was seized by the Government in November.
Mr. Seidman conceded that the current system was fundamentally unfair, but said he could do little without changes in the law. He said Freedom had failed to meet current standards, which require that its existence was essential to the community it served, and that it was cheaper to close it than to save all of its depositors. In the case of the Bank of New England, he said, a failure to protect all deposits would have further destabilized the area's economy.
Mr. Clarke said the losses from the Bank of New England to the insurance fund "may well have been reduced" because the Government waited more than a year after the bank's difficulties began to appear to declare the institution insolvent. He said the decision to approve a new management team at the bank early last year had made it possible for the bank to sell many of its assets and reduce its overhead more efficiently than the Government might have done.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Congress Nears War Debate, as Bush Side Gains

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9

 BODY:
Congress stepped to the brink today of debating war in the Persian Gulf, with the House's agenda clearer than the Senate's. The outcome in both chambers is dependent on how many Democrats join nearly solid Republican ranks in support of resolutions backing President Bush's use of force in accordance with United Nations resolutions.
Mr. Bush's chances of prevailing were increased, according to Representative Lee H. Hamilton, Democrat of Indiana and chairman of the House foreign affairs subcommittee on the Middle East, by the apparent failure today of the Geneva meeting between Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz of Iraq. That "raises the temperature, makes war more likely, and probably helps the President get votes for his resolution," he said. 
 Earlier in the House, Speaker Thomas S. Foley squelched an effort by Democrats on the Foreign Affairs Committee to join with Republicans and endorse a resolution backing the use of force, as a majority appeared ready to do. At his insistence, the committee planned to report out that resolution, probably Thursday, along with one calling for further reliance on sanctions and diplomacy, and a less controversial statement reasserting the exclusivity of Congressional power to declare war.
The House Rules Committee will meet early Thursday afternoon to set procedures for the debate on those three declarations. The debate is expected to begin later in the day and conclude with voting on Saturday.
 
Senate Discussions Continue
 In the Senate, the majority leader, George J. Mitchell, said debate could start as early as Thursday morning. He said discussions about language of various possible resolutions was continuing, and said he personally favored trying sanctions and diplomacy longer.
But Senator Bob Dole, the minority leader, complained: "We don't have any idea what the Democrats intend to do. We don't have any idea what they want to vote on."
Then, warming to partisanship, he added, "The Republican strategy is to get Saddam Hussein out of Kuwait. Some of the Democrats' strategy appears to be to get Bush out of the White House."
The partisan division was actually clearer in the House than in the unsettled Senate. A survey taken Tuesday and today by The New York Times and CBS News, in which Congressional press secretaries were asked where their bosses stood, found that 142 House Democrats preferred to let economic sanctions have more time to damage Iraq, while only 32 of them wanted to use force promptly if Iraq was not out of Kuwait by Jan. 15.
 
Independent Favors Waiting
 Among House Republicans, 74 said they favored force now, while 11 wanted to try the sanctions longer. The House's one independent, Representative Bernard Sanders of Vermont, also favored waiting.
That left 93 Democrats and 82 Republicans not answering the survey, and the backgrounds of those who did not respond suggested, tentatively, that the President's position would prevail narrowly, as Mr. Foley has predicted.
Some Democrats on the Foreign Affairs Committee, insisting that their names not be used, complained about Mr. Foley's interference. They said a majority of the committee, led by its chairman, Representative Dante B. Fascell of Florida, wanted to agree to President Bush's request that Congress support the use of force if Iraq did not withdraw from Kuwait by the United Nations deadline of Tuesday.
 
Foley's Reasons Given
 But an aide to the Speaker argued that Mr. Foley's purpose was only to make sure that the committee did not narrow the options that would come before the House. He also said that while the committee had been constituted early, so that it could hold hearings on the gulf situation, it was not yet filled with Democrats chosen this month, from the new Congress.
Along with the resolution sought by Mr. Bush, Democratic aides said, the House will also consider a resolution assembled by Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the majority leader, and Mr. Hamilton. That resolution will insist that Iraq withdraw from Kuwait but say that for the time being force should not be used to attack Iraq while diplomacy and economic sanctions are given more time. It also maintains that Mr. Bush should return to Congress with another request to use force if he wants to employ it later.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Cheney Says He Will Seek Longer Term for Reservists

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9

 BODY:
The Defense Department plans to ask the White House for emergency authority to keep reservists in the military for as long as two years, Pentagon officials said today.
The officials said they needed the expanded authority primarily because the six-month tour of reservists already called up for support roles in the Persian Gulf and the United States would begin to expire in February, depriving the military of critical specialists like doctors, water purifiers and chemical decontamination experts. 
 The statute that allows the Pentagon to seek expansion of its authority to keep reservists also contains a provision that would give it authority to summon up to one million reservists.
 
No Big Effort Planned
 Defense Secretary Dick Cheney told reporters today that the Pentagon does not plan such a large call-up.
The Bush Administration has the authority to call up to 200,000 reservists at any one time. About 150,000 reservists have been called up for support and combat roles. Under the current authority, reservists summoned for support roles can only be called up for six months. Those called up for combat roles can have their tours extended to a year under special authority granted last year by the Congress.
Mr. Cheney told reporters at a White House news conference today that a formal Pentagon request to the President for expanded reserve call-up authority was "in the works" and was needed to maintain reservists with critical skills.
"We have no intention of calling one million reservists," Mr. Cheney said. "But that's the provision that's available for me to be able to extend those people in critical skills, whose services are now being utilized, and whom we would like to keep for this period of time so we don't have to release them immediately back to reserve status."
But a Pentagon official said the Defense Department could use its expanded authority to call up more than the 200,000 reservists allowed if war broke out. Reservists' extended terms would most likely be measured in months, since the Pentagon has said that any war with Iraq would take place soon and be relatively brief.
 
Backing Appears Certain
 Though not formally transmitted to the White House, President Bush's acceptance of the Pentagon recommendation appears to be assured. Mr. Cheney, who carefully weighs his public pronouncements, would not discuss his recommendation in a news conference if he had doubts about its political acceptability at the White House.
Besides enabling the Pentagon to keep reservists in critical skills, some specialists on military manpower issues said the expansion of the Pentagon's call-up authority had other advantages for the Defense Department.
Martin Binkin, a specialist on military manpower issues at the Brookings Institution here, said the expanded authority the Pentagon was seeking would also enable the Defense Department to summon members of the Individual Ready Reserve, who have needed skills. The reserve is made up of people who leave the military with a reserve obligation but do not belong to units or train regularily. They cannot be summoned to duty under the Pentagon's existing authority.
Mr. Binkin said expanding the Pentagon's call-up authority would also send another signal to Iraqi President Saddam Hussein that the United States was ready to go to war to evict Iraqi troops from Kuwait.
"It will deepen the Congressional debate," Mr. Binkin said. "Everyone has got reservists as constituents. It is a good step to test public support for this operation."
The new Pentagon request is the latest in a series of moves to support the deployment of more than 400,000 troops to the Persian Gulf.
 
Changes for Active Personnel
 The Defense Department has suspended the retirements, transfers and tour expirations of all active-duty peronnel in the gulf with critical skills. In November, the Army extended the order to include all Army personnel, regardless of where they were serving.
The service says that it took the step to avoid depleting its ranks around the world during the buildup in the gulf and to insure that it will have needed replacements should war erupt.
The Marine Corps is offering some former Marines, who would not have ordinarily been allowed to re-enlist, a chance to do so. The program, which begun in mid-December, is intended to attract Marines with critical skills.
Pentagon officials have been signaling that they might need expanded call-up authority, either by asking the President for more emergency authority or by asking the Congress for added power to summon reserves.
The Bush Administration has repeatedly stressed that it has no intention of resorting to a draft.
Keeping reservists for longer than six months will extend the financial hardships that many are suffering.
Military pay is generally considerably lower than pay in the civilian economy. While some private companies who temporarily lose employees to the reserves make up the difference in pay, many do not.
 
Jobs Are Guaranteed
 By Federal law, reservists are guaranteed that they will have a job with their employer upon their return that is of the same pay level and stature.
Reserves were first called up in August, after President Bush issued an order on Aug. 22 authorizing the Defense Department to summon as many as 200,000 reservists to duty.
Mr. Cheney, in turn, gave the military services specific authorization to call up to 188,000 reserves. So far, 151,700 have been summoned to duty. About half have been sent to the Persian Gulf, while others have filled in for troops sent there.
Of the reservists called to duty, 108,531 are in the Army, 18,957 are in the Marines, 13,656 are in the Air Force, 9,939 are in the Navy, and 628 are in the Coast Guard.

HEADLINE: Grace Moving 400 Employees

 BODY:
W. R. Grace & Company, whose ties to New York City go back a century, said yesterday that it would move most of its staff, about 400 employees, from Manhattan to Boca Raton, Fla.
The company said, however, that it would keep its headquarters in the Grace Building, a skyscraper at 1114 Avenue of the Americas at 43d Street. Only 40 to 50 employees will be left there.
A spokesman said the move, expected at the end of the summer, was for economic reasons.
Mayor David N. Dinkins said Grace had made up its mind without consulting the city.
William R. Grace, grandfather of the chemical company's current chairman, J. Peter Grace, was Mayor of New York in 1891-92.
The move, first reported on Wednesday in The Wall Street Journal, will involve about 400 of the fewer than 500 Grace staff members in the New York headquarters, which now occupies 10 floors of the 50-story building. Grace is its main tenant but not its owner.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

MARKETS
Financial markets gyrated as traders reacted first with hope, then with alarm, to the American-Iraqi talks in Geneva. [Page A1.]
Stocks, after trading sharply higher much of the day, fell steeply only minutes after Baker grimly went before TV cameras. The Dow, up 45 earlier, ended at 2,470.30, down 39.11. [D1.]
Oil prices took a wild ride but came to rest just about where they started. When Baker announced the failure of the talks, the price jumped nearly 30 percent in five minutes, but crude ended up gaining just 9 cents, to $27.26. [D1.]
The credit markets were thrown into turmoil, as prices of Treasury securities tumbled and long-term rates rose. [D16.]
The dollar opened sharply lower amid hopes for peace but then soared when the bad news came. [D17.]
Prices for precious metals futures fluctuated wildly, moving sharply lower in the morning and reversing direction later. [D17.]
 
THE ECONOMY
More large failures like the Bank of New England will occur if the economy does not turn around by the middle of the year, the nation's senior banking regulators said. [D1.]
The takeover of Connecticut Bank and Trust, a Bank of New England unit, could help Connecticut's economy if the F.D.I.C. sells the bank to a strong institution soon, some in the state say. [D8.]

HEADLINE: Debt Warning On Car Makers

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 9

 BODY:
The Standard & Poor's Corporation said today that it had put the Big Three auto makers on notice that their corporate debt ratings could be lowered because of a worsening economic picture and specific problems at each company.
Standard & Poor's placed the General Motors Corporation, the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation on its "credit watch" list.
Any subsequent lowering of the debt ratings would make it more difficult and more expensive for the companies to borrow money.

LENGTH: 998 words

HEADLINE: Weicker, an Independent, Is Sworn In, Asking Bipartisan Help

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Jan. 9

 BODY:
Lowell Palmer Weicker Jr., who broke the rules of Connecticut politics last year with his successful third-party run for governor, took the oath of office today as the state's first independent chief executive in more than a century.
An hour later, in his first State of the State address before the Democratically controlled legislature, the General Assembly, Mr. Weicker urged legislators to discard party politics, just as he had, in the interest of solving the state's problems. 
 But he provided almost no specifics about what he wanted them to achieve, and his references to the large and growing gap in the state budget were vague enough that lawmakers in each party seemed to think Mr. Weicker had taken their point of view rather than their rivals'.
He did not mention, for instance, the possibility of laying off state employees or closing down state institutions to save money. He did not name any specific taxes, either ones that are on the books and that could be increased or ones that might be proposed, like an income tax. And although he once again ruled out borrowing money through the sale of bonds, he suggested no other revenue-raising alternatives.
 
'Looking to Citizen Patriots'
 "In the budget battle ahead, I'm looking to citizen patriots, not partisans," Mr. Weicker told the legislators. "What I seek is your grit and ingenuity, your resolve to accept sacrifices long postponed to gain achievements long denied."
For both Mr. Weicker and the legislative leaders he must work with, it was a day of setting tones and issuing general declarations: that the state's budget problems are serious but can be resolved, that an independent governor can indeed work with a two-party legislature, and that communication is essential between all parties.
For Mr. Weicker, who is 59 years old, the processions and ceremonies were a sort of personal vindication. A Republican United States Senator for 18 years, he lost his seat in 1988 in a bitterly fought race against Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, a Democrat.
Today, Mr. Weicker was sworn back onto the public stage as Governor. Retired Supreme Court Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr., a friend of the Weicker family, administeredthe oath in a frigid and icy outdoor ceremony on the steps of the Capitol. Mr. Weicker stood hatless in the 26-degree chill and blowing sleet as a 19-gun salute thundered across the Capitol grounds and a band played "Hail to the Chief." He became the 81st governor of Connecticut and its first independent one since Alexander H. Holley, who served from 1857 to 1858.
The General Assembly also began its fivemonth 1991 session with the swearing-in today of its 187 members. In his speech to them, Mr. Weicker said the state's looming revenue shortfall had "taken control of our lives, coloring all else as it climbs beyond comprehension, sapping our confidence and humbling our visions."
The shortfall is projected to reach $670 million in the year that ends on June 30. If current spending is maintained, it will growto $1.5 billion in the following year in a budget of slightly more than $7 billion. State tax officials have said that falling tax collections from corporations and declining sales-tax revenues are the direct cause of the budget gap, and that a recession in real-estate, banking, construction and other industries underlies it. Some lawmakers who believe the state's first priority must be to stimulate the economy -- and thereby get tax revenues flowing again -- said they were encouraged by Mr. Weicker's promise to "rekindle business" and "save and expand jobs."
Those who feel the budget crisis is an opportunity to overhaul the tax system said they were heartened when Mr. Weicker said that in February, when he proposes his budget, "we will all be tested for courage and constancy."
"I think he's going to come in with an income tax," said the Deputy House Speaker, Dean P. Markham, a Democrat from East Hampton. "He seemed to talk about taking care of all Connecticut's needs immediately -- we're not going to put them off for the future, we're going to address the problems we have now -- and that's admirable."
 
Looking for Cues on Income Tax
 Connecticut is one of 10 states that do not tax regular income, and lawmakers in both parties have watched Mr. Weicker for cues as to whether his administration will break the long political taboo against the tax.
Even what was not said was carefully noted. In a short speech after his swearing-in, for instance, Mr. Weicker told shivering friends and supporters gathered on the Capitol steps that he meant to "be tough in establishing a quality of life second to none, paid for by all."
But when Mr. Weicker spoke later to lawmakers, the "paid for by all" phrase was not included.
Instead, Mr. Weicker spoke in bruising football terminology that some lawmakers said pointed toward the same thing anyway -- making all people pay for the state's problems. At the least, it indicated to lawmakers that a lot of pain should be anticipated.
"No broken-field running, ladies and gentlemen," Mr. Weicker said. "Straight into the line. We take our licks so that we can restore the caring and quality of life that is Connecticut."
Some Republican legislators said they were particularly concerned that Mr. Weicker, who had a liberal voting record in Congress on social issues, had not given sufficient emphasis to spending cuts as a way to cut the deficit. But with so few specifics in the speech, even the critics had to base their opinions on what they thought Mr. Weicker should have said rather than on what he did say.
"He wasn't very detailed about what the sacrifices would be, and I wished he had been," said Representative Edward C. Krawiecki Jr., a Republican from Bristol and the House minority leader. "I think he certainly could have laid down the law little bit more, been perhaps a bit sterner. This is the this most difficult group to convince that sacrifice is neccessary."
