LENGTH: 1343 words

HEADLINE: Old Reliables Shine At Wares Show

BYLINE: By ERIC N. BERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Jan. 9

 BODY:
Marketing experts say rule No. 1 in a recession is not to be overly daring. Stick to familiar, time-honored designs. Use natural materials when possible. And make sure to meet genuine needs rather than engage in gimmickry.
So as 1,800 housewares manufacturers, thousands of retailers and others concerned about the economy's slowdown gathered here this week for the semiannual convention of the National Housewares Manufacturers Association, "take no chances" was the watchword. 
 True, this winter's show, which ran from Sunday through today at the McCormick Place Exposition Center, featured the usual array of newfangled contraptions. The Welbilt Corporation displayed a product called the Hot Diggity Dogger that cooked frankfurters and buns at the same time in the same appliance; the Peterboro Basket Company offered an insulated picnic basket with a lid that can be sat on, and Rhythm USA offered a singing chicken alarm clock.
But there was row after row of products that had not changed at all: everything from nonstick cookware to water purifiers.
Many manufacturers chose to play it safe, updating already successful products or reintroducing products that had once been successful but had been withdrawn years ago. All of the products will be available in stores or catalogues in coming weeks.
About 13 years ago, Farberware Inc. of the Bronx stopped producing a scaled-down version of its famed tabletop broiler and rotisserie. Farberware found that the smaller unit was unsuitable for larger families that ate big chickens, turkeys and steaks. And many single people complained that it took up too much space in tiny kitchens.
 With the increase in one- and two-person households, Farberware has decided to reintroduce the mini-broiler without a rotisserie. The new Smokeless Indoor Grill, priced at $49.95, is collapsible; it can be stored in a space about 8 inches wide, 13 inches long and 4 inches high.
The base, which is made of durable heat-resistant plastic instead of steel, is hinged so that it can be broken down and placed inside the broiler along with the grill rack, drip pan and heating element.
"We can't keep cluttering the counter," said Irwin J. Gerber, a Farberware sales director.
Although Farberware officials said the folding broiler is more convenient, they noted that it still retains features of the old broiler that consumers seemed to like most, including an adjustable grill and an almost-smokeless cooking system. Hot drippings are vaporized by the 2,000-degree heating element, and surrounding air keeps the broiler body at a temperature so low that any fat hitting it does not turn to smoke.
 Health o Meter Inc. of Bridgeview, Ill., has also revamped an old product. Almost 70 years ago the company introduced a floor scale that became an industry standard. Made of heavy-gauge steel with big black numbers on the dial and with oversized, slip-resistant mats on the base, the scale was a hit because of its durability, ease of use and accuracy.
Now the decades-old design has been updated. Health o Meter's new Big Foot Electronic scale is still rugged and oversized; the unit weighs more than 10 pounds and can accommodate a man with a size-15 shoe. What is different is the system inside the scale for measuring weight, which is almost entirely electronic. Moreover, the digital display produces two-inch-high numbers -- the largest readout in the industry, according to Health o Meter officials.
"It was such a strong design that we wanted to retain it but we needed to offer some variations," said Michael Brezette, a company vice president.
Company officials said the new floor model should remain as accurate as most doctors' balance scales for many years, because it has virtually no mechanical parts like springs or balances that can reduce its accuracy. To show it means business, Health o Meter offers a five-year warranty with the Big Foot electronic scale and says it will fix the $80 scale after the warranty period for just what it costs the company to repair it.
Knowing that there are few things more disappointing at breakfast than cold toast, Krups has come up with a Toastronic Signal toaster that has a warming feature. The toast does not pop up when the feature is on but is kept warm by residual heat inside the machine. Krups officials said the residual heat can last up to three minutes -- long enough, for example, to complete a telephone call before sitting down to breakfast.
The Toastronic Signal, a wide-mouthed, long-slot toaster that can handle two slices of bread, bagels or waffles, has a number of other features that, while not unique, are nonetheless handy.
Cooks who worry about having the toast ready at the same time as the bacon and eggs will like the new toaster's light-emitting diode display. One by one, the lights go off, indicating how much longer the bread must toast to reach the desired brownness.
There is also a beeper inside the unit that announces the completion of the toasting process; this is louder than the familiar popping-up sound.
A built-in bun warmer keeps two pieces of toast warm while two other pieces are toasting. The warmer consists of a pop-up wire shelf. The toaster, which also has a removable crumb tray, will sell for $90.
 Woodlore of Port Washington, Wis., has improved a simple household item: the cedar hanger. The problem with most cedar hangers, said Jay Wilcox, the company president, is that they are designed for shirts rather than expensive suits. They tend to be of the same thickness throughout, he said, and therefore offer no support in the shoulders or neck.
"They basically are no better than wire hangers," Mr. Wilcox said.
Woodlore's new Ultimate Cedar Hanger comes closer to duplicating the human form by being bulkier around the shoulders and neck.
The extra support means that suits hold their shape better and wrinkle less, Mr. Wilcox said.
The company says the hanger, which is 100 percent cedar, will remain naturally aromatic for three years, after which time it can be sanded so that the sweet smell returns. The new hanger will also absorb perspiration in much the same way as cedar shoe trees protect the linings of shoes.
With a suggested retail price of $32.50, the Ultimate Cedar Hanger may be the most expensive hanger around. It is guaranteed for life against such defects as the hook pulling out of the hanger top or the pants bar unscrewing from the hanger body.
 While the Adirondack chair has been a favorite in backyards and at country homes, it has never been known for its comfort. Back support was always questionable in chairs with wide openings between the slats.
 Now designers at Milano Series in Mount Vernon, N.Y., have come up with what they call an ergonomically designed Adirondack chair, which is priced at $125. "It has been updated for the 1990's in terms of design and made more comfortable," said Bruce Parisi, a marketing representative for the company.
First consider the seat of the new chair. Rather than being flat, the seat on the Milano Series chair is curved into a hump for greater comfort and improved posture.
Next consider the back of the chair. The slats are wider than usual to provide greater support. And while many Adirondack chairs are square at the top, the back of the new chair finishes at a point.
Designers have also experimented with Shaker-style furniture. Modulus , a company in Chicago, is importing a line of reproduction Shaker-style furniture made in Malaysia that is almost 100 percent collapsible and that can be shipped via United Parcel Service.
Because the hardware for the Modulus line has already been installed, a leg to a table top, for instance, can be joined by hand without any tools. That holds true for drawers, which come fully assembled with dovetailed joints.
The Shaker furniture includes a night table (suggested retail $190), a coffee table ($230), a single-drawer desk ($300), a sideboard ($580), a mirror ($100), a dining table ($430) and a bureau ($650).

LENGTH: 1687 words

HEADLINE: Whither Design? Thithers Aplenty

BYLINE: By PATRICIA LEIGH BROWN

 BODY:
LOOK backward, angel. To many architects and designers, this seemed to be the credo of the 1980's. Revivals of revivals, neo-Gothic or other, seemed to be the designer's mission.
Enough! many designers have long thought, and more are now saying outright. It seems a fitting time to ask, What in our own time might be considered truly modern? What new influences are inspiring architects and designers? In a dark economic climate, where are the beacons to the future? 
 These questions were put to people who ought to know: architects, product designers, graphics designers and landscape architects. Their answers, which appear here and on page C6, were far reaching. Some found sustenance in ceramic knives and scissors; others, in a growing sensitivity to the natural world. Many are looking to Japan for new forms and technologies.
Given the economic climate, designers seem to be trying to "simplify, rather than elaborate," in the words of Deborah Sussman, a graphics designer in Los Angeles. It is a time of retrenchment, of taking stock.
Having taken the temperature of the current moment, it appears that the patient will live: though this seems to be a period of uncertainty for designers, breakthroughs, both large and small, abound.
Hartmut Esslinger, product designer and founder, Frogdesign, with offices in Menlo Park, Calif.; Altensteig, Germany; Tokyo, and Taipei, Taiwan.
Ceramics as a material are very modern. They're going to be the material for future consumer goods. Kyocera , a Japanese manufacturer, for instance, has introduced a knife and a pair of ceramic scissors with light-blue blades. They're very original. They stay sharp forever, don't rust and have a smooth cut that feels wonderful in the hand.
Philip Johnson, architect, New York City
One thing that comes to mind immediately is the Vitra Museum in Weil, Germany, by Frank Gehry. It's a wild one. It shows an independence from classical presuppositions. The architect has been able to make the most extraordinary curves, and the lighting is especially good: it shows off the furniture. It's a delicious interior.
Kathryn Hiesinger, curator of European decorative arts, Philadelphia Museum of Art
People are looking at thinner and smaller. The objects created by Shiro Kuramata in Japan, for example, are unprecedented in their innovative use of materials and technologies. They don't look like anything else. In his boutiques for Issey Miyake, the steel mesh is practically transparent. He makes the structure and support of objects look insubstantial. There's a wonderful, paradoxical relationship between weight, support and space.
Junichi Arai, another Japanese designer, is exploring new technologies in textile design. His experimental use of computers has resulted in fabrics with triple and quadruple weaves; they pucker in a seersucker effect. He's driven textile technology to new and fabulous degrees.
ID Two 's prototype design for a glass-screened fax machine is truly modern. It's a laptop you can draw on. It's a very clever elimination of one step in the transmittal process.
Eric Chan, product designer and founder, Ecco Design, New York City
Today, the modern approach is understanding emotion. Philippe Starck's juicer for Alessi is an example of a breakthrough design in its use of form to reflect emotions. It simplifies function to its essence and proves that you don't really need gadgetry.
Trying to solve problems with complicated technical solutions feels wrong now. People don't want to add; they want to subtract.
Dakota Jackson, furniture designer, New York City
Two pieces come to mind as modern. The first is the Tango lamp designed by Stephan Copeland for Atelier International . It has an anthropomorphic shape, both futuristic and prehistoric looking at the same time. I also like the chair designed by Joey Mancini and Gaby Dorell for Sawaya & Moroni . It's a simple side chair with somewhat sweeping shapes. It refers to a kitchen chair, yet is far more poetic. Both are modern in a contemporary sense. If you can express that without being historically referential, that's modern.
William McDonough, architect, New York City
Artists are on the forefront in exploring new materials. Interference paint, which we've been working with, gives the architect an ability to model light and color in a way we never have before. It allows you to create three dimensions on a two-dimensional surface.
Michael Graves, architect, Princeton, N.J.
One that springs to mind is Aldo Rossi's Il Palazzo hotel in Fukuoka, Japan. When you see the facade of the building from across the river, it bowls you over. It blends the rational and romantic. It has a power that hasn't been seen in a very long time.
James Wines, architect, Site, New York City
The protection of our natural environment is clearly the major world concern of the 1990's. The question is, What will be the role of architecture?
The notion of "green" buildings integrates architecture with the existing environment. Through the use of gardens, interior courtyards, terraria, landscaped walls and other elements, buildings can become microcosms of the landscape. Rather than solar panels or buried buildings, our inspirations will be Japanese gardens and Frank Lloyd Wright.
Peter Eisenman, architect, New York City
What I see as "new" are not truly modern or revivals. It's a more pluralistic view of architecture: mixing new colors, fragments of the past and science fiction together in strange ways. Just as David Lynch mixes humanity, pathos and terror all at once, we're taking traditional architectural conventions and placing them in shocking contexts, to reveal the hidden meanings of forms. I think you'll see this in our work as well as the work of Frank Gehry, Rem Koolhaas and Coop Himmelblau .
Tibor Kalman, graphics designer and president, M & Company, New York City
People have really had it with nostalgia. In graphics design, there's a renewed concern with function: how the idea gets communicated, versus style. There's been a rediscovery of modernism. The original modernists rejected decoration in favor of function. I think we have exactly the same moment now.
Kevin Walz, interior designer, New York City
Right now there's very little encouragement to design anything new. I think this period of time is about being safe. We're at the end of a century, and the furniture that was produced at the beginning of the century is a lot more daring than now.
Frederic Schwartz, partner, Anderson/Schwartz Architects , New York City
I think people are tired of "how much more can I lay on" architecture. What tries so hard to be new gets old very quickly.
In contrast, the chapel at Emory University in Atlanta by Max Scogin gets back to the essence of architecture. In one very small place, it captures light, space and craftsmanship in a magical way. It has a spiritual quality.
In our design with R. M. Fischer for the Rector Gate at Battery Park City, the idea was to project classical notions of a gate into the future. There is a whirligig quality.
Bill Moggridge, product designer and founder, ID Two, San Francisco, London and Hanover, Germany
When people stop noticing the electronics and the software, and just see neat features, products become fun to use. The computer part becomes transparent. That's modern.
One of them is the Canon Photura, which I gave my wife for Christmas. It's a one-handed camera, with a built-in telephoto lens and auto-focus,that's convenient for the customer. It doesn't look like a computer. If it had been designed with a software-style approach, she would have become irritated and never used it.
Deyan Sudjic, editor, Blueprint magazine, London
The new design for the Dutch post office by Gert Dumbar looks like an anarchist let loose. This is an unstuffy public design which doesn't try to impress you by looking serious. It redefines what you expect from a post office. It's as if someone redesigned the dollar bill to look like MTV graphics.
Frank Gehry, architect, Los Angeles
Artists like Mike Kelley and Sophie Calle are exploring voyeuristic intimacy and the dark side of our world. There are clues in that for us who are doing architecture. These artists are taking the temperature of the culture.
Eric Owen Moss, architect, Los Angeles
We've just finished the Gary Group office building in Culver City, Calif., which is conceived as a picaresque novel, a series of discontinuous adventures. The wall leans back from the street, destroying the sense of equilibrium. The pieces are not static but moving, connected only in the twisted mind of the architect.
Harvey Bernstein, product designer, Bernstein Design Associates, New York City
Filmless cameras -- the ones that plug into the TV set -- are modern. They're the next generation of photography. Waiting three minutes for a Polaroid picture today is too long.
Deborah Sussman, graphics designer, Sussman/Prejza, Los Angeles
Much of the 80's was about abstract, referential design. One thing that's happening now is a scraping away of the nonessentials. We're trying to simplify, rather than elaborate.
There's a lot of experimentation going on with inexpensive, unexpected materials. Rather than applying paint in a complex way, we're becoming more involved with the actual material. Color is coming from the material itself.
Susan Child, landscape designer, Child Associates, Cambridge, Mass.
One of the most interesting projects is Peter Eisenman's concept for the Banyoles Olympic hotel in Barcelona, Spain. The building relates to the existing agricultural patterns and context of the landscape.
 Stan Eckstut, architect, Ehren krantz, Eckstut & Whitelaw Architects, New York City
If there's anything positive to say about the economic downturn, it's that it's probably forcing everyone to be more careful, think smaller and take more advantage of our limited resources. They say that sometimes the most creative thinking, such as the W.P.A. movement, is done when times are hard. There's more time for thought now, forced or not.

SECTION: Section A; Page 24; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 590 words

HEADLINE: The Larger Patriotism

 BODY:
The world's hopes for a diplomatic breakthrough at Geneva have been cruelly disappointed. Today Congress begins to debate peace or war; Iraq's intransigence invites an angry vote. What Members of Congress owe America, however, is neither anger nor truculence but their best judgment on what best serves the vital interests of the United States.
At this time, those interests would not be served by the offensive use of military force to expel Iraq from Kuwait. 
 It would be a mistake for Congress to confuse patriotism with blind loyalty to the President. A strong America is a democratic America, functioning in accordance with the constitutional design. The larger patriotism is to be wise, not merely tough.
From the start, this newspaper has supported Operation Desert Shield, President Bush's deployment of a multinational force to defend Saudi Arabia. We have supported the international embargo that is daily making Saddam Hussein pay for his aggression in Kuwait, and steadily weakens his military potential. And we have supported the President's able assemblage of a broad coalition against naked aggression.
Nor do we shrink from the ultimate prospect of war. There are circumstances that justify, even compel, the sacrifices of war. But those circumstances are not now present.
America's vital interests in the Middle East -- the security of oil supplies and the security of strategic allies -- are in no imminent danger. As for pushing Iraq out of Kuwait, the embargo remains a plausible lever. The evidence so far, not conclusive but strong, is that it is steadily grinding Iraq down.
Saddam Hussein's crimes offend most Americans, most Arabs and most of the world. But the right response now is not a U.S.-led attack. For Congress to authorize an immediate use of force under these circumstances would be unwise. And to sign off instead on a blank check, leaving it to the President to fill in a future date, would be a dereliction of constitutional duty.
Even if it should come, war promises no neat solution. A limited war that left much of Baghdad's military capability intact would only inflame future crises with a heightened sense of Iraqi grievance. Yet an all-out war that destroyed Iraq's military potential would create a destabilizing power vacuum adjacent to both Iran and Syria.
Nor do America's allies in the broad anti-Iraq coalition insist on immediate war. Quite the contrary. France, one of the U.N. Security Council's five permanent members, even now presses for a diplomatic solution. Many allies endorse fighting in Kuwait but not in Iraq. If, as the Administration fears, the coalition is weakening, that's true precisely because of the imminent threat of force, not any strains arising from the long-term embargo.
Congress's constitutional war-making authority fell into disuse during the cold war. Under the thermonuclear shadow, Presidents brushed aside the deliberative mechanisms designed to protect against premature or reckless war. The decisions before Congress now call for a return to constitutional norms.
First, the members must reassert their right to decide when and whether to go to war. Then, turning to the President's request for authority to use force now, they should trust evidence instead of sentiment. So far, America's vital interests are protected; there's reason to believe the embargo is working; the deadline of Jan. 15 is arbitrary.
If circumstances should change, there will be time for a fresh look. For now, the wise, brave vote on war is no.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Sophomore Year;
Mr. Dinkins Turns Wishful

 BODY:
To think back to Mayor David Dinkins's inaugural last January is to reflect, sadly, on what has happened to him and his city in just one year. The inauguration was a moment of excitement and promise; even the broadening signs of fiscal trouble could not still the enthusiasm. Then reality hit. The economy got worse, and the Mayor's life became one problem after another.
Mr. Dinkins thus begins his second year as a very different Mayor. He speaks of hope, but so great are the city's struggles that his State of the City speech this week was less convincing than dutiful. It could hardly have been otherwise. A relentlessly growing budget deficit means that his only options are painful ones. And that may be why Mr. Dinkins used his speech, traditionally a public relations opportunity, to offer more hopes than plans, and to spend more time praising New Yorkers than promising what he can do for them. 
 "New Yorkers do not give up; they simply change the rules," he said in one of his more positive lines. But it was less than heartwarming to hear him try to fashion virtue from adversity. Elsewhere he noted that because of falling real estate prices, New York is no longer the most expensive city to live in. That may be true; but the depressed real estate market is hardly a sign of health and vitality.
Mr. Dinkins emphasized important issues, including gun control, juvenile justice and fiscal stability. The last of these was particularly welcome, since the Mayor's performance in managing the city's finances has been uneven, if not downright alarming. But even if he had avoided his most serious fiscal mistake -- approving labor settlements that will cost the city dearly in layoffs and service cuts -- the city would still be reeling from forces no mayor can control.
New York's 106th Mayor finds himself struggling just to stay in place. What his city can hope is that a year of adversity has prepared and toughened him for the difficulties ahead.

HEADLINE: Sophomore Year;
Mr. Florio Tiptoes Into 1991

 BODY:
A chastened Gov. Jim Florio proposes nothing bold for New Jersey this year. Scorched by the uproar over last year's hefty tax bill and increased aid to poor school districts at the expense of those better off, he carefully avoided new controversy in his State of the State address. Mr. Florio is presumably more interested in retaining Democratic control of the Legislature in the November elections than in making new waves.
If 1991 plays out as the Governor says, New Jersey faces the recession in good shape because last year "we made choices that others are just starting to face up to." But even before he spoke, the State Senate's Democratic leaders were threatening a $450 million raid on the new school aid funds to pay for statewide property tax relief. Their proposal is irresponsible, but a clear warning to Mr. Florio that he must give some ground. 
 The Governor said little about the $600 million budget deficit. Obviously, the window for new taxes is shut. He proposes unspecified savings from mergers of state agencies and from letting private garages make the state's auto emission inspections. But he and the Legislature have yet to deal with the harsh reality of still more cuts.
Mr. Florio's initiatives were modest and meritorious, and for the most part wouldn't worsen the budget problem. He would fight unemployment with $400 million from the transportation trust fund, to pay for highway work. He calls again for two worthy bond issues: $600 million to fix up rundown schools, and $135 million to subsidize affordable housing. And he endorses a proposal for $50 million of tax-free savings bonds that could be used to pay college tuition. He wants to tackle health care for the uninsured and child care, too, but hasn't spelled out how.
Well-spoken and compassionate, Mr. Florio offers sensibly restrained plans for steering his state through a difficult year.

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
The Letter Rejected

BYLINE: By William Safire

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Saddam Hussein's Foreign Minister took in hand the letter from the President of the United States, read it carefully, and answered it in the most contemptuous way available to nations: he passed it back across the table, refusing to "receive" it.
The representative of the nation that reintroduced poison gas to modern warfare, used hostages as human shields and is now systematically pillaging its Arab neighbor -- this man was instructed to say that the tone of the communication from Mr. Bush was insufficiently polite. 
 So ended the "phony war." After five months of wishful thinking in the West and ringing rhetoric in Baghdad, the regime in Iraq made clear to the world in the most insulting way possible that it is not about to give up its conquest of oil-rich Kuwait.
We can now clear our minds of self-delusion. This includes:
1. We are not communicating with the Iraqi leader; if only he knew of the firmness of the world's resolve, he would stop miscalculating.
The problem has never been lack of communication. As Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz made clear, Baghdad is well aware of what the world wants and what power the U.S. has in place to enforce its demands.
2. Give sanctions a couple of years to work, and economic strangulation will bring Iraq to its knees.
This satisfies those who want to do nothing but seem to do something; it dresses weakness in a tough jacket. Thus we hear "stay the course," and "tighten the noose"; in reality, the embargo is more annoyance than siege, and is already being breached by Iran, Jordan and the Soviet Union.
3. Saddam Hussein may be an assassin by profession, and responsible for two invasions and more than a million deaths to date, but he is not irrational; he will recognize the reality of superior power.
This foolishly projects onto him the view from our side. From his side, he sees the ground forces arrayed against him and assumes that we will wage his kind of trench warfare. With the help of poison gas, he defeated a neighboring nation nearly triple his population. With more blood to expend -- and he is prepared to lose another half-million Iraqis -- he thinks the world's forces will tire and make a deal.
4. A compromise is easy to envision: give him a couple of islands as access to the gulf, plus a fig leaf of linkage to the Palestinian cause, and he'll be willing to pull out of Kuwait.
The woods are filled with pundits and diplomats certain of his willingness to withdraw under the proper inducement, but whenever the opportunity arises -- he concedes nothing. The "deal" is in the mind of the aggression-rewarders; in Saddam Hussein's mind, Kuwait is his 19th province.
5. We want a peaceful solution, and would be content with his withdrawal.
A peace (to which he shows no sign of agreeing) that would permit him to build long-range missiles and to equip them with nuclear, germ-warfare and chemical warheads is no peace at all but an invitation to a war in the mid-90's at a high cost to the U.S. civilian population.
6. Once he sees we're serious, or united, or ready -- he'll cave.
A dozen U.N. resolutions, a deadline, an invisible Congress and implacable President, with massed troops and air power ready -- what further proof does he need? He knows what is coming, and he is not caving.
7. But he's not crazy -- he knows he'll lose; at the 11th hour, he'll become reasonable.
This is another bite at the rationality apple. If he cannot draw us into a long land war, he faces the prospect of defeat; but by cloaking his land-grab in a pan-Arab cause, he sees martyrdom ahead. Never a religious man, he does not see this as a way to Heaven, but his consuming ego envisions a Viking's funeral, with his nation the burning boat.
8. Air power has never won a war.
Give modern air power a chance to decide this war, with a two-front invasion on the ground from north and south in the final stages. Not all Iraqis are loyal to the dictator; we can encourage a Kurdish uprising and a military coup. Because Iraq is the center of world terrorism, we must expect counterattack from that quarter, but we are moving now to prevent terrorists from gaining nuclear arms.
The spurned letter means the time for self-delusion is over. Let Congress express its resolve in a resolution. And let the White House make public the undelivered mail: the world should read the message that was too direct and forceful for the tender eyes of Saddam Hussein.

HEADLINE: Why New York State Faces Crisis and Must Resort to Layoffs

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The impact on individuals, programs and operations of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's deficit reduction plan has generated much discussion, particularly among New York State employees. This has centered on two basic questions: 
 (1) Why is the state suddenly facing an economic crisis?
(2) Why is the Governor using layoffs and other work-force saving plans for state employees, instead of eliminating waste in government?
These are legitimate questions.
As the news media have reported for months, much of the country is in a severe recession. The impact is felt by New York and many other states, with massive budget deficits in Florida, Pennsylvania, Texas and California. The Associated Press reported that a survey conducted by the National Conference of State Legislators found two-thirds of the states expect major difficulty in balancing their budgets. Conditions appear to be deteriorating faster than in the recession years of the early 1980's.
The impact of the national economic downturn, exacerbated by the invasion of Kuwait and its effect on oil prices, has caused a serious decline in state revenues. Combined with decreased Federal funding, the effect on New York's finances has been dramatic and inescapable. New York has had to take immediate steps.
The deficit reduction plan will produce savings of $1 billion without new taxes and will meet the requirements of fiscal soundness to protect the state's credit rating. It cuts all areas of the budget: more than 60 percent is local aid, including aid for education and social services. Nearly 30 percent of the spending reductions are in state agency costs.
The furlough plan proposed by the Governor would have reduced the number of layoffs needed this year to about 2,000. The deferred compensation plan that the Legislature enacted instead meets all the fiscal requirements and accomplishes the same objectives as the Governor's furlough proposal. Without adoption of one of these plans, many thousand more layoffs would be required. Despite public opposition by union leaders, many rank and file employees have expressed support for measures that ultimately reduce layoffs.
While the fiscal situation demands dramatic spending cuts, efforts to improve productivity and efficiency in state government have reduced the people and programs affected. The portion of the budget spent on state purposes has been reduced from 25.9 percent in 1983-84 to 22.4 percent this fiscal year. We have instituted hiring freezes, sold surplus state property, cut back on consultants and travel, closed outmoded facilities, reduced the state's passenger car fleet by 25 percent and have improved operations through the Governor's Office of Management and Productivity.
However, the deficit reduction plan and these initiatives do not eliminate the necessity of further budget cuts next year. These are not choices that are made lightly.
New York has responded to challenge with intelligence and innovation. In this time of fiscal stringency, we will have to reassess priorities and redirect resources to insure that we provide quality services. We welcome the public employee unions to work to continue the tradition of excellence.
 
ELIZABETH D. MOORE
Director, Governor's Office
of Employee Relations
Albany, Dec. 27, 1990

HEADLINE: We Can't Afford Big Science's Price Anymore

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Would that Marvin L. Goldberger and Wolfgang P. K. Panofsky were right in "All Science, Great and Small" (Op-Ed, Dec. 22): that the debate between small science and big science could come to an end; that the debate on choices of future scientific projects could be based only on scientific merit, irrespective of relative costs. Unfortunately, the ivory tower of basic scientific research must occasionally open its doors to the world around it, and that world has finite financial resources. 
 Since the end of World War II, we have accorded science a special place among intellectual and cultural disciplines and spent more public money on it than, for example, on theater, music and philosophy. We have done this not because we are enamored of science as an intellectual discipline, but rather because we believe it serves our national needs. We believe that it has the capacity to provide us with a higher standard of living, greater longevity, improved economic and military security, and generally a better quality of life. And that belief more often than not has proved to be correct.
In good economic times we have had the luxury of being able to support a wide range of scientific activity with little regard for the potential long-term social benefits of individual projects. During the 1960's we were able to provide more than adequate Federal funding for large-scale and small-scale projects, for individual university investigators and for major national facilities. Today, as a result of Federal tax policies enacted during the 1980's, we have less Federal money for basic scientific research. At the same time, scientific research has become more expensive, reflecting the growth of technological complexity.
Our diminished resources now force us to make hard choices. One of those is whether or not we can afford big science projects, particularly if our commitment results in inadequate overall support for small science. The question is not whether or not big science is ipso facto less desirable than small science, but whether or not the relatively fixed pot of Federal dollars is better spent on many small projects that have relatively greater educational and potentially greater economic benefits than on a very small number of megaprojects that are extremely meritorious scientifically, but have few rationales for their pursuit save the advancement of intellectual knowledge.
The 1990 budget compromise, which has fixed the size of the pot for the next five years, forces us to make these choices. As an educator, as a researcher in big and small science projects for 20 years, as a politician, and as an advisor to politicians, I must conclude that until we alter our national taxing and spending priorities we simply cannot afford megaprojects such as the space station and the superconducting supercollider. Deep down I suspect that Messrs. Goldberger and Panofsky must also agree.
 
MICHAEL S. LUBELL
Westport, Conn., Dec. 22, 1990
 
The writer is professor of physics at City College, CUNY.

HEADLINE: Trade U.S. Food and Goods for Soviet Oil

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The United States and the Soviet Union are now at a unusual juncture of interlocking needs and resources. A bold trade would resolve many of each country's problems for the present and the future. 
 The needs: The Soviet Union needs food and consumer goods; the United States needs a stable supply of reasonably priced oil.
The resources: the Soviet Union has the world's largest oil reserves; the United States has tremendous oil-drilling expertise and equipment, and underused production capabilities in farming and consumer goods.
Clearly, we should gear up our farms and factories for full production, put all our workers back to work, trade the food and goods for $16 a barrel Soviet oil, end our recession and at the same time end Soviet shortages and domestic turmoil. Such an exchange arrangement could also cool down the Middle East because it would end everyone's dependency on that region's oil.
This interim solution to our problems would allow the politics and economies of both countries to set new and appropriate courses for the next century, based on the necessary premise of cooperation, rather than on conflict.
Domestically, it would allow us to refocus our energies and resources on solving our problems, including education, housing and the urban infrastructure. Abroad, it would allow us to play our part in helping the rest of the world.
 
PAUL SEGAL
New York, Dec. 27, 1990

HEADLINE: We Can't Afford Big Science's Price Anymore;
Home-Growing Centers

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Needed: Home-Grown Talent" (editorial, Dec. 26) joins the chorus calling for dramatic improvements in the development of home-grown scientists and mathematicians. You also identify some of the necessary ingredients: start early, make it user-friendly, teach science literacy to the entire population. 
 However, you do not mention one of the popular tools for accomplishing this. Throughout the United States, in every large city and in a remarkable number of smaller ones, there is a science museum or science center that makes an important contribution. The typical institution of this sort (the Exploratorium of San Francisco is a highly regarded example) introduces science to children -- often preschool -- using hands-on, interactive exhibits to enable them to see, feel, touch and therefore understand science and technology.
New York City has but one, the Hall of Science at the World's Fair ground in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in Queens. Soon, the Liberty Science Center, under development on the New Jersey side of New York Harbor, will provide another such resource for the region. Finally, a new one is being planned to serve the high-tech community of Long Island, to be called the Long Island Museum of Science & Technology and probably to be in central Nassau County.
While these science centers in no sense take the place of the primary and secondary school system, they are vital adjuncts and need support from the private and public sectors. In a time of recession, they should be seen as prerequisites to a healthy economy.
 
ARTHUR L. ROSSOFF
Huntington Station, L.I., Dec. 27, 1990

HEADLINE: F.D.I.C. Fails in Plan to Sell Giant Texas Development

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Jan. 9

 BODY:
The Government's plan to sell a prized 6,200-acre real estate development north of Dallas to a Japanese businessman collapsed late Tuesday after he said he could not obtain financing.
The collapse of the deal for the sprawling community of expensive homes and scenic golf courses called Stonebridge Ranch seems certain to increase a bill to taxpayers on the project earlier estimated at $270 million. The savings and loan that had backed the development was seized by the Government two years ago. 
 The decision by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation late Tuesday to break off talks with Yukio Kitano, an Osaka industrialist who had agreed last June to acquire Stonebridge for $61 million, underscores the increasing trouble the Government faces in finding buyers for large, costly real estate projects.
Plummeting Japanese stock and real estate values since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, and fears of approaching war, have forced Japanese banks to sharply restrict their overseas lending. Mr. Kitano had counted on those banks for much of the money he needed to buy Stonebridge.
A lawyer in Dallas who represented Mr. Kitano, Clay Mulford, said talks with the Government would continue and Mr. Kitano hoped an agreement could be reached on "mutually satisfactory terms."
The vast Stonebridge property, situated on rolling prairie land 35 minutes north of downtown Dallas and 43 miles south of the Oklahoma border, was acquired and developed between 1983 and mid-1990 at a cost of $300 million to $330 million.
Most of the money came from Gibraltar Savings, a large Texas savings institution. With two high-quality golf courses, 13 man-made lakes, a beach, an elaborate club house and tennis center, stables and five miles of bicycle and bridle paths, Stonebridge was considered one of the most ambitious developments conceived in Texas during the state's boom years in the early 1980's.
The project was managed until 1989 by Richard C. Strauss, a son of Robert S. Strauss, the influential Washington lawyer who was chairman of the Democratic Party during the Carter Administration. The senior Mr. Strauss was a director at Gibraltar Savings, whose chairman, J. Livingston Kosberg, was a prominent fund-raiser in Texas for the Democratic Party.
Mr. Kosberg and the Strausses no longer have any involvement at Stonebridge. Gibraltar Savings and a sister institution, First Texas Savings, were declared insolvent by the Government in 1988. The two institutions were later sold, along with three smaller institutions, for $315 million to a group headed by Ronald O. Perelman, the investor and chairman of Revlon Inc.
That newly capitalized institution operates as First Gibraltar, and is the largest savings unit in Texas, with more than $11 billion in assets.
 
$7 Million for Maintenance
 Real estate professionals in North Texas said a prospective bidder for the Stonebridge land and facilities faced annual costs of approximately $7 million to maintain the property and its amentities. In addition to those costs and the interest charges on money borrowed to buy Stonebridge, a new owner must construct roads, pay utilities and oversee other development services required by home builders.
Stonebridge has been one of the more popular new residential developments in the Dallas-Fort Worth area since it opened in 1988. The Government said 380 homes, ranging in price from $75,000 to more than $1 million, are occupied. Home builders own another 200 developed lots, as well as enough land to construct another 150 homes. Zoning eventually would allow 27,500 homes and 91 million square feet of retail, commercial, office, research and industrial space.
 
Slow Development Pace
 Yet many local brokers say the current pace of home development at Stonebridge is too slow to provide enough of a return for investors unwilling to stay with the project for 20 years or more. A spokesman for the F.D.I.C. said Government officials familiar with Stonebridge were not available to comment on the project today.
One person familiar with the development raised the prospect that the Government might be forced to sell Stonebridge for far less than $20 million.
"It is extraordinarily difficult to finance anything in real estate right now," said David Shulman, managing director and head of real estate research at Salomon Brothers, in New York. "Raw land only has value to a developer, but if there is a limited market for developed product, then there is very little value for the land. Most of what the R.T.C. owns on the commercial side is land. And that's the problem." The R.T.C., or the Resolution Trust Corporation, is the agency in charge of the Government savings and loan bailout.
The deal with Mr. Kitano had been scheduled to close last Sept. 13, but regulators extended the deadline twice. The financing delays in Japan forced Mr. Kitano to forfeit $4.9 million he had advanced last summer to the Government.
In a statement, the Government said it had ended the talks with Mr. Kitano because of his "continuing difficulties in obtaining financing." It was unclear whether the F.D.I.C. would conduct another private auction for the property, or negotiate privately with other bidders. The Government said it soon planned to announce how it would market the property.
Stonebridge is situated 15 minutes from a large corporate office park in Plano, Tex., where the J.C. Penney Company is building a new headquarters. Electronic Data Systems and the Frito-Lay division of Pepsico Inc. have also built sprawling, campus-style headquarters there in the last five years.
Stonebridge is in the town of McKinney, Tex. Town officials said Stonebridge was zoned to eventually house between 45,000 and 60,000 people. "We want the long-term issue of ownership at Stonebridge resolved as soon as possible," said Thomas E. Palmer, head of the town's economic development agency.
The land development subsidiary of the Mobil Corporation seriously considered making a bid for Stonebridge last year but later backed away, said John Lord, a Mobil spokesman. He said he could not comment on whether Mobil might still be interested. The Mobil unit is a major developer in Reston, Va., where it is based.
H. Ross Perot, the Texas billionaire, has also had an interest in the property, according to Dallas real estate professionals. In an interview, Mr. Perot denied bidding for Stonebridge last year, but he sounded as though he had closely followed the Government's talks with Mr. Kitano.
"At some point, they'll decide they want to sell it in a hard money deal," Mr. Perot said, referring to property sales officials at the F.D.I.C. "Their basic problem is that they prefer a soft deal at a big number, rather than a lower bid with real money behind it."

CORRECTION-DATE: January 14, 1991, Monday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Thursday about the Government's inability to sell a real estate development near Dallas misstated the involvement of Robert S. Strauss, the former chairman of the Democratic National Committee, in the Gibraltar Savings Association, a Texas institution that was declared insolvent in 1988. Mr. Strauss owned stock in Gibraltar Savings but did not serve as a director.

HEADLINE: Metro-North Chief Is Called Choice to Head M.T.A.

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
Peter E. Stangl, president of the Metro-North Commuter Railroad, has been chosen by the Governor's selection committee as the next chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, high-ranking officials of the state authority said yesterday.
Mr. Stangl, who had been rumored to be the leading candidate, would succeed Robert R. Kiley, who resigned in November after seven years with the authority to become president and chief executive of the Fischbach Corporation, an electrical engineering concern. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo is expected to meet with Mr. Stangl today and then announce his appointment. 
 Mary Ann Crotty, deputy director for state operations in the Governor's office, said that while Mr. Cuomo was close to naming a new M.T.A. chairman, no final decision had been made.
Mr. Stangl's turnaround of Metro-North and his political and personal skills won him the nomination for the M.T.A. post, transit officials said.
 
More Trains on Time Now
 When Mr. Stangl was named president of Metro-North in 1983, the railroad, which is part of the M.T.A., was considered one of the worst in the nation. Trains were consistently late, crowded, uncomfortably hot and filthy.
Metro-North, which provides rail service to commuters between New York City and Westchester and Connecticut, now stands head and shoulders above other railroads in the region and beyond. About 90 percent of its trains are on time, it has more of them, and the cars are clean and air-conditioned. While ridership on the city's subways and other rail systems has declined, Metro-North's has increased.
At the M.T.A., Mr. Stangl would oversee a vast network of state transit agencies including the Transit Authority, which operates the city's subways and buses; the Long Island Rail Road; the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority and Metro-North. Many of those agencies are facing swelling operating deficits and declining ridership.
 
A Former Professor
 Mr. Stangl, a 49-year-old former economics professor, has worked in mass transit in New York and New Jersey for 20 years.
"Peter is clearly an expert transit manager, but more than that, he knows how to deal with people," said Jo Ann Katzban, associate director of the M.T.A.'s Permanent Citizens Advisory Committee, a consumer advocacy group. "He's formal, but he still has a lot of warmth in his dealings."
Perhaps the biggest challenge the authority's new chairman faces is persuading legislators to approve a $12 billion capital plan when the region's economy is in a decline and state and city governments face huge deficits.
 
Need to Be Forceful
 "We hope he does well and increases ridership the way he has done at Metro-North," said Joseph Rappaport, a spokesman for the Straphangers Campaign, a subway riders' group. "The challenge for the new chairman will be to get a new capital improvement program in place and that means being a forceful, visible spokesman for transit up in Albany and to the business community and to riders."
Thomas F. Egan, chairman of the M.T.A.'s Metro-North committee, said Mr. Stangl "stakes his reputation on his ability to confront a problem and find the long-term solution" and "doesn't like to take short cuts." For example, to avoid service cuts in times of economic decline, Mr. Stangl has reduced Metro-North's reliance on government subsidies by controlling costs like travel budgets for rail officials and by raising productivity, Mr. Egan said.
Since 1984, he has reduced Metro-North's employees by 520 to 5,800 positions without layoffs and has cut overtime 37.5 percent. The railroad's operating expenses have risen 12.6 percent since 1984, compared with a 26.3 percent rise in the Consumer Price Index.
Metro-North executives and workers say that while he is personable, he is a demanding boss who has been known to scream and pound his fists on his desk when upset and also to dismiss an employee who does not work quickly enough. "You have to be smart, sharp and fast to work for him because he a no-nonsense guy," said a Metro-North official who asked not to be identified.
Metro-North officials said yesterday that Mr. Stangl was declining all interviews concerning his possible appointment as M.T.A. chairman.
Mr. Stangl, who was born in Waterbury, Conn., graduated from the University of Connecticut. He did graduate work in economics at the University of Connecticut and later taught at Wheaton College in Norton, Mass.
 
In Lindsay Administration
 He worked as a program planner for the New York City Budget Bureau in 1970 and later as an assistant administrator for public transportation in Mayor John V. Lindsay's administration. From 1974 to 1978, he was assistant commissioner for public transportation in New Jersey.
After a brief period as a public policy consultant, Mr. Stangl joined the M.T.A. in 1980 as assistant executive director for policy and operations and oversaw Conrail's management of the Hudson, Harlem and New Haven lines. He became president of Metro-North, which took over operations from Conrail in 1983.
Perhaps Mr. Stangl's biggest asset as a public-service manager, transit officials said, is his desire to please the customer. Once, when a Metro-North train crew skipped a station in the Bronx, Mr. Stangl demanded that the crew members apologize to each passenger on the train the next day.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Peter E. Stangl, who is expected to become chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. (William E. Sauro/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Rochester Telephone In Deal With Centel

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
Two large independent telephone companies signed an agreement yesterday to exchange operations in a deal involving cash and stock.
The Rochester Telephone Corporation agreed to buy the Centel Corporation's local phone operations in Minnesota and Iowa for $100 million in cash, 2.8 million shares of new Rochester Telephone stock and the Rochester company's minority stakes in the cellular telephone franchises in 20 cities and towns. 
 The new shares of Rochester Telephone were worth $82.2 million at yesterday's closing price of $28.50 a share on the New York Stock Exchange. Alvin S. Mirman, a telephone industry analyst at Gruntal & Company, estimated that the minority stakes would fetch about $67 million if sold separately, giving the deal a value of about $250 million.
Rochester Telephone and Centel's shares both fell 12.5 cents each yesterday, with Centel's closing at $28.25.
The companies said they expected the deal to close by midyear.
The new stock will give the Chicago-based Centel a 9.1 percent stake in Rochester Telephone. Centel also signed an agreement that neither it nor any acquirer of Centel would seek to increase the stake to more than 10 percent before the end of 1995.
"Centel is a company we respect a great deal, and we feel very confident having them as a major stockholder," said Alan C. Hasselwander, Rochester Telephone's president and chief executive.
Companies within an industry sometimes arrange stock deals when they fear hostile takeovers, to place shares in friendly hands. Mr. Hasselwander and John P. Frazee Jr., Centel's chairman and chief executive, said in separate telephone interviews that neither concerns had been approached recently by anyone interested in buying a large or majority stake.
Mr. Hasselwander said Rochester Telephone had decided in early 1988 that it wanted to diversify by having at least a third of its local telephone operations outside New York State. Rochester Telephone then stepped up its purchases of small-town telephone companies.
The acquisition of Centel's Minnesota and Iowa operations will give Rochester Telephone about 825,000 access lines, with 35 percent of them outside New York State. Rochester Telephone retains cellular franchises in New York State, Alabama, Iowa, Kansas and Georgia.
Mr. Frazee said Centel, twice the size of Rochester Telephone, found the Minnesota and Iowa units too small to operate economically.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Mideast Standoff's Effect on Business

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
THE markets reacted with alarm to what President Bush called a "total stiff-arm" by Iraq at the Geneva talks between Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and the Iraqi Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz. And it looks as though the markets and business decision-makers will have to live with extreme uncertainty on war or peace, not just for a few days but possibly for weeks or months.
What will be the economic consequences of this confrontation? Nobody knows; the crisis in the Persian Gulf appears to have blown the art or science of economic forecasting out of the water. Everything now depends on whether there will be war or peace, and what kind of war or peace it will be. 
 Some analysts say that what lies ahead is a stalemate that will be agonizing for business and the markets. Roger E. Brinner, chief economist of DRI/McGraw-Hill, said that given the necessity for business planning of making explicit assumptions about Iraq's future occupation of Kuwait and the implications for oil prices, DRI "assumes that rumors of war and hopes for peace will alternate in ascendancy throughout the winter and spring," adding, "If war means $50 a barrel for oil and peace means $20, then markets today are betting 2 to 1 on peace and thus establishing a trading range near $30."
Every flicker of hope or fear drives oil prices up or down wildly. On Wednesday, when the failed talks in Geneva turned hope into fear, the oil price shot up 30 percent in 5 minutes, to $31 from $24.
The oil market, like any other market, is driven by information, psychology and an effort to guess how other traders will react to new information. But if, in coming days or weeks, the oil price showsa tendency to move up to a much higher trading range, say, above $40, it would mean that the information, open or covert, that the market is getting has strongly shifted the odds toward war.
John Steinbrenner, director of foreign policy studies at the Brookings Institution in Washington, said on Wednesday morning that he was "betting against war." His reasoning was that the confrontation between Iraq and the United States and the other Western nations is "really about money" and that "Saddam gets more if he deals now than if he forces a fight."
But the issue is whether a deal is possible if the Administration sticks to its position of "not rewarding aggression." Mr. Steinbrenner suggested that a deal was possible to get Iraq out of Kuwait if it enabled Iraq to get its oil out and provide it with substantial investment capital for economic development, with the money coming primarily from the other oil states that have made large windfall profits from the confrontation, and from international bodies, like the World Bank or International Monetary Fund.
War, he said, would be devastating to Iraq's interests. But the doubters say this argument falselyassumes that President Hussein is rational; they insist he is a power-crazed dictator, and rewarding him would only feed his appetite. This is the "Hitler" analogy, which President Bush himself has used. But those who still think a deal is possible say that despite President Hussein's threats of "rivers of blood," he is still making the most of his negotiating power and will make a deal at the final moment.
Peter G. Peterson, head of the Blackstone Group and a former Secretary of Commerce, said his intuition was that "all the signals Saddam is sending out" make him think the Iraqi leader is looking for a deal.
Mr. Peterson, an experienced negotiator himself, said his friends in the diplomatic world have told him that this is the way the Arabs bargain: "It is almost digital," he said. "They say no, no, no, day after day, until one morning they do a fast turnaround and say yes." But that morning had not come this week in Geneva and it now seems unlikely to come before or immediately after Jan. 15.
So what if, as President Bush and Secretary Baker have warned, Saddam Hussein has again miscalculated and war comes before a deal? Robert J. Eggert, president and chief economist of Blue Chip Economic Indicators, said the Administration and the large majority of economists he surveys are expecting a short and moderate recession in 1991, "counting on the rejuvenative power of the American economy."
"But if war erupts and the conflict drags on for more than a few weeks," he said, "current optimism that the recession will prove to be relatively short and shallow may evaporate as fast as water in the desert."
Indeed, in the event of a long war, economic policy would confront a whole new ball game, with the oil price soaring, the budget deficit climbing over $400 billion for 1991, the costs of waging the war mounting rapidly, a need for raising taxes -- and other pains not yet contemplated.
Oil closed at $27.71 yesterday, up 45 cents, and the odds are still against war.

HEADLINE: I.M.F. View Of Recession

BYLINE: REUTERS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10

 BODY:
The International Monetary Fund believes the recession in the United States will be short and not very deep, the fund's managing director, Michel Camdessus, said today.
"It looks as though the present decline in the U.S. will be short and relatively shallow," Mr. Camdessus told a gathering at the National Press Club. 
 He declined to say what the economic effect of a war in the Middle East would be, noting that financial problems would be small when compared with the human suffering.
He did say that he believes the world economy would adjust to oil prices if they were to steady at around $26 a barrel over a long period. This would be about 50 percent higher than the level before the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait by Iraq.
Mr. Camdessus praised the Federal Reserve, which has been pushing down interest rates to revive the economy. Its last credit easing came on Tuesday, when it nudged the overnight Federal funds rate down a quarter of a point, to 6.75 percent.
"I am impressed," he said, "by how careful the Federal Reserve has been in allowing some easing of credit to support the economy but in a way that seeks to safeguard against inflation."
Answering questions from reporters, Mr. Camdessus said he was not opposed to further loosening by the Federal Reserve, as long as such a policy did not involve pumping up the economy without regard to the effect on inflation.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Slides in New York After Hectic Asian Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar slipped yesterday against most major foreign currencies as traders caught their breath after Wednesday's unnerving market session.
Among precious metals, gold fell slightly in New York after rising in earlier overseas markets. It closed down 80 cents an ounce, to $390.40, on the New York Commodity Exchange. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $390.50 an ounce, down 75 cents from Wednesday's close. 
 Currency dealers said trading represented mostly a follow-through from volatile overnight trading in Asia, when foreign traders drove the dollar down and then up amid conflicting sentiments about chances for peace in the Persian Gulf.
"By the time New York came in today, the moves were over," said Maria Nordone, vice president and sales manager for the Security Pacific National Bank in Los Angeles.
"It should be quiet until we get the next directive on whether there will be a war or not," she said.
The quiet trading contrasted with the wild swings Wednesday in reaction to the breakdown in United States-Iraq talks to resolve the Middle East crisis peacefully. The dollar had been down before the breakdown in the talks but jumped sharply on the announcement, which helped the currency's safe-harbor appeal.
Yesterday, though, "nobody went out and bought dollars or sold dollars," said Thomas J. Palladino, currency trader at Oesterreichische Landerbank in New York. "We're in a holding pattern," he added. "The longer we stay in a holding pattern, the greater chance the dollar will come off based on economic fundamentals."
Mr. Palladino said a key currency movement yesterday was a weakening of the German mark against the Japanese yen after tough talk from President Mikhail S. Gorbachev that he might impose direct Kremlin rule on the rebellious republic of Lithuania unless it complied with national laws.
However, foreign exchange dealers in Europe said the volume was limited and the day's trading range for the dollar was established in Asian dealings before European trading opened.
The dollar fell more than two yen in New York trading against the Japanese currency, closing at 134.50, down from Wednesday's 137.05. Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar dropped to 135.10 Japanese yen from Wednesday's closing 136.83. In London later yesterday, the dollar traded lower at 134.70 yen.
Against the German currency, the dollar fell to 1.5270 marks, from 1.5400 in New York.
In London, one British pound cost $1.9055 late yesterday, down from Wednesday's late $1.9260. Sterling closed stronger in New York, fetching $1.9122, more than late Wednesday's $1.8970.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Scott Paper Effort To Sell Off Assets

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 10

 BODY:
The Scott Paper Company said it would sell off some assets to improve its earnings potential and reduce debt as the economy headed into recession. The company also said it would reduce capital spending, lower working capital and intensify cost-reduction efforts.
Scott said the assets that would be sold are most of its food-service business; its specialty paper businesses, including a paper mill in Westbrook, Me., and a converting plant in Belgium, and its bulk nonwovens business, with manufacturing sites in the United States and Germany. Scott's chairman and chief executive, Philip E. Lippincott, said the company would concentrate on its core businesses of personal-care and cleaning products and quality coated printing paper.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Speculators Help to Raise Prices

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Speculators, apparently gambling that peace in the Persian Gulf still has a chance, buoyed the Treasury securities market yesterday by stepping up and buying notes and bonds.
Yesterday's gains, which amounted to more than a point for some long-term bonds, more than erased the market's sharp drop on Wednesday afternoon, after Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d told reporters that talks with the Iraqi Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, had not brought the parties any closer to a settlement of the Persian Gulf crisis. 
 It may prove fleeting, but a sense that a solution to the crisis may be found re-emerged again yesterday, after the United Nations General Secretary, Javier Perez de Cuellar, disclosed the outlines of a proposal he will present to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq over the weekend.
"There is still hope that Perez de Cuellar's trip will accomplish something," said James R. Capra, a senior vice president at Shearson Lehman Government Securities. "There is also a thought going through the market that a war, if it happens, will be so contractionary for the economy that it will make the recession that much worse."
The price rebound began during overnight trading in Tokyo, continued when trading shifted to London and was sustained once activity began in American financial markets.
 
Nervousness of Participants
 Nevertheless, the market's extreme volatility over the last few days merely underscored how nervous participants are about the Middle East.
"There is a bit of lunacy in the way positions are being handled by speculators, be they dealers or others," said William Brachfeld, an executive vice president at Daiwa Securities.
"There is probably no more rationality behind the big rally today than in yesterday's big drop in prices," said Robert Chandross, chief economist at Lloyds Bank.
By late in the day, the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 104 5/8, up nearly 1 1/2 points, or nearly $15 for each $1,000 face amount of securities, to yield 8.32 percent, compared with 8.45 percent late Wednesday.
After running up sharply early on Wednesday, bond prices tumbled more than 2 points from their highs after the results of the meeting between Mr. Baker and Mr. Aziz were disclosed, and closed at a price to yield 8.45 percent.
In the secondary market for Treasury notes, the 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 102 17/32 late yesterday, up 26/32, to yield 8.11 percent. And the 7 1/4 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 9/32, up 3/ 32, to yield 7.09 percent.
Dealers said demand at an auction for more than $11 billion of new one-year Treasury bills was strong.
The notes were sold at an average discount rate of 6.22 percent. The rate was down sharply from the 6.58 percent rate at the last one-year bill auction on Dec. 13, and is the lowest rate in nearly three years.
 
Treasury Bill Rates Rise
 Interest rates on outstanding Treasury bills rose slightly yesterday, reversing some of the steep plunge recorded on Wednesday.
By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 6.24 percent, up six basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates rose by four basis points, to a late offered rate of 6.30 percent.
The overnight rate for bank loans in the Federal funds market, which has gyrated wildly for the last few days, traded in a somewhat narrower range yesterday. The funds rate traded as high as 7 1/4 percent and as low as 6 1/2 percent. Earlier this week the Fed was widely seen as lowering its target for the funds rate, the money market rate it most directly controls, by one-quarter of a percentage point, to 6.75 percent.
Big price swings will probably be evident again today, as traders position themselves in advance of the Perez de Cueller visit to Baghdad.
"There will be great skittishness on Friday," a bond trader said. "People won't want to be buying or holding securities if the news out of the Middle East is terrible. But they won't want to be selling if the news is good."
If economists are right, a report on inflation that is expected to be released this morning should help to calm a few nerves.
Due in large part to sagging energy prices, most economists are projecting that the Producer Price Index was unchanged to down slightly in December. Excluding the volatile food and energy components, the so-called core inflation rate rose by two-tenths of a percentage point, most ecnonomists predict.
"Absent the Middle East, the producer price report would probably make the market do better," Mr. Chandross said.
Activity in the tax-exempt municipal securities market was highlighted by a competitive offering of $320 million worth of general obligation bonds for the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania.
A bid from an investment group led by the First Boston Corporation won the issue, which consists of serial bonds maturing from 1992 to 2011.
The securities were reoffered at yields from 5.30 percent in 1992 to 6.10 percent in 1996, 6.55 percent in 2001, 6.95 percent in 2006 and a maximum 7.05 percent in 2011.
The securities are rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service and AA-minus by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Among the new issues priced in the investment-grade corporate bond market was a $200 million offering of seven-year notes by the Great Atlantic Pacific & Tea Company.
The 9 1/8 percent A.&P. notes, which mature Jan. 15, 1998, are noncallable for life. They were priced at $99.50, to yield 9.224, 1.20 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 7/8 percent seven-year notes at the time of pricing.
Dillon, Read & Company acted as lead manager for the transaction. The securities are rated A-3 by Moody's and A-minus by Standard & Poor's.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, traders said that prices of most issues improved by about 1/2 point.
Participants in the secondary market for municipal securities said that prices of most widely quoted issues rose by between 1/4 point to 3/8 point.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday that two of the three measures of the nation's money supply rose during the week ended Dec. 31. The third, broadest measure, M-3, fell by $1.4 billion.
Even with its increase during the last week of the year, M-2, the aggregate followed most closely by the Fed, grew 3.7 percent from the fourth quarter of 1989 to the fourth quarter of 1990, the lowest rate since 1959.
M-2 includes currency in circulation, checking accounts and certain savings accounts.
Some Fed governors have reportedly become increasingly concerned with the slow growth in the money supply. However, yesterday's report had no impact on prices in the credit markets.

HEADLINE: Ford Maintains Dividend, But May Cut Future Payouts

BYLINE: By PAUL C. JUDGE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 10

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company did not cut its dividend this time, but a top company official said it might do so in the future. Amid predictions that it might trim its quarterly payout, the company today declared the regular dividend of 75 cents a share for the first quarter of 1991.
Allan D. Gilmour, Ford's executive vice president in charge of automotive operations, was quoted by the Reuters news agency as saying the nation's No. 2 auto maker might consider lowering the dividend "if the recession is a lot worse than normal." Speaking to reporters at the North American Auto Show in Detroit, Mr. Gilmour said it was "too early to predict what's going to happen to the economy."
 
Bonuses Are Canceled
 Although Ford will maintain its dividend, "it doesn't appear likely at this point" that the company will make profit-sharing payouts to its hourly employees for 1990, Mr. Gilmour said. 
 He also said Ford would not pay executive bonuses for 1990. "We didn't make enough to pay bonuses," he added.
Analysts have suggested that the Big Three auto makers face increasing pressure to cut dividends because of deteriorating sales and dwindling profits.
But "each company hopes that one of its competitors will cut the dividend first and receive the initial bad publicity," said Ronald A. Glantz, an analyst with Dean Witter Securities in San Francisco.
 
Debt Ratings at Risk
 Mr. Glantz added that unless Ford, the General Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation pare their dividends this year, "each faces having its credit rating lowered, which would add hundreds of millions of dollars to their borrowing costs."
The Standard & Poor's Corporation announced on Wednesday that it had placed the Big Three United States car companies on its credit watch list, raising the possibility that the debt ratings of some or all of them might be downgraded.
Chrysler's senior debt is now rated at BBB-, one notch above S.& P.'s speculative category. The senior debt issues of Ford and G.M. are rated at AA-, well above the threshold for investment grade.
Some analysts said the decision today by Ford's board to maintain the 75-cent dividend simply delayed the inevitable, given the uncertain economy and the unhealthy state of the American vehicle market.
 
Big Losses Predicted
 Ford is expected to post an operating loss of as much as $500 million for the fourth quarter.
Analysts expect G.M., the No. 1 auto company, to announce an operating loss of $1.4 billion for last year's fourth quarter, which would be the largest quarterly operating loss in the company's history.
Chrysler, the No. 3 auto maker, is also expected report a loss on operations in the fourth quarter of 1990, Mr. Glantz said. He predicted Chrysler would post a loss of $34 million on its operations during the period.
The auto makers have been hurt by the high costs of paying rebates to attract customers. Ford spent a record $3 billion on buyer incentives and another $1 billion on fleet and leasing incentives in 1990, Mr. Gilmour said.
