HEADLINE: In Rare Move, Big Donors Push Energy Efficiency

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN TELTSCH

 BODY:
In a rare collaborative undertaking, three of the country's leading philanthropies are establishing an Energy Foundation to promote energy efficiency and greater reliance on renewable sources like wind and solar power.
The foundation is being financed by an initial $20 million from the Rockefeller Foundation, the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation of Chicago and the Pew Charitable Trusts of Philadelphia. 
 The partnership was conceived long before the Persian Gulf crisis, the sponsors said after announcing the plan yesterday at a news conference in Washington. But they said current events underscored the need for a new energy strategy for political, economic and environmental reasons.
"At a time of grave danger and volatility in the Middle East, it is worrisome that the United States is increasing its dependence on foreign oil, especially so because there are other proven alternatives," said Hal Harvey, an energy engineer who will be executive director of the Energy Foundation.
 
Goals of Foundation
 The foundation, which will have its office in San Francisco, will identify innovations for conserving energy and will seek to promote their use nationwide. It will also provide funds for research and public education and work with government agencies and environmental groups.
Peter C. Goldmark Jr., president of the Rockefeller Foundation, said: "It is time to conceive of energy efficiency as a source of energy just like oil in Alaska or coal in Montana. That's what this foundation is all about. We want to promote an 'efficiency reserve' that is one of the cleanest, safest and cheapest sources of energy we have."
Adele Simmons, president of the MacArthur Foundation, said the sponsors conceived their energy partnership in 1989, convinced that there was growing public support for the concept of energy efficiency. "It was clear to us," she said, "that there are many constituencies ready to move ahead -- the utilities, regulators, environmentalists and policy makers -- and this was so even before the Iraqi developments put energy on the national agenda."
Pew, the country's second largest philanthropy after the Ford Foundation, joined the venture because of its potential to make a difference, said Rebecca W. Rimel, its executive director. "With some effort, we should be able to save between 30 percent and 50 percent of the energy this country now consumes annually. That's what makes this a beautiful program. Regretfully, we do not have the means to do away with poverty, crime or drugs. This is doable."
The foundation will start out by focusing on areas where there is a high potential for energy savings, in fields like electrical utilities, building construction and transportation.
 
Rewards for Efficiency
 For example, it will promote model practices adopted by electrical utilities like Pacific Gas and Electric, which offers cash rebates for customers who switch to more efficient energy equipment, ranging from light bulbs to refrigerators.
In the transportation field, which consumes 27 percent of the country's energy supply each year, the foundation will encourage the use of technologies that could double the fuel efficiency of automobiles in this country.
In the building construction trades, the use of more efficient windows, advanced lighting, heating and cooling systems could reduce energy consumption by 50 percent, said Mr. Harvey.
He said costs of renewable energy sources were significantly reduced in the last decade, making them competitive with fossil fuels. "Wind power produced by California utilities now produces enough electricity to meet the annual needs of 900,000 people," he said.
Welcoming the establishment of the foundation, Dr. John H. Gibbons, director of the Congressional Office of Technology Assessment, noted that the Federal budget for energy conservation, which he said "should be the centerpiece of any United States strategy to reduce oil dependency," was cut drastically in the early 1980's. Predictably, he said, progress in energy efficiency suffered.
"This new foundation," he added, "has unfettered resources, not tied by ideological in-fighting."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Three philanthropies are collaborating to create an Energy Foundation to promote energy efficiency. At a news conference yesterday were, from left, Rebecca W. Rimel, executive director of the Pew Charitable Trusts; Adele Simmons, president of the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation, and Hal Harvey, an energy engineer who will be the foundation's executive director. (Andrea Mohin/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Florio Needs $800 Million To Balance Budget for '92

BYLINE: By PETER KERR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 10

 BODY:
Gov. Jim Florio's administration acknowledged more bad news today: the state needs to find about $800 million in cuts to balance its budget for the fiscal year beginning in July. Administration officials are asking labor unions to bear half the burden of finding the money.
The administration has told unions representing 64,000 of the state's 87,000 workers that unless they are willing to accept major concessions in salaries and benefits, $400 million in budget cuts involving workers could translate into 10,000 lyoffs, union and administration officials said today. 
 An administration official said that the state expected to lay off several thousand workers but that with union cooperation it could be far less than 10,000. A spokesman for the state's largest union reacted with anger.
The latest news underscored the contrast between the economic and financial outlook for New Jersey in 1991 and Mr. Florio's generally upbeat State of the State address on Tuesday.
Under the slogan "New Jersey Works," Mr. Florio proposed state programs to create tens of thousands of construction jobs, make mortgages available to 3,000 first-time homebuyers, help middle-income parents send their children to college and reduce automobile vehicle inspections that have long irritated the public.
 
Up to 20% Cut
 Vincent Trivelli, legislative coordinator for the Communications Workers of America, the largest of several unions that met with representatives of the administration this week, said the Governor's aides had said that the state had to find $800 million in budget cuts for the fiscal year beginning July 1, and that layoffs and give-backs on the part of state workers would account for $400 million.
An administration official, who spoke on the condition that he not be identified, said estimates for the shortfall in the $12 billion-plus budget for the fiscal year ending in June were holding steady at about $600 million. He said the $800 million for the next fiscal year would require severe cutbacks, including the elimination and merging of some government departments.
Mr. Trivelli said the administration had asked his union, which represents 38,000 employees, to give up 20 percent of their salaries, including a series of salary increases and health benefits granted under a contract signed in January 1990.
"We are not accepting these cutbacks," he said. "They would be a devastating attack not only on the living standards of our members, but for all working people in New Jersey. It will set a pattern that will move into the private sector."
Mr. Florio's hope this week was to create programs with funds from authorities and from the Federal Government to aid, among others, an ailing construction industry and middle-income homeowners and parents.
 
Construction Jobs
 The Governor referred in his State of the State speech to programs that his aides hope will create more than 30,000 construction jobs on transportation and other public works projects. More than $865 million of the money is already drawn rom state and Federal transportation money, officials say, and an additional $200 million would be taken from the state's Transportation Trust Fund, which derives its revenues from a gasoline tax.
In addition, administration officials expect that the New Jersey Turnpike Authority and Port Authority of New York and New Jersey will create tens of thousands more jobs with their construction plans over the next three years. But none of the money from independent authorities and the Transportation Trust Fund could be used to close the gap in the state's budget, which pays the salaries of state employees.
Economists say that such projects could significantly aid the construction industry, which has seen a drop in employment to 152,000 from 181,000 between July 1988 and last fall, according to employment statistics that have not been seasonally adjusted.
 
Vehicle Inspections
 A source of irritation for many New Jerseyans has long been the safety and emissions tests conducted by the Department of Motor Vehicles, which adjusted its hours this year in an economy move to make lines that were often long even longer.
The administration has announced that it plans to eliminate much or all of the safety inspections and turn emmissions testing over to a private contractor in hopes of making the test more efficient and saving the state $22 million. It plans to eliminate testing at 3,900 privately run stations.
The plan would require cars under six years old to be inspected for emissions every other year and would centralize inspections at 30 to 40 franchised locations. Motorists would have to pay between $6 and $15 for inspections, which have been free at state inspection centers. The administration says it plans to have the new system under way by the end of this year.
 
College Savings
 Another program mentioned in Mr. Florio's speech was a $50 million plan to provide loans of up to $5,000 for college tuition, a mearsure aimed at parents with annual household incomes of $60,000 to $90,000 who are not eligible for other loans.
Also aimed at middle-income parents was a $50 million savings bond program for people saving for their children's college educations. The tax-free zero-coupon bonds could be cashed in at maturity. Or they could be used to pay tuition at New Jersey state colleges and universities, where they would be worth 5 percent to 10 percent more than their cash value. The bonds, similar to programs in about 20 other states, would be floated by a variety of independent state authorities.

HEADLINE: Paine Webber Expects A Loss of $95 Million

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
Yet another Wall Street firm gave out some grim numbers yesterday. The Paine Webber Group Inc. announced that it would have a quarterly after-tax loss of about $95 million because of the cost of hundreds of dismissals as well as for new reserves against risky investments.
Executives with the firm said Paine Webber had dismissed about 400 people in the fourth quarter, including about 250 professionals. Those dismissals included 30 investment bankers who were let go late in the year. 
 In a statement describing its financial actions, Paine Webber said it would take a one-time restructuring charge of $24 million to pay for the changes. That money will be used to pay for severance, as well as to consolidate office space. Some branches will be discontinued.
 
Reserves Increased
 The firm also said it would add $71 million to its reserves against its merchant banking investments, many of which plunged in value after the collapse of the "junk bond" market. The new amounts will triple that fund.
Paine Webber's merchant banking problems involve bridge loans that cannot be repaid, including a loan made for the Campeau Corporation's acquisition of Federated Department Stores, which filed for bankruptcy protection shortly after the deal was completed.
In the deal-making days of the 1980's, investment banks provided such loans to corporate acquirers, charging large amounts for the short-term extension of credit. The firms expected that the merged companies would dip into the junk bond markets to raise capital to repay the loans. But the collapse of the market left the companies unable to make good on the loans, choking the capital base of a number of Wall Street firms.
The firm said that before the charges it expected to break even in its operating results for the fourth quarter. With the charges, it anticipated a loss of $95 million for the quarter, and a loss of $55 million for the year.
 
$50 Million Savings Seen
 Donald Marron, Paine Webber's chairman, said the firm expected to reduce its costs by about $50 million annually, primarily because of the dismissals. He also said the firm had increased its capital base to $1.56 billion for 1990, compared with $1.52 billion in 1989.
"Clearly, the economic climate is not very good," Mr. Marron said. "We thought it was prudent to increase our reserves based on the 1990 climate and the 1991 climate. We are adjusting the size of the staff to the new environment."
By taking the charges, Paine Webber joins a number of other firms that have undertaken costly reorganizations since 1989. In December, Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. said it expected to have a $250 million loss for the year as a result of a major realignment of its businesses. That included the dismissal of hundreds of people.
In addition, Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc., a subsidiary of the American Express Company, had a $915 million loss in one quarter of 1990 because of costs associated with its reorganization. And Merrill Lynch & Company, the nation's largest brokerage, took a charge against earnings of $470 million late in 1989 to pay for its restructuring.

HEADLINE: Overseers Silence Bridgeport's Talk of Bankruptcy

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 10

 BODY:
When Mayor Mary C. Moran said this week that she was considering declaring Bridgeport bankrupt, something that has never been done by a city its size, state officials were stunned, credit markets were shaken and residents were talking about it everywhere.
But today, state monitors stepped in and said, in effect, that they would have none of this talk of bankruptcy in Connecticut's largest city. They barred it from considering such an option and voted to impose their own plan to balance the city's budget. 
 Mayor Moran had suggested that declaring bankruptcy might offer a kind of shock treatment to the city, sparing homeowners from further tax increases and reopening expensive union contracts.
Today, the State Treasurer, Francisco L.Borges, who is chairman of the state board overseeing the city's finances, insisted to the Mayor's face that she "unequivocally" recant her statements.
"The words you used -- 'explore' and 'option' -- mean an awful lot to the marketplace," Mr. Borges told the Mayor at a meeting between the city and the panel, the Bridgeport Financial Review Board.
The Mayor, however, bluntly refused. In an irate tone she explained that "as the C.E.O. of this city, it's incumbent upon me toexplore every single avenue, and I will not apologize for that."
The state board countered that under the law only it could approve a municipal bankruptcy proceeding -- a claim the Mayor said she may challenge -- and it passed a resolution never to give such a sanction.
"Bankruptcy is inappropriate because the city has cash, and it's up to date on its obligations," Mr. Borges said after the meeting. "The city's problems are management-driven."
The board also rejected Bridgeport's plan for closing a $7.5 million budget gap. Instead, the board decided that its staff members would come up with a plan and that the board would vote on it next week. The city proposal would have left a $3 million shortfall in its $290 million budget. It also faces a projected shortfall of up to $22 million in the fiscal year that begins July 1. Mr. Borges also announced that he was withdrawing the city from the state's clean-water assistance fund, which relies on revenue bonds. He said he could not be certain that Bridgeport would be able to pay back its loans.
Bridgeport's financial problems did not surface overnight. State officials say years of mismanagement, lax tax collection and overly generous union contracts helped bring this industrial city of 135,000 people to such a stage.
But the recession has dealt a blow to hopes that Connecticut's boom of the 1980's would lift Bridgeport back to the health it had in the postwar years.
"What has tipped it is the change in the economy and the drop in property-tax revenues," said Donald A. Kirshbaum, the executive director of the financial review board.
 
600 Already Laid Off
 Bridgeport averted a brush with bankruptcy in 1987 when it sold state-backed bonds to cover a $60 million deficit. In return, the state assumed oversight of all fiscal matters.
In the year since Mayor Moran took office, 600 city employees have been laid off, including about 100 teachers and 500 workers at a city-owned nursing home that was sold recently. The layoffs cut the city work force to 3,600.
While Mayor Moran's search for high-level managers beyond the city's borders was an encouraging sign to the state monitors, management problems persist, they say.
"Most of the top people around the Mayor have only been there one year," Mr. Kirshbaum said, "so there's not enough institutional memory."
 
While Its Neighbors Flourished
 The city acknowledges doing a poor job collecting revenues. And property taxes, the largest source of revenue, have not kept pace with expenses. While other towns and cities in Fairfield County saw their tax bases expand tremendously in the 1980's as corporations moved in and housing values soared, little development came to Bridgeport, and the value of its taxable property grew only 10 percent from 1983 to 1988.
In addition, state officials say that Bridgeport has agreed to union contracts that are too expensive; one gave workers a 32-hour workweek. "Bridgeport has a history of not negotiating its contracts well and giving away management rights," Mr. Kirshbaum said.
One outcome of a bankruptcy declaration could be the dissolution of the city's 14 union contracts, which account for 60 percent of the budget. This week, Mayor Moran, a former real-estate agent who had no political experience before running for mayor as a Republican, told The Bridgeport Post that declaring bankruptcy would provide an opportunity to "present a plan on what you'll do with contracts."
The city's unions reacted angrily. "It would not be in our members' interest or in the citizens' interest," said Wayne A. Gilbert of the National Association of Government Employees in Bridgeport, which represents 650 workers, mostly in clerical and custodial jobs.
 
Would Be a First
 If Bridgeport were to declare bankruptcy, it would be the first large city in the United States to do so, bankruptcy experts say. School districts, water districts and several small towns have filed for bankruptcy under Chapter 9 of the Federal bankruptcy law, which was established in the Depression for municipalities.
Chapter 9 enables a municipality to delay paying its debts while it arranges a payment schedule with creditors. It does not allow a city's assets to be sold to pay creditors, nor does it remove city officials' governing powers.
Credit-rating officials hurried to review the city's rating this week. Moody's, for instance, decided to keep Bridgeport's rating of BAA after being assured by city officials that a bankruptcy declaration was not imminent. The city's rating was downgraded two months ago to BAA from BAA1. An A rating is average.
In coffee shops and on street corners, Bridgeport residents fretted over their city's future this week, and most appeared to reject the notion that bankruptcy would make things better.
"I wouldn't like to see bankruptcy because too many innocent people will get hurt," said Frank Marsillio, a retired carpenter sitting at the counter at the New Colony Diner.
Dwight Walker, the owner of New York Express, a clothing store in a half-vacant shopping arcade on Main Street, worried about what bankruptcy would do to Bridgeport's image. "How are you going to get people to want to come here?" he said.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Legislators Take Sides for Combat Or for Reliance on the Sanctions

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10

 BODY:
Congress today began debating the prospect of war in the Persian Gulf, arguing whether an early attack on Iraq or continued reliance on economic sanctions was more likely to force Iraq out of Kuwait.
A strong sense of history permeated the day's proceedings. The proposal backed by President Bush and the one thought most likely to pass, the "Authorization for Use of Military Force Against Iraq Resolution" was described by a pivotal sponsor, Representative Dante B. Fascell, Democratic of Florida, as the "practical equivalent" of a declaration of war, a step the Congress has taken formally only five times. 
 In the Senate, Paul D. Wellstone, a freshman Democrat from Minnesota, said he had hoped his first Senate speech would be about children, education and health care, but instead it was about war.
"This cause is not worth fighting for right now," he said. "We must stay the course with economic sanctions, continue the squeeze, continue the pressure, move forward on the diplomatic front, and, Mr. President, we must not, we must not rush to war." [Sampling from speeches, page A8.]
But Senator John C. Danforth, Republican of Missouri, said he had recently changed his mind and decided to support President Bush's use of force because "it is clear to me that sanctions alone cannot succeed. They will inflict difficulties on civilians, but sanctions alone will not force Iraq out of Kuwait."
In the House, Mr. Fascell, the chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee, was joined by two other Democratic committee chairmen and the Republican leadership in backing the proposal that would specifically authorize President Bush to use military force against Iraq if it has not withdrawn from Kuwait by Jan. 15. Representative Stephen J. Solarz, Democrat of Brooklyn, a key drafter, argued that the resolution took pains to maintain Congressional prerogatives and would show Iraq that the United States was united.
 
Sanctions Are Backed
 But Democratic leaders there and in the Senate advanced counterproposals, urging instead continued reliance on economic sanctions. Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, said, "If we go to war now, no one will ever know if sanctions would have worked if given a full and fair chance." Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader, said "the tough measures we have already taken have stopped the Iraqi war machine dead in its tracks."
Republicans countered with a new letter from the Director of Central Intelligence, William H. Webster, saying the power of Iraq's ground forces was "unlikely to be substantially affected" by sanctions over the next 6 to 12 months. He also said there was little evidence that President Saddam Hussein of Iraq faced political difficulties because of shortages.
Throughout the debate, lawmakers spoke of the votes they expected to cast Saturday as the most important of their careers. But in neither the House nor the Senate today were the issues often clearly joined face to face. In the Senate, even though the gulf crisis was taken up well before noon, there were rarely more than a handful of Senators present, although this was more than the usual number of Senators on most days and there were fewer interruptions for quorum calls while speakers were sought.
 
More Than Usual Present
 In the House, competing news conferences were the early forums of choice until the Rules Committee met in midafternoon and proposed an extraordinary amount of time, 15 hours, for floor consideration of the issue. And as the House for an hour considered adopting those procedures, there were typically about 40 of the House's 435 members present, again well more than the usual number.
The House had three resolutions before it, one favoring sanctions, one authorizing President Bush to use of force and a third merely asserting the exclusivity of the Congressional power to declare war. The Senate had a pro-sanctions resolution on the floor, and it was expected that a contrary proposal backing force would be introduced.
Despite the clear differences between most Republicans and most Democrats on the war versus sanctions issue, some leaders in both parties sought to blunt any partisan edge. Mr. Gephardt, opening the formal debate in the House in late afternoon, said, "In this vote, we are not Democrats. We are not Republicans. We are Americans."
 
No Lining Up of Votes
 He said there would be no Democratic whips trying to line up votes for the sanctions proposals he supported. "We expect and want all of the members to vote their conscience, what in their mind is the right thing for this country to do."
Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, the minority leader, praised that commitment, and said he, too, would support whatever result the House settled on.
He went on to call for military action, saying, "Saddam Hussein has more tanks, planes and men under arms than Hitler did when Chamberlain came back saying 'peace in our time.' Either we stop him now and stop him permanently or we won't stop him at all." He said those advocating further reliance on sanctions amounted to "a brass choir of doubt and confusion."
The resolution that he, Mr. Fascell, Mr. Solarz and others from both parties settled on this morning, the provision that most House leaders predicted would be adopted on Saturday, would authorize the President "to use United States Armed Forces pursuant to United Nations Security Council Resolution 678." That resolution, adopted Nov. 29, authorized members nations to use "all necessary means" to get Iraqi forces out of Kuwait if they were not withdrawn by Jan. 15.
 
One Condition Sought
 The only condition of the Congressional resolution was to require the President first to notify Congress that diplomatic efforts and economic sanctions "have not been and would not be successful in obtaining such compliance."
A comparable measure was expected to be introduced in the Senate after Republican leaders there conferred at the White House and then met in a caucus this afternoon.
The alternatives introduced in the House and the Senate were very similar in language and identical in intended effect.
They declared Congressional insistence on an end to Iraq's "brutal and illegal occupation of Kuwait." They said military force was appropriate to protect American forces, enforce the embargo and defend Saudia Arabia. Each declared that continued economic and diplomatic sanctions were appropriate now, and promised to consider with expedited procedures any future request from President Bush for a declaration of war or other authorization of military action.
 
2d House Resolution
 Finally, the House is also considering another brief resolution declaring "The Congress finds that the Constitution of the United States vests all power to declare war in the Congress of the United States. Any offensive action taken against Iraq must be explicitly approved by the Congress of the United States before such action may be initiated." It is expected to pass.
The resolution introduced by Mr. Solarz was frequently faulted as amounting to "an unlimited blank check to initiate war," as Mr. Mitchell put it. But Republicans insisted that the time was now ripe for action.
Senator Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah, contended that the President had "taken every step short of the use of force" and that now it was time for the Senate to join in his support.
In the House, Representative John Miller, Republican of Washington, said proposals to rely on sanctions for another year would be translated by the Iraqis to mean "you've got another year to pillage and rape, another year to threaten other nations."
 
How to Go About It
 But Senator Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia and chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, said the issue was "not whether we agree with President Bush's goals. We do. The real question is how we go about it, whether we actually use military force or whether we use the embargo. In either event, the Iraqis must get out of Kuwait."
Mr. Webster's letter, sent today to the House Armed Services Committee, stated that although Iraqi ground forces could weather the embargo largely unscathed, Iraq's air force and ground-based air defenses would suffer far more from the embargo. But Mr. Webster suggested that air power "is not likely to play a major role in any battle for Kuwait."
That conclusion was quickly contested by Democratic Congressional experts on the sanctions, who said that any military action against Iraq almost certainly would begin with a prolonged air bombardment of military targets in Kuwait and Iraq, not with a ground attack.
"Isn't it fair to say that if Iraq's air defenses go down in a significant way, that fewer American pilots will be killed if we wait to begin a war?" a Senate aide said.
 Many lawmakers complained that other nations, some especially menaced by Iraq, were not doing their part. Senator David L. Boren, Democrat of Oklahoma, said, "I cannot in good conscience vote to initiate full-scale war now to restore the Government of Kuwait if 90 percent of the risk and burden will be borne by America while other nations like Japan and Germany sit on the sidelines not doing their share."
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, also questioned why the United States was particularly concerned about defending the Kuwaitis. Recalling his years as United States chief delegate to the United Nations, he said, "I remember the Kuwaitis as a particularly poisonous adversary of the U.S., and their anti-Semitic attitude was at the level of being personally loathsome."

HEADLINE: Weicker and the Assembly: New Lines of Power

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Jan. 10

 BODY:
When Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. stepped into the House chamber on Wednesday to deliver his State of the State speech, not a single member of his own party was there to gaze up at the rostrum and applaud on cue. Mr. Weicker, representing the independent Connecticut Party, stood alone at last against the sea of Democrats and Republicans and the two-party system that he railed against in last year's election.
The moment drove home what was largely an abstraction until then: The General Assembly, as the legislature is known, has become as independent as Mr. Weicker. Released from the bonds of party loyalty that have tied its members to past governors, the state's 187 legislators will have to redefine their institution's role in the new political order, just as Mr. Weicker is reshaping the old patterns of the executive branch. 
 Many people think the process will be difficult. The House and Senate have held over the years to the traditions of a strong chief executive expected to lead, matched against a legislature that dots the i's and crosses the t's.
"The governor proposes; the Assembly disposes" is repeated like an article of faith in a building where Gov. William A. O'Neill, the Democrat who preceded Mr. Weicker, governed for 10 years without having a veto overridden. The question is: How much of that tradition can or should hold with a governor who cannot call on even one member of his own party for support, advice or consent? Should the General Assembly still follow, obediently or obstinately, as in the familiar days of Mr. O'Neill and his predecessors, or stake out a new independent leadership course of its own?
Looming over the government is a huge and still growing gap in the state budget. Budget officers now predict that Connecticut will fall $2.2 billion short in revenue over the next 18 months, in an annual budget of just over $7 billion. Both of the state's largest revenue sources -- the corporate profits tax and the sales tax -- have shrunk in the regional economic recession.
 
'Legislative Proposing'
 Some lawmakers think that re-examining the old assumptions about government and party politics will help resolve the crisis, while others fear that it could heighten the potential for chaos. More than a few see long-term opportunity: whichever group or subgroup in the legislature succeeds in getting the Governor's ear will have power, no matter the party labels. At the least, a new assertiveness is anticipated.
"Ultimately, I think we'll see a rapid expansion of legislative proposing," said Representative Jonathan Pelto, a Democrat from Storrs and deputy majority leader in the House. "But's it's something that will take time for us to get used to."
In his State of the State speech on Wednesday, Mr. Weicker encouraged lawmakers to abandon their old assumptions, forget the rules of partisanship and look anew at how government should and should not work. "The state's political clothes are worn out, and it is up to all of us to cut a new suit for these times," Mr. Weicker said. "People are sick of partisan games and want results, not scorecards."
But the early rumblings show ambivalence about what direction the Assembly may take. The Speaker of the House, Richard J. Balducci, a Democrat from Newington, announced last week that his party, which is in the majority, would formulate its own budget proposals in coming weeks with elements that might parallel Mr. Weicker's budget package but might not.
 
Old Tie
 But conforming with tradition, Mr. Balducci said the Democrats had no plans at present to submit a formal budget bill until Mr. Weicker makes his budget address next month.
The Republicans have called for a budget meeting between Mr. Weicker and legislative leaders in both parties, but House and Senate minority leaders also clearly have their own agenda. Mr. Weicker, who served in the United States Senate for 18 years until 1988, was a liberal Republican throughout his career until last year, and some think the old ties may still bind.
Democrats outnumber Republicans by 89 to 62 in the House and by 20 to 16 in the Senate.
"The shackles of partisan politics are now shaken," said the House minority leader, Edward C. Krawiecki Jr., a Republican from Bristol. "This is a new opportunity for Republicans."
Mr. Weicker's own signals shed only limited light on how involved he wants the General Assembly to be in proposing legislation. Today at a news conference in his office, for example, he said he had no intention of having his budget plans come out in "snippets and bits and pieces," and that he wanted to present the budget to legislators on Feb. 20 as "a whole package."
But moments later he repeated the pledge he made on Wednesday that his door would be open to any and all lawmakers and that legislative leaders would not only be informed of budget plans in advance of the February announcement but also be fully consulted along the way.
Some legislators say that even without Mr. Weicker's independent administration and even without a budget crisis, the General Assembly was heading toward greater independence.
In the last few years, for example, the Senate President Pro Tempore, John B. Larson, a Democrat from East Hartford, developed and proposed a series of bills dealing with parents and children, including a law that took effect last year giving parents the right to take time off from their jobs for a child's birth or illness. Such initiatives had been rare.
"Times of great problems are times of great opportunities," said Representative Richard T. Mulready, a Democrat from West Hartford and co-chairman of the legislature's Finance, Revenue and Bonding Committee.

(Steve Miller for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Saudi Contributions in Crisis Are Called Generous

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Jan. 10

 BODY:
Saudi Arabia has spent every penny it earned from windfall profits from oil sales last year and has committed double that amount to defend itself from Iraq and support those who have come to its aid, diplomats and Saudi officials say.
In interviews this week, Saudi businessmen and officials and Western diplomats said that Saudi Arabia had earned roughly $15 billion in windfall oil profits in the first five months of the crisis last year, and had made $30 billion in gulf-related commitments, only $15 billion of which it had spent. Thus, they said, the kingdom had effectively mortgaged a large part of whatever oil profits it might earn in 1991. 
 Saudi Arabia's budget deficit for 1990, they said, probably totaled at least $15 billion owing to the gulf crisis, roughly double the shortfall anticipated before Iraq's invasion in August.
The Saudis and diplomats who provided the estimates said they were doing so partly in response to critics in the United States Congress who argued that Riyadh had not given as much as it should have to the American-led effort to oust Iraqi forces from Kuwait.
 
'Taking a Definite Risk'
 "I think Saudi Arabia's contribution to this effort has not fully been understood or appreciated," said Saleh al-Malek, a former Deputy Minister of Municipal and Rural Affairs who now heads a social research consulting agency.
Western diplomats here estimated the shortfall at $15 billion. Most agreed that Saudi Arabia had committed more than the diplomats had expected.
"They are taking a definite risk," one economist said, "because their ability to pay for what they've committed assumes that no major new commitments will be necessary -- unlikely if there is a war -- and that oil prices will stay high enough to enable them to pay for what they have already pledged."
Saudi and Western officials estimated that because of a large increase in Saudi oil production and rising market prices, the Saudis' net oil revenues for 1990 totaled about $40 billion, about $15 billion more than the Government had projected before the crisis began.
 
Produced More Oil and Aid
 Prince Abdelaziz bin Salman bin Abdelaziz, a senior adviser in the Ministry of Petroleum, said: "We have contributed enormously in two respects -- by increasing production to lower prices, and by supporting those countries that sent forces here. Just imagine how much more we could have earned had we limited oil production to seven million barrels per day."
The largest single commitment was $13.6 billion in new arms and equipment for the Saudi armed forces. Almost $3 billion to military support for the United States and other "friendly" countries, $1.7 billion in extra mobilization and deployment costs, and $1 billion for civil defense brought the unofficial estimate of total Saudi defense commitments to more than $19 billion.
The Saudis are reported to have made more than $6 billion in grants and Government-guaranteed loans to friendly governments to offset the cost of the economic effects of the crisis.
"In relative terms, these figures are even more striking," a Western economist said. In 1990, he said, crisis-related costs led to 25 to 30 percent of the Kingdom's total spending, or 15 to 20 percent of its gross domestic product. He said United States spending was $9 billion at most, no more than 1 percent of annual spending and less than one-fifth of 1 percent of its gross domestic product.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
ARABS SAY IRAQ PLANS OFFER LINKING PULLOUT TO ISRAEL; CONGRESS OPENS WAR DEBATE

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 10

 BODY:
Arab diplomats here said today that they had been told that President Saddam Hussein plans an initiative soon after the Jan. 15 United Nations deadline for giving up Kuwait that will express his support "in principle" for pulling out of Kuwait and simultaneously call for an international conference to address Palestinian grievances against Israel.
The Iraqi leader, those diplomats said, is expected to wait until a day or two after the United Nations deadline has passed to make his statement to demonstrate he has not been intimidated. He is also expected to seek international guarantees that Iraq will not be attacked, and to propose negotiations on disputes between Iraq and Kuwait.
 
Previous Hints
 While he has previously hinted that he might respond in some fashion to a linking of the two issues, Mr. Hussein has never said he will leave Kuwait. 
 Reports of the planned Iraqi initiative also suggest that President Hussein is unlikely to make substantive concessions to Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar during his 11th-hour mediation trip to Baghdad.
The Secretary General left New York for Baghdad tonight via Paris and Geneva. He is scheduled to meet in Geneva on Friday with the 12 foreign ministers of the European Community and with the Foreign Minister of Yugoslavia, which is currently chairman of the movement of nonaligned states. [Page A10.]
 
Five Days to Go
 With only five days left before the Jan. 15 deadline, Arab and European governments have become involved in seeing whether a formula can be found to settle the Kuwait crisis peacefully. In Geneva on Wednesday, Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz of Iraq called for an "Arab solution" to the crisis but was unspecific on what Iraq might do. Mr. Aziz and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d failed to make progress at a meeting in Geneva.
It was impossible to confirm that Mr. Hussein will make the kind of statement that the Arab diplomats at the United Nations say they have been told about. Those diplomats, from Arab countries aligned with the Saudis and Americans against Iraq, said they had received reports of such an impending Iraqi initiative from Algeria, Jordan and Yemen, the three Arab countries closest to Baghdad.
The diplomats said they had no doubt that the Bush Administration would reject such an Iraqi proposal because of the linkage between the Kuwait withdrawal and the Palestinian question and because there would be no guaranteed deadline for an Iraqi pullout from Kuwait.
But the diplomats said the expected move could strengthen the hand of those in Congress and elsewhere who want to give economic sanctions more time to force Iraq out of Kuwait.
They also argued that the negotiations Iraq offers on unresolved issues with Kuwait -- like ownership of the Rumaila oil field and the islands of Bubiyan and Warba -- could drag on almost indefinitely, leaving Baghdad still in control of Kuwait.
 
'A Nightmare Scenario'
 Meanwhile President Hussein could reinforce his position as a hero to the Arab masses by asserting that he had effectively linked the surrender of Kuwait with new steps to settle the Palestinian issue and force Israel to give up the Arab territories it occupied after the 1967 war.
"Frankly, it's a nightmare scenario," an Arab diplomat said.
Mr. Perez de Cuellar's scheduled arrival on Saturday in Baghdad will follow a visit by President Kenneth Kaunda of Zambia, who was reported there today on a similar peace mission. Mr. Kaunda obtained the release of a British nurse imprisoned by Iraq last year in a purported espionage plot for which an Iranian-born British journalist was hanged.
Diplomats stressed that the Secretary General would have almost no margin for negotiation when he meets the Iraqi leadership because he is bound by the resolutions of the Security Council, which demand Iraq's unconditional surrender of Kuwait.
 
Pullout Arrangements
 The more optimistic diplomats here said they hoped that the Iraqi leader might find it easier to make concessions to the Secretary General of the United Nations than directly to the United States. But most argue that the Secretary General can do little more than explain once again to the Iraqi leader the options he faces.
"The Secretary General must paint a plain, unvarnished picture of exactly what is possible and what is not," Britain's United Nations representative, Sir David Hannay, told reporters tonight.
Sir David said the Secretary General can tell Mr. Hussein that the Security Council is ready to guarantee that he will not be attacked, and to offer its full support for a negotiated settlement of his disagreements with Kuwait, but only if he immediately starts pulling out his forces.
The Secretary General is also ready to talk about technical arrangements for an Iraqi pullout, including the dispatch of a United Nations peacekeeping force to oversee the withdrawal and preserve calm along the Iraq-Kuwait frontier afterward.
 
Promise of Nordic Troops
 Earlier this week the five Nordic countries, Sweden, Norway, Denmark, Finland and Iceland, told the Secretary General that they were ready to contribute troops to such a force if the Security Council asks them to do so and urged him to start contingency planning for an Iraqi withdrawal.
The Secretary General is expected to return to New York on Sunday and report on his mission to the Security Council next Monday, one day before it has authorized the use of force to expel Iraq from Kuwait.

HEADLINE: Steel Output Is Off by 1.8%

DATELINE: GENEVA, Jan. 10 (Reuters)

 BODY:
World crude steel production fell by 1.8 percent, to 769.4 million tons, in 1990, mainly because of reduced output in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe, the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe said today.
The Soviet Union was the top world producer with 155.8 million tons, but its output was 4.3 million tons less than in 1989. The combined output of Eastern Europe totaled 50.3 million tons, a drop of 14.7 percent.
Output of the 12-nation European Community fell by 2.1 percent, to 137.3 million tons. Production in the United States rose slightly, to 88.7 million tons, third highest. Japan was the No. 2 producer with 110.3 million tons, up 2.2 percent.

HEADLINE: Salomon Brothers May Move 700 Jobs Out of New York City

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
Joining the corporate concern about the cost of doing business in New York City, Salomon Brothers Inc., the large Wall Street investment house, is considering moving hundreds of jobs out of the city, executives with the firm and city officials said yesterday.
The executives said the firm was negotiating to move 700 jobs in its operations division to sites in Tampa, Fla., and Columbus, Ohio. Although keeping the jobs in New York has not been ruled out, they said Salomon was leaning toward a move to Tampa. A final decision is not expected for 60 days. 
 No employees would be moved until after the end of the year, the executives said. Salomon is said to be planning to keep 3,000 employees in New York.
The disclosure of the negotiations came a day after W. R. Grace & Company, whose ties to New York go back a century, announced it would move most of its staff from Manhattan to Boca Raton, Fla. The move was made for economic reasons.
"We obviously can't be happy that they are considering moving personel out of the city," said Jeanne Nathan, a spokeswoman for Sally B. Hernandez-Pinero, the Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development. "But we are glad that they are keeping their headquarters in the World Trade Center and that they will continue to have a very major stake in New York City."
While the Salomon negotiations involve only workers in the operations division, known in Wall Street parlance as the back office, such a move could have a large impact on employment in the city. The back office is a labor-intensive part of any Wall Street firm. Through the back offices, millions of securities trades are cleared each day, meaning that securities are moved to the account that purchased them and cash is moved to the seller.
In recent years, city officials have been working to provide spaces for back offices to move to, but some firms have moved their operations from Manhattan. Some have moved out of Manhattan to less expensive boroughs, while others have left New York State.

HEADLINE: Rich Got Richer in 80's; Others Held Even

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10

 BODY:
The wealth of affluent people grew substantially in the 1980's while the assets of other Americans barely kept pace with inflation, the Census Bureau reported today.
The Government and private economists have been reporting for several years that the nation's income distribution was becoming more unequal, with a bigger gap between people of high and low incomes. Today's report was one of the first systematic examinations of wealth, reflecting not just one year's income but the lifetime accumulation of property and other assets. 
 The Census Bureau said that for the most affluent fifth of all households, wealth rose 14 percent from 1984 to 1988, after adjusting for inflation. For other households, wealth was not significantly different in 1984 and 1988, the bureau said.
In 1988 the United States had 91.6 million households. The top fifth consisted of 18.3 million households with income of more than $46,600 a year; the median wealth of those households was $111,770. In any group, the number of households above the median is the same as the number below it.
Wealth, or net worth, is defined by the Census Bureau as the value of savings and checking accounts, real estate, automobiles, stocks and bonds and other assets, minus debts. The value of pension plans, jewelry and home furnishings was not included. The Census Bureau report is based on interviews with 24,000 households chosen to be representative of the nation's 92 million,
White households typically have 10 times as much wealth as black households, the Census Bureau reported. The difference between the races was about the same in 1988 as in 1984, the only other year in which the bureau collected comprehensive data on wealth.
Judith H. Eargle, an economist at the Census Bureau, said that as expected, the latest study showed that wealth increased with a person's income, age and education.
While the median income of whites is roughly twice that of blacks, the disparity in wealth is much greater, partly because wealth reflects decades of differences in earnings, investment and the inheritance of property. The data in the report suggest why economic disparities between blacks and whites are likely to endure even if blacks' incomes catch up with whites': People with similar incomes may have very different levels of wealth.
The median wealth of all households in 1988 was $35,750, the bureau said. The median was $43,280 for whites, $4,170 for blacks and $5,520 for Hispanic households. The Hispanic category may overlap with the other two, since Hispanic people may be of any race.
Elderly couples often have lower incomes than younger couples. But the median wealth of elderly married people, $124,420, is about 10 times that of couples in which the head of household is under 35 years old, the bureau said.
The Government has much more information about income than about wealth. Many people do not know the total value of their assets, and many regard detailed questions about their wealth as intrusive. But wealth, Ms. Eargle said, "may be just as important as income as a measure of a person's economic well-being."
Robert B. Avery, an economist who used to supervise surveys of consumer finances for the Federal Reserve Board, said the increased wealth of the top 20 percent of the population was "a little bit surprising" because the board found "no change in real household wealth," after adjustment for inflation, from 1983 to 1986. In those years, "we saw no demonstrable evidence that the rich were getting richer," said Mr. Avery, now a professor of consumer economics at Cornell University.
In the Census Bureau survey, 29 percent of black households reported that they had no wealth, meaning that they owned no assets or that their liabilities exceeded their assets. By contrast, 9 percent of all white households and 24 percent of Hispanic households reported having no wealth.
At the other end of the scale, 29 percent of white households reported wealth of $100,000 or more, as against 5 percent of black households and 12 percent of Hispanic households.
About two-thirds of all families own their homes. But the equity value of such homes declined from 1984 to 1988, suggesting that mortgage debt went up or the homes' market value went down after adjusting for inflation. The median equity was $43,070 in 1988, as against $46,110 in 1984.
 
More Have Stocks and I.R.A.'s
 Mr. Avery said the bureau's survey of 24,000 households gave a reliable picture of the population in general but was "not good in measuring the very top of the wealth distribution because there is no particular effort to sample high-income people." Surveys by the Federal Reserve Board suggest that 1 percent of all households hold one-third of all personal wealth, he said.
Predictably, the Census Bureau found that married couples were much wealthier than households headed by men or women with no spouse present. Married couples had median wealth of $57,130 in 1988.
But somewhat surprisingly, the bureau found that the median for households headed by women, $13,570, was higher than for households headed by men with no wife present, $13,050.
Ms. Eargle of the Census Bureau observed that many women heading households were elderly and were able to accumulate wealth over a longer period of time than the single men heading households, who tend to be younger. "These elderly female householders include widows, a portion of whose wealth has been inherited," she said.
The Census Bureau said in 1986 that it intended to publish studies of household wealth every year or two. But the tabulation and analysis of data have taken longer than expected. Ms. Eargle said the agency still wanted to issue such studies every two or three years.
The report said 22 percent of American households owned stocks or mutual fund shares in 1988, up from 20 percent in 1984. In 24 percent of households, people had individual retirement accounts or Keogh plans, up from 20 percent in 1984.
Ms. Eargle, the author of the report, said the difference in the wealth of blacks and whites might be explained partly by marital status: only 35 percent of black households included married couples, as against 60 percent of white households and 55 percent of Hispanic households.
The racial disparity is smaller among married couples than among all households. The median wealth of married white couples, $62,390, is three and a half times the median for married black couples, $17,640.

HEADLINE: New England Bank Review

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BOSTON, Jan. 10

 BODY:
L. William Seidman, the chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, said today that he will try to assess how well the F.D.I.C. is running three failed New England banks when he visits Boston on Friday.
Mr. Seidman was also scheduled to meet with the governors of the six New England states. 
 The visit comes less than a week after the F.D.I.C. seized three banking units of the Bank of New England Corporation.
The F.D.I.C. took over the banks on Sunday, injecting about $750 million in capital. The Government is seeking bidders for the banks, which are in Massachusetts, Maine and Connecticut.
Mr. Seidman said the main purpose for his visit was to meet with F.D.I.C. officials and bank personnel.
"In particular, I hope to meet with many of the hundreds of bank employees and thank them for their efforts and support during this difficult period," Mr. Seidman said.
As for his meeting with the governors, Mr. Seidman said, "These officials expressed an interest in sharing their first-hand impressions of general economic and industry conditions in New England."

HEADLINE: Rohatyn Agrees To Retain Post On Fiscal Panel

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 10

 BODY:
While Felix G. Rohatyn won't be staying in his post as head of New York City's fiscal watchdog agency for very long, he won't be leaving right away either.
Mr. Rohatyn, the investment banker who helped New York steer its way through its fiscal crisis in the mid-1970's but who has quarreled with city and labor officials over how to cope with the present turmoil, said he would remain as chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation "for a limited period of time," according to an announcement issued today by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. 
 That means that the 62-year-old Mr. Rohatyn, who said last fall after a public spat with union leaders that he would resign his post by the end of 1990, will remain during critical negotiations in the next few months over both New York State's and New York City's budgets. The news did not generate much surprise today among state or city officials, who seem to have expected that Mr. Rohatyn would allow himself to be coaxed into staying on as the action unfolded.
 
'Doesn't Always Agree With Him'
 "His experience and judgment are especially valuable as we cope with the effects of the recession that is burdening the nation's state and local governments," the Governor said.
Calls to Mr. Rohatyn this afternoon and evening were not returned.
Mayor David N. Dinkins, who often lists Mr. Rohatyn as one of his most valued advisers but who politely ignored his suggestions that the contracts he was negotiating with teachers and other unions were excessive, said through a spokesman that despite their differences over the contracts, he had no desire to hasten Mr. Rohatyn's departure.
"The Mayor seeks his counsel all the time," said Mr. Dinkins's press secretary, Albert Scardino. "He doesn't always agree with him, because Felix, necessarily, has a focus that is far narrower than what the Mayor has to consider."
 
Possible Struggle Avoided
 Still, in retaining Mr. Rohatyn, whose assessment of the city's budget difficulties seems to mirror his own in many respects, Mr. Cuomo clearly has avoided the prospect of having to carry out a struggle right now with the Mayor over a successor to Mr. Rohatyn. The final choice is up to the Governor, but city officials would be expected to have a hand in the decision.
Last month, the Governor warned that the city's finances were out of control and might need to be taken over by a state control board. Both he and Mr. Dinkins have since then taken pains to play down that rift, saying they were more interested in working together to avoid the need for a takeover.
The Municipal Assistance Corporation, created by state legislation in 1975 to issue bonds on behalf of a nearly bankrupt New York City, is not expected to play the same critical role in solving the city's financial problems now that it did in the 1970's, largely because the immediate constraints on the city are of a different nature.

HEADLINE: New York Dismisses Official Who Attacked Bridge Cuts

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
New York City's Deputy Commissioner for Bridges, who spoke out publicly against cutbacks in bridge maintenance, warning that they would endanger public safety, was dismissed last night.
Transportation Commissioner Lucius J. Riccio said in a statement that he had dismissed the Deputy Commissioner, David Steinberger, because the two had differences of opinion over how the Bridge Bureau should be managed. 
 "At this time I believe a change is necessary," Mr. Riccio said. He said he would not make any other comment.
Mr. Steinberger's dismissal comes justtwo days after an article in The New York Times reported that Mr. Riccio had reopened the south side of the Manhattan Bridge to subway trains last year despite warnings from Mr. Steinberger that the deteriorating bridge would suffer serious structural damage and that subway service would have to be suspended repeatedly for repairs to the bridge.
 
'Bad Decision for the Bridge'
 In a memo to Mr. Riccio dated Aug. 17, Mr. Steinberger said returning trains to the bridge was a "bad decision for the bridge" and he urged Mr. Riccio to reconsider it. The Manhattan Bridge is one of the city's most deteriorated bridges. Stateinspectors have discovered more than 300 hazardous conditions on the bridge, including large cracks and corroded steel beams.
But Mr. Riccio reopened the subway tracks in September, and the city was forced to stop service on Dec. 27 after inspectors found that a beam supporting the subway tracks was an inch away from failure. City engineers and officials of the Transit Authority have said that if the the beam had slipped, the subway tracks would have sagged, causing a train to derail and great injury to passengers.
Albert Scardino, a spokesman for Mayor David N. Dinkins, said last night that the Mayor was aware of the dismissal but he would not comment on the degree of the Mayor's involvement in the decision. He would say only: "The Mayor has been in communication with his Commissioner of Transportation. It's his department and his decision to make about his staff."
The dismissal comes amid indications of growing dissension among officials and engineers of the Transportation Department on the bridge issue. Three deputy and assistant commissioners and senior officials in the Bridge Bureau who have supported Mr. Steinberger's position on the return of trains to the Manhattan Bridge said last night that they had lost faith in Mr. Riccio's ability to manage the city's bridges. They asked to remain anonymous, saying they feared retribution.
The dismissal comes at a time of increasing concern about the conditions of the city's bridges. In recent months, state inspectors have found evidence of rapid deterioration. More than half of the bridges are considered structurally deficient and unable to carry the loads for which they were designed.
As the city's fiscal problems have deepened, the Dinkins administration has said it would reduce the preventive maintenance program for bridges by 38 percent this year, to $5.8 million, and would reduce spending on other bridge projects to $930 million from $1.2 billion over the next five years.
In a rare move by a Deputy Commissioner, Mr. Steinberger openly opposed such cuts, saying the city was "creating a time bomb" on the bridges.
 
Officials Formerly Close
 Mr. Steinberger, who is 30 years old, joined the Transportation Department in 1982. Senior administration officials said that Mr. Riccio and Mr. Steinberger had been close at one time and that Mr. Riccio had sponsored Mr. Steinberger's promotion to Deputy Commissioner last January after Mr. Dinkins named Mr. Riccio the Commissioner. The promotion came even though Dinkins administration aides expressed some reservations about his qualifications.
But the senior administration officials said it was well known within the administration that the relationship had become strained recently and that Mr. Riccio had stopped discussing sensitive matters in the presence of his deputy because he feared that they would be leaked to reporters.
Mr. Steinberger said in an interview last night: "I have always tried to do what is right for the bridges and to be open about the seriousness of the problem. There was no other way to do this job. The public was counting on us."
 
'He Told Me Not to Write'
 Mr. Steinberger said Mr. Riccio had "made it clear to me on several occasions that he did not want to be informed of certain public safety risks concerning the bridges."
"He told me not to write certain memos like the one I wrote on the Manhattan Bridge because he felt that they were dangerous and there should be no public record of such warnings," Mr. Steinberger said.
Mr. Steinberger said he was shocked not only at his dismissal but at the way that it had happened. On Wednesday, he said, he was asked to report at 5 P.M. yesterday to the office of Michael Weiss, the Transportation Department's chief of staff.
Mr. Steinberger said he and Mr. Weiss were joined by Seth Cummings, the department's legal counsel, and Mr. Riccio. Mr. Steinberger said Mr. Riccio told him: "It's obvious we have significant differences, and I have two choices for you. Either you resign, or I will terminate you. I'll leave the details to Mike or Seth."
 
5 Minutes to Decide
 Mr. Riccio then left the office, and Mr. Weiss and Mr. Cummings told Mr. Steinberger that he had five minutes to decide, Mr. Steinberger said.
Mr. Steinberger said that he had asked the two officials if he could consult with his lawyer and that they had allowed him to use the telephone and left the office. Despite several attempts, Mr. Steinberger said, he was unable to reach his lawyer, and Mr. Weiss and Mr. Cummings knocked on the door of the office and demanded that he make a decision, he said. When he said he needed more time, they read him a letter informing him of his dismissal.
"At the direction of Commissioner Riccio, I am writing to advise you that your services as Deputy Commissioner of Bridges will be terminated as of 5 P.M. today," stated the letter, which was signed by Mark Barron, the Transportation Department's personnel director.
A native New Yorker, Mr. Steinberger joined the Transportation Department as an analyst after graduating with a degree in industrial engineering from the Columbia University School of Engineering. He held several management positions in the department's analysis division and became a Assistant Commissioner for Budget Management in 1988. In 1990, he was appointed Deputy Commssioner for Bridges.
Mr. Steinberger is enrolled in the M.B.A. program for executives at the Wharton School of Economics and said he expected to receive his M.B.A. in the spring.

GRAPHIC: Photo: David Steinberger, who was dismissed yesterday as Deputy Transportation Commissioner. (The New York Times)
