HEADLINE: Religion Notes

BYLINE: By Ari L. Goldman

 BODY:

In Religion We Trust
Americans have far more faith in religion than politics as a vehicle for solving community problems, a new Gallup poll has found.
The survey, conducted in early November, asked 1,025 adults around the country to rate the ability of various institutions to act effectively on the local level. Churches, synagogues and other religious organizations headed the list, with 57 percent; political parties were at the bottom, with about 15 percent.
In between, in descending order of confidence expressed, were volunteer groups, schools, the local news media, local business, local government, state government, the Federal Government and national business.
The survey, conducted by telephone Nov. 6-9, had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points. Its results appeared in the December newsletter of the Princeton Religion Center, an affiliate of the Gallup organization in Princeton, N.J.
Women were more inclined than men to place their trust in religious institutions (65 percent to 48 percent), and adults under the age of 30 less inclined than those over 30 (52 percent to 60 percent).
At the same time, young people tended to show higher confidence than their elders in all other institutions listed in the survey.
"This could suggest that the initial impulse of people when they are young is to seek solutions from secular institutions," the report said, "but later in life they can be expected to turn more to the church to channel their voluntary instincts to serve the community."
 
A Surfeit of Reaction
A weekly column by the Rev. Richard P. McBrien, a liberal theologian at the University of Notre Dame who has frequently challenged the Vatican on various issues, has been dropped by The Brooklyn Tablet, the newspaper of the Roman Catholic diocese that comprises Brooklyn and Queens.
Ed Wilkinson, editor of The Tablet, said he had stopped running the nationally syndicated column because Bishop Thomas V. Daily of Brooklyn, who heads the diocese and is the publisher of The Tablet, "didn't want it in the paper anymore."
Mr. Wilkinson said Bishop Daily had complained that Father McBrien "shows too much disrespect for the Holy Father." The Bishop also discontinued the McBrien column when he was head of his previous diocese, in Palm Beach, Fla.
In November, when controversy over the McBrien column first appeared in the Brooklyn Diocese, Mr. Wilkinson said that he might not always agree with what Father McBrien had to say but noted that the theologian "gets a lot of reaction."
Asked about that comment yesterday, Mr. Wilkinson said, "I guess he got too much reaction."
A spokesman for Bishop Daily said the cleric was out of the country and unavailable for comment.
In his most recent column, which Tablet readers never saw, Father McBrien had a "wish list" that included this: "Wouldn't it be wonderful if in 1991 Catholic newspaper editors and publishers were to recognize that the Church's capacity to teach with credibility is harmed, not helped, by the suppression of opinion columns with which they are personally uncomfortable?"
 
Jews Reach Out
In an effort to attract young people, the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, which comprises 800 Reform synagogues, has announced a plan to reduce or eliminate synagogue dues for young, unaffiliated Jews.
In making the announcement earlier this week, Rabbi Alexander M. Schindler, the president of the organization, said the unaffiliated "are the fastest growing group in the American Jewish community." He cited statistics showing that more than 50 percent of the nation's 5.8 million Jews do not belong to synagogues or temples.
Many synagogues charge from $500 to $1,000 a year in dues, which usually includes sanctuary seats for the High Holy Days of Rosh ha-Shanah and Yom Kippur. Under the new plan, unaffiliated Jews from 22 to 30 years of age would be issued "privilege cards" that would enable them to join a Reform congregation at little or no cost for up to two years. In addition, college students would be issued "access cards" granting them free seats for High Holy Day services and other congregational events.
Rabbi Jerome Epstein, executive vice president of United Synagogue, said his group, which represents Conservative congregations, tried a similar program of free and reduced-cost membership 20 years ago.
"It didn't work," Rabbi Epstein said. "The congregations brought people in but didn't do anything to engage them in synagogue life."
Still, he said, he would carefully watch the Reform program, "Just because it didn't work then doesn't mean it won't work now," he said.

HEADLINE: Dow Up 2.73 Points After a Slow Session

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stocks edged ahead yesterday for their second consecutive gain, but activity continued to be extremely light.
Practically all of the gain in the Dow Jones industrial average came from Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, the producer of Scotch tape, which rose 2, to 81 5/8. It said it had invested in Forstmann Little & Company, the leveraged buyout firm. 
 Many traders headed for home shortly after noon as a big snowstorm moved into the New York area. Activity had been sluggish anyway as traders hesitated to act before today's talks in Baghdad between Javier Perez de Cuellar, the Secretary General of the United Nations, and President Saddam Hussein of Iraq.
 
 'A Little Bit' Positive
 "I thought it was a surprisingly good day, given the lack of activity and the apprehension," said Laszlo Birinyi, president of the research firm of Birinyi Associates. "I wouldn't have been surprised if the market had dropped 20 points, given the apparent stalemate in the Middle East. And the fact that the market came back on a Friday afternoon when a lot of people were leaving early was a little bit of a positive sign."
Most of those active in the market yesterday were day traders -- people who buy in the morning and sell before the day ends to avoid exposure in the event of some unforeseen development over the weekend.
The Dow, which rose 28.46 points on Thursday, tacked on 2.73 more yesterday, to bring the blue-chip index to 2,501.49. It was only the second advance in the Dow this year, after six straight declines. The Dow lost 64.60 points for the week.
Activity slid to 123.1 million shares, from 124.5 million the day before.
 
 2 Crucial Factors
 The crisis in the Middle East and the price of crude oil have practically replaced economic developments in shaping the thinking of investors. Traders contended that yesterday's report on the Producer Price Index -- showing that wholesale prices dropped six-tenths of 1 percent in December, more than economists had expected -- should have pushed bond prices higher.
They argued that with inflation subsiding, as the December figures showed, the Federal Reserve might more readily cut interest rates without fear of overheating the economy. But bonds fell, followed by stocks, although both came back a little toward the end of the day, with the Dow closing at a slight gain and bonds showing a small loss.
In one of the day's biggest moves, Motorola headed the Big Board active list, falling 2 3/4, to 47 3/4, with 2.8 million shares changing hands. Thomas Kurlak, a Merrill Lynch analyst, downgraded the stock and cut his earnings estimate in anticipation of weaker cellular phone business. Motorola fell to a new low of 47 before bouncing back.
 
 Oil-Service Stocks Fall
 Baker Hughes slid 1 1/4, to 21 5/8, on 2.5 million shares after the oil-service company said the Justice Department had subpoenaed it and unidentified others for price data. The stock reached a new low of 20 3/4 yesterday before recovering.
Dresser Industries, saying it had been subpoenaed for information on drill-bit prices but had no indication it was the target of an investigation, rose 1/4, to 19 3/8.
Among other active stocks in the oil-service group, Schlumberger fell 1/2, to 51 1/2; Halliburton was off 3/8, to 41 1/8, and McDermott International was down 3/8, to 21 3/4. Rowan, which hit a new low during the day of 9, ended down 3/8, to 9 1/8, on 1.1 million shares.
Household International, which owns Household Finance, rose 1 3/8, to 30, after forecasting record earnings for 1990 and 1991.

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Fell Last Month

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11

 BODY:
Reflecting a sharp decline in energy prices and the inflation-dampening effects of recession, prices paid to American producers fell six-tenths of 1 percent in December, the first decline since April, the Labor Department reported today.
The drop, also the biggest since mid-1986, pulled the advance for the year in the Producer Price Index for Finished Goods back to 5.6 percent -- or 3.2 percent when the gyrating energy component is excluded. 
 Today's report, which was somewhat better than most economists had been expecting, benefited from the first decline in oil prices since June and the first drop in food since September. But it also underscored the difficulty faced by producers seeking to raise prices in a slumping economy.
 
 'Weak Demand'
 "There's very weak demand out there, and companies are finding it hard to pass along price hikes," said Micheal W. Casey, an economist at Maria Ramirez Capital Consultants. "The economy's pretty clearly in recession."
"The producer price figures confirm what our members, the wholesaler-distributors who pay these prices, are telling us," said Ron Schreibman, vice president of the National Association of Wholesaler-Distributors. "The economy is too weak to sustain such broad-based price increases."
While the overall finished goods index was down last month, the core inflation for the Producer Price Index, which excludes food and energy, was up, but just three-tenths of 1 percent for the month and 3.5 percent for 1990, a performance that analysts said should reassure the Federal Reserve as it considers further cuts in interest rates to arrest the economy's decline.
 
Little Inflation Pressure Seen
 In its inflation report, the Department also said that prices at the intermediate and crude stages of production fell last month, by nine-tenths of 1 percent and 5.4 percent, respectively. This suggested little inflation pressure ahead for the finished-goods index, which tallies prices of those goods, like a dress, that are ready for sale to the final business user or consumer.
Comparable intermediate and crude items would be a bolt of cloth and a bale of cotton.
For all of 1990, the 5.6 percent increase in the finished goods index compared with 4.9 percent for 1989 and was the highest since 1981's 7.1 percent jump. Intermediate goods climbed 4.3 percent last year, nearly twice as much as in 1989, but crude goods' rise of 6 percent was down from 1989's 7.1 percent.
The small rise last month in core inflation was mainly attributed to automobiles and tobacco. But analysts observed that cars, selling slowly these days, were an unlikely source of sustained price increases. In tobacco, soaring exports have been a big factor in driving prices up.
On the other hand, the producer price indexes do not include imported goods, which are being made relatively more expensive here by the dollar's weakness in world currency markets.
December's Consumer Price Index, which includes imports and far more services than the Producer Price Index, is to be published on Wednesday. Prices at the producer level generally feed through to the consumer with a lag of several months. The consumer prices report for December, is expected to show a modest increase of perhaps two-tenths of a percent.
The six-tenths of 1 percent decline in December's finished-goods index -- which followed four months of increases averaging more than 1 percent -- had little effect on the markets. This, analysts said, was because rumors of a favorable report had prompted bond buying on Thursday, depressing interest rates then.
Finished energy goods tumbled 4.8 percent, after changing negligibly in November and rocketing 34.1 percent in the August-October period, which occurred before the lost Persian Gulf production was fully replaced.
 
Vegetable Prices Drop
 The sharp downturn in food prices, was paced by fresh and dried vegetables, pork and roasted coffee. Processed turkeys dropped more than 15 percent and dairy products fell for the fourth straight month.
Tobacco rose four-tenths of 1 percent after a 3.7 percent November jump, and the increase for automobiles was halved, to nine-tenths of 1 percent. Women's apparel fell 1.1 percent, much more than in November, but increases accelerated for prescription drugs, cosmetics and light trucks and household appliances turned up after falling in November.
Finished capital equipment rose four-tenths of 1 percent, twice the November increase, the Labor Department also reported.
Among intermediate goods, energy dropped 5.5 percent while nondurable materials used in manufacturing turned down, by two-tenths of 1 percent, after three straight sizable advances. Durable manufacturing materials, which fell 1 percent in November, dropped another 1.2 percent last month.
In addition to petrochemicals, prices turned lower for paperboard, paint and fertilizer materials, and also fell for aluminum mill shapes, copper and brass mill shapes, primary lead and copper and aluminum extrusion billets.
In crude goods, energy materials dropped a record 10.7 percent, but foods and feeds fell just one-tenth of 1 percent compared with November's 1.7 percent drop. The price of fresh vegetables turned down, and increases for fresh fruit slowed, but the December survey was taken before the California freeze and thus the price effects of extensive crop damage will not show up until the January report.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Gorbachev Seeking a Way Out in Gulf

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11

 BODY:
President Mikhail S. Gorbachev set off a round of Soviet-American consultations today by offering President Bush new proposals about ending the Persian Gulf crisis. But the White House said Mr. Gorbachev presented "nothing that looks like a breakthrough."
After an unexpected 8 A.M. telephone call from Moscow, Mr. Bush told reporters that Mr. Gorbachev was "thinking innovatively" about how to get Iraq out of Kuwait without war. He met twice with Aleksandr Bessmertnykh, the Soviet Ambassador to Washington, during the day to discuss the Soviet President's proposals. 
 Mr. Bush and his aides refused to give details on Mr. Gorbachev's suggestions. But they suggested that they focused on finding a new way to offer President Saddam Hussein of Iraq some enticement to leave Kuwait without having that appear to be a step back from the United Nations' demand for a complete and unconditional withdrawal.
 
Little Hope Seen
 Administration officials said they were taking Mr. Gorbachev's suggestions seriously, but held out little hope that what the Soviet leader outlined was different enough from earlier attempts at a diplomatic solution that Moscow's ideas might signal real progress toward a peaceful settlement.
"There's nothing that looks like a breakthrough," said Marlin Fitzwater, Mr. Bush's spokesman, adding that the White House was anxious "not to get anyone's hopes up."
Mr. Gorbachev's telephone call provided an unexpected note of drama to a day that was devoted primarily to lining up Congressional backing for a resolution that would endorse Mr. Bush's policy in the Persian Gulf and give him authority to use force against Iraq if necessary.
Mr. Bush made the votes in the House and Senate a matter of personal loyalty, as well as national security, in meetings and telephone calls to wavering members of Congress, especially in the Senate, where the White House was most concerned about losing what it has increasingly come to see as a critical test of domestic political support.
Administration aides acknowledged that the White House had to scale back its hopes for a large margin of victory in the Senate as a number of key moderates opposed Mr. Bush's position, includin Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who chairs the Senate Armed Services Committee, and David L. Boren, the Oklahoma Democrat who heads the Select Committee on Intelligence.
 
'Twisted Our Arms'
 "Those moves really twisted our arms, since a lot of moderate Democrats fell in behind them,' said a senior Administration official. "Everyone feels that if we get a big margin in the House, any margin in the Senate is fine. We'll have made our point and the President will be free to do anything that he wants."
Senator Thad Cochran, Republican of Mississippi, said, "At one time, they were worried that a close vote like that would be a sign that we were sharply divided and send the wrong message to Saddam Hussein. But I think they've come around to thinking that a victory is a victory."
Just as the White House tried to put the best face on what promised to be at best a slim victory on the vote in the Senate, Administration officials also tried to keep control of the flurry of speculation prompted by Mr. Gorbachev's telephone call.
Mr. Bush himself stressed that he and Mr. Gorbachev were "in sync" on their policy toward the gulf. "They are absolutely convinced that Saddam Hussein should get out of Kuwait in total compliance with the U.N. resolutions" that demand Iraq's withdrawal by Jan. 15, Mr. Bush said.
He said that Mr. Gorbachev, who has argued at times that economic sanctions be given more time to work, did not make that case in the telephone call today. But he said the Soviet leader had mentioned "some ideas" about solving the crisis without war.
"We are leaving no stone unturned to try to find a peaceful solution of this question," Mr. Bush said.
Mr. Fitzwater told his daily news briefing that Mr. Gorbachev asked Mr. Bush to meet with Mr. Bessmertnykh. Later, he said the two had met twice and that the Soviet envoy "wanted to flesh out these ideas a bit more."
He said that the Administration has been expecting a flurry of diplomatic activity as the Jan. 15 deadline approaches.
"There are a lot of people with different ideas," he said, that focus mainly on how to approach the idea of holding an international conference, or how to deal with Iraq after a withdrawal, or about the future of Kuwait once its deposed government was restored.
"But basically, they're all within the same parameters of unconditionally requiring Saddam to pull out by Jan. 15," he said. "Within that parameter, it's hard to give any hope or credence to these ideas since Saddam has shown no interest in any number of formulations before."

HEADLINE: How Harsh Will the Recession Be? Most Experts Forecast a Mild One

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11

 BODY:
There is no dearth of intrepid economists who forecast that the recession will be brief and mild, as these things go. In fact, that is the predominant view of leading analysts. But economic predictions, which are inherently risky, are particularly hazardous now, with new cracks showing in the nation's financial structure and increasing fear of war in the Persian Gulf.
The conventional view of economic forecasters and the White House is that the worst is already over and that the economy will begin to recover in the spring or summer. 
 Morgan Stanley & Company's chief economist, John D. Paulus, espouses this view, and points to, among other things, a lack of a big inventory buildup. Unlike in most recessions, that means smaller piles of cars, appliances and clothing that need to be sold before companies order new merchandise and reorder supplies.
 
'Short and Shallow'
 He and others also noted a clear trend toward lower interest rates, which should help restore the consumer's ability to buy, and a general confidence in the economy. A decline in the prices paid to American producers in December, the first drop reported by the Government since April, should help keep the path clear for further cuts in rates. [Page 31.]
Looking at these and other factors, Mr. Paulus said, the recession is "likely to be short and shallow," which to him would be a 1.75 percent decline in the total output of goods and services from the peak of economic growth to the lowest point. If he and those who agree with him are right, this recession would be less than half as severe as those of 1981-82 and 1974-75, the worst in the postwar period.
On average, postwar recessions have lasted 11 months, during which the total output of goods and services fell about 2.25 percent from peaks to troughs.
But a substantial group of economists and business people are more pessimistic about the length and depth of this recession. They point to the extremely high debt of American families, businesses and governments and a financial and banking system more fragile than at any time since the 1930's.
There is time for either group to be right, depending on several factors.
For one thing, it is hard to forecast the recession's end when no one yet knows when it started. The best guess by non-Government economists is that it began between the Fourth of July and Halloween, though some say earlier. The National Bureau of Economic Research, charged with dating business cycles, has not made a formal decision, although it issued a statement last month that a recession probably began in the summer.
 
This One's Different
 More significant is that the cause of this recession, and thus its dominant features, seem markedly different from those of previous recessions. Typically, recessions in the last 45 years started out with rapid price inflation, tight money and high interest rates, followed by high inventories of unsold merchandise.
This time interest rates have been going down, spending has not dropped rapidly and businesses have reported relatively low inventories. A faster recovery from recession should result, theoretically.
Then there is the not-so-small matter of possible war in the Persian Gulf. If that happens, it creates more uncertainty not only about oil prices but also about the United States and world economies and about public and business psychology. The run-up in crude-oil prices after Iraq invaded Kuwait last August is tied to a loss of consumer confidence in the economy that many experts say pushed the tottering economy over the edge into a recession.
"It is very early and very difficult to tell how long and how severe this recession will be," said Victor Zarnowitz, speaking for himself as an economics professor at the University of Chicago and not as a member of the National Bureau of Economic Research. He said that in the last month, expectations have dropped sharply about the economy's performance in the fourth quarter of 1990. First estimates, due on Jan. 25, could show that the gross national product may have fallen as much as 4 percent at an annual rate, he said.
 
Net Worth Is Down
 The more pessimistic group of forecasters contends that this recession is more worrisome, perhaps substantially so, even without a war with Iraq.
These economists maintain that rather than well-controlled inventories and falling interest rates, what really distinguishes the early stages of this recession is that in many ways the net worth of individuals and corporations is declining because of a combination of high debts and lower values of property and other assets.
"This cycle differs from others in the postwar era," said M. Kathryn Eickhoff, a New York consultant who was formerly chief economist for the Office of Management and Budget, "by the amount of debt creation that preceded it and the extent to which falling prices of assets are a major factor." She contrasted the situation to the ebb and flow of cyclical economic forces like inventories.
"This is a balance sheet recession, Ms. Eickhoff said. "The others primarily affected the income statement."
She and others sharing her view say that a major factor is the decline in home prices and that the drop is just now hitting the Midwest as it has the Northeast and California. Given that big sections of the nation are just beginning to feel that particular pain, the confidence of millions of more consumers is expected to be undermined.
 
Real Estate Values Shrink
 "Families do not know what they're worth," said Roger M. Kubarych, a former Federal Reserve economist who now works for Henry Kaufman & Company. "People all over the country are selling houses for 75 percent of what they thought" they would get.
In some cases, especially in commercial real estate, values have plunged below the mortgage balance, threatening the lender as well as wiping out equity.
"We have built up a superstructure of financial claims that far exceeds the value of underlying real assets," said John E. Silvia, economist for Kemper Financial Services Inc. in Chicago. "The boom and excesses of the 1980's have been financial, not industrial, and the correction must also be financial," he said.
Others said it was troublesome that corporations have little cash on hand as well as shrinking profits, and use, on average, almost 60 percent of their earnings just to pay interest, about twice the proportion of a decade ago.
Looming behind the economic considerations is the possibility of a Middle East war, one that it is widely assumed would be short-lived and lead to a drop in oil prices and a stimulus for the economy.
But, Administration assurances to the contrary, there is no guarantee that oil from Saudi Arabia and other Persian Gulf sources would continue to flow without interruption and at low prices, even after a war ended.
Even if a prolonged Middle East conflict is avoided, many believe that anything other than a peaceful resolution of the crisis could be highly disruptive to the economy. "In the event of a war in the Persian Gulf," economists for Lloyds Bank say, "the price of oil could surge to $40 per barrel or higher, thereby obsoleting most economic forecasts for major industrial countries."
Still, if the length and severity of anything is harder to call than a recession, it is a war: At the beginning of the Civil War, President Lincoln was advised it would last no more than 90 days.

HEADLINE: Emergency Oil Release Plan Is Set

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Jan. 11

 BODY:
The International Energy Agency, a 21-nation group of oil-importing nations, adopted an emergency plan today to bolster oil supplies by releasing two million barrels a day from government reserves if war begins in the Persian Gulf.
The decision -- the first time the Paris-based agency has adopted an emergency contingency plan -- was welcomed by petroleum experts, who said it would help to moderate prices and keep supply and demand in balance in the event of a gulf war. 
 Although the 2 million barrels represent a small fraction of the 54 million barrels consumed worldwide each day, oil analysts said the emergency plan would help calm oil markets if war erupted. Agency officials declined to disclose how much each member country would contribute.
 
 'Will Reassure Markets'
 "It's a very good plan because it will reassure the markets that there is an additional availability," said Robert Mabro, director of the Oxford Institute for Energy Studies in England. "It's bound to have a dampening effect on prices."
He added that the two million barrels a day to be released from emergency government reserves "is enough at this stage, but they might have to do more later on."
Under the decision, the agency's executive director, Helga Steeg, would order the plan into effect as soon as she learned that war had broken out. Under the plan, which seeks to act "in anticipation of any possible temporary shortfall in oil supplies," the additional oil would become available 15 days after Dr. Steeg activated the plan.
The plan also calls for freeing an additional 500,000 barrels a day by putting conservation measures in place, having power plants switch from oil to other fuels, and using the little spare oil production capacity left in the world.
 
 Established After Embargo
 Oil-importing nations set up the International Energy Agency in 1974 after Arab nations embargoed oil shipments to the United States. The agency -- which includes the United States, Japan and most Western European nations -- aims to coordinate a response to any oil-supply emergency, encourage conservation and promote l long-term balance in splply and demand.
According to the agency, oil stocks in the industrialized Western nations are at a comfortable level of 3.6 billion barrels.
Industry officials said they could only guess to what extent supplies would be impaired by war. Some say the effect will be minimal, while others fear there could be serious disruptions if Iraq manages to destroy Saudi oilfields or if the war seriously disrupts shipping in the gulf.
"No one knows what the shortfall will be," Dr. Steeg said.
 
 Supplies Exceed Demand
 The agency's decision comes at a time when oil supplies slightly exceed demand despite the embargo on Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil. When Iraq invaded Kuwait in August, many oil experts predicted a serious shortfall because of the loss of 4 million barrels a day. The current surplus in supply resulted from a big increase of Saudi output and a decline in consumption resulting from higher prices and an economic slowdown.
"The market is very well supplied right now," said Peter Bogin, an oil analyst in the Paris office of Cambridge Energy Research Associates. "If you release another two milion barrels a day, your objective isn't to keep the market supplied. Your objective is to moderate the price. That represents a shift in attitude for the I.E.A."
The agency has been criticized for being slow to draw down emergency government reserves. After Iraq invaded Kuwait, many industry analysts said it should have approved the release of emergency reserves to prevent oil prices from soaring.
Agency officials have long said that it is not their business to manipulate the world's oil prices, but to insure that oil needs are met.

HEADLINE: Seidman Is Hopeful on Boston Bank

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Jan. 11

 BODY:
L. William Seidman said today that he hoped the Bank of New England would be sold in three to four months and added that several more potential buyers had emerged.
In a quick visit to the scene of the action, Mr. Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, declined to identify the possible buyers, but did say that about a half-dozen large and responsible organizations had expressed interest. So far, BankAmerica of San Francisco and Banc One of Columbus, Ohio, have said they are considering an acquisition of Bank of New England, the region's third-largest bank, which is now in the hands of Federal regulators. 
 The F.D.I.C. will most likely set a schedule requiring all bidders to submit their offers within two or three months and would like to select a buyer within a month after that, Mr. Seidman told reporters at a breakfast news conference here. He said he wanted to make the bidding process "as short as possible to move the bank into private hands as soon as possible."
The Bank of New England was seized Sunday in a rescue that is likely to cost the Federal insurance fund up to $2.3 billion, making it one of the costliest bailouts ever. Federal officials acted just days after the bank, which has operations in Massachusetts, Connecticut and Maine, said it expected a huge loss that would leave it unable to absorb future losses and depositors reacted by quickly withdrawing about $1 billion. The deposit drain ended when regulators stepped in to take control and assured that all bank deposits would be protected, even those that exceeded $100,000, the amount guaranteed by the bank insurance fund.
Mr. Seidman also met yesterday with Bank of New England executives and assured them that the management team put in place shortly before the bank failed would stay on during the transition period. He also met with executives of the much smaller Capitol Bank and Trust Company, a Medford, Mass. bank that failed last month, as well as F.D.I.C. employees.
In addition, Mr. Seidman met with the Governors of the New England states in a lunch meeting at the Massachusetts State House. The meeting was at the invitation of Gov. William Weld of Massachusetts, but included the region's five other Governors.
The purpose of the meeting was strictly informational, Mr. Seidman said.
"My message to the Governors is that we are interested in the stability of the financial system and credit availability in your area," Mr. Seidman said. At the State House lunch, the group discussed the region's credit squeeze and the collapse of several regional banks, a spokesman for Governor Weld said. At that meeting, Mr. Seidman also repeated a proposal he presented to Congress earlier this week to set up a fund that would make investments in troubled banks to avert any capital and liquidity problems.
The Governor's spokesman said Mr. Seidman was praised by the Governors for his agency's quick action in taking over the Bank of New England. "The was a sense of disturbance on Saturday and then calm on Monday once the regulators stepped in," said Jordan St. John, the spokesman.
In questioning, Mr. Seidman declined to identify whether any other regional banks would need Federal assistance. Banks in New England have been hard hit by a real estate recession that follows several years of lending to risky real estate development projects. In addition, an overall reluctance by any investors to back projects in this region has made it difficult for banks to restructure and recapitalize troubled real estate portoflios.
"We want to restore confidence to this area as a whole and to provide capital to banks that are capital-short," Mr. Seidman said. This plan, which is being discussed in Washington, would draw capital from the private sector as well as from increased assessments on banks in the Federal insurance fund. This money would be used to make capital infusion into shaky banks.

GRAPHIC: Photo: L. William Seidman, left, the chairman of the F.D.I.C., and Lawrence K. Fish, the chairman of the Bank of New England, held a breakfast news conference yesterday in Boston to discuss the future of the ailing bank. (Associated Press) (pg. 33)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
A brief, mild recession? That's the predominant view, but making economic predictions seems particularly hazardous these days. The conventional wisdom, subscribed to by the White House, is that the worst is over, and numbers abound to support that view. But pessimists point to the extremely high debt of American families, businesses and governments and a banking system more fragile than at any time since the 1930's. [Page 1.]
Prices paid to American producers fell 0.6 percent in December, the first decline since April, the Labor Department reported. The decline, the biggest since 1986, pulled the advance for the year back to 5.6 percent, or 3.2 percent when the gyrating energy component is excluded. [31.]
Seidman said he hoped the Bank of New England would be sold in three to four months. On a visit to the scene of the action in Boston, he added that several more potential buyers had emerged. [31.]
No single statistic can foretell which banks will fail, but from the welter of financial reports banks issue, government and private analysts can glean strong hints about which are the shakiest. While most bank failures involve small institutions, analysts say some large banks are in serious trouble. [31.]
U.S. oil consumption fell in 1990, the first year-to-year drop in seven years, driven by war fears, recession and the weather, the American Petroleum Institute said. Domestic oil production fell to its lowest level since 1961. [31.]
The International Energy Agency adopted an emergency plan to bolster oil supplies by releasing two million barrels a day from government reserves if war begins in the Persian Gulf. [31.]
A judge dismissed 12 fraud counts against Keating and three Lincoln associates, citing technical problems with amended charges filed by the prosecution, but left 34 counts intact. [33.]
 
Companies
The talk of the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas has been the increasingly likely war between Sony's and Philips' versions of the new generation of cassette recorder. [31.]
Pan Am got access to $50 million of the $150 million loan that was authorized by a bankruptcy judge. The money, from a bridge loan arranged by Bankers Trust and United Airlines, is aimed at keeping Pan Am flying until it can complete the sale of its London routes to United. [32.]
A judge shaved $36 million off Polaroid's award in its patent infringement suit against Kodak. The original award had been $909.4 million, considerably less than the $1.5 billion to $2 billion many analysts had expected. [33.]
 
 Markets
Stocks edged ahead for their second straight gain, but activity continued to be extremely light. The Dow rose 2.73 points, to 2,501.49, but for the week it lost 64.60. [34.]
A rally late in the day helped long-term Treasury securities erase a good part of their earlier losses. [34.]
The dollar finished mixed in subdued trading, as investors awaited Mideast developments. Gold prices advanced. [40.]
Oil prices fell in slow action as traders drew their breath and waited for Persian Gulf news. Crude fell 42 cents, to $27.29. The week's gain was $2.39. [40.]
 
 Today's Columns
Many loyal employees who hold company stock have seen their nest eggs cracked in bankruptcies. Your Money. [32.]
A minute electrical jolt takes the itch out of bug bites. The battery-powered device that delivers the jolt was developed by a Minneapolis inventor. Patents. [32.]

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Excerpts From Gulf Resolutions Before Congress

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from resolutions on the Persian Gulf before Congress:
 
Mitchell-Nunn
Proposed by Senators George J. Mitchell, Democrat of Maine, and Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia.
 That:
(a) The Congress is firmly committed to reversing Iraq's brutal and illegal occupation of Kuwait.
(b) The Congress authorizes the use of American military force to enforce the United Nations economic embargo against Iraq to defend Saudi Arabia from direct Iraqi attack and to protect American forces in the region.
(c) The Congress believes that continued application of international sanctions and diplomatic efforts to pressure Iraq to leave Kuwait is the wisest course at this time and should be sustained, but does not rule out declaring war or authorizing the use of force at a later time should that be necessary to achieve the goal of forcing Iraqi troops from Kuwait.
(d) The Congress pledges its full and continued support for sustaining the policy of increasing economic and diplomatic pressure against Iraq, for maintaining our military options, and for efforts to increase the military and financial contributions made by allied nations.
(e) The Constitution of the United States vests all power to declare war in the Congress of the United States. Congress will expeditiously consider any future Presidential request for a declaration of war or for authority to use military force against Iraq.
 
Hamilton-Gephardt
Proposed by Representatives Lee H. Hamilton, Democrat of Indiana, and Richard A. Gephardt, Democrat of Missouri.
That:
(a) The Congress is firmly committed to reversing Iraq's brutal and illegal occupation of Kuwait.
(b) The Congress authorizes continued use of American military force to enforce the United Nations economic embargo against Iraq, to defend Saudi Arabia from direct Iraqi attack, and to protect American forces in the region.
(c) The Congress believes that continued application of international sanctions and diplomatic efforts to pressure Iraq to leave Kuwait is the wisest course at this time and should be sustained.
(d) The Congress pledges its full and continued support for sustaining the policy of increasing economic and diplomatic pressure against Iraq, for maintaining our military options, and for efforts to increase the military and financial contributions made by allied nations.
 
Michel-Solarz-Warner
Proposed by Representatives Stephen J. Solarz, Democrat of Brooklyn, and Robert H. Michel, Republican of Illinois. John W. Warner, Republican of Virginia, proposed the resolution in the Senate .
The President is authorized, subject to subsection (b), to use United States Armed Forces pursuant to United Nations Security Council Resolution 678 (1990) in order to achieve implementation of Security Council Resolutions 660, 661, 662, 664, 665, 666, 667, 669, 670, 674, and 677.
. . . Before exercising the authority granted in subsection (a), the President shall make available to the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the President pro tempore of the Senate his determination that:
(a) The United States has used all appropriate diplomatic and other peaceful means to obtain compliance by Iraq with the United Nations Security Council resolutions cited in subsection (a); and
(b) That those efforts have not been and would not be successful in obtaining such compliance.
 War Powers Resolution requirements:
(1) Specific statutory authorization. Consistent with section 8 (a) (1) of the War Powers Resolution, the Congress declares that this section is intended to constitute specific statutory authorization within the meaning of section 5 (b) of the War Powers Resolution.
(2) Applicability of other requirements. Nothing in this resolution supersedes any requirement of the War Powers Resolution.
At lease once every 60 days, the President shall submit to the Congress a summary on the status of efforts to obtain compliance by Iraq with the resolutions adopted by the United Nations Security Council in response to Iraq's aggression.
 
Bennett-Durbin
Proposed by Representatives Charles E. Bennett, Democrat of Florida, and Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois.
The Congress finds that the Constitution of the United States vests all power to declare war in the Congress of the United States. Any offensive action taken against Iraq must be explicitly approved by the Congress of the United States before such action may be initiated.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: BAKER WARNS OF FAST STRIKE IF KUWAIT DEADLINE PASSES: SUPPORT IN CONGRESS IS SEEN;
Slim Senate Majority Is Expected But House Backing Appears Solid

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11

 BODY:
After a second day of sober debate, Congress appears ready to vote over the weekend to give President Bush the authority to go to war against Iraq.
A solid margin of support is expected in the House, where votes are scheduled by early Saturday afternoon, but the outlook in the Senate is for only a bare victory. Voting there is scheduled to be held on Saturday as well. 
 By nightfall, more than 200 members of Congress had taken the floor to speak either in favor of giving Mr. Bush the authority to attack if Iraq has not withdrawn from Kuwait by Tuesday or of continued reliance on economic sanctions as the better policy.
 
'The Voices of Democracy'
 A key speech favoring the sanctions approach was delivered by Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia, chairman of the Armed Services Committee, whose influential opposition to using force has now appeared to swing votes.
But he said he thought his side would lose and concluded by warning Iraq: "These are the voices of democracy. Don't misread this debate. If war occurs, the constitutional and policy debates will be suspended, and Congress will provide the American troops whatever they need to prevail. There will be no cutoff of funds for our troops while they engage your forces on the field of battle." [Sampling from speeches and excerpts from resolutions, pages 6 and 7.]
Mr. Bush, lobbying about 100 House members at a White House breakfast, said that "the last, best chance for Saddam Hussein to get the message is in your hands," said Marlin Fitzwater, his spokesman.
The debate also had moments of intense emotion. Representative Craig Thomas, Republican of Wyoming, insisted that for weeks "Congress has dodged this important vote." He said, "The President needs our support -- 400,000 servicemen need our support."
But Representative Andrew Jacobs Jr., Democrat of Indiana, said: "Must we all believe that we're playing Rambo, that we're playing war games here? It's forever. It's total war for the kid who gets blown away."
There was also one brief angry moment in the Senate gallery when about a dozen demonstrators interrupted Mr. Nunn's speech to shout antiwar slogans like "No Blood for Oil!" and "No War for Bush!"
Capitol policemen dragged them from the gallery and 11 were arrested and charged with disruption of Congress. Senator Donald W. Riegle, Democrat of Michigan, said, "While I condemn that kind of outburst, it is a sign of things to come."
 
2 Competing Resolutions
 Aside from the speeches, in which one lawmaker after another -- more than 200 by nightfall -- announced his or her intentions, most of the activity went on behind closed Senate doors. Republicans, and a few Democrats, including Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut, worked hard at lining up votes to authorize Mr. Bush to use military force.
Only when it appeared that they had assembled a majority did they introduce their proposal in the Senate, copying it word for word from the House measure offered on Thursday that cited Iraq's offenses in Kuwait and warned that its "chemical, biological and nuclear weapons and ballistic missile programs" threatened world peace.
But even then, the President's supporters had appeared to line up nothing close to the 60 votes Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, had forecast on Sunday.
With the issue down to two competing resolutions, one favoring force in accordance with the United Nations resolution demanding an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait by Jan. 15 and the other calling for continued reliance on sanctions but promising fast action if the President again asked for the use of force, it appeared that Mr. Bush had 51 to 53 senators prepared to authorize force.
 
99 Senators Expected to Vote
 Of the 44 Republicans in the Senate, only the votes of Senators Mark O. Hatfield of Oregon and Charles E. Grassley of Iowa were in doubt. Neither has publicly committed either way.
But even if both deserted Mr. Bush, Democratic support would more than make up the difference. In addition to Mr. Lieberman, who announced his decision by saying "Our final, last chance for a truly peaceful end to this crisis is to send a clear, unequivocal message to Saddam Hussein," these eight Democrats said today that they would support using force: Senators John B. Breaux of Louisiana, Richard H. Bryan of Nevada, Bob Graham of Florida, Howell Heflin of Alabama, J. Bennett Johnston of Louisiana, Harry Reid of Nevada, Charles S. Robb of Virginia and Richard C. Shelby of Alabama.
Senator Alan Cranston, Democrat of California, is undergoing cancer treatments and will not be here to vote but the other 99 senators are expected to vote.
In the House, there will be votes on three resolutions -- a declaration asserting Congress's sole power to declare war and a pair of resolutions, like those in the Senate, favoring continued reliance on sanctions and authorizing the use of force.
 
Bush's Spurned Efforts
 Congressmen on both sides of the issue predicted first an easy victory for the resolution asserting congressional prerogatives, and then a victory by 230 to 240 votes of the 435 in the House for the side urging the authorization of the use of military force in the Persian Gulf.
Today's House debate focused repeatedly on the issue of how long economic sanctions and diplomacy should be tried as a lever to force Iraq from Kuwait. Representative William S. Broomfield, the senior Republican on the Foreign Affairs Committee, argued that "a look at the record shows that the President has done all he can to find a peaceful solution."
He said President Saddam Hussein of Iraq had spurned Mr. Bush's efforts, and, "It is now time for Congress to make the Iraqi leader understand that America stands behind the President, and that his recent letter was not an idle threat but a credible warning."
But Representative Gerry E. Studds, Democrat of Massachusetts, argued: "Our choice today is whether to persevere on the path of patience and determination and peace or to stray from that path into the wilderness of war. Whether to walk together the extra mile or the extra two miles in pursuit of a bloodless resolution to this crisis or to declare war and fight war and count the bodies and bury the bodies and never know whether a single American soldier really had to die."
 
Major Statement by Nunn
 Thomas J. Bliley Jr., Republican of Virginia, argued that sanctions would fall away if the resolution authorizing force was defeated, "for in the eyes of the world, Saddam will have won." Then, he said, "the road to Baghdad will be jammed with diplomats cutting a deal, supplying him with whatever he needs."
Mr. Nunn's speech was a major statement in the long Senate day. He argued that the nation too often identified its foreign interests as vital, without thinking through the consequences.
"We throw around the word 'vital' very carelessly," he said. "When politicians declare an interest to be vital, our men and women in uniform are expected to put their lives at risk to defend that interest."
He argued that "on balance there is a reasonable expectation that continued economic sanctions backed up by the threat of military force and international isolation can bring about Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait."
 
'A Succession of Dictators'
 "I believe that the risk associated with continued emphasis on sanctions are considerably less than the very real risk associated with war and, most importantly, the aftermath of war in a very volatile region of the world," he continued.
Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, said: "It is clear to me that if we fail to act there will be inevitably a succession of dictators, of Saddam Husseins, of which around the globe there is an abundance. Those dictators will see a green light, a green light or aggression, a green light for annexation of its weaker neigbors."
Senator Bryan, explaining his decision, said other countries had not helped enough with troops or money, but he said it was essential to grant Mr. Bush's request for authority to use military force against Iraq.
"We should not risk the sending of anything less than a unified signal to Saddam Hussein," he said. "The dictator's ability to miscalculate is our greatest danger."
Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts said: "War is not the only option left. Our policy in the Persian Gulf is not broken, and it cannot be fixed by war. There is still time to save the President from himself -- and save thousands of American soldiers in the Persian Gulf from dying in the desert in a war whose cruelty will be exceeded only by the lack of any rational necessity for waging it."

HEADLINE: The Search for a Safer Humidifier

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER

 BODY:
Health concerns about humidifiers have led several manufacturers to refine older technologies to try to reduce the bacteria and mineral dust they discharge.
The newest design, known as a "wicking" humidifier, updates a process in use for at least 20 years: the evaporation of water to produce a vapor. "Warm mist" humidifiers are being refined, too; they first boil water and then mix the steam with cool air to create a mist. 
 In recent years, Government studies have found that harmful bacteria and molds multiply in the water tanks of humidifiers and are spewed into the air. The studies have raised the possibility that some humidifiers also emit toxic substances like lead and asbestos if they are present in the water that goes into the tank.
Ultrasonic humidifiers, whose popularity peaked in 1987, became a particular focus of public-health concerns, and their sales have suffered. The newer humidifiers represent efforts by manufacturers to restore consumer confidence.
"I expect that the warm-mist market will grow, and the ultrasonic market will diminish," said Brett Gannon, the vice president of finance at Bionaire, a company in Lachine, Quebec, that makes humidifiers and other appliances. Mr. Gannon said Bionaire expects sales of its warm-mist units to surpass those of its ultrasonic models this year.
 
Sound, Mist and Heat
 There are three kinds of humidifiers besides evaporative and warm-mist units: ultrasonic, impeller or cool-mist, and steam. Ultrasonic devices use high-frequency sound to break up water into mist. Cool-mist units do the same thing mechanically. And steam units, as their name implies, make steam by boiling water.
A study completed in 1989 at the Oak Ridge (Tenn.) National Laboratories found that ultrasonic and cool-mist units released the most bacteria, while warm-mist units released insignificant amounts. The study also found that cool-mist units released significant levels of mold.
Some scientists maintain that a strain of bacteria that can be released by humidifiers can cause a respiratory disease similar to pneumonia and that molds from humidifiers can produce allergic reactions.
The new wicking humidifiers are supposed to reduce bacteria, molds and mineral dust, their makers say. In older evaporative models, a belt of sponges passes through water; air is blown across the sponges to dry them and release water vapor. In the newer models, water is drawn up through a paper wick that is supposed to trap bacteria and other contaminants. This wick can be replaced.
"The big problem with the older units was that they were difficult to clean," said Michael Berger, a national sales manager for the Bemis Manufacturing Company in Sheboygan Falls, Wis. Bemis sells wicking humidifiers, as do Sears and the Emerson Electric Company.
The suggested retail prices for Bemis table-top units are $39.95 to $59.95, with larger console-size units costing $79 to $119, Mr. Berger said. Gordon Jones, a Sears spokeman, said console models retail for $89 to $149. Bionaire said its warm-mist humidifers retail for $100 to $165.
Eva Lehman, a toxicologist at the Federal Consumer Product Safety Commission, said her agency had not studied wicking humidifiers. But she said that evaporative units generally discharge insignificant levels of bacteria. "They emit a fine mist which does not seem to pick up a lot of microbials," she said.
 
Cutting Mineral Dust
 Mineral dust is not believed to reach dangerous levels in vapor from steam, evaporative or warm-mist humidifiers, several health experts said. To reduce mineral-dust emissions from ultrasonic humidifiers, several makers sell demineralization cartridges with their units or offer them as accessories.
There is still some scientific debate over the medical value of humidifiers. But regardless of a humidifier's design, all health authorities urge that it be kept scrupulously clean. And those who maintain that humidifiers can be of value emphasize that they must be properly maintained.
"If there is mold growing in a reservoir, an asthmatic will do himself more harm than good," said Dr. Norman H. Edelman, a professor of pulmonary medicine at the Robert Wood Johnson Medical School in New Brunswick, N.J.
In winter, the relative humidity in a home should be kept at 30 to 50 percent. A level of about 60 percent will lead to indoor condensation and contribute to the growth of mold and bacteria. Hygrometers, which measure indoor humidity, can be bought at many hardware stores.
 
1. SCRUB IT
2. SCRUB IT
 Don't use a humidifier unless you are prepared to take care of it. To reduce the chance of health hazards, the Federal Consumer Product Safety Commission recommends some precautions.
Change the water daily if possible, and clean the water tank vigorously, following the manufacturer's instructions. Consumer Reports recommends using a cleaning solution of an ounce of chlorine bleach to a pint of water; rinse thoroughly with fresh water.
Use distilled or demineralized water in the humidifier to reduce deposits and the release of mineral dust. Use demineralization cartridges or filters if supplied or recommended for your unit.
Drain and clean the tank before storing a humidifier, and dust the unit when taking it out of storage.

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
The Gulf: Postcards From the Edge

BYLINE: KARL E. MEYER

 BODY:
How does the looming showdown in the Persian Gulf look to worried neighbors in South Asia? In a month's travels through India, Pakistan and Nepal, a visiting American learns there is no consensus.
In New Delhi, members of the political elite urge concessions to Iraq to avert a war. In Islamabad, diplomats talk of a new alignment with fundamentalist Iran to contain Saddam Hussein and get badly needed oil at a discount -- and also to show that Pakistan is nobody's lapdog, especially not America's. 
 But in Nepal, a tiny Himalayan kingdom anxious about preserving its own independence from an overbearing India, it looks very different. Immediately on learning Kuwait's fate, Nepal denounced the aggressor and called for collective action against Iraq.
In India and Pakistan, newly installed leaders preside over shaky Governments and foundering economies. And Nepal is about to hold its first multiparty elections in 30 years. Thus self-interest and concern with immediate survival has sent politicians scrambling for lifeboats.
No longer so self-righteous, Indians speak about the costs of a military conflagration. Their overriding worry is that soaring oil prices may wreck hopes for growth in an energy-poor country coping with communal violence.
"The countries most affected by the gulf crisis have been left to fend for themselves," laments The Telegraph of Calcutta. "The only response has come from the International Monetary Fund, but what it is offering is inadequate. India, for instance, will get less than $500 million from the I.M.F., whereas the additional oil burden could be to the tune of $3 to $4 billion."
Indians desperately search for reassuring omens. A senior diplomat who recently visited Baghdad cites the looting of Kuwait as hopeful evidence that Saddam Hussein knows he must yield up his conquests -- otherwise why plunder what Iraq claims it owns? Adding urgency to pleas for a settlement is anxiety about Indian workers trapped in gulf countries, and fear of a backlash among millions of Muslims in India should war erupt.
Pakistan has taken a firmer line against Iraq, even sending a token military force to Saudi Arabia. But nationalism has surged since the suspension in November of U.S. aid to discourage Pakistan's nuclear arms quest. Politicians talk of self-sufficiency, and the press bristles with anti-Americanism. Some commentators even accuse the U.S. of engineering the gulf crisis, citing as evidence the most paranoid of forgeries, the Protocols of Zion.
Estranged from its longtime friends in Washington, Islamabad now seeks friends in Iran and Turkey. A flurry of high-level visits is meant to cement a regional Islamic alliance as a bulwark against Iraq's radical threat. Yet no officials there can say who is in charge in Teheran, and the closer Pakistan moves to Iran, the more it risks angering its Arab benefactors, notably Saudi Arabia.
By contrast, there's nothing convoluted about Nepal's condemnation of Iraq. Independence is the lodestar in Katmandu, where few need reminding of India's absorption in 1975 of a neighboring kingdom, Sikkim. The world's smaller states are plainly united by a bond hardier than ideology, and thicker than oil.

HEADLINE: Flunking World Order 101

BYLINE: By Richard H. Ullman; Richard H. Ullman, professor of international affairs at Princeton University, is author of the forthcoming "Securing Europe."

DATELINE: PRINCETON, N.J.

 BODY:
Iraq's intransigence notwithstanding, George Bush is heading toward a C minus or worse in World Order 101, the newest elective course in the foreign policy curriculum.
A passing grade might be generous. It would be based on the President's declaration last August that using force to grab territory simply isn't acceptable, and his success in getting the U.N. to back his message with tough economic sanctions. 
 But Mr. Bush flunked the November midterm when he began to mass forces for a possible American invasion of Iraq. If he continues on his present course, he may well fail the final examination.
The buildup could lead to a failing grade for two reasons. First, it shows that the Administration's proclaimed new world order is remarkably like the old one: The United States still calls the tune and bears the burden. War will begin only if the President so decrees; most of the body bags coming home from the gulf will have Americans in them.
Second, the new order seems to be grounded in the threat of a massive offensive use of force when it should be based on the use of as little force as possible -- and only for defensive purposes.
Mr. Bush's course in world order includes a laboratory exercise: the blockade of Iraq. Not a drop of oil -- Iraq's only important cash crop -- has flowed out of that country. Flowing in are medicines and some foods, not the industrial materials needed to maintain the fighting strength of Iraq's armed forces and to run the modern part of its economy.
The blockade is a crucial experiment, an attempt to compel an aggressor to remove his troops and to repair the damage they have done, and to do so by the steady, measured use of coercive pressure but not -- unless Iraq attacks -- by the use of violence.
The President has declared that his patience with Iraq is wearing thin. But patience is just what is needed for this one or two or even three year experiment to succeed. If Mr. Bush decides to attack, the experiment will be ruined. The world will not learn whether strong economic sanctions, imposed by a nearly united international community, are sufficient to reverse an act of armed aggression.
The experiment matters. The crisis springs from a unique combination of oil, unprovoked aggression and the volatile Middle East. It is difficult to imagine any other circumstances that would lead an American President (let alone any other world leader) to send such a large force halfway around the globe. But it is not difficult -- if the present sanctions work -- to imagine the U.N. Security Council voting to impose a tight embargo against another future aggressor, say a Libyan attempt to take over Chad or a Serbian invasion of Croatia.
The ground rules of the new world order should be plain. The unilateral use of military power to change state borders, to seize economic resources and to right perceived wrongs is unacceptable. Governments that violate these rules will be punished. Punishment will take the form of economic pressure, applied internationally, that would be certain, severe, sustained and enforced -- pressure that would not work tomorrow or the next day, but would work eventually.
The Security Council resolution ordering Iraq to remove its troops from Kuwait by Jan. 15 only permits the use of force; it does not require it. With the hostages out of Iraq, Mr. Bush can justifiably claim that the military buildup has accomplished a vital purpose and he can afford to wait for the economic squeeze to work. But enforcing the blockade will not require the vast array of ships, aircraft and troops currently assembled in the gulf.
Saddam Hussein's rape of Kuwait built the coalition against him. There is no reason to think that, provided its forces on the scene are reduced to sustainable numbers, the coalition will not stay together. If it does, Saddam Hussein will be made to understand that any use of force to break the blockade would bring a devastating international response. He will come to recognize that for Iraq to survive as a modern state, he must totally reverse August's aggression. Patience can make that plain to Saddam Hussein -- and even enable President Bush to salvage an A in World Order 101.

HEADLINE: Africa Suffers From Leadership Problems

 BODY:
To the Editor:
You report that Nigeria's President, Ibrahim Babangida, speaking at a conference in Lagos, called on Western nations to pay compensation to Africa for damage done to the continent by the slave trade (news article, Dec. 24). While no one with a good sense of history will dispute that the slave trade wreaked incalculable havoc on the black race, it is preposterous to blame it for Africa's underdevelopment.
As a Nigerian living in the United States who travels frequently to Africa (I returned from Nigeria on Nov. 21), I have seen more damage done to that continent by incompetent and corrupt leadership than slavery ever did. The African landscape is awash with a class of leadership whose revolutionary songs were about ultimate redemption of the masses. Nevertheless, soon after they establish their rulership, they focus on personal enrichment. When things go wrong and the people start complaining, they resort to blame-the-West syndrome.
Was it the West that supervised the depletion of Nigeria's $100 billion oil fortune, earned between 1970 and 1980? Was it the West that was responsible for diverting much of those earnings to private bank accounts in Switzerland? Perhaps President Babangida should have explained to conference participants why Nigeria's telephone system hardly works?
Or is the West responsible for roads that are never maintained? Or is the West also responsible for the National Electric Power Authority's inability to deliver steady electric services to Nigerian homes?
How could any government that is worth its mettle spend so much time and effort persuading its citizens to learn to live with economic austerity measures only to turn around and sell its crude oil, its single most important source of revenue, at below-market price?
Instead of lavishing our energy on organizing conferences whose sole purpose is cheap self-serving international publicity, our attention should be on the serious problems confronting us. What better reparations can we give ourselves than making genuine efforts to improve our health-care system?
Our hospitals continue to operate at subsistence level; basic drugs are never available, and our doctors and nurses continue to flee to the West for better conditions of service.
Our educational system is far worse than in colonial days, all because of bad policy and neglect. Our judicial system is a joke because of persistent interference by successive rulers. Food is lacking because of bad agricultural policy. Basic transportation and shelter are hardly affordable because of inadequate planning.
Perhaps when we have helped ourselves, we can look to others for reparations.
 
C. CHUBA JON-NWAKALO
Albany, Dec. 25, 1990

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
