HEADLINE: TV VIEW;
A Very Model of a Modern Major Mini-Series

BYLINE: By John J. O'Connor

 BODY:
Turning 20 this month, public television's "Masterpiece Theater" will be feted from coast to coast, more or less, with elaborate tributes planned in Los Angeles and Washington. Hearty congratulations are certainly in order.
The series, consisting largely of imports from Britain, has compiled an enviable record in bringing a touch of class to a prime-time schedule that in 1971 was dominated almost exclusively by action-adventures, westerns and sitcoms. "Masterpiece Theater" institutionalized the mini-series, or "serialized dramatization" -- generally running from 5 to 13 hours -- perhaps television's most original and exclusive programming vehicle. 
 For a variety of reasons, the form is not being used in abundance these days. What the American networks usually label a mini-series is too often only a long movie, presented in two parts and running, minus commercials, for less than three and a half hours. But, if not entirely well, the mini-series is still very much alive.
Coming up on "Masterpiece Theater" in March is the four-part series "House of Cards," with a plot that quite by accident paralleled recent developments in Margaret Thatcher's career. Among the productions on tap next season is the four-part "Portrait of a Marriage," based on Nigel Nicholson's biography of his parents, Harold Nicholson and Vita Sackville-West.
The history of "Masterpiece Theater" actually begins in 1970 with public television's presentation of the BBC's 26-part "Forsyte Saga." Its success prompted Christopher Sarson, a Briton working for Boston's WGBH, to suggest that the station find other serialized novels. Fortunately, BBC drama output at the time, under Sean Sutton, was in a remarkably creative period, overseen by executives who had a broad knowledge of literature and the theater.
WGBH officials approached Herbert Schmertz, then Mobil Oil's vice president for public affairs, for underwriting, and a transplanted Briton named Alistair Cooke -- already familiar from the American series "Omnibus" -- was signed up as weekly host. A series of substance was born, making its debut with a decidedly clunky costume drama called "The First Churchills." Comedy troupes everywhere would soon have a new cultural artifact to parody.
"Masterpiece Theater" quickly found its stride in adaptations of Balzac, Dostoyevsky and Henry James. It blossomed further with "Upstairs, Downstairs," an exquisitely crafted soap opera that was an original endeavor not from the BBC but from London Weekend Television. Another triumph, "The Jewel in the Crown" (1985) was a Granada Television production. The series became so synonymous with quality imports that to this day I have trouble remembering that it cannot lay claim to "Brideshead Revisited," another Granada production, which was broadcast on "Great Performances."
The American commercial networks did not fail to notice that something new was happening. Long committed to open-ended series, running until they expired, and periodic single-shot specials, the networks moved gingerly into the mini-series arena with "QBVII" and "Rich Man, Poor Man." Later they would gain both prestige and ratings with such champions as "Roots," "The Winds of War," "The Thorn Birds" and "Lonesome Dove" (being repeated next week on CBS, Sunday and Tuesday through Thursday from 9 to 11 P.M.).
More often, however, Americans were content to stick with the glitzy romps of novels by Judith Krantz or Sidney Sheldon. CBS even tried, and failed, to do an American version of "Upstairs, Downstairs," called "Beacon Hill." And then there was the occasional disaster, such as ABC's "Amerika," inevitably triggering pronouncements that the mini-series was finished.
Intriguingly enough, the form would seem perfectly suited to established film makers who want to work in television but who are unable to devote all their time and attention to a long-term project. David Lynch and John Sayles are among current examples. As a 12-part mini-series, "Twin Peaks" could have been a tightly contained masterpiece instead of a drawn-out exercise in meandering improvisation.
Admittedly, the mini-series is in trouble, and the reasons are almost wholly economic. An ambitious production, on the level of a "Jewel in the Crown," is almost prohibitively expensive. And the markets in syndication and world sales are limited, or at least not as quickly rewarding as for more popular, easy-to-digest fare. One result can be heard in the current international buzzing about co-productions. Now, more and more, British and American producers are likely to undertake a major mini-series effort only with a consortium of worldwide partners.
The "Masterpiece Theater" costume dramas of old do indeed seem to be relics of the past. Rebecca Eaton, executive producer for WGBH, puts it this way: "We have taken the risk of reinventing ourselves on the air." Why? It is argued that, as new and younger executives -- not to mention audiences -- come on the line in British television, there simply isn't much interest in fine dramatizations of the classics.
Whatever the reason, the "Masterpiece Theater" schedule is increasingly veering toward self-contained presentations -- Maggie Smith in "Talking Heads: Bed Among the Lentils" and Eileen Atkins in "A Room of One's Own," among the best of them -- or more contemporary stories such as (again the best) "A Very British Coup" and "Traffik." Last year, "Masterpiece Theater" presented for the first time a film that had previously been shown in theaters: "The Dressmaker," with Joan Plowright and Billie Whitelaw.
One encouraging development: audience numbers for the series are up a bit from year-ago levels. But one foreboding danger is that the series will take its eye off the quality ball. The prospect of international productions put together by committee does not augur well for independent visions and uncompromising standards. A French-English co-production of "A Tale of Two Cities" and the British-Japanese version of "The Ginger Tree," both seen on "Masterpiece Theater," did not inspire an abundance of confidence about the future.
"Masterpiece Theater" itself has established a record that will be difficult to match, never mind top. Beginning tonight at 9:30 on Channel 13 with three vintage episodes of "Upstairs, Downstairs," the program will over the next several Sundays present a sampler of past triumphs. On tap are single episodes from "The Six Wives of Henry VIII," "I, Claudius" and "The Jewel in the Crown," plus such self-contained presentations as "On Approval," with Penelope Keith and Jeremy Brett, and "A Dedicated Man" with Alec McCowen and Miss Plowright. The reminders of what can be done, and has been done, in television drama are bracing.

HEADLINE: ART;
Wanted: Art Scholar, M.B.A. Required

BYLINE: By ALEXANDER STILLE; Alexander Stille is completing a book on the experience of Italian Jews under Fascism, to be published in the fall by Summit Books.

 BODY:
When Jack Lane took over as director of the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art three years ago, one of the first things he did was shut his office door. "The previous director's door was open to everyone who wanted to talk to him," Mr. Lane explains. "That just seemed unworkable. I wanted to clarify the chain of command, so we divided the museum into four major areas, and the heads of those areas report directly to me."
It was the kind of tough-minded decision the museum's trustees had hired Mr. Lane, who holds a master's degree in business from the University of Chicago as well as a Ph. D. from Harvard, to make. They wanted a director with a degree in business as well as art to lead the museum through a period of major expansion. 
 Their choice is representative of a growing perception that leadership at museums requires business acumen as well as connoisseurship. Although business management techniques have been used in museums for at least two decades, in the last few years those skills have been more heavily emphasized -- to the dismay of some in the art world.
 While many cultural institutions have long had business departments to take care of marketing, public relations and accounting functions, the emphasis at the top had been on scholarship. But now, at some major museums, even directors are being chosen for their business training as well as for their fine arts backgrounds.
Perhaps the most conspicuous, and controversial, appointment has been that of Thomas Krens at the Guggenheim Museum in New York. The 43-year-old director, who has a master's degree in business from the Yale School of Management, has come under criticism for his plans to create a multinational museum with branches in this country and abroad, and for selling paintings from the museum's permanent collection to buy newer works.
 Museums run by art historians are also making increasing use of modern management techniques. "You have to know how to negotiate with unions, hire contractors, run a restaurant and a bookstore," says Patterson Sims, associate director of the Seattle Art Museum, who does not hold an M.B.A. "Those are not issues that connoisseurship prepares you for.
To help meet the demand, several of the country's best business schools -- Harvard, Yale, Stanford and the University of California at Los Angeles -- offer courses in arts management. And the American Federation of Arts, a New York-based service organization that offers both exhibitions and professional training to 600 member museums, runs a summer program to train museum curators in business administration.
Perhaps not surprisingly, this mingling of art and business tends to polarize the museum world. "Administrative imperatives are taking precedence over artistic judgments," says Hilton Kramer, art critic and editor of The New Criterion, a magazine of cultural criticism. Others disagree. "A well-run operation should free the curator," counters Graham W. J. Beal, director of the Joslyn Art Museum in Omaha, who made the jump from curator to administrator after participating in the American Federation of Arts' training program.
Whether they see it as a blessing or a curse, there is widespread agreement that a business orientation in museums is here to stay. "It's not a question of whether it will happen," says Roger M. Berkowitz, deputy director of the Toledo Museum of Art. "It is happening."
 
The Changing Profile Of the Curator
 According to museum professionals, the trend is linked to the increased size and complexity of many art institutions.
"Museums are demonstrably more complex," says J. Carter Brown, director of the National Gallery in Washington and perhaps the first museum head to combine a joint M.B.A.-art history track as a calculated career strategy. He decided to take a business degree from Harvard while pursuing a master's degree in art history at the Institute of Fine Arts in New York. "When I became director in 1970," says Mr. Brown, "we had 350 employees. Now we have 1,000. Back then the museum was all in one building; we have doubled the space. Our budget was $5.9 million in 1970; today it's $53.9 million.
"My predecessor's fund-raising activities were simple," he continued. "He had lunch with Ailsa Mellon, and if he needed a Leonardo she would write the check." During Mr. Brown's tenure, the National Gallery has raised $40 million from 92 corporations.
As a result of such changes, the profile of the typical museum director has changed since the mid-70's. Directors of the old school tended to be socially prominent connoisseurs, as knowledgeable in wooing wealthy collectors as in evaluating art. "It was a hobby," says Thomas Hoving, director of the Metropolitan Museum from 1967 to 1977 and now editor in chief of Connoisseur magazine. "When I first got out of graduate school, people told me that the biggest prerequisite for becoming a curator was an outside income."
Although Mr. Hoving has no degree in business (nor does his successor, Philippe de Montebello), many credit -- or blame -- him for starting the focus on business in museums. "It was during Hoving's tenure at the Met that museums became broad, popular institutions, with blockbuster shows, expanded education programs, gift shops, bookstores and restaurants maximizing income," says Mr. Lane, who has raised more than $65 million for the San Francisco museum and will double its exhibition space with a new building.
 
The Blockbuster: A Catch-22
 Many museums grew rapidly on a steady diet of big exhibitions and expanding staff, membership and budget. But in many ways, museums have become the victims of their own success. The cost of buying, insuring, shipping and storing art has lifted blockbusters beyond the means of most institutions. "The cost of some of these shows is mind-boggling," says Steven A. Nash, associate director and chief curator of the De Young and Legion of Honor Museums in San Francisco, who spent a year at Stanford business school before getting his Ph. D. in art history. "In one recent exhibition I know of, it cost $100,000 just to insure one painting. We have had to say no to some blockbuster shows."
Without any major exhibitions in the last few years, the De Young and Legion of Honor have seen attendance drop from about 800,000 in 1988, the year of the Andrew Wyeth "Helga" show, to about 550,000 in 1989. "We have really had to streamline the institution, cut people by attrition and eliminate any redundancies," says Mr. Nash.
The Toledo Museum of Art went through a similar drought, in which annual attendance dropped from 493,000 in 1983, when it put on a major El Greco show, to 280,000 last year. Along with a 15 percent budget cut, the Toledo Museum has devised another solution to its problems. Borrowing a concept from the business world, it has formed a "consortium" with museums in St. Louis, Kansas City, Minneapolis and Pittsburgh, to mount a major Impressionist exhibition that none of them could have afforded otherwise. The show has broken attendance records at the museums.
Last year the Minneapolis Institute of Art hired Daniel E. O'Leary as deputy director, in part because of his experience in turning around a financially troubled museum. After earning a joint Ph. D. and M.B.A. at the University of Michigan, Mr. O'Leary became director of Artrain, a Michigan-based regional museum that presents traveling exhibitions in a railroad car. "I applied classical business school analysis," he says. "We booked exhibitions of greater appeal, extended the touring schedule to create a greater economy of scale. We managed to more than double the revenues and cut expenses by a third, and the audience went from 40,000 annually to 130,000."
One of the first things he did at Minneapolis was to conduct a market survey. "We live in a competitive world. We have to justify ourselves to government, to foundations, to corporations."
Some critics of the trend toward a business mentality fear that museums' preoccupation with attendance is inimical to their artistic purpose. "Museums are market-driven," says Hilton Kramer. "Museum directors have become salesmen."
Others insist that ignoring the bottom line can jeopardize a museum's artistic mission.
"A number of museums have become more or less insolvent," says Myrna Smoot, director of the American Federation of Arts. "They reduce their hours, they don't change their collection, they reduce maintenance and security, stop paying to conserve the collection, in order to keep the doors open."
 
Does Thank You Mean Forever?
 The problem of continual growth is one that preoccupies Mr. Krens at the Guggenheim, the most outspoken advocate of the so-called M.B.A. revolution, who has sought to challenge the assumptions on which museums have traditionally operated. "It's increasingly expensive to store and preserve works of art," he says. "When you accept an object into your collection, do you take on an obligation to preserve that work forever?" Older museums, he says, are at a critical juncture; they cannot continue indefinitely as both custodians of the past and purveyors of the new. "Do you go on collecting forever? And if not, where do you stop?"
Mr. Krens clearly answered his own question with his decision to sell a Kandinsky, a Modigliani and a Klee last year to pay for a major collection of Minimalist art from the Italian Count Giuseppe Panza.
Among Mr. Krens's ambitions are to expand the New York Guggenheim building, push forward the on-again, off-again project to establish a contemporary art museum in North Adams, Mass., and to supervise international Guggenheim outposts, including one in the Panza villa near Milan. Mr. Krens even has a possible business solution for the spiraling cost of conserving works of art. "We have talked about selling the maintenance of works of art. Let donors select works of art they want to pay to maintain and we will put their name on the wall label. It introduces a certain shopping quality to it."
Most M.B.A.-curators warn against taking the trend too far. "If M.B.A.'s are running museums without an art-history background, we're in for a grim future," says Mr. Nash. "You have to have people who can think with both sides of their brain."
For the moment, anyway, the low wage scale of the not-for-profit world insures to some degree that the M.B.A.'s entering the museum world will have to be passionate about more than money.
 
 
 
A Degree From Disneyworld
 Thomas Hoving, former director of the Metropolitan Museum, does not mind being seen as the harbinger of the current wave of M.B.A.'s in museums. "I didn't just bring in one M.B.A.," he said of his tenure at the Met. "I brought in about 25 M.B.A.'s. After I'd been director about a month, I realized that the curators knew absolutely nothing about administration. One department had more employees than 90 percent of all other museums in the United States.
Mr. Hoving has little regret for having disrupted the genteel, old-fashioned atmosphere that prevailed at the Met. "The good old days weren't so marvelous at all," he says. "Museums were run by badly paid lackeys of rich trustees.
In preparing the blockbuster shows that became his trademark, Mr. Hoving says he learned a great deal from the business world. "When we built a new wing for the museum, we spent a lot of time in airline terminals to study how to move crowds of people around. The first thing you see when you walk into the Met is not art but happy, smiling faces behind a brass information counter. We learned that from Disneyworld: they are masters in hospitality, in making people feel glad they came.
"Anybody in the museum world who hasn't spent time at Disneyworld is making a big mistake."

HEADLINE: Parks That Preserve the Old Hawaii

BYLINE: By ROBERT LINDSEY; ROBERT LINDSEY is former chief West Coast correspondent for The Times.

 BODY:
MILES -- and sometimes centuries, it seems -- from the posh resorts with swimming pools measured in fractions of an acre, which have been rising near almost every sandy beach in the state recently, another Hawaii is surviving, preserved by state and Federal park agencies.
During the last two decades or so, as its basic commodities -- sugar cane and pineapple -- have declined in importance on world markets because of new international competition, Hawaii has been forced to turn increasingly to tourism to support its economy. 
 The result has been great change. Before it became a state in 1959, and for a time after that, most of Hawaii's visitors were well-heeled and arrived by luxury ship, and there were a handful of grand hotels scattered along Honolulu's Waikiki Beach, whose South Seas ambiance stirred the pens of writers from Mark Twain to Somerset Maugham to James Michener. The advent of the jumbo jet and the lower air fares it made possible lured millions of middle-income tourists from the mainland. Now, except for one stretch of beach preserved by the Federal Government, there's hardly an inch of Waikiki not flanked by high-rise hotels, condominiums and other threatening walls of concrete, and one of the city's perennial political issues is whether it should spend hundreds of millions of dollars to build a rail rapid transit system to decongest motor vehicle traffic that, at its worse, ranks with the rush-hour jams of many cities on the mainland.
Maui, second largest of the Hawaiian Islands (after the island of Hawaii, usually referred to as the Big Island), was next to feel the impact of increased tourism and population growth: As more and more people sought escape from the urbanization of Oahu, columns of luxury hotels and condominiums began to rise along its shores, jumbo jet service was instituted directly from the mainland, and now Maui, too, is wrestling with serious road congestion and other problems of urban growth.
Even on the Big Island and the island of Kauai, perhaps the state's most beautiful, there has been population growth and a surge of resort and condominium construction. As a result, vestiges of what locals call Old Hawaii -- the pre-statehood Polynesia ofempty beaches and rain forests, of whaling
 ports, quiet plantation towns, and a slow-paced, sun-soaked territorial way of life -- are getting harder and harder to find.
Yet, many traces of Old Hawaii can still be found, in part because the resources of state and Federal taxpayers have preserved more than 60 parks around the state, ranging from small roadside enclaves to remote jungle recreation areas accessible only to the most dedicated backpacker. Several of the parks offer modest overnight cabin accommodations (in addition to campgrounds) that may be among the better travel bargains in the country, with rates as low as $14 a night.
Following is a report on several selected parks on Kauai, Maui and the Big Island, with emphasis on those that are most easily accessible by car and have overnight accommodations.
A complete list of the state's parks is available from the Hawaii Department of Land and Natural Resources, Division of State Parks, Post Office Box 621, Honolulu, Hawaii 96809; (808) 548-7455.
 
Kauai
Seated in front of the blazing lava-stone fireplace in the bar of the Kokee Lodge in Kokee State Park, visitors may easily forget they are not in the Rocky Mountains. A crisp mountain chill outside often heightens the illusion.
Not far away, however, are lush rain forests that are among the most beautiful in the Pacific. At the edge of an alpine meadow some 3,600 feet above sea level, the lodge is in the heart of Hawaii's most rugged mountain scenery, about 90 minutes' drive from many of the island's major hotels. Although much of the year the weather at the summit is tropically warm, conditions are unpredictable and visitors are wise to bring a sweater or rain-repellent jacket .
 From State Highway 540, which crosses a coastal plain in the southern part of Kauai, turn north near the town of Waimea (where the British navigator Capt. James Cook landed in 1778) via either the Waimea Canyon Drive or Highway 550.
After climbing about 11 miles, past vast fields of sugar cane set against the retreating backdrop of the Pacific, you will reach several turnouts for automobiles on the right side of the road that lead you to the rim of Waimea Canyon. Mark Twain called this vast gorge of jagged red and rose colored peaks, valleys and distant waterfalls "the Grand Canyon of the Pacific." Its beauty is enhanced by its seeming incongruity in the center of a tropical island.
At the roadside look-outs, visitors are likely to have their first meeting with one of Hawaii's most distinctive animals -- the moa, a wild red jungle fowl festooned with brilliant iridescent plumage, which is descended from birds brought via outrigger canoe to Hawaii by Polynesian explorers centuries ago. Once abundant throughout the islands, the untamed but friendly chickens now survive principally in the high country of Kauai.
After skirting the edge of Waimea Canyon, passing the entrance to a NASA space tracking station, Highway 550 continues past Kokee Lodge and ends, 19 miles from the town of Waimea, on a 4,000-foot-high plateau with another spellbinding vista: the jungles and meadows of the sweeping Kalalau Valley and, beyond it, the fluted cliffs of Kauai's Na Pali Coast.
 A dozen modest cabins, furnished with linens, refrigerators, stoves and basic cooking utensils, are available at the Kokee Lodge (Post Office Box 819, Waimea, Kauai, Hawaii 96798, [808] 335-6061 for reservations), for $35 to $45 nightly, plus 9.1 percent tax. The cabins accommodate from three to seven people.
The lodge's restaurant is open for lunch seven days a week, with dinner served Fridays and Saturdays only. Its specialties include a dish that is popular in Hawaii, Portuguese sausage and bean soup ($4.50). More ambitious items, such as roast Cornish game hen, also are on the menu. Dinner for two costs about $60.
While sun-bathing, dining and Polynesian music revues generally take center stage at Hawaii's beach resorts, the emphasis in the high country of Kauai is on leisurely exploration of a tropical wilderness, hiking and keeping an eye out for the distinctive flowers, trees, birds and other wildlife, such as wild pigs, deer and feral goats. In late June and early July, thousands of wild Methley plum trees ripen in the Kokee State Park and adjacent Waimea Canyon State park, providing a succulent bounty for hikers. And for visitors who are so inclined, permits can be secured for trout fishing and hunting wild boar.
Maps detailing more than 40 miles of trails into Waimea Canyon and surrounding forests, some of the walks not overly challenging , can be obtained at the lodge or park headquarters nearby.
Hikers throughout Hawaii are advised to take sunscreen, a protective hat and a quart of water , and to register their route at the park headquarters before leaving. Swimming or drinking from rivers and streams is not recommended: Kauai's waterways are infected with leptospirosis, a waterborne disease that produces high fever, chills and nausea.
Besides Kokee Lodge, privately owned Kahili Mountain Park ([808] 742-9921), a mile off Highway 50, one of the island's major arteries, offers modest, get-away-from-it-all cabins in the mountains. A cabin for two with private bath costs $38.15 nightly, cabinettes without private bath rent for $21.80.
The private park is near some of Kauai's most easily accessible tropical scenery: At Wailua River State Park bordering State Highway 56 visitors can ride a riverboat past a rain forest to a huge "fern grotto," a cave filled with vivid green maidenhair ferns. Also nearby are several scenic waterfalls, including Wailua Falls and Opaekaa Falls, which plunge out of the jungle and cascade to deep pools beneath them.
 At the northern end of Kauai, beyond the rural Hanalei Valley and Hanalei Town, there is a trail-head at Haena State Beach Park that takes hikers a mile and a half to the edge of the Na Pali Coast State Park; hikers are rewarded with views of the 15-mile stretch of craggy, primitive volcanic bluffs. Park officials say only experienced overnight hikers should go beyond this point and enter the 11-mile Kalalau Trail, which, following a route high among the towering bluffs, takes them into the heart of the park, a wonderland of lush valleys and plunging waterfalls.
 
Maui
Few communities have managed to retain the atmosphere of Old Hawaii better than Hana on the eastern coast of Maui, perhaps because getting there is so difficult.
 Although air taxi service has been available in recent years, automobile travel from other parts of the island has long been discouraged by the obstacle of a narrow, often tortuous 52-mile road of switchbacks, blind curves and single-lane bridges between Hana and the island's main jetport at Kahului.
 For those who make the three-hour drive and with a reservation in hand for one of the 12 cabins at the Waianapanapa State Park in Hana, the payoff can be an unparalleled, no-frills respite from urban life in a wild Polynesian setting.
The cabins rent for $14 a night, with a five-day limit. They tend to be booked several months in advance, with weekends most in demand. Reservations are made through the Division of Parks office in Maui (Post Office Box 1049, Wailuku, Hawaii 96793; [808] 243-5354).
Within the 120-acre park is a dense tropical forest, a treasure of temple ruins and archeological finds that bring Hawaii's past to life, a beach of volcanic black sand, trails and underwater caves and lava tubes that are the topics of island lore and legend. Most visitors, at least once, hike 3 miles along the rugged shoreline to Hana Town to buy a cone of fruit-flavored shaved ice -- an island tradition -- or visit a Hana landmark and the town's gossip-central, Hasegawa's General Store.
A different kind of experience, one at a higher altitude, awaits travelers not many miles from Hana, at Haleakala National Park, the site of a enormous volcanic crater that last erupted about 1790.
Standing at the rim of the crater more than 10,000 feet above sea level, visitors gaze out at an undulating moonscape of mountains and valleys that stretch for eight miles, a vast bowl painted red, pink, brown, yellow and other shades that change with the hour, the movement of the sun and the timeless movement of clouds overhead.
By tradition, the most popular moment to see Haleakala -- which in Hawaiian means House of the Sun -- is sunrise, when a ball of fire suddenly materializes at the eastern lip of the crater and explodes with a fiery brilliance that suggests the beginning of time.
Still, the panorama is stunning any hour when the crater is not totally covered by a layer of clouds, which occurs not infrequently. Before driving to Haleakala, it's a good idea to check with the Park Service at (808) 572-7749 regarding the weather and sightseeing conditions at the summit of the crater.
Driving to the park, which takes about two hours from most of Maui's principal resort areas, is as enjoyable as seeing the crater. State Highway 37 ascends Mount Haleakala through what Hawaiians call Maui's Upcountry, a bucolic area on the slopes of the volcano of pastoral farms and cattle ranches, where wild plumeria, protea and other flowers flourish and the rolling terrain is often reminiscent of the Chiltern Hills in Britain.
The Halimaile General Store ([808] 572-2666), a restored former pineapple plantation company store, is a pleasant place for a meal en route to or from the crater. Set amid cane and pineapple fields in the tiny hamlet of Halimaile two miles off Highway 37, the restaurant is run by Joe Gannon, a producer of concerts for rock stars such as Alice Cooper and Barry Manilow before he and his wife, Beverly, decided to move to Maui. Their menu features items such as blackened sashimi and roast duck with maple pecan sauce. Dinner for two: about $75.
Throughout the Upcountry, often waiting to be discovered on rural backroads by chance, are countless churches built by some of the missionaries who flocked to Hawaii during the 19th century. One example is the Church of the Holy Ghost near the town of Waiakoa. Also worth a visit is the nearby town of Makawao whose weathered wooden buildings (some of them converted to boutiques and art galleries) have the look of the Old West, befitting its role as a center of cattle ranching, and Paia, an old sugar processing town now filled with arts and crafts shops, some of them opened by mainland dropouts who a generation ago were called hippies.
A fee of $3 is charged each car entering the Haleakala National Park. Although many visitors are content to enjoy the view from the rim of the crater, others go into it, taking either a one-mile self-guided tour along a marked path or a hike that can last up to several days; guided trail rides into the crater are organized by a horseback riding concession at a cost of about $100.
The National Park Service makes available, by lottery, an opportunity to spend up to three nights in the crater at three government-owned cabins, an experience some former visitors have compared with overnighting on the moon. Four, 6 and 10 miles, respectively, from the lip of the crater, the cabins are equipped with a stove, bunks for up to 12 people, blankets, limited water and firewood, and cooking utensils. The charge is $2.50 a night for each person, with a minimum of $15 for each cabin.
At least 60 days before the proposed trip, travelers who want to stay in one of the cabins are required to submit their names and the date of their visit to the Park Superintendent, Haleakala National Park, Post Office Box 369, Makawao, Hawaii 96768, (808) 572-9306,; park rangers say travelers who offer several alternative dates are most likely to be selected for a reservation.
For people who want to spend a night near the crater under less Spartan conditions, the Kula Lodge (808) 878-2517, is on the slopes of Mount Haleakala. Rates are $120 to $140 nightly for two .
 
The Big Island
The Kalopa State Recreation Area is tucked into a mountainside tropical forest at an altitude of 2,200 feet midway between two of the Big Island's major population centers, Hilo and Kailua-Kona.
Within its 100 acres and adjoining 515-acre state forest are specimens of virtually all of Hawaii's native plants. The park is three miles inland from State Highway 19 and five miles southeast of the town of Honokaa. Cabins rent for $2.50 a person a night, with a minimum of $14, including linens. Cooking facilities are available. For reservations contact the State Division of Parks, 75 Apuni Street, Hilo, Hawaii 96720; (808) 933-4200.
Within a short drive of Kalopa are several plantation towns, such as Paauilo and Honokaa, whose narrow streets are lined with wooden buildings. Also nearby is Akaka Falls State Park. Five miles off the main highway, the falls plunge 420 feet over a mossy cliff into Kolekole Stream amid a lush jungle of azaleas, orchids, ferns and ginger trees.
 After spending the night at the edge of a rain forest, visitors need drive only 70 miles to spend a night not far from a hissing, lava-spewing volcano, at Hawaii Volcanoes National Park, (808) 967-7311, the site of two of the world's most active volcanoes, Kilauea and Mauna Loa. The volcanic activity is intermittent; a National Park Service telephone line, (808) 967 7977, provides up to date information on eruptions. The park can be toured by car in roughly half a day. A $5 entry fee is charged at the gate. The Visitors Information Center, (808) 967-7311 , provides maps with walks from 1 to 11 miles.
At the Volcano House, (808) 967-7321, the hotel at the park, rates range from $75 a night to $125 for a room with a crater view. Volcano House handles reservations for cabins in remote sections of the park that rent for $24 nightly.

SECTION: Section 5; Page 16; Column 1; Travel Desk

HEADLINE: It's Not Just Steak or Poi Anymore

BYLINE: By ROBERT LINDSEY

 BODY:
ASKED four or five years ago to define the ingredients of Hawaiian cuisine, many of that state's chefs would have listed local fish, pineapple, mangoes, coconut and poi, the starchy paste pressed from the root of the taro plant that has long been a fixture at island luau dinners.
At that time, ordinary residents of this multicultural melting pot enjoyed the flavors of Japan, China, Korea, Thailand, Portugal, the Philippines and other countries. But visitors, at most hotels and island resorts were offered a mainland diet of steak, prime rib and baked potato, frozen lobster tail and, occasionally, more ambitious Continental-style dishes bathed in cream and butter, or the ubiquitous luau. 
 Those days are gone. A new generation of young resort and restaurant chefs is offering sophisticated menus that combine classic European methods of preparation with the flavors and cuisine of Pacific Rim countries -- dishes such as fresh ahi (yellow fin) tuna seared and blackened in a wok and served barely cooked, like Japanese sashimi; steamed clams with Chinese black bean sauce; carpaccio of beef with red chili lentils; shitake and brie won tons with escargot and candied shallots; rack of lamb cooked slowly in the smoke of guava wood and Hawaiian coffee beans and served with wild poha berries and taro root pancakes.
"The changes I've seen since I came to Hawaii in 1983 are incredible," said Peter Merriman, the 34-year-old owner-chef of Merriman's, a well-regarded restaurant in the town of Waimea on the Big Island of Hawaii. "At that time, everybody was using frozen food and trying to emulate Europe; now, everything's got to be fresh and there's a blending of Pacific cultures that I don't think you see anyplace else. It's a new regional cuisine."
Dinner at Merriman's might start with an appetizer of locally produced goat cheese baked in phyllo dough or a slice of tender white fish from local waters that has been flavored by a marinade composed of coconut milk, lime juice and Maui onions. Among the choice of entrees are herb-roasted chicken served with a zinfandel-papaya sauce; a melange of shrimp and scallops served with a light Thai yellow curry, and one of the best examples of rare wok-seared ahi.
To a large extent, the renaissance in Hawaiian cooking is part of broader culinary trends that have occurred around the country during the past decade, changes that have placed new emphasis on using fresh, creatively prepared local food instead of processed or frozen foods; lightly broiled and grilled meats and fish; lighter sauces (if any sauce at all is used), and a general shift toward lighter, fresher foods.
What's different in Hawaii is a much stronger Asian influence than on the mainland, along with the availability of fruits, vegetables, herbs, spices and seafood not usually found elsewhere. The new Hawaiian cuisine uses not only such familiar Hawaiian products as coconut, guavas and mangoes, but also berries, squash, hibiscus leaves, seaweed and other ingredients not routinely available on the mainland.

 AND after years of often-difficult experimentation with such ocean farming techniques as pumping very cold water from the ocean's depths to provide a nurturing environment for seafood not normally found in tropical waters, aquaculture entrepreneurs in Hawaii are now turning out commercial quantities of many species from the deep sea: high quality prawns; abalone similar to the delicious pink shellfish that was once plentiful along the California coast; King salmon similar to fish native to the Pacific Northwest, and even "Maine" lobster. Coming soon, the entrepreneurs say: sea bass, trout, talapia, Belon oysters and "Dover sole" they say will taste very much like the fish netted in the cold waters of the English Channel.
"Almost everything I use now is a local ingredient -- at least 90 percent," said George Mavrothalassitis, a classically trained French chef from Marseilles who oversees the respected, expensive Le Mer restaurant in the Halekulani Hotel in Honolulu.
During the last three or four years, he said, Hawaiian farmers, responding to requests from local chefs, have taken advantage of the islands' seemingly omnipresent sun to produce a previously unavailable cornucopia of herbs, spices and vegetables, including sweet corn and plump vine-ripened tomatoes. All he misses now, he said, is locally produced foie gras and truffles.
Le Mer overlooks Diamond Head and the Pacific Ocean from one of the most beautiful spots on Waikiki Beach. Although classic European dishes are on his menu, Mr. Mavrothalassitis puts emphasis on island fish, which is often served with a sauce made from such indigenous ingredients as seaweed.
George Gomes Jr., the 28-year-old chef at the Garden Restaurant at the Mauna Kea Beach Hotel on the Big Island of Hawaii, said: "I think it's just in the past two or three years that cooks here have begun to realize how much Hawaii has to offer -- not only produce and other ingredients, but the variety of cultural influences we can choose from -- Korean, Thai, Japanese, Chinese and others. Suddenly, everything is coming together; they're all being blended into what we call this new regional cuisine."
He said the island chefs still generally used the basic European style taught to them in culinary schools, but modified it with unconventional ingredients: a beurre blanc sauce, for example, is prepared in the classical manner, but incorporates less butter and ingredients such as sesame oil, miso (soy bean paste), wasabi (a type of Japanese horseradish) or sweet onions grown on the mountain slopes of Maui.
Elements of several Asian cultures are often combined in unconventional ways, he said, as in an appetizer he prepares called Firecracker Salmon -- a six-inch cylinder-shaped piece of farm-raised Hawaiian salmon that is wrapped in Chinese cabbage, dried seaweed and a thin crepe popular among Filipino residents of Hawaii and served with a hot and sour chili dip. His other specialties include island-raised abalone served with Kuki nuts and a Tahitian lime-caviar sauce, and ocean-farmed Hawaiian King salmon glazed with a Hoisen pineapple sauce. Like many of Hawaii's new chefs, Mr. Gomes takes pains not to overcook seafood and, unless ordered otherwise, usually serves it tender and medium rare.
Although there is not a consensus on who invented the new Hawaiian cuisine, many cooks credit the Honolulu chef Roy Yamaguchi with having a major influence in it. After developing a large following at a restaurant in Los Angeles where he successfully combined French and Asian culinary influences, Mr. Yamaguchi opened Roy's restaurant in Hawaii Kai, a Honolulu suburb, two years ago. It offered a similar menu that won plaudits from diners and was subsequently emulated by a number of other chefs.
Constantly experimenting, Mr. Yamaguchi changes his menu frequently. A recent $30 prix-fixe menu included a warm appetizer of smoked baked salmon served with a watercress sauce, a shrimp salad served with a hot Thai sauce, roasted duck in a cognac-Madeira sauce, and desert.
Another force in the emergence of the new culinary style was Roger Dikon, executive chef at the Prince Hotel on Maui. When the Maui Prince opened in 1986, he said, he was given a blank check by the management to design a menu for its largest restaurant, the Prince Court, and decided to break from what he called traditional hotel food then common at island resorts, many of which were operated by large chains.
 Impressed by the culinary ferment in California, where many chefs were turning their backs on European tradition, Mr. Dikon said he set out to emulate some of the best California cooks; but he said he soon discovered, in a state whose economic strength had long been based on agriculture -- sugar cane and pineapple -- many of the products that were routinely available to California chefs couldn't be found here. "The only kind of lettuce you could get was Romaine and butter lettuce and no one grew fresh basil," he said.
In his backyard, Mr. Dikon planted 11 varieties of lettuce, 6 varieties of basil and many other herbs and vegetables and he began serving them in the new restaurant. Since then, he has managed to find farmers willing to sell the items to him, and he has acquired a reputation as one of the brightest innovators among the new generation of chefs in Hawaii. His specialties include black bean soup with country ham, duck, sausage and garnished with salsa, spiced cashews and bananas; blackened ahi with a salsa of Japanese cucumber, mirin (a sweet Japanese wine) and mint, and duck confit and pan-roasted breast of lamb served with candied figs and sun-dried cranberries.
Already, the new Hawaiian cuisine can be sampled on virtually every major island in the state. A partial list of some of the islands' other better known chefs includes:
* Alan Wong of the Canoehouse in the Hotel Mauna Lani on the Big Island; his specialties include blackened ahi and other island fish.
* Jean Marie Josselin, proprietor of A Pacific Cafe in the Kauai Village shopping center in Kapaa. He also features seafood, which is seasoned with a rainbow of flavors from many Pacific Rim countries. One example: stir-fried scallops with lemon grass and black bean sauce.
* Jeff Wind, of Bagwells 2424 at the Hyatt Regency Waikiki in Honolulu. He uses pineapple wine made on Maui in several dishes.
* Guy Higa, at the Inn on the Cliffs at the Westin Kauai hotel, who says he apprenticed at an Italian restaurant run by a Japanese cook and has never stopped trying to meld Asian and European cuisines.
* John Farnsworth, of the recently opened Lodge at Koele -- the only resort hotel on an island previously restricted to producing pineapples -- who not only prepares the new Hawaiian-Pacific Rim cuisine, but grows some of his own produce. Recently, he established a piggery to provide raw material for one of his specialties, grilled pork loin marinated in olive oil, pineapple juice and herbs and served with an aioli sauce whose ingredients includes petals from hibiscus flowers.
 * Adi Kohler, president and general manager of the Mauna Kea, a resort built in the 1960's by Laurance S. Rockefeller that is still a standard-setter among the state's luxury hotels, said competition at the top end of the resort market is intensifying. He also said competition was likely to be so keen in the future that resorts will have to have restaurants that can compete on an equal footing with the best on the mainland.
Affluent vacationers, he said, have come to expect higher standards from their restaurants at home and won't settle for conventional hotel food when they travel. The relative quality of resort restaurants, he said, will become increasingly important in the competition for customers.
"There are some very good restaurants in Hawaii now, but I think it's only beginning," Mr. Merriman said.

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
Post-Modern Kisses and Other Ideas

BYLINE: By PAUL GOLDBERGER

 BODY:
Since we ended 1990 with a look back, it seems appropriate to start 1991 with a look ahead. The outlook, to be sure, is gloomy: The new year begins with a depressed economy, not a single trendy new style to distract us, and not even a new architectural celebrity on the horizon. What can follow a year in which Peter Eisenman, the master of obtuse architectural theorizing, reached such heights of media fame that he was profiled in Vanity Fair? Herewith a few events that may happen in the world of architecture in 1991 -- or may not. 
 Jan. 20: Prince Charles announces the appointment of Ralph Lauren as chief architect and city planner for London, stating that he represents the platonic marriage of popular taste and respect for history that the Prince has been seeking. Mr. Lauren says he is honored to accept the position, and immediately announces plans to convert the Queen's House, the classical gem by Inigo Jones in Greenwich, into the Prince's personal Polo shop. Leon Krier, the classicist who has been designing a new village for the Prince in Dorset, retires to Florida in bewilderment.
Feb. 5: Philip Johnson and John Burgee, architects of the four skyscrapers that are to be the centerpiece of the Times Square redevelopment project, first announced in 1981 and still unbuilt, unveil yet another version of the project. After starting out with stone-and-glass buildings with mansard roofs and moving on to "deconstructivist" towers full of anxious angles, this time they try simple glass boxes. "It's all over, all this fancy nonsense," says Mr. Johnson. "I've just discovered this wonderful old architect named Mies van der Rohe, and his work is ripe for the picking." Architecture critics retire to their word processors in bewilderment.
Feb. 14: Michael Graves, who has designed teapots, shopping bags, fabrics and address books, announces a line of chocolates."There is no reason why architects cannot bring their special talents to bear in the important arena of Valentine's Day," Mr. Graves states. His rust-colored chocolates are in the shape of a classical column topped by a heart.
March 15: Donald Trump announces that Trump City, his vast project on the Hudson River on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, has finally been "certified," declared ready by the New York City Planning Commission to begin the official review process leading to final approval. How a builder with a nearly negative net worth could actually put up the world's tallest building in a city with a real-estate market so depressed that no one can sell a studio apartment is not explained. But Mr. Trump says he intends to plunge ahead, and promises an end to the recession if approvals for Trump City are granted.
April 15: The New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission designates a shelter for the homeless as its first "depression landmark," stating that "a city has a responsibility to preserve a full range of its artifacts."
April 24: The J. Paul Getty Trust, parent of the world's richest museum, abruptly cancels the unveiling of plans for its new museum and study center in Los Angeles, an elaborate complex the architect Richard Meier has been designing since 1984. A Getty spokesman explains that the institution doesn't like to rush things, "and anyway, after six years, isn't the suspense at least as much fun as any actual building?"
May 1: Hearings for Trump City begin. Mr. Trump says his project will not only end the recession but stimulate the economy so forcefully that the city's problems with homelessness, education and AIDS will be eradicated. If the project is not approved, Mr. Trump says, he has an alternative in mind that "will give all of you what you deserve."
May 10: The Walt Disney Company, which has become the nation's most aggressive corporate client of serious architecture over the past few years, announces that it has commissioned Peter Eisenman to build a new theme park based on the notion that confusion and angst can be fun.
May 20: Michael Graves announces a new line of architect-designed light bulbs.
May 30: Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, the huge architecture firm that dominated corporate architecture in the 50's, 60's, 70's and 80's, announces that it is having a harder time than expected competing in the economy of the 90's, and lays off another 20 architects. Mitsubishi, the vast Japanese industrial enterprise, is rumored to be considering buying Skidmore.
June 20: At another hearing for Trump City, it leaks out that Donald Trump's threatened alternative plan is to continue Riverside Drive southward and fill the 72-acre site with conventional New York City blocks containing medium-sized apartment buildings and row houses, and a riverfront park. Community members, stating that this is what they have wanted all along, are left flustered. "If Donald Trump is willing to do this, what is left for us to complain about?" one of them says of the scheme. Mr. Trump issues a press release calling the plan "my most brilliant idea ever," and says he would have proposed it years before except for his architects, "who were so hung up on that foolish business of putting up the world's tallest building that they couldn't focus on anything else."
July 15: Mitsubishi purchases Skidmore for $3 billion. After the deal closes is it revealed that the Japanese conglomerate went ahead only because it overheard Skidmore partners bragging about the quality of the firm's studio.
Aug: 10: Mitsubishi, unwilling to admit that it had not realized that the studio it was buying was a drafting room and not a movie company, tries to save face by appointing the action-film producer Joel Silver, a well-known architecture buff, as the new head of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill.
 Sept. 5: Unwilling to be bettered in the Mitsubishi-Skidmore deal, Michael Ovitz, the head of Hollywood's powerful Creative Artists Agency and the man who put together the purchase of MCA-Universal by Matsushita, tries to sell I. M. Pei, the architect of C.A.A.'s much-acclaimed headquarters building in Beverly Hills, to the Mitsui Corporation, another Japanese conglomerate.
Oct. 15: Michael Graves announces a new line of architect-designed paper clips.
Nov. 1: David Geffen, the entertainment mogul who is a major client of the New York firm of Gwathmey Siegel, buys this purveyor of sleek buildings, saying that it is cheaper for him to own an architecture firm outright than to continue paying it fees. To make the deal more attractive to Gwathmey Siegel, which has just designed a new headquarters for him in Beverly Hills, Mr. Geffen promises to let the architects start designing his record album covers and movie titles.
Nov. 10: The architect, author and teacher Robert A. M. Stern denounces the loss of independence on the part of architecture firms as a "sellout of our mandate to show the world our dreams." But a few days later, bowing to economic reality, Mr. Stern quietly launches a search for an appropriate buyer for his own firm, stating that it must be someone worthy of the traditional architecture and interiors he produces. He hints that Prince Charles would be ideal. Ralph Lauren, as adviser to the Prince, steps in and tries to buy the Stern firm himself.
Nov. 20: Mr. Stern, in desperation, goes to Michael Eisner, the chairman of the Walt Disney Company, in the hope that he will save him by outbidding Ralph Lauren and making the Stern firm part of Disney. But Mr. Eisner, who is Mr. Stern's biggest client, says he knows the difference between a studio and a drafting room, and he wants only the one, not the other.
Dec. 1: The real reason for Mr. Eisner's reluctance to buy the Stern firm leaks out: Disney is negotiating to buy the entire American Institute of Architects. "I've already got most of them at retail -- why not get the whole shebang at wholesale rates?" Mr. Eisner says. He announces that the A.I.A. will make the perfect substitute for the planned purchase by Disney of Henson Associates, makers of the Muppets, which fell through at the end of 1990.

HEADLINE: Landmarking's Doubled-Edged Sword

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:
EVIDENCE is mounting that in many parts of New York City, landmark and historic-district designation is acting as a force for neglect rather than for the encouragement of improvement and preservation.
Some owners are willing to risk Buildings Department fines and let buildings sit with crumbling facades, sagging roofs, cracked and broken ornamentation, leaky windows or tired-looking storefronts -- which often belie improvements made inside -- rather than face the trouble and expense of winning approval from the Landmarks Preservation Commission for facade improvements and repairs. 
 Moreover, the economy's downward slide, which has made it harder to recover the costs of improvements through resale or higher rents, may further dampen owners' enthusiasm for work or changes that require the commission's approval.
The picture is not uniform. In the Longwood Historic District in the South Bronx, for example, designation is credited with contributing both to the survival and enhancement of architectural richness. In the 80's, with property values generally rising, owners of numerous landmarked and historic district properties showed a readiness to accept the added costs and difficulties of making landmark-quality improvements. These usually require approval by the 11-member Landmarks Preservation Commission.
Laurie Beckelman, chairwoman of the commission, acknowledged the long-standing problem of making the review system workable and efficient and challenged owners who have had complaints about it to apply for project approvals again. Many owners are unaware of procedural changes that have been made to improve matters, she said.
Nevertheless, numerous instances of neglect of landmarked properties have demonstrated that communities can hardly rely on landmark designation as a means to force owners to maintain their property. Some eyesores, like the building with a peeling facade at 166 East 73d Street in the Upper East Side Historic District, are jarring standouts on otherwise well-kept residential blocks or thriving commercial strips.
Some even stand neglected and all but abandoned even though they are occupied, like the house at 213 Cumberland Avenue in Brooklyn's Fort Greene Historic District. The owner of that property, with a two-story crack in its exterior wall, has piled up thousands of dollars in fines for Building Code violations.
In still other cases, owners of buildings in historic districts have forgone facade improvements as a strategic decision. These owners cite as the main deterrents the higher cost of facade improvements in historic districts, where the landmarks agency requires historically accurate design or replacement materials, as well as the landmarks approval process, which they say remains lengthy and cumbersome despite the recent procedural changes.
The 1965 landmarks law cannot compel owners of landmarked buildings or those in designated historic districts to undertake restoration projects. But once an owner makes even minor changes in a facade the law gives the agency a considerable say in what is done to a protected building.
A PERMIT known as a "certificate of appropriateness" is needed to make a visible alteration to a protected building. This includes projects such as storefront redesign or major facade reconstruction. Work such as masonry cleaning or door replacement can often be done with a "permit for minor work." Over the last few years the commission has expanded the types of restoration and repair projects that owners can submit for staff approval instead of a full commission review.
"I think landmarking is a wonderful idea," said Jimmy Silber, whose family owns a 17-story apartment building on Christopher Street and Greenwich Avenue in the Greenwich Village Historic District. "The entire community benefits from it. But being the owner in a historic district can be a curse. I would like there to be more than a token attempt at financial aid or at least some sort of specific tax deduction for the expense."
Mr. Silber has vowed to refrain from making any improvements that require commission approval. Two years ago the commission required him to replace ornamental balconies that he removed from the facade without authorization. All the costs associated with replacing the balconies came to $100,000, Mr. Silber said.
"When I took them off I thought I was complying with the law," said Mr. Silber, referring to Local Law 10, which requires owners of buildings erected before 1980 to inspect facades every five years for loose materials and to make repairs. "The engineering company inspecting the building said the heavy ornamental balconies at the 12th level were loose and posed a safety hazzard. But it turned out that I should have had the commission's approval."
Mr. Silber said he felt that instead of spending $100,000 to replace 12th-floor features that are barely visible from the street he could have spent the money on a restoration job with visual impact.
The building at 166 East 73d Street, a former chapel between Lexington and Third Avenues apparently now used for commercial storage, offers an example of the helplessness of historic-district designation to force facade improvements on unwilling owners.
The structure is violation-free, the Buildings Department says. Some neighbors see facade disrepair as evidence of owner neglect. But the situation appears to illustrate that even in high-land-value locations, if an owner chooses not to improve a property to extract from it a higher economic value, the landmarks law cannot force him to do so.
Even supporters of expanded landmarks designations acknowledge the problem posed by laws that dictate alteration or improvement standards and prohibit demolition of designated buildings but provide only token financial assistance. The Landmarks Commission has about $250,000 a year to distribute to owners for facade improvements.
The burden can be heaviest for owners of small properties in neighborhoods with modest property values, such as Greenpoint in Brooklyn or the Morrisania section of the Bronx.
"In some neighborhoods, gentrification has helped the owners justify the costs of restoration," said Norman Marcus, a lawyer who, as counsel to the city's Department of Planning from 1963 to 1985, helped draft the landmarks law.
"But there is not much you can offer as inducement in some low-density neighboroods where property values have not gone up that much, beyond pointing to the benefits that come to neighborhoods that have a sense of their places in history and a self-esteem that goes with that."
PRIDE had been the motivating force behind the preservation of the tiny enclave of turn-of-the-century homes in the South Bronx known as Longwood. A group of middle-income homeowners there has successfully restored and maintained their homes despite the decay that surrounds them.
In 1980, at their urging, the neighborhood bounded roughly by Prospect, Leggett and Longwood Avenues was designated a historic district. Of major concern now are the city-owned vacant and derelict homes in their midst. For several years they have tried without success to patch together enough money in city and Federal grants to rescue these buildings.
But owners of small commercial buildings in historic districts whose livelihood is tied to their property ownership maintain that restoration and preservation are luxuries they can not afford.
Murray Miller, a merchant and small-building owner whose property is in the Greenpoint Historic District in Brooklyn recently gave up a plan to put in new windows in his two-story building. Even with a grant from the city's Office of Business Development, which would have paid part of the expense, he said, the estimates for the cost of the wooden frames the commission wanted him to install was more than for the metal frames he planned to install.
"There was the time factor, too," said Mr. Miller, whose business is on a street where rents average about $25 a square foot and few tenants have more that 2,000 square feet. "I had an empty space on the second floor and wanted to get the work done before a new tenant came in. But after three months I had a tenant but didn't have approval for the windows. The tenant was more important."
ANOTHER property owner in the historic district in Greenpoint says he lost more than a chance to replace windows when it took the city more than two years to approve the zoning change and facade design and interior plan needed for him to turn a former embroidery and sewing factory in a landmarked district into a 30,000-square-foot commercial building.
"The approvals were just too late," said Henry Montag, who scrapped his plans to redevelop three adjoining red-brick buildings at 126-132 Greenpoint Avenue a few months after all the approvals were in place. "I am not going to blame the Landmarks Commission or the Buildings Department for the downturn in the market or the construction loan industry. But we did have tenants ready to sign leases when we started."
Mr. Montag says that while he waited for the appropriate permits, he watched prospective tenants drift away and construction financing dry up. Still empty, with all approvals for development in the owner's files, the buildings are now up for sale.
"We took the time to hire an architect with experience in projects in landmarked districts," said Mr. Montag. "We really wanted to do a nice job there. But whole experience had really turned me off on getting involved in projects that are in historic districts."
Ms. Beckelman, who took over as Landmarks Preservation Commission chairwoman eight months ago, said that some of the problems of delays were attributable to a lack of understanding of the process by owners and the fact that they fail to use resources available to them. "I challenge them to try again," she said.
Ms. Beckelman said that owners with even major projects who work with staff members from the beginning of the approval process usually can move through the system in two or three months. She pointed to procedural changes -- including the window guidelines -- made in the last few years to speed the process. Currently, more than two-thirds of theapplications for window replacement and repair projects are approved by the commission staff without a hearing by the full commission, which was required in the past. Petitions for approval of window work account for about 25 percent of submission to the commission.
Ms. Beckelman said the staff is working on similar guideline for doors and air-conditioners.
The new commissioner has staff members working on guidelines that would extend to other historic districts those that allow commercial owners on Madison Avenue to expedite storefront changes. On Madison, owners can have most street-level facade changes approved after a review by the staff without having to submit their designs to the commission.
Guidelines for retailers on Lower Fifth Avenue in the Ladies' Mile Historic District, for example, are now in the works.
"I want to give owners more certainty when it comes to landmark requirements," Ms. Beckelman said. "More guidelines are needed. And more approvals can be done at the staff level. The commission has 40 items to hear at the next meeting."
But Konrad Wos, a developer and consultant in Brooklyn who is involved in projects throughut the borough, including the Greenpoint section, said it will take more than new guidelines to motivate small commercial owners. He believes a revision of the landmarks requirements is necessary to interest them in the sorts of renovation projects the commission ususally requires.
"It is not right to have the same standards for places like Ladies' Mile on Fifth Avenue where owners have hundreds of thousands of square feet," said Mr. Wos, "and places like Greenpoint where the commercial properties are ususally no larger than a couple thousand feet. These owners don't have the capitalization that owners in Mahattan do.
"It is an issue of appropriate scale of response," he continued. "Without changes to make it easier and more cost-effective for small owners, there is little chance that they will participate."

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:

Paying Off Liens
 
Question: I am considering buying foreclosed property through public auction. I have noticed that some properties have mechanic's liens attached to them. If, for example, there is a mechanic's lien of $15,000 against a property and I have a winning bid of $10,000, would I have to come up with $25,000 to make the purchase? . . . Timothy Keane, Staten Island
 
Answer: It would depend on the rules of the particular public auction.
In New York City, for example, buyers are not responsible for paying off most liens. According to a spokesman for the Division of Real Property, the agency that conducts auctions of properties taken for nonpayment of municipal taxes, the city would wipe out back taxes as well as liens, like the mechanic's lien.
The exception would be Federal liens that might be outstanding at the time of sale. The city would not have the authority to remove them.
 
M.C.I. Increase
 
Question: I have been notified that there will be an increase in my rent because of the installation of a new water tank. The increase has been calculated according to a 60-month schedule. When the 60-month period ends and the cost has been paid off, will I get an automatic reduction in my rent? . . . Elie Meinstein, Manhattan
 
Answer: No. Increases for major capital improvement are permanent and become part of the base rent.
"The 60 months that this tenant refers to," said Thomas R. Viola, a spokesman for State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, "does not refer to a timetable for how long the rent increase will last but is used as a way of calculating the rent increases for each tenant. There are limits on how high the rent increases can be."
For rent-stabilized apartments the owner many not collect in any one year an increase of more than 6 percent of the rent as listed on the schedule of rents filed with the owner's application. Permanent increases above the 6 percent can be spread out to future years.
Owners who make improvements before their M.C.I. increases are approved by the division may be entitled to additional temporary retroactive rent increases as well. "We do not penalize owners for the amount of time it takes us to process the application," said Mr. Viola.
There is also a 6 percent cap for the temporary retroactive portion of the rent increase. But once the amount of any retroactive portion of the increase has been collected, the temporary rent increase ends.
 
Window Gates
 
Question: I live in a rent-stabilized apartment with some windows that open onto fire escapes. Is the landlord obligated to install security gates on windows that open onto fire escapes? . . . Julie Christiansen, Brooklyn
 
Answer: No. Neither the rent stabilization code nor the rules that pertain to residential multiple dwellings in the city require owners to install security gates at windows facing fire escapes. However, the New York City Fire Department prohibits security gates if access to the windows they cover is restricted by fixtures or furnishing. Such gates would be illegal, for example, if used at a kitchen window above a sink or cabinets.
Another requirement is that the design of the security gates conform to city-approved standards. One requirement is that the lock on the gate is a type that can be opened without a key.

HEADLINE: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester;
Down and Out in Darien: The Shopping

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
DARIEN'S reputation as a town teeming with beautiful and expensive homes matches that of Greenwich, Westport and New Canaan. But when it comes to shopping, Darien runs a poor third.
 "We don't want to be Westport or have a mall, but it's too bad when people have to leave town to make purchases in other communities," said Doug Milne, head of Kelly Milne, a realtor. 
 Worried about declining business, the Chamber of Commerce commissioned two studies in 1988 and '89 showing that customers were going elsewhere because of shabby-looking stores, poor parking facilities, and an inhospitable location -- a little over a half mile on Route 1 from Leroy to Sedgwick Avenue, interrupted by an antiquated railroad trestle.
 Crossing the Post Road with a baby carriage, customers reported, is high adventure, parking in the jam-packed lot behind the Manfield to West Avenue stores is terrifying and tilted, broken sidewalks do not square with Darien's image.
 When the findings were presented to the Board of Selectmen last summer a task force was appointed to see what could be done. "We hope to present a program to the Representative Town Meeting at its May budget session," said Warren Tuttle, head of the task force and president of the Chamber of Commerce. If approved, work could begin in July.
 The deteriorating Metro-North trestle cannot be moved, according to William Keish, a spokesman for the Connecticut Department of Transportation, but $1 million has been allocated to rehabilitate the structure by 1995. More control of Post Road traffic is possible through better defined crosswalks.
 The task force is concentrating on pragmatic improvements at four sites, and four civic-minded architects -- Neil Hauck, Robert Young, David Heuer and Howard Patterson -- are drawing up plans for West to Mansfield Avenues, Tokeneke Road, a supermarket and empty lot and a block opposite the vacant Darien Playhouse without charge.
 The first site to be improved will be the block between West and Mansfield Avenues where Mr. Tuttle is the proprietor of the Good Food Store and the Complete Kitchen. The task force has recommended repaving the sidewalks with concrete and brick; putting in benches, trees and lighting; rebuilding the rear parking lot and connecting it to an under-utilized bank parking lot; and giving several stores a front and rear facelift.
 The town's share -- sidewalks, parking lot, lighting and trees -- will cost up to $700,000. Property owners would refurbish at their own expense front and rear facades of their buildings, install new signs and provide benches.
 Sandy Falconer, owner of the building on the Mansfield Avenue corner, is willing. "I've been here 10 years and there is no question that Darien is losing business," she said. "The town has been very sluggish in responding to the problems." Two stores and some second-floor offices occupy her building. The third floor is unfinished and vacant, and must remain so under a 1962 zoning regulation that freezes existing usage of the buildings.
 Ray Nurme, the Town Planner, said that in return for conveying ownership of the parking area to the town for a town-built and town-managed lot, property owners would be allowed to increase the use of their buildings or put up new buildings. If the increased usage happens to generate more parking than the lot allows, "that will be another problem," said Mr. Nurme.
AN existing 134 parking spaces could only be increased to 146, but Mr. Nurme pointed out that dozens of spaces are now lost to Dumpsters and the cars of store employees and commuters. "Under municipal management, they would all be ticketed by the police," he said. Customers could park free for specified periods.
 Of the 369 downtown municipal parking spaces, 70 were built for employees across the street from the Post Road shops where the work, "but only six or seven cars are ever there," said Mr. Nurme. This could be because employe parking permits cost $170 a year, while parking behind the stores is free.
 George Zengo, a member of the task force and a Republican member of the Board of Selectmen, favors reducing the cost of the permits by half. Not entirely convinced of the merits of the whole project, he said, "It's a lot of money to spend on making a parking lot look spiffy."
 "There are a lot of people opposed to doing anything that will cost money," said Lawrence B. Morris, a task-force member. "Dyed-in-the-wool Republicans, yuppies with big mortgages and no jobs, local firemen who grew up here but can barely afford to stay, and the retired country club set."
 Mr. Tuttle is aware of the obstacles. "Besides getting the town behind this, there are 32 businesses and six building owners that must be in agreement," he said. Ms. Falconer and the actor Paul Newman are his landlords and pose no problem. Other agreeable owners include Michael Sherman, a Stamford laywer and William T. Lapcevic, a Greenwich lawyer who owns a building jointly with Whaja Chung, wife of the Stamford architect Do Chung.
 "This may not be a time when people want to spend money," said Mr. Lapcevic, "but if we wait, more people will just drive through here on their way to shop somewhere else." His building contains four stores renting at $30 a square foot and six two-bedroom apartments that rent for $1,000 each.
 "Five years ago when we bought the building apartment rents were around $500," said Mr. Lapcevic. Store rentals were around $10 a square foot. "We paid $1.2 million for the property and the old rents just didn't pay for the mortgage," he said.
 Another prickly downtown issue is the movie theater, vacant and in disrepair for more than four years. United Artists, the owner, has been at loggerheads with the Darien Planning and Zoning Commission and a group of residents over installing a proposed 200 or so additional seats, because of anticipated parking problems. "UA is losing interest," said the movie company's lawyer, Wilder Gleason. "Today the economics require 14-screen theaters for profitability."
 Jany Caroli, whose elegant antiques shop La Caleche is next door, is moving her shop to Greenwich. Triple-whammied by the disintegrating theater, by the troubled First Constitution Bank, which is selling her building, and by dwindling customers, she has concluded that "Darien is not good for business."
