HEADLINE: Faded Movie Palaces Recall Gilded Past

BYLINE: By CAROLYN BATTISTA

 BODY:
EVEN in these days of sterile suburban multiplexes, some moviegeors still prefer the old downtown theaters that were built with details like plaster gargoyles on the balconies and painted dragons on the ceilings.
"I love the old theaters -- the grandeur, the beauty, the experience," said Andrew Rosetti of Manchester. "They were the focal point of the community."
And Barry Goodkin of Trumbull noted, "The price of admission included views of art and sculpture." 
 Mr. Rosetti and Mr. Goodkin share their devotion with a thousand other members of the Theater Historical Society of America, based in Chicago. The organization encourages the preservation of old theaters, organizes tours of them, publishes a quarterly magazine called Marquee and maintains archives filled with photographs, clippings, programs, books, blueprints and more.
Several members of the society in Connecticut, including Mr. Rosetti and Mr. Goodkin, are particularly interested in 1920's movie palaces that provided mass entertainment in grand settings.
"Architecturally, these places are beautiful," said Mr. Goodkin. "But you can't operate buildings of that size just because they're beautiful. Many are gone, and some of those that remain are quite forlorn."
Mr. Goodkin has compiled a listing of more than 200 theaters built in Connecticut between the 1890's and the 1960's, many of which started their lives as vaudeville houses.
"I averaged 10 hours a week in libraries and historical societies for the best part of two years," he said. He listed every theater's size, dates of operation and architect. For some entries, he also noted the date and manufacturer of the theaters' organs.
Last spring, Mr. Goodkin and Mr. Rosetti organized a tour for the society of surviving theaters in Connecticut and nearby New York and Massachusetts. The itinerary included several old halls with new lives, including the Palace Theater in Danbury. A film and vaudeville house when it opened in 1928, it is now a movie multiplex, but it still has some of its "original grandeur," Mr. Goodkin said.
The tour also visited film and vaudeville theaters that have been restored as performing arts centers, including the Palace in Stamford, which opened in 1927 with the decor of a Spanish villa; the Warner in Torrington, whose gala 1931 opening was attended by Gov. Wilbur Cross; the Garde in New London, which opened in 1926, and the Palace in New Haven.
Built in 1926 as the Roger Sherman Theater, the New Haven structure was rededicated in 1984 as the Palace Performing Arts Center, after a major restoration. And Mr. Goodkin noted that while the balconies no longer have their original plaster gargoyles with electrically lighted eyes, the ceilings are still adorned with birds and fire-belching dragons. Tour members also visited the Palace in Waterbury. Opened in 1922 by Sylvester Z. Poli, who once owned 30 theaters, it is being restored by Domenic Temporale, a developer, as part of an arts center.
And they stopped to gaze regretfully at the deteriorating Palace and Majestic in Bridgeport, also built in the 1920's by Mr. Poli. The city has long been trying to foreclose on them, said Michael Nidoh, Bridgeport's planning director. He said the proceedings will begin early in 1991.
Many other theaters on Mr. Goodkin's list are gone -- demolished, destroyed by fire or converted to non-theatrical uses, from stores to storage. "The Palace in Norwich is now a parking lot," he said with a sigh.
Many society members have strong ties to the old theaters. Mr. Rosetti, manager of Cinema City in Hartford, once ran the Capitol in New London, another elegant 1920's theater now closed and in disrepair. Mr. Goodkin, a longtime General Electric employee, said his father managed theaters, his mother played the piano for silent films, he worked in his youth as a theater usher and manager, and he met his wife in a movie house.
Another society member who is a former usher, Edgar Kloten, is a theater critic and professor who lives in West Hartford. "I've always been interested in the gorgeous quality of those old theaters," he said.
Mr. Kloten was an usher at the Fox in Washington, D.C., and later wrote about that theater for Marquee magazine. He said he has collected a good deal of information for what may become a writing project on the old theaters of Hartford.
Charles Turner of Riverside, a retired film director, is a collector of theater memorabilia. His contributions to the society, have included files that he rescued some 30 years ago from a theater in Washington, D.C., that was about to be demolished. Mr. Turner had seen his first talking film at that theater, he said. The files contained a photo of a latticed arcade next to the theater -- the outdoor spot to which, in the days before air conditioning, the management moved projector, film and audience whenever the hall became too hot.
Another Marquee contributor is Jeanne Poli of West Haven, granddaughter of Sylvester Z. Poli.
"My grandfather was the biggest single theatrical magnate in history," she said. "He had his first theater, the Bijou, here in New Haven."
 
Three Theaters Remain
 She said that she spent a year and a half researching her grandfather's career, which began in the 1890's, for an article in Marquee.
"My grandfather was extremely artistic," she said, noting that he introduced design features like cantilevered balconies. Only three of his theaters in Connecticut are still standing, the Waterbury Palace and the unfortunate Majestic and Palace in Bridgeport.
"It's tragic," she said, adding that she does not approve of the modern theaters. "I wouldn't go to those cracker boxes we have now," she said.
Other Connecticut members of the Theater Historical Society acknowledged that moviegoing has changed, and that keeping the old theaters usually means coming up with ideas, skills and money.
"These are tough economic times," said Mr. Goodkin. But society members said they hope that people will continue to take an interest in old theaters.
Mr. Goodkin said he was pleased that a theater buff in his 20's came from California to join the spring tour. "We have to have young people involved," he said.

Left, vents for the theater's original air conditioning system, run by two diesel engines; One of the architectural wall details at the theater (pg. 10) (Photographs by Dave LaBianca for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Welfare System Is 'Muddled,' Says New Commissioner

BYLINE: By James Feron

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
WHEN County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke introduced Mary E. Glass as the new Commissioner of Social Services earlier this month, he spoke of her as "an innovator, a leader, a compassionate administrator and disarming." In fact, he added, "She disarmed a person who brought a shotgun into a district office and has taken a few knives from clients."
It was a light touch for a serious occasion. Ms. Glass, who has risen through the ranks of the Westchester welfare system from a $4,600-a-year junior social caseworker to the $79,605 post as Acting Commissioner, takes over a vast agency of 1,400 employees that consumes $2 of every $3 in county taxes paid by Westchester homeowners. 
 It is an agency, Ms. Glass conceded, "where the rules, regulations, notices, procedures and forms have become the end product of what we do, rather than the delivery of services."
"It's so cumbersome and muddled," she added, "that it's very, very hard to see the clients or have them take us seriously."
 
Coordinator of Workfare Program
 Ms. Glass replaces John J. Allen, who retired as Commissioner at the end of last year. She has worked since 1987 as a special assistant to Mr. O'Rourke in coordinating such new programs as Workfare, where eligible clients for welfare are required to accept work assignments or face removal from the rolls, and an assessment center for the homeless that has been weeding out roughly half the new applicants for shelter.
The appointment places the 49-year-old Buffalo native, whose father was a teacher and whose mother was Director of Child Welfare in Erie County, under competing pressures from social service workers, welfare recipients and some elected officials who had hoped Mr. O'Rourke would look beyond the county for a new commissioner.
In fact, the County Executive coupled the announcement of her appointment with news that he was also initiating a nationwide search, likely to cost $50,000, to determine if any other candidates had the "qualifications, experience, verve and drive of Mary Glass." He said he felt "pretty secure" that her job was safe.
 
System Termed Counterproductive
 The County Executive said he was responding to a request by the Board of Legislators, "whose members just want to be assured that I have taken a very wide look at possible candidates." He said he did not think the wider search was needed but had "acquiesced" to the Board in this case, reminding those who had gathered in his office for the announcement that he needed the Board's confirmation of the proposed commissioner "under any circumstances."
Mr. O'Rourke, a former welfare worker himself, said that "we have a social services system that was absolutely needed in the 1930's and the beginning of the 40's, a system that has not worked well since the 50's and has been counterproductive probably since the 70's and into the 80's."
He described it as a system that now imposes "tremendous burdens" on its workers. "I was once told that the average social service worker has a pile of documents that is two feet high and weighs 50 pounds and changes on a daily basis," he said. "And we expect these men and women to keep down the error rate."
Ms. Glass had her own horror stories. She said she had just heard that the Federal Government had "changed its mind on the monitoring of clients in jobs programs, asking that it be done weekly instead of monthly." A welfare official in Maryland, where the new schedule is under way, "said the directive could only have been devised by someone who doesn't know anything about what it is to implement on a local level," Ms. Glass said.
Even as she assumed her new position, welfare rolls were expanding. The recession, she said, was adding 1,061 new home relief cases a month in the category of healthy childess adults, compared with 751 in 1989. Home relief, one of the department's smaller programs, has a caseload of 6,650. It would be higher, she said, if 4,670 cases had not been removed through the Workfare program that began in early 1989.
The new Commissioner, who was lauded by Mr. O'Rourke as an innovator, has been working since last March on changes that she said would enable directors in the district offices to change places with directors in the central office, a switch that is dependent on Civil Service tests under current regulations and difficult to achieve.
 "The department is generally divided into two parts -- the district offices, where we have district directors, and the central office, where we have program directors," she said. "This division has solidified the department, with each division pointing to the other saying, 'If only you did your job we wouldn't be in this situation.' "
 
38 Job Titles Become Five
 She said she expected the situation to improve with the changes. "What I've been working on, with county personnel experts and the State Department of Civil Service, is to give them the same titles, say Managers One through Four, and in that capacity they can work either in the field or in central office." She said 38 job titles had been consolidated into four or five generic titles so far.
A senior county official said, "We'd reached a point where employees working in the field found that their career path blocked them from advancing to higher-paying positions in central office, and vice versa." The change, he said, "will allow people to move back and forth between program functions and line functions."
"Anybody from the lowliest caseworker to somebody who's bored doing program work and wants to go back out there and work directly with clients will be able to do it and won't be stuck, because of Civil Service, in positions they don't necessarily want," the county official said.
Ms. Glass has told colleagues that people in the central office who make program policy or interpreted it should have some idea of working conditions in the field and that there should be some movement in middle-management ranks between the central office and the field so that nobody loses touch with what is happening there.
 
'They Need a New System'
 These changes could improve the operation of a bureaucracy regarded by its clients, at least in some cases, as an administrative maze. One such welfare recipient, Myrtle Acklin of Yonkers, a former nurse's aide at the Ruth Taylor Institute, said last week that "they need a new system, one geared to getting people off welfare instead of turning borderline cases into hard-core cases."
She said she had lupus, which sometimes caused joint pain, and which forced her "to lose time" occasionally, leading to a loss of benefitsand prompting her to approach welfare officials for assistance. She said she had a 21-year-old daughter, who also had a daughter, aged 5, living with her at home.
"I wanted to continue to work," Ms. Acklin said, "although I never knew when I was going to be out. They said 'Why bother?' They also encouraged my daughter to be at home, but now she's a secretary who pays her own day care -- that's $75 a week -- and goes to college on weekends." Ms. Acklin is not working and receives benefits.
Paul J. Feiner, a county legislator from Greenburgh and a persistent critic of the County Department of Social Services, said the department "should figure out ways to work with other departments to find jobs for people who want to work but who are eaten up by the system and become permanent welfare cases."
 
Pride and Dignity a Factor
 Mr. Feiner operates an assistance program for the homeless out of his office in the County Office Building in White Plains. His program, the Have a Heart for the Homeless Committee, has helped 120 families since 1986, he said, and has distributed $36,000 in loans, with $8,000 of that amount "coming from families we helped."
"The county makes such a big thing out of Workfare, but people who need temporary help, who still have pride and dignity, get eaten up by the system and become full-time welfare cases," Mr. Feiner said, suggesting that the system was geared less to finding jobs for clients than to providing assistance.
"They are so messed up that they have a caseworker whose only job is to handle other social service workers who can't pay their rent or are marginal welfare cases themselves," he said. "Most of the people who come to us want to work, but the Department of Social Services doesn't know how to break the cycle of dependency."
 
Glass Defends Department
 "The primary function of my department is to issue benefits," Ms. Glass said. "Unfortunately, we have been charged with a number of responsibilities beyond our purview, from housing to jobs. That is why we have a contract with Westchester Community College to help us make judgments about other providers, so we can move people quickly from application to jobs or training.
"I think social workers are very good at what they do, but we're not the be-all and end-all of everything. We're not educators or builders of houses, so we look to others to be involved."
The department, Mr. Feiner said, "should figure out ways to work with other county departments to find jobs for clients."
"They could assign them to municipalities with financial problems," he suggested. "Or invite those municipalities to consider them for training for real jobs, anything to keep them from turning borderline welfare recipients into people totally dependent on the system."

HEADLINE: Technology;
Pursuing Zero Defects Under the Six Sygma Banner

BYLINE: By GLENN RIFKIN; Glenn Rifkin writes frequently about technology. He is based in Sudbury, Mass.

 BODY:
When Motorola Inc.'s fiscal year ended in December, the payoff from improving the quality of the company's manufacturing operations suddenly became evident: $500 million saved during the year from reducing defects.
The Digital Equipment Corporation benefited from improving its quality as well. Its storage division cut its product-defect rates by 60 percent in one year, which meant a 25 percent reduction in overall product costs. 
 What these success stories have in common is that they were accomplished under the banner of "Six Sigma," a three-year-old defect-reduction strategy. Six Sigma was first used by Motorola and is now being embraced by a growing number of American companies seeking to improve quality.
"If you control your processes very tightly, you don't produce defects and therefore you don't have to refine and repair defects," said Richard Buetow, senior vice president and director of quality at Motorola. "You don't need the extra people and equipment."
Six Sigma is a statistical term attached to the concept of achieving approximately zero defects -- actually 3.4 -- per million opportunities. Sigma -- the 18th letter of the Greek alphabet -- refers to the number of standard deviations from the mean in any given statistically measurable process. The mean is the arithmetic average; the standard deviation is a measure of variation from that average.
Six Sigma requries no new manufacturing equipment, but it does require rethinking the manufacturing process. It is, therefore, very difficult to take an existing product line and bring it all the way up to Six Sigma. "You can't take an old product and move it to Six Sigma.," said Mr. Buetow. "You need to start with a clean sheet of paper."
According to John Early, vice president of research and development for the Juran Institute, a quality-consulting firm in Hilton, Conn., every process has a measure of variability to it, whether it is soldering a chip onto a silicon wafer or delivering a package. "A key thing in quality is to keep the variation as close to the mean target as you can," Mr. Early said.
If Six Sigma were used at home in the kitchen for baking bread -- which would never the case -- the process might work like this: First the recipe would be analyzed to see if there were ways to reduce the number of ingredients. Next, the measuring process would be assessed to see which were the more difficult tasks. Goals would be established for the number of acceptable measuring errors. Technologists would assess whether the rising time of the dough could be shortened and they would refit the over controls to make them more accurate. In the end, the bread would be sampled by the group that wrote the recipe to see if it conformed to expectations.
The quality of most manufacturing processes in the United States is plus or minus three sigma, which means that there are 66,810 defects per million opportunities for error. Motorola saw a clear potential to achieve better results.
"There's no great secret to all this," Mr. Buetow said. "You simply look at a process, center the mean and reduce the variation; do it the same way every time." In other words, with Six Sigma, the company sets a target for the number of permissible errors for each series of operations and holds to that goal.
SIX SIGMA was conceived at Motorola in early 1987. Motorola's chairman, Robert Galvin, tired of hearing customer complaints about quality, sent out a companywide directive. In it, he urged all employees to be relentless in improving quality.
"We could be doing from 5 percent to 20 percent more business and providing a steadier base of products and services, if we would but rise to the challenge and provide our customers the perfection that they expect," Mr. Galvin wrote.
Motorola's 5-year quality plan, which began with Mr. Galvin's 1987 memo, called for the company to achieve Six Sigma capability by 1992. That meant a tenfold reduction in defects by 1989 and a hundredfold reduction by 1991 from the 1987 rate.
Mr. Buetow says Motorola is well on its way to Six Sigma. "We will be close," he said. "The evolutionary process is already paying off. We realized a savings of $500 million in manufacturing costs this year. The target is to reach $1 billion in savings in 1992."
As a winner of the Malcolm Baldrige Award for Quality in 1988, Motorola was required by the Commerce Department, which awards the prize, to open its doors and let other American companies see how it has achieved its quality goals. Among the first visitors were the International Business Machines Corporation and Digital and others like Corning, Northern Telecom, Boeing, Caterpillar and Raytheon, that have subsequently initiated Six Sigma programs.
According to Stephen Schwartz, I.B.M.'s senior vice president of market driven quality, Six Sigma is now a critical part of a companywide initiative to improve quality. At the end of this year, I.B.M. expects to reduce defects by 10 times; by 1993, another ten times and by the end of 1994, the company says it should attain Six Sigma. "Six Sigma brings a common language to understanding defects and putting an action plan into place," Mr. Schwartz said.
I.B.M., is hoping that Six Sigma will help cut significantly into the $2.4 billion it paid in warranty costs in 1989. "People always gave lip service to quality," Mr. Schwartz said. "Ninety-nine percent good sounded terrific."
But in fact, according to an I.B.M. management report, a 99 percent defect-free rate translates nationally into 20,000 pieces of mail lost every hour; 5,000 incorrect surgical procedures every week, and, inside I.B.M., 10 defects out of every 1,000 solder joints on a computer motherboard.
I.B.M. is using its Rochester, Minn., plant to set the standard for quality across the entire company. In 1990, that plant won a Baldrige Award for its work on the AS/400 midrange computer. A specialist in the company's electronic card assembly group was able to show the Baldrige examiners weekly quality reports detailing a defect rate of 7 parts per million, almost Six Sigma.
Digital is requiring its senior managers to take Six Sigma training, according to Frank McCabe, vice president of corporate quality. Digital's Six Sigma plan is aimed at eliminating "non-value-added costs" like warranty repair service, which generally take 25 percent from each sales dollar at most companies.
"Our focus is to eliminate 50 percent of the defects per year in every part of the company until we get them all," Mr. McCabe said. Mr. McCabe predicts that the program can improve the entire company's financial picture by as much as 5 percent of net sales -- or about $650 million.
At I.B.M., Digital and Motorola, every process has been or is being reevaluated to eliminate defects. "We've even reduced defects in the way we do our financial reporting," Mr. Buetow explains. "By reducing cycle times, we've cut $44 million out of the cost of our final audit."

HEADLINE: Raul Ricardo Ardito Barletta, Banker, Is Married to Jacqueline Anne Blau

 BODY:
Jacqueline Anne Blau and Raul Ricardo Ardito Barletta were married yesterday in Washington at St. Alban's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Bruce Jenneker. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Juan Jose Blau of Buenos Aires. Mr. Ardito Barletta is a son of Martii Preston Barletta of Southport, N.C., and Nicholas Ardito Barletta of Panama.

Her father is the vice president and the general manager of Texaco of Argentina in Buenos Aires. Her mother, Virginia Farrell Blau, is a retired teacher.
The bridegroom, 27, is an associate at Chemical Bank in New York. His mother is a fine arts conservator in Southport. His father, who was the President of Panama from 1984 to 1985, is chairman of the International Center for Economic Growth in San Francisco.

HEADLINE: Peru's New President Unable to Halt Rising Rebel Violence

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, Jan. 12

 BODY:
Dashing hopes for a drop in South America's highest rate of political violence, Peru's internal war has claimed 1,500 lives in the six months since Alberto Fujimori was inaugurated President.
Overall, 3,384 people -- civilians, soldiers, policemen and Marxist guerrillas -- were reported killed in 1990, according to figures issued this week by a commission on violence of Peru's Senate. The toll represents a 10 percent increase over 1989. 
 "I estimate that 25 to 40 percent of the national territory is now under the open or semi-clandestine control of the Shining Path," said Gustavo Gorriti, a Peruvian journalist. The Shining Path, a Maoist group, and the Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement, a rival, Castroite group, are Peru's main guerrilla organizations.
"The change of government in Lima was completely irrelevant to the insurgent violence," said Mr. Gorriti, referring to the inauguration in July of Mr. Fujimori.
 
Campaign Vows Unrealized
 At the time, hopes were high for the start of a gradual pacification. An agronomist of Japanese descent, Mr. Fujimori received strong electoral support from Peru's rural Indian and mixed-race voters, a politically, racially and economically disenfranchised group that has provided the Shining Path with much of its support.
But Mr. Fujimori has been unable to translate into reality his campaign vows to fight guerrillas through rural development and a more professional army.
Instead, Peru's violence has not skipped a beat. In Lima, guerrillas have carried out dynamite attacks against the embassies of Germany, Japan, the Soviet Union and the United States. A car bomb damaged a luxury shopping center four days before Christmas. In mid-November, guerrillas shot to death a prominent judge four blocks from a tourist hotel where President Fujimori was attending a banquet.
 
Lima Without Power 66 Days
 Attacks on electric power pylons left this city of seven million people without power for 66 days last year.
In late November, a Shining Path guerrilla squad killed Javier Puiggros Planas, an agronomist who wrote a farm column in a leading Lima newspaper. In another rural incident in late November, Shining Path guerrillas killed a Japanese tourist, Wakamiya Makamori. A note left on the body said Mr. Makamori was killed "for being Japanese, like Fujimori."

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Discounting a Short Mideast War

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
Stock markets regularly surprise or confound. They did so again last week and produced interesting signals about the impact of a war -- or the avoidance of one -- in the Persian Gulf.
First, markets in Europe and the United States rose sharply Wednesday simply because the intensely watched meeting between Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz went on for several hours. Market players chose to read hope for peace into the longer-than-expected discussion. 
 In Germany, for example, the DAX Index of 30 leading shares jumped 21.21 points, or 1.6 percent, and prices continued to rise in after-hours trading. In France the CAC-40 index of blue chips jumped 49.42 points, or 3.3 percent. The FT-SE Index in Britain climbed 29.0 points, or 1.4 percent. The Spanish, Swedish and Belgian markets also rallied. Only in a few bourses, including Austria and Norway, did prices barely move.
The fact that markets rallied so much on such shaky speculation points to the potential for a hefty bounce upward should war against Iraqi President Saddam Hussein be avoided. .
Then, of course, Mr. Baker and Mr. Aziz emerged separately to tell news conferences that their talks had failed. That should have precipitated a wave of heavy selling, so certain did the prospect of war seem to many at that moment. In the United States and Canada, where stock markets were still open, it did.
But the next day, less than 24 hours after the disappointment had sunk in, the rest of the world markets sprung another surprise. They hardly flinched.
In Europe, where markets had closed before the announcement of the failure of the Iraqi-American talks, there was no panic selling on Thursday. In Germany, the DAX even rose 8.24 points. In Tokyo, where the Nikkei 225 had fallen sharply early in the week, the index managed a modest 78.08 rise on Thursday. In France and Britain, where the markets did decline, the falls were large but did not wipe out the gains on the "hope" of Wednesday. On Wall Street, the Dow Jones Industrial Average also rallied 28.46 points or 1.2 percent. On Friday, Tokyo rose again while there were only slight declines in Frankfurt and London.
How should such behavior be explained?
Michael Howell, director or research in London for Salomon Brothers, said the market response showed that "investors have already generally discounted the effect of a short war."
But the response also seems to reflect a lingering optimism in the markets, a hope for the best outcome if there is a war. Many analysts have spoken for weeks with confidence about the chances that any war would be quick.
Good outcomes in war, however, are hard to come by. Barton M. Biggs, director of worldwide strategy at Morgan Stanley & Company, wrote recently that an iron rule of forecasting is that "Events always take much longer to develop than expected, but once they begin, they occur much faster and go much farther than anticipated."
If the lingering market optimism is a misreading of the situation, that could mean the potential for a slump in stock prices if a war starts is much greater than many people think. And if the war goes on for a time, the fall could be farther -- 10 percent, 20 percent, or more -- and even longer lasting.
Of course, no one really knows what a "quick" war is. Is it a week? A month? "Maybe everyone is miscalculating Saddam's ability to resisit, his ability to hold on to power," said Michael Diehl of Kleinwort Benson. "He might hold on longer than we think."
But even if the best outcome -- no war or a very short war -- is possible, it will not unburden the world's stock markets of their more fundamental troubles. Once the uncertainity over the Perisan Gulf disappears, uncertainty over the world economy, corporate earnings and banking's troubles will return to the fore.
Yuichi Kohashi, executive vice president of Daiwa Securities America, said a rally in Japan, one of the stronger economies but one that is generally slowing down, would be limitied. The Nikkei 225, he said, would probably stop at 25,000, a jump of less than 8 percent from the 23,241.02 the Nikki 225 closed at on Friday.
"Even absent the war risk, we would not think the markets at these levels are particularly attractive," said Jeffrey M. Weingarten, director of international equity research for Goldman Sachs & Company in London.
"If there were a settlement in the Persian Gulf, we would expect a 15 percent to 20 percent bounce in markets overall," he said. "But that still leaves you to face the economic problems. We face the worst combination for equities worldwide -- slowing growth and rising interest rates. The markets are generally overvalued by 8 percent."
Mr. Howell of Salomon Brothers agreed. "Once the conflict is settled, what the markets have got to return to is is this economic background -- that the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development countries are heading toward a recession. That fact is not in many prices, especially in the United States."

HEADLINE: All About/Hats;
The Baseball Cap Is Breathing Life Into Headwear Sales

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
Roy Langenberg says that people burst out laughing when he tells them he produces hats. "How do you make a living?" they ask. But Mr. Langenberg, the fourth generation in his family to head the Langenberg Hat Company of Washington, Mo., says that the headwear business is actually enjoying a comeback. No one in the industry expects formal felt hats to recapture the universal popularity they enjoyed before World War II. But most Americans own many more caps and leisure hats than they realize and seem eager to accumulate more.
The Headwear Institute of America, a New York-based group, estimates that sales have been growing at 5 percent to 10 percent for the past few years. More precise statistics are hard to come by because all the companies are small, most of them secretive and none publicly traded. Many manufacturers say that despite the recession, sales are still growing, driven by everything from changing fashions to the awareness that sunburn can contribute to skin cancer. Hat and cap makers hope that they will scarcely feel the recession because, for every customer who suddenly feels too poor to buy, others decide that they can economize by purchasing a hat instead of a complete outfit. 
 "Everyone was quite pleased with sales over the holidays," said Susan Tildesley, the Headwear Institute's executive director. She estimated that retail hat sales will top $2 billion this year, up from $750 million in the early 1980's, not including women's hats and odds and ends like construction hardhats. The more fashion-oriented $450 million women's hat business is growing 15 percent to 20 percent annually, according to Casey Bush, director of the Millinery Information Bureau in New York.
Like other apparel sectors, hat and cap makers have long been under pressure from imports. The huge cap market is dominated by the Chinese, who pay workers as little as 25 cents an hour with no fringe benefits or safety regulations, according to industry consultants. Taiwan and South Korea are also major exporters.
An anti-dumping suit against China in 1988 resulted in a finding that imports were being sold below cost but failed to prove that domestic manufacturers had been harmed. Imported caps typically cost 20 percent to 50 percent less wholesale than domestic products, according to Paramount Cap Manufacturing Company, a Bourbon, Mo., concern that, according to industry executives, is probably the largest producer.
 
The Industry Star
A Cap, a Logo, Voila! A Promo
 If the era when most men went to work in fedoras, homburgs or other formal hats is long gone, the day when every man, woman, and child wears a cap for recreation may well be approaching. Headwear makers estimate that cloth goods, primarily baseball-style caps, now account for as much as 80 percent of sales.
The biggest sellers boast logos of colleges and professional sports teams. Movies like "Batman" have touched off their own cap fads. Long a favorite advertising medium for farm equipment companies and seed producers -- the beloved "gimme" caps -- billed headwear is now widely used in corporate promotions and fast-food restaurant uniforms. An order for as many as 500,000 caps with a corporate logo is not uncommon, according to cap manufacturers. But imports account for about two-thirds of the business.
Domestic manufacturers rely mostly on design abilities, nimble marketing and quick response to customers to counter the lower costs of imports. None are big enough to fight back with extensive automation.
"Even the biggest just don't have enough employees cutting cloth to justify spending $500,000 on something like computerized cutting equipment," said C. Leon Sherman, president of CLS Associates Inc., an Aurora, Col., company that is the headwear industry's best-known consultant. Because the industry is too small to attract machine makers, it gets its new equipment by customizing devices made for other apparel makers.
Mr. Sherman said that the most successful domestic cap makers have lucrative businesses, routinely building up 10- to 12-week backlogs during the busy spring and summer seasons. "There are serious capacity shortfalls at times," he said. "This industry is far better off than the rest of the apparel business."
 
Fads and Niches
Boom-Bust Cycles With a Vengeance
Hats that attract the fashion spotlight can generate big sales, but manufacturers have learned that popularity can disappear with equal speed. In the most notorious modern case, the movie "Urban Cowboy" touched off a craze for cowboy hats. Overall hat sales nearly doubled from 1979 to 1981, Mr. Langenberg said. But instead of the gradual retreat the industry anticipated, demand fell abruptly. "Some people went out of business and a lot of others changed owners," Mr. Langenberg said.
Now, Western hats are once again selling briskly, but primarily in their native regions and in other nations. Many of the biggest names are owned by companies that market a wide variety of hats. Stetson is owned by AJD Corporation, an enterprise formed by Irving Joel, a Richmond, Va.-based entrepeneur who has acquired several hat companies.
Some companies try to smooth the business cycles by staying in niches. Kova Quality Hatters of Brooklyn concentrates on supplying traditional black brimmed hats to Orthodox and Hasidic Jews.
"The market is made up of about 100,000 people, who buy 50,000 hats a year," said Yaakov Ehrman, the owner of Kova Quality. "It goes up with the population."
Makers of military and uniform hats are also largely immune from style changes and foreign competition. But producers of uniform hats have been losing business as more police departments and other enforcement agencies switch to caps, according to Harold Selvin, president of the Keystone Uniform Cap Corporation in Philadelphia.
 
Hat Makers' Heroine
The Singular Impact Of Debbie Gibson
 If milliners were asked to vote for their favorite recording star, the clear winner would undoubtedly be Debbie Gibson. When Ms. Gibson, then a Long Island teen-ager, hit the pop charts with best-selling albums in 1988 and 1989, her distinctive hats sent fans flocking to the stores. Then young buyers turned to gaucho hats. Now, even with a recession looming, makers of women's hats are optimistic. "Business is very good," said Bernard Grossman, president of Betmar Hats Inc., which has made midpriced women's hats in Passaic, N.J., since 1933. Annual sales approached $15 million last year, which Mr. Grossman says places Betmar among the largest makers of women's hats in the country.
The new popularity of hats among younger women reinforces strong sales in high-fashion headgear. Ann Albrizio said that the designer hat business was "practically dead" when she began teaching a course at the Fashion Institute of Technology 14 years ago. Today, she has more than 200 students. Many of her former pupils are apparently prospering, designing hats that can cost hundreds of dollars or even, in the case of handmade designs from imported furs, several thousand. "I don't think the problem was ever lack of demand," said Ms. Albrizio. "It was lack of people knowing how to make hats because the children of people who got wealthy in millinery didn't go into the business."
Frank Olive of New York designs hats for every social purpose. "My customer goes out a lot, to luncheons, to meetings, to the races at Ascot," he said. For $500, he said, a hat might include imported silks and flowers, ribbons, or even jewels. The core clientele for midpriced hats has long been what Stephanie Caruso, a buyer for J. C. Penney in Dallas, calls "church ladies." But even among these conservative buyers, millinery fashions seldom last longer than a season. "We don't have basics," said Mr. Grossman. "Twice a year, you have to wipe the blackboard clean."
 
 
A SURVIVOR TOUGHS IT OUT
 When the first Worth & Worth store opened in Manhattan in 1924, hats were a high-growth business. Within two decades, the company had five shops.
Today, after several difficult decades that wiped out most of its local competitors, Worth & Worth operates a single small showroom on Madison Avenue, with 4,000 hats on view and an additional 10,000 in stock. But business is better than the reduced circumstances suggest. Harold Rosenholtz, who married into the family-owned business that he now runs, figures that his shop's annual sales of nearly $2 million probably make it the nation's top hat store. Sales in 1989 were strong and, until December's warm weather kept some customers away, 1990 was better still, he said. The company has benefited from its two-year-old campaign to sell its hats through retailers like Barney's and Neiman Marcus.
Mr. Rosenholtz said that hat retailers can improve sales 15 percent to 20 percent a year "if you make the right choices about stock." His shop displays fur hats, Panamas and famous names like Borsalino of Italy and Stetson. Increasingly, the hats are the company's own brands. Mr. Rosenholtz recently became part owner of a hat factory in Colombia, said to be the world's second oldest. He admires the workers' skills, noting that it takes 60 steps to convert animal fur or wool into a felt hat.
The price of hats in his shop range from $75 to $275, attracting a clientele that has included John Chancellor, Mike Tyson, David Hockney and Madonna.

LENGTH: 1401 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary/December 6-11

BYLINE: By Allen R. Myerson

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
Baker and Aziz Send the Markets Spinning
 
Minutes before 2 P.M. on Wednesday, Brian Tagler of Shearson Lehman Brothers was trading oil for $23.85 a barrel. Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d had been meeting with Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz. The moment Mr. Tagler heard Mr. Baker say on television, "Regrettably . . . ," the trader was on the phone to the commodity pit. Buy orders had pushed the price to $31 -- the quickest rise he had ever seen. Economists are somewhat more stable in their sentiments, occasionally holding them for a whole week. Their consensus by the weekend was that if the United States fights and wins quickly and tidily, oil prices would fall and the economy would benefit. "I understand the mood swings, but people are exaggerating," said Lawrence Kudlow, chief economist at Bear Stearns. "There is a worldwide glut of oil against a backdrop of weak demand." But if there is a protracted war, many economists say, the budget deficit would widen, and oil prices and interest rates would rise. "The uncertainty will have a debilitating effect," said Richard B. Berner, a Salomon Brothers economist. "People will hold back from making long-term commitments." Even a last-minute settlement will not be enough to overcome recession, economists say, since growth was slowing before Iraqi troops set foot in Kuwait.
 
Again, Sweat Doesn't Pay
 
Will the returns on labor rebound and surpass the returns on wealth in the 1990's? From 1984 to 1988, the wealthiest gained in net worth, while everyone else stagnated, the Census Bureau reported last week. The less affluent depend mostly on their wages, which in the 1980's barely kept pace with inflation. Stocks and bonds, meanwhile, enjoyed strong returns. Lacy H. Hunt, chief United States economist for the Hongkong Bank Group, doubts that investments will continue soaring. But wages will rise as labor supplies tighten, he says. "The headlines of one decade go into the trash bin of the new decade," he said. For investors, "The decade hasn't started off very well, has it?"
 
Wholesale Comfort
 
The wholesale inflation news for December was comforting at every stop in the production chain. For finished goods, prices fell six-tenths of 1 percent overall; they only rose three-tenths of a point excluding food and energy. Prices for intermediate and crude goods, earlier in the production process, also fell. Stephen S. Roach of Morgan Stanley said the report leaves the Federal Reserve plenty of room to stoke the economy. "The fundamentals are as constructive for inflation as they have been at any point in the onset of the last few recessions," he said. The annual gain, 5.6 percent, was the highest since 1981, but a mild 3.5 percent core rate.
 
An Uptown Jazz Market
 
Where sopranos now screech, saxaphones will squeal and coo. Lincoln Center has launched a jazz department with a $1 million annual budget. The marketing problem for Rob Gibson, the department's chief: How to create an uptown audience, week after week, for music usually heard in downtown clubs. His answers include children's concerts, master classes and small, informal theaters in the center. One possibility is a tribute to Sun Ra, the band leader whose fans can verify his claimed birth in outer space. But judging by what works best at Lincoln Center, Mr. Gibson might better raise his top ticket prices to $115, require black tie on opening nights and drag dozens of shield-bearing supernumeraries on stage.
 
Banking Forecast: Rain
 
At times last week, L. William Seidman's spirits improved to merely gloomy. Otherwise, he was downright dismal. On Wednesday, the chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation warned the Senate Banking Committee that more major bank failures were likely if the recession persists past mid-year. On Friday, he landed in Boston, like a governor visiting a hurricane disaster zone, to say that the region needs more widely available bank credit to free itself from a recession. "I don't think there's probably a bad loan being made in New England at this time," he said. "Unfortunately, there aren't many others either."
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
A Payoff for Turkey?
 
One possible winner in the Middle East crisis: Turkey, which right after Saddam Hussein's invasion of Kuwait cut off Iraqi oil pipelines and made military bases available to counter Iraq. Turkey hopes the United States and its allies will offer more help in its continuing disputes with Greece. And Turkey can look forward to closer economic ties with Europe's wealthier nations, said Robert G. Neumann, director of Middle East programs at the Center for Strategic and International Studies and a former Ambassador to Saudi Arabia. Turkey needs aid to improve its infrastructure -- the phone lines are too feeble to carry faxes abroad, for example -- if it hopes to capitalize on its low labor costs. Although the European Community is considering several applications for admission, Mr. Neumann said, "Turkey may very well move up in the line." With luck, Turkey might prove that it can approach the prosperity of the West.

Oil Importers Prepare for War
 
The International Energy Agency, representing 21 oil-importing nations, agreed on Friday to release 2 million barrels a day from reserves in case of war in the Middle East. The United States, the largest oil importer, cut petroleum consumption 2.1 percent in 1990, the first drop in seven years. Domestic oil production fell to the lowest level since 1961.
